fields.headline: Healy rewards positive Preston
fields.trailText: Stockport 1 - 0 Preston
fields.body:
David Healy earned Preston a deserved victoiry here last night with his fifth goal since arriving at Deepdale from Manchester United in December. He volleyed home from six yards in the 72nd minute after Brian McBride had flicked on Gary Parkinson's corner.

The club record £1.5m Preston's manager Dave Moyes invested in Healy looked like sound business as the Ulsterman's effort nudged his side closer to the play-off zone.

It extended Preston's recent winning run to three matches and their bleak mid-winter run of five consecutive defeats must have seemed a distant memory.

Stockport, though, continue to hover dangerously above the relegation zone despite having lost only three times 18 games - including cup matches.

Moyes's decision to field three strikers in their previous two matches had seen North End collect the full six points and the Scotsman decided to keep faith with same line-up.

Healy was the liveliest of Preston's triumvirate and Stockport's captain Mike Flynn had to draw on all of his experience to keep the Northern Ireland international in check.

But a mistake by Flynn presented Healy with a chance in the 21st minute. He failed to intercept a through pass from the United States international McBride and Healy raced clear only to be denied by Stockport's goalkeeper Lee Jones who advanced rapidly to claim the ball.

Jones had to be at his best again in the 35th minute to tip Gary Parkinson's fierce 20-yard free-kick over the bar after Simon Grayson, sent off five minutes before the end for a second bookable offence, had fouled McBride.

After having a quiet first-half Stockport's Finnish forward Shefki Kuqi came to life just after the interval. Brian Carrigan's cross found him unmarked on the penalty spot, but Kuqi's effort was tipped around the post by his fellow countryman Tepi Moilanen.

Kuqi should have done better, but his subsequent anger had more to do with referee Steven Lodge's decision to award a goalkick.

webTitle: Roussel bound for Wolves in Coventry clearout

fields.headline: Roussel bound for Wolves in Coventry clearout
fields.trailText: Coventry hope to recoup at least £1.5m of their expected outlay on John Hartson by accepting an offer from Wolves for Cédric Roussel.
fields.body:
Coventry hope to recoup at least £1.5m of their expected outlay on John Hartson by accepting an offer from Wolves for Cédric Roussel.

Wolves, having tracked the Belgian striker for weeks, are confident they will swiftly agree personal terms with the 23-year-old. He was highly impressed with the Molineux set-up in recent talks.

The fee will rise to £2m depending on appearances and Wolves' progress in the remainer of the season. Roussel joined Coventry from Ghent for £1.2m last year.

Carlton Palmer has already left Highfield Road, returning to troubled Sheffield Wednesday on a three-month loan. The former England midfielder follows Colin Hendry into the First Division, the Scotland defender having just departed for Bolton in a permanent deal.

Aston Villa's manager John Gregory and his wing-back Alan Wright were slated by Najwan Grayeb as the Israeli international completed his £150,000 return to Hapoel Haifa.

Grayeb joined Villa for £1m 20 months ago and made only one league start. "Gregory kept telling me I would play but it never happened," he said, pointing out that Wright continually kept him out of the side. "If Alan Wright signed for Hapoel he wouldn't get a game. He's not bad defensively but he's no good going forward. Yet he is godlike to Gregory."

Benfica have agreed personal terms with Luis Boa Morte, on extended loan to Fulham from Southampton, to take him home this summer, according to a Portuguese report.

Colin Todd has received a three-match touchline ban from the FA. Now No2 at Derby, he was found guilty of foul and abusive language to a linesman while Swindon's manager in a league game with Millwall.

fields.headline: Hoey links passports to crime
fields.trailText: The sports minister Kate Hoey hopes that a police investigation into football's passport problem will establish whether organised crime is supplying fake documentation.
fields.body:
The sports minister Kate Hoey hopes that a police investigation into English football's dual-national passport holders will establish whether organised crime is supplying fake documentation.

"That's certainly what seems to have shown up in Italy, and of course we had some allegations that agents in Russia and other countries have the capacity to be able to get hold of a passport for a certain amount of money," she said. "We just don't know what the extent of it is.

"As sports minister it is my first concern to see that the integrity of the sport is preserved. If one club is having any kind of advantage because they are playing more players from outside Europe than they should be then this needs to be stopped."

Newcastle United's Nolberto Solano and Arsenal's Tomas Danilevicius will be investigated among players who hold European passports but were born elsewhere.

Solano, who was born in Peru, and Danilevicius, a Latvian international, both hold Greek passports. Both claim they qualify because of grandparents born in that country, but officers from the National Criminal Intelligence Service will check whether they are entitled to their documents.

Though there is no suggestion that either player has done anything wrong, they will join 78 others under investigation, 19 of whom are likewise with Premiership clubs.

The Football Association's chief executive Adam Crozier will meet Fifa's general secretary Michel Zen-Ruffinen today to discuss the problem, and the idea of a pan-European body to combat players obtaining fake passports will also be considered.

The FA has written to all England's clubs and given them 14 days to contact the immigration service and ensure their players' passports are authentic. There will be a meeting between the FA, police and the Home Office immigration service next week.

 The Scottish Football Association claims there is no problem with dual passport holders north of the border. A spokeswoman said there were "approximately 10" players claiming dual nationality. "We've not had any problems. But we have written to all clubs asking them to revisit their registration details. They've got to confirm to us any changes."

fields.headline: Valencia 0 - 0 Manchester United
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Valencia: Canizares, Carboni, Pellegrino, Ayala, Angloma, Mendieta, Kily Gonzalez, Baraja, Aimar, Angulo, Carew. Subs: Palop, Deschamps, Djukic, Alonso, Vicente, Sanchez, Albelda.

Man Utd: Barthez, Silvestre, Stam, Brown, Gary Neville, Giggs, Keane, Scholes, Beckham, Sheringham, Cole. Subs: Van Der Gouw, Irwin, Butt, Phil Neville, Yorke, Solskjaer, Chadwick.

Referee: Dick Jol (Holland)

1 Valencia waste no time in attacking United's goal as Carew crosses from the right for Kily to shoot wide from the edge of the area. The rain in Spain has been a real pain and only just stopped falling in the Mestalla stadium.
5 Giggs does well down the left when he plays a one-two with Sheringham but Cole fails to get to the cross, losing out Pellegrino in the six-yard box.
7 Giggs looking eager down the left again but Baraja and the 35-year-old Angloma read it well and cut him off.
9 And again, as Keane lifts the ball over Angloma into space for Giggs... too much power..
10 Valencia free-kick deep on the right after Silvestre floors Angloma. Mendieta takes and Barthez flaps at the far post before United can finally clear.
11 Valencia come close to an opener; Aimar slides the ball through to the on-running Angulo... in the net but offside.
12 United free-kick from near the left by-line, comes to nothing.
14 An evenly matched opening period to the game. If anything, United are getting slightly outnumbered in midfield so expect to see Beckham tuck in more from the right.
18 Beckham has a crack with his right from 25 yards - blocked.
20 Silvestre tries to play Giggs into a great position deep on the left but the ball runs away from him on the wet surface.
21 Stam caught out by Angulo after a poor ball - saved when Angulo ends up fouling the United defender.
22 Good pressure from United. Cole and Sheringham knock the ball between them in the area, but both forget to shoot. United corner; Beckham takes, comes to nothing.
23 Aimar gets away from Brown but his cross is met only by Silvestre.
24 Aimar unlucky when he is caught offside trying to meet Kily's cross from the left. Screams and whistles from the crowd.
28 United corner. Beckham takes and Brown heads over.
29 Valencia corner. Mendieta takes towards the lanky Pellegrino; Scholes clears before the ball eventually goes for a free-kick.
31 Mendieta blows the best chance of the night. Aimar plays him into acres of space in the United area (possibly offside). The Valencia star hesitates too long while Barthez holds his ground and then falls over; Brown steps in to make the telling challenge. United corner results; Barthez loses the ball before it goes for another corner. United eventually get it clear.
33 Scholes unlucky to see his rocket of a half-volley from 25 yards fly wide.
37 Never one to turn down an invitation to shoot, Scholes has another crack from distance - well wide.
41 United free-kick from 30 yards out. Beckham takes and sends it into the crowd.
43 Silvestre drifts the ball in towards Cole in the Valancia area, but the United striker is muscled off the ball by Pellegrino.
44 Stam gives away to Carew; he delivers a great cross but no one is there to meet it for Valencia. Booking Pellegrino for a foul on Sheringham.
45 United finish the half on the attack. Pellegrino slices at a Beckham cross from the right before the ref blows for half-time.

46 Important challenge by Baraca stops Sheringham getting away 30 yards out . Beckham takes the free-kick - goes for a corner. Everyone misses it; United throw before Valencia finally clear.
49 United doing a good job of pinning Valencia back, with Brown the man making many of the telling challenges to stop Valencia coming forward.
54 Booking Silvestre for upending Carew wide on the right. Mendieta's free-kick manages to miss everyone in the United area.
55 Cole breaks down the left and plays in Giggs who then tries to pull the ball back for the return... shame Cole didn't read it.
57 Barthez, having beaten former team-mate Angloma with his left foot some 10 minutes earlier, now shows Kily what he can do with his right by lifting the ball over him and into safety.
59 Aimar and Mendieta link up well on the edge of the United area to play in Kily, who is unlucky to be called offside.
62 Concerted pressure from Valencia results in a corner after Kily shoots from 25 yards. Mendieta takes but comes to nothing.
63 Ayala fouls Giggs on the left of the Valencia area. Giggs takes as the ref narrowly avoids being struck by a missile. Cleared by Valencia, allowing Stam to have a crack from distance. Not surprisingly he misses.
68 Lots of pressure from Valencia. Barthez on top of it mostly, but needs Stam to help him out with the lively Carew.
70 Great save by Barthez from Kily in the six-yard box but no one there for the rebound.
71 Booking Stam for a foul on Aimar.
72 Valencia keep on coming - corner, cleared by a United side now pushed well back into their own half.
73 Mendieta shoots with his right from just outside the area - fortunately for United it's straight at Barthez.
75 Substitutions Alonso on for Carew. Butt on for Beckham.
80 Baraca makes a crucial intervention to prevent Sheringham shooting from a Silvestre cut-back in the Valencia area. Still lots of movement from both teams but no clear threats on goal for several minutes.
82 United corner after Sheringham falls foul of the wet conditions on the by-line and is challenged when trying to cross. Giggs takes, comes to nothing.
84 Cole claims a penalty under pressure from Ayala in the Valencia area.
85 Substitution Solskjaer on for Cole.
86 Sheringham plays it over the top to Solskjaer on-side. Solskjaer cuts inside and passes to Keane but Carboni makes a crucial challenge just outside the six-yard box to keep Valencia in the game.
89 Booking Ayala.
90 Four extra minutes to play. Both teams chasing things down as if their lives depended on it. No time on the ball for anyone in the closing stages. Full-time. Valencia 0 - 0 Man Utd. Great game with United owing their point in large part to Stam and Brown at the back. If United can beat Valencia next week at Old Trafford then they are through to the quarter-finals.

fields.headline: Route to the top
fields.standfirst: The old image of the social services director is changing. Marcia White examines why
fields.trailText: With 211 social services departments across the UK, employing thousands of staff, there should be enormous potential for ambitious social workers to progress through the ranks to become director.
fields.body:
With 211 social services departments across the UK, employing thousands of staff, there should be enormous potential for ambitious social workers to progress through the ranks to become director.

But, until the latest local government re-organisation in the mid-1990s, the top posts were dominated by white men - despite women and ethnic minorities representing a big proportion of staff at grass-roots level. Between two thirds and three quarters of social workers are women, and around one in 100 is black. In 1999-2000, 3,183 of the 4,099 diplomas in social work awarded went to women, and 465 to black people. In 1998-99, women were awarded 2,941 diplomas, and black people 488, of a total of 3,966. In 1997-98, it was 3,255 and 618, respectively, of 4,387.

There are some concerns that part of the problem may have been the attitudes of councillors, who are very influential in senior appointment.

Nevertheless, since then, there has been more upward movement, with around 40% of social services directors now women in England and Wales. As in other sectors, women are increasingly a force to be reckoned with. Lisa Christensen is one of the newest. Appointed to Lambeth council in October 1999, as executive director of social services and health improvement, she was the department's fifth head of social services in as many years.

Christensen came to Lambeth from Hackney council, where she was one of four executive directors responsible for health and voluntary sector issues. Her first local government job was with Islington council architect department, in 1979.

However, subsequent posts in Haringey, Bradford and Yorkshire saw her working closely with social workers, housing officers, occupational therapists, special needs, language therapists and other health professionals.

Ms Christensen does not hold a social work qualification. "I don't need to have that particular one myself," she says. "The job that needs doing within Lambeth is a managerial job. I need to make sure that within the team I have the range of skills the organisation needs.

"What social workers want to know is whether somebody is going to stay for a while, make some decisions, show some leadership and give them the support to do their job."

So, wide experience in different fields can be an alternative to the traditional route of qualifying in social work.

In direct contrast, Roy Taylor, one of the longest serving directors and president of the Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS) from 1997 to 1998, conforms to the image of the white, male director. However, Mr Taylor has been keen to change the old order. He was the brains behind Horizons, a mentoring pilot scheme set up by the ADSS and the Improvement and Development Agency, aimed at helping black managers progress to assistant director and director levels within social services departments.

In terms of his own career, Mr Taylor volunteered in a mental health project while at university in the 1970s. After graduating - and either side of six-month break playing in a rock band in Tunisia - he did unqualified social work before pursuing two social sciences degrees.

Afterwards, he worked for Sutton, Surrey and Bromley before gradually working his way from frontline social work to managerial level, eventually becoming director at Kingston-upon-Thames in 1990.

"The job of director is different now," he says, nostalgically. "Back in the 1970s, it looked as if careers in social work, child care and probation were all very good things to do. It was before Maria Colwell was killed [by her stepfather, in 1973] and it felt like they were respected careers - it felt really useful and a positive thing to do in society."

Like in any other sector, showing interest in the field, taking training courses and actively seeking promotion can do more good than harm for social workers keen to break into management. The growth of the social care sector has also seen a similar spurt in the number of available jobs which cut across other related sectors, such as housing and health. Experience in these areas can help potential directors get a foot in the door.

Finding himself at the cutting end of new developments helped catapult the career of Chris Williams, director for Dudley council and, until very recently, the UK's only ethnic minority head of a social services department.

Mr Williams has twice been on secondment to the department of health. He was involved in policy and performance review long before performance assessments became fashionable and worked across health and social services - a policy now being pursued by government through proposed care trusts.

Despite qualifying as a generic social worker in 1975, and obtaining a certificate of qualification in social work, a diploma in social work and a degree in sociology and politics, the most important factor, said Mr Williams, is belief in one's ability. "It wasn't a conscious thought that I was going to be a director," he said. "But with each job I did, I had a realisation that I could be a director if I wanted to."

"The job of director is different now," he says, nostalgically. "Back in the 1970s, it looked as if careers in social work, child care and probation were all very good things to do. It was before Maria Colwell was killed [by her stepfather, in 1973] and it felt like they were respected careers - it felt really useful and a positive thing to do in society." Like in any other sector, showing interest in the field, taking training courses and actively seeking promotion can do more good than harm for social workers keen to break into management. The growth of the social care sector has also seen a similar spurt in the number of available jobs which cut across other related sectors, such as housing and health. Experience in these areas can help potential directors get a foot in the door. Finding himself at the cutting end of new developments helped catapult the career of Chris Williams, director for Dudley council and, until very recently, the UK's only ethnic minority head of a social services department. Mr Williams has twice been on secondment to the department of health. He was involved in policy and performance review long before performance assessments became fashionable and worked across health and social services - a policy now being pursued by government through proposed care trusts. Despite qualifying as a generic social worker in 1975, and obtaining a certificate of qualification in social work, a diploma in social work and a degree in sociology and politics, the most important factor, said Mr Williams, is belief in one's ability. "It wasn't a conscious thought that I was going to be a director," he said. "But with each job I did, I had a realisation that I could be a director if I wanted to."

webTitle: In brief: Bridget Jones movie website launched

fields.headline: Bridget Jones movie website launched
fields.standfirst: Plus: Tim Allen and Mel Gibson to team up for sci-fi comedy; Ray Liotta fans the flames in Point of Origin; Breckin Meyer lines up with Meg Ryan in time travel romance
fields.trailText: Plus: Tim Allen and Mel Gibson to team up for sci-fi comedy; Ray Liotta fans the flames in Point of Origin; Breckin Meyer lines up with Meg Ryan in time travel romance
fields.body:
 What better day than St Valentine's day for the launch of an official website for Bridget Jones' Diary, starring Renee Zellweger, Hugh Grant and Colin Firth. Among the many delights to be found on the site devoted to the highly anticipated film of Helen Fielding's bestseller is a short trailer of the forthcoming movie, plus St Valentine's Day e-cards available to send Bridget-style.

 Tim Allen and Mel Gibson are to team up in the sci-fi comedy StarChild, according to Variety magazine. Described as a "comedic send-up of the sci-fi genre," the film, which will follow the fortunes of a socially challenged CIA agent who helps a friendly alien get back home, is expected to go into production this summer.

 Goodfellas star Ray Liotta is set to play the lead role in Point of Origin, the true story of an infamous arsonist who made national headlines when he was finally caught. X-Men cinematographer Tom Sigel will direct the $11m (£7.5m) million project, in which Ray Liotta will play a well-respected fire department arson investigator, in the autumn.

 Breckin Meyer, best known for last years teen comedy, Road Trip, is the latest actor to be named in connection with Miramax's Kate and Leopold, according to Variety. The romantic comedy tells the tale of a late 19th-century duke who falls in love with a modern-day girl, to be played by Meg Ryan, and must travel forward in time to be with her.

webTitle: Mail group boss unimpressed with online news

fields.headline: Mail group boss unimpressed with online news
fields.trailText: 8.30am: DMGT chief executive Charles Sinclair has defended the Mail group's reticence over the internet, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The chief executive of Daily Mail and General Trust, Charles Sinclair, has said that he does not believe that the internet is the place for breaking news.

Giving evidence yesterday before the culture, media and sport select committee's inquiry into the communications white paper, Mr Sinclair said: "We think niche sites are a much better way of using the web than taking the whole paper and transferring it onto the internet".

Mr Sinclair was being questioned on the reticence of Associated Newspapers to launch successful newspaper brands such as the Daily Mail onto the internet.

"We have no belief that newspapers will transfer themselves onto the internet," he said.

"Of all the newspapers, the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday have been the least forward in putting themselves onto the internet."

Mr Sinclair and other senior DMGT executives were quizzed by the select committee on a paper that the company submitted on the white paper.

They were asked whether in a converged world, the admittedly "opinionated" right-wing politics of the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday could seep through into DMGT's non-newspaper media like Teletext.

Mr Sinclair dismissed such suggestions. "The last editor-in-chief of Associated Newspapers, Sir David English, was also the chairman of Teletext," he said.

"The reputation of Teletext as a provider of impartial news is second to none and the reports we have got from the Independent Television Commission have been remarkably good."

He added: "We are a broad church and we try to take every argument on its merits."

The appearance before the select committee is an unusual move for DMGT, which is traditionally reticent in talking about its business practices.

fields.headline: Bannister eyes TV and radio
fields.trailText:
6.15pm update: Matthew Bannister's new DJ talent venture will aim to get involved in radio and TV programming. By Jessica Hodgson.
Feb 14: Bannister returns
fields.body:
Matthew Bannister has said his new dance music talent venture will aim to get involved in radio and TV programming.

Mr Bannister, who is joining Trust the DJ as chief executive and chairman, said the firm "could either work with existing broadcasters or in the future run our own radio and TV operation".

"There will be opportunities for syndicating radio output both in the UK and overseas," he added.

But Mr Bannister said his first priority at Trust the DJ will be to establish its core business of talent management, running websites for DJ clients and launching a record label specialising in dance music.

"We're looking to develop a new internet offering," added Mr Bannister. "I don't think there's anywhere at the moment where you can visit 60 DJs' personal websites and buy exclusive mixes of their music."

"Each DJ will have their top 20 recommendations that you will be able to buy through us, on vinyl or CD."

He added that the outfit would initially operate the "traditional internet model - you order a record online and we'll send it to you".

But in the future, once the current copyright issues surrounding Napster and online music distribution, Trust the DJ would also look to "move to the download model", he said.

Mr Bannister added that the company would also use the internet to expand its business outside the UK, with the US the number one priority.

"Dance music maybe peaking here in the UK, but there's a major opportunity in the US, which may be 10 years behind us," he said.

"Through the internet you can connect with fans and build from the ground up, without imposing a big corporate model."

Mr Bannister added that for some clients Trust the DJ would be agent, website producer and record label. But in other cases the outfit may just produce a DJs website.

Lynn Cosgrove, who co-founded Trust the DJ with Tammy Smulders before approaching Mr Bannister, said: "We went for Matthew because we knew he was somebody with a great track record in management and a great reputation for working with talent."

Mr Bannister added: "When I left the BBC I said I wanted to get out of the world corporate broadcasting and get back to a creative business."

fields.headline: Hague 'misled Commons' over charity
fields.trailText: William Hague was last night forced to admit to making misleading claims that he distributes the            profits from public speaking engagements to a charitable trust which has never actually been            established in law.
fields.body:
William Hague was last night forced to admit to making misleading claims that he distributes the profits from public speaking engagements to a charitable trust which has never actually been established in law.

The Conservative party issued a statement in the wake of an investigation by Channel 4's Mark Thomas Product and the Daily Mirror. It highlighted discrepancies between the Tory leader's claim in the Commons register of MPs' interests and the absence of any official record of the William Hague Charitable Trust.

MPs are expected to declare earnings in excess of pounds 500 for appearances, even if the money is given to a designated charity. In the United States, where disclosure laws have long been in place, it is a notorious field of contention.

There was no immediate indication of how much money was involved in the speeches the Tory leader may have made - though such an accomplished after-dinner performer as Mr Hague could be expected to command up to pounds 10,000 for prestigious commercial events.

According to the Commons register in 1999 and 2000, Mr Hague declared: "Any fees received as a result of speaking engagements will be paid into the William Hague Charitable Trust.

"Donations from this trust will be distributed by an independent board of trustees to charitable organisations in my constituency."

But this week's investigation established that the trust does not exist, though its existence had been logged with the Commons register in advance.

Conservative Central Office said in a statement: "Since the trust has not been set up, it will not be included in future registers of members' interests. Any speaking fees, etcetera, are therefore given to local charities."

Labour's Fraser Kemp and the senior Liberal Democrat MP Malcolm Bruce, a member of the parliamentary standards and privileges committee , were both critical of Mr Hague, who has not previously fallen foul of rules governing disclosure of MPs' private financial interests, imposed in the post-Nolan anti-sleaze era.

Mr Kemp told BBC2's Newsnight: "If people are receiving large amounts of money from speaking and are indicating that they are giving it to charity, then I think that should be in the public domain. I think the public deserve and expect nothing less."

Mr Bruce was equally forthright on the same programme. "Anybody reading the entry would assume that Mr Hague was anticipating and presumably getting substantial sums of money for speaking outside Parliament and was using that money to give to charity."

The row may intensify private complaints, widespread among Tory MPs, that the leader's office is badly run despite Mr Hague's past career as a management consultant with the cult firm of McKinseys.

Echoing Mr Kemp's demand for greater disclosure, Mr Bruce added: "To leave the register running for more than two years without any change is, frankly, extraordinary for the leader of the main opposition party.

"One would assume that he would have gone out of his way to make sure that his entry was cleared and correct."

webTitle: Select committee calls for ministerial code watchdog

fields.headline: Select committee calls for ministerial code watchdog
fields.trailText: Commons committee calls for ministers to be investigated by independent watchdog to prevent repeat of rush to judge Peter Mandelson.
fields.body:
A parliamentary watchdog should be on permanent standby to investigate breaches of the ministerial code of conduct, according to an influential House of Commons select committee.

The recommendation to set up an independent investigator comes in the wake of the Hinduja passport scandal which saw Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson resign over a disputed telephone call.

Now the select committee on public administration has called for the parliamentary ombudsman - who currently investigates complaints against MPs - to scrutinize alleged breaches of the ministerial code.

At the moment any complaint is looked into by the cabinet secretary or other senior civil servants.

The aim of the recommendation, which will be sent to the prime minister, is to ensure fairness to ministers under strong political pressure to resign after allegations of wrongdoing - either from the press or political opponents.

But the scheme has run into immediate opposition from Lord Neill, chairman of the committee on standards in public life, who claimed the plan would turn into a "political football."

He said "Some complaints will be good, some bona fide, some politically motivated, and the cry will go up to refer this to the standing investigator.

"I think it will turn the thing into a political football."

The ministerial code of conduct is an informal collection of guidelines that have evolved over more than 50 years, covering general standards for ministerial conduct.

The proposal, which is unlikely to garner much support from Downing Street, would also see the prime minister face an annual question time session from the chairmen of the various Commons select committees.

The recommendations will give fresh succour to backbench MP Peter Mandelson, who is trying to clear his name after resigning in what friends describe as a "kangaroo court" as pressure from the media mounted over discrepencies in his account of his handling of the Hinduja passport affair.

The former Northern Ireland secretary resigned on January 24th after a tense meeting with the prime minister, his press secretary Alastair Campbell and Sir Richard Wilson, the cabinet secretary.

fields.headline: Electoral reform pledge on hold
fields.trailText: Prime minister Tony Blair today lowered Liberal Democrat hopes of a referendum on proportional representation for Westminster when he refused point blank to give a pledge promising a public poll on the issue after the next election.
fields.body:
Prime minister Tony Blair today lowered Liberal Democrat hopes of a referendum on proportional representation for Westminster when he refused point blank to give a pledge promising a public poll on the issue after the next election.

Lib Dem leader Charles Kennedy has threatened to end cooperation with Labour if there is not a commitment to a referendum on electoral reform in the government's manifesto.

But quizzed by Conservative MP James Gray at prime minister questions on the prospects for PR - to match last week's shock announcement of a two-year deadline on a decision for a referendum on the euro - Tony Blair simply batted away the question.

He said: "You'll have to wait until the manifesto for all that."

It is the clearest sign yet that with Peter Mandelson  the Cabinet's biggest advocate of greater cooperation with the LibDems  out of the government, the issue is rapidly losing favour inside the Labour party.

That is reinforced by Labour's continuing domination in the opinion polls, which place the government a 20 points ahead of the Tories, and with it another large majority in the Commons after the next election.

Former Lib Dem leader Paddy Ashdown initiated secret talks with Tony Blair before the last election on the possibility of two Cabinet posts for his party in return for coalition politics with the Lib Dems if Labour failed to reach a working majority.

But with Labour sweeping to a 179 seat majority at the 1997 election, the scheme was soon shelved by the prime minister.

webTitle: Corus to consider job loss alternatives

fields.headline: Corus to consider job loss alternatives
fields.trailText: 14 February: Steel giant Corus has agreed to consider alternative proposals to the 6,000 job losses it is planning after a "constructive" meeting with union leaders today.
fields.body:
Steel giant Corus has agreed to consider alternative proposals to the 6,000 job losses it is planning after a "constructive" meeting with union leaders today.

Following an earlier announcement that its redundant employees were being targetted to fill 4,000 new jobs created by telecoms company EXi Telecoms, Corus has now decided to go ahead with the statutory 90-day consultation process before it makes any cuts.

The company will meet union officials again in a month's time after looking in detail at a plan presented by unions at a meeting in London.

Michael Leahy, general secretary of the iron and steel trades confederation, said he was hopeful that progress could be achieved. Union leaders are also planning to meet the government to discuss their plans, believed to involve retraining of steel workers for other jobs while still emplyed by Corus.

The training could still help prepare Corus workers for jobs at EXi Telecoms, which employs around 1,700 staff. The company is aiming to recruit other manufacturing workers across the country over the next two years under a huge programme to upgrade infrastructure for the booming sector.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, which has an agreement with EXi, earlier said: "This will be a genuinely radical way of dealing with the threat of redundancies at Corus.

"We can offer our members at Corus a chance to retrain for a new job with new skills."

Meanwhile, a steelworker and his wife and 10-year-old twin children were today presenting a petition to Corus protesting at job losses in the North East.

Teesside steelworker Matthew Lodge, his wife Dorothy and children Lucy and Matthew were handing over the petition to Corus executives at the company's London head office.

Union leaders will arrive at the same offices later today for last-ditch talks with Corus after spending the last two weeks drawing up a detailed rescue package.

"The more we look at the Corus plans the more faults we find," said ISTC general secretary Michael Leahy.

The union said Corus's transport costs will increase if the cuts go ahead, because some steel products will have to be taken from the North East to Llanwern in south Wales, instead of being 'rolled' at another factory on Teesside.

"It is the economics of the madhouse," said an ISTC spokesman. Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers has urged Corus to "think again" before pressing ahead with the redundancies.

"We think there is a better way forward and we hope that even at this late stage Corus will reconsider the position they have adopted."

Corus chairman Sir Brian Moffat is due to be questioned by the trade and industry select committee today.

Sir Ken Jackson said that former Corus workers would be given the first opportunity of retraining for the 4,000 jobs that would be created over two years.

"It is going to happen this morning. We are going to announce it this morning," he confirmed to the Today programme on BBC Radio Four.

"It is going to be 4,000 jobs over two years. Obviously we are interested in people from Corus being given the first opportunity."

webTitle: Foreign donor ban dogged by loopholes

fields.headline: Foreign donor ban dogged by loopholes
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Government plans to ban foreign donors from giving cash to political parties appeared in disarray last night.
fields.body:
Government plans to ban foreign donors from giving cash to political parties appeared in disarray last night. The Home Office has admitted to the Guardian that the government's pledge on donors will be unenforceable at the next general election - expected in May - and a host of loopholes could scupper bans in the future.

Legislation which had been designed to stop all foreigners donating to parties comes into force on Friday. But foreign money can still be received by individual party candidates until July 1.

This will leave an anomaly allowing anyone standing for parliament to receive personal donations from any foreign donor contributing to their campaign, providing it does not exceed their spending limits. It will also allow them to receive large donations before the campaign starts.

Last night some Tory candidates were furious at the confusion. One candidate, David Shaw, who is fighting the Liberal Democrat marginal of Kingston and Surbiton, said: "I have just turned down a personal donation from an American supporter on the grounds that it would be banned from Friday.

"Now I am told I could accept it - or perhaps even accept a larger donation - which I could then hand on as my personal donation to party funds. This is a ridiculous situation. This new law is riddled with anomalies."

Details of the anomaly in the new law were disclosed during a briefing for the Guardian by Home Office officials and attended by Mike O'Brien, the minister responsible for implementing the new act.

The anomaly, which will only apply for any general election held before July 1, is also compounded by other loopholes which could remain for much longer, until the new electoral commission has brought a series of test cases.

The aim of the new law was to limit donations to UK voters and ban donations from everybody else. Ministers have already had to give a four-year exemption to Northern Ireland, allowing foreign donations to all parties putting up candidates for parliament. Special rules have had to be introduced to prevent the cash being transferred from Northern Ireland.

Ministers then had to agree to a further relaxation allowing all European Union and Commonwealth citizens resident in the UK, who are entitled to vote, to give donations. This will now also apply to citizens from Mozambique after it joined the Commonwealth.

The Home Office said only EU and Commonwealth citizens whose main residence was in the UK would be allowed to give donations.

fields.bodyText: Government plans to ban foreign donors from giving cash to political parties appeared in disarray last night. The Home Office has admitted to the Guardian that the government's pledge on donors will be unenforceable at the next general election - expected in May - and a host of loopholes could scupper bans in the future. Legislation which had been designed to stop all foreigners donating to parties comes into force on Friday. But foreign money can still be received by individual party candidates until July 1. This will leave an anomaly allowing anyone standing for parliament to receive personal donations from any foreign donor contributing to their campaign, providing it does not exceed their spending limits. It will also allow them to receive large donations before the campaign starts. Last night some Tory candidates were furious at the confusion. One candidate, David Shaw, who is fighting the Liberal Democrat marginal of Kingston and Surbiton, said: "I have just turned down a personal donation from an American supporter on the grounds that it would be banned from Friday. "Now I am told I could accept it - or perhaps even accept a larger donation - which I could then hand on as my personal donation to party funds. This is a ridiculous situation. This new law is riddled with anomalies." Details of the anomaly in the new law were disclosed during a briefing for the Guardian by Home Office officials and attended by Mike O'Brien, the minister responsible for implementing the new act. webTitle: Arms controls still lax despite Scott

fields.headline: Arms controls still lax despite Scott
fields.standfirst: Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: Gaping loopholes in Britain's weapons export controls remain five years after they were identified by Lord Scott's report on the arms to Iraq affair, Amnesty International and Oxfam say in a stinging report today.
fields.body:
Gaping loopholes in Britain's weapons export controls remain five years after they were identified by Lord Scott's report on the arms to Iraq affair, Amnesty International and Oxfam say in a stinging report today.

There are still no adequate controls to ensure arms are sold to their stated destinations, and British weapons brokers can easily bypass existing controls, say the campaigning groups.

Policy is still determined by a 1939 emergency law which gives the executive wide powers with no proper parliamentary scrutiny, despite recommendations in Lord Scott's report published five years ago tomorrow.

"Despite their scathing criticism over the arms to Iraq report while in opposition, leading members of the government have let five years pass without acting to introduce tough new arms controls laws," said Robert Parker of Amnesty.

Justin Forsyth, Oxfam's policy director, said: "Small arms brokered from Britain will continue to cause suffering around the world. Having made so much noise about the Scott report in opposition, the government should be ashamed by its failure to introduce tough new arms laws."

Lord Scott disclosed how British arms had reached Iraq through third countries - notably Jordan and Saudi Arabia - as a result of the failure to monitor end-user certificates. Checks are still not made to ensure arms stay in the countries to which they are sent.

Amnesty and Oxfam also point out that the government has admitted it is still unable to track arms exported from Britain. And arms deals brokered in Britain do not require a licence if the weapons are shipped from a third country.

In a notable example, Heckler and Koch guns manufactured in Turkey were exported to Indonesia when Britain had imposed an arms embargo on weapons sales to the country.

webTitle: Corus to consider job loss alternatives

fields.headline: Corus to consider job loss alternatives
fields.trailText: Steel giant Corus has agreed to consider alternative proposals to the 6,000 job losses it is planning after a "constructive" meeting with union leaders today.
fields.body:
Steel giant Corus has agreed to consider alternative proposals to the 6,000 job losses it is planning after a "constructive" meeting with union leaders today.

Following an earlier announcement that its redundant employees were being targetted to fill 4,000 new jobs created by telecoms company EXi Telecoms, Corus has now decided to go ahead with the statutory 90-day consultation process before it makes any cuts.

The company will meet union officials again in a month's time after looking in detail at a plan presented by unions at a meeting in London.

Michael Leahy, general secretary of the iron and steel trades confederation, said he was hopeful that progress could be achieved. Union leaders are also planning to meet the government to discuss their plans, believed to involve retraining of steel workers for other jobs while still emplyed by Corus.

The training could still help prepare Corus workers for jobs at EXi Telecoms, which employs around 1,700 staff. The company is aiming to recruit other manufacturing workers across the country over the next two years under a huge programme to upgrade infrastructure for the booming sector.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, which has an agreement with EXi, earlier said: "This will be a genuinely radical way of dealing with the threat of redundancies at Corus.

"We can offer our members at Corus a chance to retrain for a new job with new skills."

Meanwhile, a steelworker and his wife and 10-year-old twin children were today presenting a petition to Corus protesting at job losses in the North East.

Teesside steelworker Matthew Lodge, his wife Dorothy and children Lucy and Matthew were handing over the petition to Corus executives at the company's London head office.

Union leaders will arrive at the same offices later today for last-ditch talks with Corus after spending the last two weeks drawing up a detailed rescue package.

"The more we look at the Corus plans the more faults we find," said ISTC general secretary Michael Leahy.

The union said Corus's transport costs will increase if the cuts go ahead, because some steel products will have to be taken from the North East to Llanwern in south Wales, instead of being 'rolled' at another factory on Teesside.

"It is the economics of the madhouse," said an ISTC spokesman. Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers has urged Corus to "think again" before pressing ahead with the redundancies.

"We think there is a better way forward and we hope that even at this late stage Corus will reconsider the position they have adopted."

Corus chairman Sir Brian Moffat is due to be questioned by the trade and industry select committee today.

Sir Ken Jackson said that former Corus workers would be given the first opportunity of retraining for the 4,000 jobs that would be created over two years.

"It is going to happen this morning. We are going to announce it this morning," he confirmed to the Today programme on BBC Radio Four.

"It is going to be 4,000 jobs over two years. Obviously we are interested in people from Corus being given the first opportunity."

webTitle: Blair pledges to cut class sizes

fields.headline: Blair pledges to cut class sizes in problem schools
fields.standfirst: Education site
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday toughened his drive to improve standards among secondary schools by promising to set maximum class sizes in problem schools.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday toughened his drive to improve standards among secondary schools by promising to set maximum class sizes in problem schools.

The recognition that secondary class sizes should be reduced is a key concession by the government, which until now has focused on primary school ages. There was no mention of the proposals in Monday's green paper on schools, despite the acknowledgement that standards for pupils aged 11 to 14 are not high enough.

Blair is also in urgent discussions with Ofsted, the government inspectorate, to see how the administrative burden of regular inspections could be lifted. He is also to provide £80m to give small schools administrative support in handling an inspection.

Without withdrawing from the commitment to rigorous external inspection, Mr Blair is aware that red tape is reducing the time teachers spend in the classroom. Red tape is the single biggest complaint levelled against the government by the teaching unions.

The proposal to cut class sizes is likely to start with only 10 or so secondary schools, often in areas where English is not the pupils' first language. In some cases the class size will be cut to as low as 10 to 15. The scheme will be extended if it is seen to improve the performance of failing schools.

At the same time Mr Blair told the Guardian he was not interested in setting up a two-tier secondary education system based on selection. He said in time he wanted all secondary schools to develop some form of distinctive ethos.

The prime minister has been hammered by supporters of the comprehensive system for proposing in the green paper that by 2005 nearly half of all secondary schools would be specialist schools.

Critics fear the remaining half of schools will be "bog standard comprehensives", the description given by Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's press secretary.

Mr Blair said he wanted several kinds of secondary schools: foundation, city academies, church and specialist.

"I will not be deflected by criticism," he said. "I still consider our proposals are the best way for the first time to give every child, and not just a privileged few, the chance of a decent education.

"The aim is that every school becomes a distinctive school."

He added that the evidence was overwhelming that specialist schools had produced superior results, praising the sports specialist school in his Sedgefield constituency.

Defending his drive to cut red tape in schools, Mr Blair said the number of documents sent out by the government to schools would be reduced by a third.

He added that the government and Ofsted were looking into ways to make "inspections less bureaucratic".

Discussions between Ofsted and Whitehall have located unnecessary investigations. Ministers have already promised that successful schools will not be subject to full-scale investigations, but instead subject to "light touch" inspections.

The plan to reduce infant class sizes was one of Labour's five key election pledges in 1997. That commitment that five- to seven-year-olds would be in a class of less than 30 will be met ahead of schedule in September 2001, largely through extra investment of some £620m.

At primary level, Labour has also taken steps to improve pupil-teacher ratios, and is investing further cash this year to ensure that eight- to 11-year-olds who had been in smaller classes in the earlier age group would continue to benefit.

But teachers leaders' calls to extend targets to secondary schools have until now fallen on deaf ears.

Ministers have insisted that it is down to the discretion of individual heads to use government cash to reduce class sizes by employing extra teachers.

webTitle: Letters: Tony Blair's education green paper

fields.headline: A comprehensive thumbs down
fields.trailText: How refreshing to hear that Mr Blair (Anger over two-tier school plan, February 13) sees the future of secondary education as schools which "develop a distinct ethos and deliver learning tailor-made for each pupil".
fields.body:
How refreshing to hear that Mr Blair (Anger over two-tier school plan, February 13) sees the future of secondary education as schools which "develop a distinct ethos and deliver learning tailor-made for each pupil". That's exactly what good comprehensive schools have done for decades. To suggest this can only happen in specialist schools is nonsense. As the head of a school which does not have specialist status, the work undertaken by my staff is anything but "bog standard". Day after day they recognise the individual needs of pupils and ensure that they do succeed, often against impossible odds.

Under the new proposals, almost half the schools in the country will be eligible for this additional funding and be able to select a proportion of their pupils. What then happens to the intake of the 54% of schools without selection and without additional funding? The answer is obvious, but what happens to parental choice? The premier league schools will only take a certain percentage of pupils, and who will want to join the second division?
Jo Dibb
London

As a head teacher during most of the Thatcher/Major years, my heart sank every time the Tories produced a new paper on education. I witnessed the gradual erosion of the principle of equality of provision and the constant push towards elitism - opted-out schools, city technology colleges, grammar schools - with a mixture of sadness and anger. The only thing which kept me going was the hope that one day we would have a government determined to promote genuine equality of opportunity through a well-funded comprehensive system. In May 1997 I dared to think that moment had come.

I was wrong. With a Labour government pursuing education policies even more right-wing than the Tories, what choice do I have now?
Derek Gillard
Oxford

Congratulations on your excellent leader (February 13). You make the important point that specialisation should not start before the age of 14. My only quibble is with your conclusion that the "plan smacks of a wish to please everyone". It certainly doesn't please Labour members like myself who are now ashamed of our party's policy. In fact the plan smacks of a wish to please the Daily Mail leader-writers, and has clearly done so, judging by their headline today: Death of the comprehensive.
Prof Keith Barnham
London

How insulting to the many excellent comprehensives across the country for a government spokesperson to use the term "bog standard". Government policy seems to be aimed at making people ashamed of being at a comprehensive, teaching at one or sending their children to one.

If specialising leads to better results then surely all schools should be given the money to specialise? If by design half get "bog standard" funding then of course the others will improve by comparison.
Margaret Tulloch
Campaign for State Education
tulloch-case@mcr1.poptel.org.uk

Please tell everyone to stop saying "bog standard" as a measure of normality. The correct phrase is "boxed standard" as in "this is our boxed standard model."
John Berry
Newark, Notts

Is two-tier education really what I want for my child's future? Our local comprehensive is already suffering the consequences of middle-class flight. Over the next few years the funding differential with its specialist neighbours will be progressively enhanced until it reaches its nadir just as the current Year 7 approach GCSE. Why not close down the non specialist schools now and save us all the agony of waiting ?
Ann Miles
Milton Keynes

The claim that a two-tier system will be avoided by specialist schools sharing "good practice" with neighbouring schools is unrealistic. The "good practice" of a school with a better paid staff and a partially selective intake will have little relevance to those lacking these advantages.
DH Kedge
Sonning Common, Oxon

Will Mr Blunkett help student teachers who have juggled jobs and study to avoid "burdening" parents, tax payers or themselves with debt? If students are to have loans paid off over 10 years, may they have their social life, sanity and sleep-deprivation compensated with a four-day week?
Jennifer Gibb
Glasgow
9503971g@student.gla.ac.uk

So there will be more schools admitting children based on their religious background. Just the kind of arrangment which has worked so well in Northern Ireland, where you may study Catholic or Protestant maths and geography as well as Protestant or Catholic domestic science. That really is progress.
Bob Holmes
Axbridge, Somerset
HOLMESR923@aol.com

In keeping with Blair-speak's idea of "post-comprehensive" education, may I suggest that the non-selective non-specialist schools be renamed "secondary modernised"?
D Cameron
Stoke-on-Trent

webTitle: Comment: Jeremy Hardy, learning the hard way

fields.headline: Learning the hard way
fields.trailText: You might argue that, if a child shows great aptitude for languages, she should go to a specialist school. But if her local specialist school happens to be St Nike’s Academy For Keeping Troublesome Youths Shagged Out By Running, how exactly is her linguistic genius going to be fostered?
fields.body:
Well, my little girl's pushing 11 now so I suppose it's high time I was choosing her career. I can't decide whether she has a special aptitude for computers or whether Virtual Springfield falls into the category of what used to be called "fun". She's very good at getting money out of me but I'm not sure she'd enjoy business studies, which is about taking money from strangers, something I've told her not to do. In fact, she lends me more than I give her, and at zero interest, so I don't think she's equipped for the greed GNVQ.

She very much enjoys the performing arts and I think she excels in them. The trouble is that all parents think their child is the most magical, special and beautiful child in the world, which is clearly irrational, because my child is the most magical, special and beautiful child in the world. In any event, the nearest performing arts school has the good sense not to open their doors to children under 14, realising perhaps that children who are too young to know that Hollyoaks is unrelenting bollocks shouldn't be planning their working lives just yet.

It occurs to me that I haven't even chosen a religion for my daughter, but perhaps it's a bit late for that. Being an unbeliever, I tried to choose secular education, but it's not available, so I've put up with the obligatory religiosity of the nearest state primary. I've always figured that religion should come as the result of a blinding light, a nervous breakdown or a prison sentence, rather than being something that goes on a blazer or a blackboard.

The faith communities, however seem to see scripture as something that needs to be injected into the child not long after the MMR vaccine. Once children are old enough to suss that "Because I said so" is not a reasoned argument, they are susceptible to all kinds questioning impulses. That is why faith declines the more freely people think. We don't yet know whether the government wants failing religions to be taken over by those with improving attendance figures, or simply handed over to the private sector and converted into academies of consumer fetish-ism, or luxury belfry apartments.

Those who want children to be segregated according to their parents' real or professed creeds, claim that religious schools teach pupils to respect other religions. But, I am slightly sceptical about the idea that the best way to promote understanding is for children never to meet one another. "Equal but different" has never been a happy prescription. No society that is serious about equality promotes segregation. Still, they get very good exam results in Northern Ireland. It's a shame about the bitter sectarian hatred but you can't have everything. And at least in Britain we have greater diversity of faith. Parents can choose from a rich variety of possible ways to isolate their children from others.

Perhaps the coming increase in religious schools will be the model for all specialisation and selection. In schools which, under the sponsorship and control of industry, concentrate on science and technology, pupils will learn about the existence of other ways of making a living, without really giving them serious consideration. Perhaps they will learn to respect the arts, while knowing that information technology is the one true vocation.

Specialist schools will say they do very well over a range of subjects. If true, it might have something to do with the fact that they get more money and resources, and the better they do, the more money and resources they get. They also practise selection, something that this government has done more than 18 years of Thatcherism to promote. It's impossible to believe that its great vision for education is not about sorting the managers from the underlings as early as possible. Selection is always at the expense of someone. It means choice for the few, potluck for the many.

You might argue that, if a child shows great aptitude for languages, she should go to a specialist school. But if her local specialist school happens to be St Nike's Academy For Keeping Troublesome Youths Shagged Out By Running, how exactly is her linguistic genius going to be fostered? What if, being Nigerian, she has an interest in her ancestral homeland, and her local centre of excellence is the Shell College of Short Memory?

What if you just want your child to go to an inclusive, free, well-resourced nearby school, with a range of abilities, a balanced curriculum and a policy of keeping children's options as wide as possible for as long as possible? But then, I'm talking about enriching children's lives with the joy of learning. I'm not thinking about the short-term needs of New Labour's business partners. Sorry kids, it's time for a word from our sponsors.

fields.headline: The alternatives to Napster
fields.standfirst: Sarah Left takes a look at the sites who may be poised to steal the embattled song-swap service's crown - if they can attract similar numbers of users
fields.trailText: Sarah Left takes a look at the sites who may be poised to steal the embattled song swap service's crown - if they can attract similar numbers of users.
fields.body:
With the future of popular song swap service <A HREF=""Napster in doubt, the hunt is on for the next big music sharing site.

Napster may yet tough out its lawsuit from five of the world's biggest record companies, but it remains to be seen how loyal its 50m users will be once subscription charges are introduced.

Napster hopes to re-emerge as a legal service if an eventual trial finds it guilty of copyright infringement. It has plans to charge users to download music, thereby supplying the record companies with payment for copyrighted material.

But aside from Napster itself, the internet offers a great number of filesharing alternatives, some of which charge for the material downloaded, and some of which do not.

Gnutella is a large, diversified service with no central server, which makes it difficult - if not impossible - to shut down. It's not as obviously user-friendly as Napster, and America Online, fearing legal fallout, will have nothing to do with it. But it has a large community of users that share everything from music to software to recipes.

Scour.com, formerly a place to swap music files for free, was shut down and has now been bought by CenterSpan Communications. The company plans to put the Scour Exchange back online as soon as it has found a way to make it legal, which the CenterSpan defines as any method of exchange that avoids $250bn lawsuits.

CuteMX is very much in the mould of Napster, allowing users swap music and video files for free. It includes an address for record companies and artists to write in if they feel their copyright has been infringed by CuteMX users.

European newcomer Zden charges for its services as a marketplace for digital files, where people can buy, sell and store their own original content. The company describes itself as "halfway between eBay and Napster" and it controls the legality and copyright of centrally stored files. The site is far more business-focused than the other alternatives.

In any filesharing service, the critical element is the number of users it attracts, so aside from the copyright issues, any service lives or dies by its membership. It is precisely the unprecedented membership numbers that may keep Napster alive and well ahead of its competition.

webTitle: Call for 'bodies in the chapel' boss to be reinstated

fields.headline: Call for 'bodies in the chapel' boss to be reinstated
fields.trailText:
Doctors at the hospital at the heart of the Bedford "bodies in the chapel" scandal have called for the reinstatement of the chief executive forced to step down in the wake of the incident. Patrick Butlerreports
Analysis: the Bedford inquiry
fields.body:
Doctors at the hospital at the heart of the Bedford "bodies in the chapel" scandal have called for the reinstatement of the chief executive forced to step down in the wake of the incident.

Hospital consultants have written to the health secretary, Alan Milburn, saying that Ken Williams was unfairly "sacked" before the inquiry had reported and he should be given back his job.

The call follows a BBC investigation which claims that the official Bedford hospital NHS trust inquiry report refused to publish key evidence surrounding the incident last January.

The affair broke after national newspapers carried pictures of seven wrapped corpses stored in the "chapel" area of Bedford hospital mortuary because a temporary mortuary was inaccessible.

The inquiry report said most staff "refused to believe that the photographs could have been obtained except by tampering with the bodies and their coverings beforehand".

But it did not include evidence from a hospital consultant which suggests that the bodies may well have been "styled" to provide maximum impact for the cameras.

According to the BBC, Jane Hurst, a consultant anaesthetist looked in on the chapel of rest earlier in the evening in question - and she said the bodies were undisturbed. "All the bodies were wrapped up and labelled and tidy. When I saw the bodies they were absolutely neat and tidy and placed perfectly respectfully on the floor."

The BBC also reports that a mortuary assistant has said there were two available spaces in the main mortuary at the time when the bodies were placed in the chapel.

The trust has launched its own internal investigation in an attempt to discover how the newspaper gained access to the chapel, which is a "secure" area of the mortuary, not normally accessible to the public.

It is clear that many at the trust believe the scandal was deliberately engineered by disgruntled staff. Industrial relations at the trust have been poor in recent months.

Dr Richard Rawlins, a consultant at Bedford hospital trust and a British Medical Association consultant's committee member, said the inquiry had not got to the core of the scandal but had merely attempted to retrospectively justify the removal of Mr Williams.

He said Mr Williams should have at the very least been given leave until the inquiry had reported, rather than asking him to resign just hours after the official investigation was announced.

Bedford hospital trust said today that Mr Williams had "stood down" rather than "resigned". This distinction enables him to continue to be paid until a severance agreement is agreed with the trust. If he had resigned, he would have forfeited his salary immediately.

fields.headline: About The Baggies newspaper
fields.trailText: That's right - the fanzine that's also, uniquely, a full colour tabloid newspaper.
fields.body:
That's right - the fanzine that's also, uniquely, a full colour tabloid newspaper.

You won't find us listed in the fanzine section of When Saturday Comes - "too professional" was what we were told when we asked for a listing when we launched eight years ago. Fair enough, we'll take that for a start.

We're put together completely by professional, award-winning journalists and designers who also happen to be life long Albion supporters, and do the job as a labour of love.

We look like a top-end colour monthly mag, but read like a fanzine, written by Albion experts (who have published an amazing twenty books about the club). We have three photographers and two reporters at every Albion match, League game or friendly, so we cover all the games, offer inside news and opinions and shift more copies than the official programme.

We led the campaign to oust the previous board of directors and we will always remain fiercely independent of the club, whilst supporting and trying to maintain cordial relations with it.

Every issue we have interviews with current players, the manager, old stars (Johnny Giles, Brendan Batson, Bobby Robson coming up soon), massive colour posters, historical features -- we're the fanzine that you never imagined existed.

We also regularly publish acclaimed Baggies books - an annual Albion Review, Bomber Brown, The Tony Brown story, and many more.

We're on sale outside The Hawthorns at every home game, but you can get a sample copy of our current issue (and subscription details) by sending £1.50 (£1.80 Europe, £2.40 rest of the world) to: The Baggies, 54 Newhall Street, West Bromwich B70 7DJ.

You can contact the editor on: gwillmore@baggies.org.uk. Our web-site is at: www.baggies.org.uk.

webTitle: Can the Albion restore old glories?

fields.headline: Can the Albion restore old glories?
fields.standfirst: Glenn Willmore, editor of The Baggies newspaper, is pretty happy with Gary Megson the moment
fields.trailText: Glenn Willmore, editor of The Baggies newspaper, is pretty happy with Gary Megson the moment. Here's the history behind the smile.
fields.body:
When I first started watching the Baggies, in 1969, they were without question one of the top dozen clubs in English football. A top flight club for almost all of the previous ninety years, they had been winners of all the domestic trophies and possessed a side with a reputation for playing quality football.

As recently as 1984 they were still a quality side, but it's all been downhill since then, and the Albion would figure in few people's top thirty clubs. One only has to look at Leicester City - who have always lagged well behind the Albion in every aspect, on and off the pitch - to see where we could have been now, with decent leadership at board level.

Latent support for the club in the Midlands is such that if Albion can get into the Premiership, they would have no problem in filling the ground and financing the creation of a team that would survive - and compete -- at the higher level. Hopefully, promotion can be achieved this season. If not, there will be few Albion fans complaining if it takes another year or so.

This season is a bonus - unexpected early success under a hard working manager after years of failure - and we are prepared to wait, if needs be, until the time is right.

The most astonishing thing about the Albion this year is just how well they're doing in the First Division. It would be no exaggeration to call last season "traumatic" - not only did we have three managers during the season, in Denis Smith, Brian Little and Gary Megson, we also had two different boards of directors, and sold our two best players in Kevin Kilbane and Enzo Maresca.

Add to that a campaign which started with the club's best ever unbeaten start, but ended with the team needing to beat champions Charlton in the final game, to stop up, and you have the classic "rollercoaster" season that Albion fans have become used to.

Things started to happen around Christmas 1999, when, one by one, all credibility gone, the old board of directors resigned and a new board, led by chairman Paul Thompson (see below) took over and started to lead the club away from its old corner-shop mentality.

Soon after, Brian Little was on his way and dark horse Gary Megson was appointed to lead a team that was heading for the Second Division.

Realising that he hardly had any quality players, he went out on transfer deadline day and signed five new men, and gave them all their debuts in one game at Maine Road. They went down in that game to an injury time goal, but lost just once more in the last eight fixtures, to hang on to their First Division place.

More astute signings followed in the summer - Megson has now signed 14 players in a year, for £5m, and not one of the deals has been anything less than a success, with Neil Clement, Player of the Year in most peoples' eyes, a fantastic signing for just £100,000 from Chelsea.

The manager has built up a team spirit that was totally lacking, and created a side that looks certain to reach the Play-offs. It's been some turnaround, and has been much appreciated by the success-starved fans of one of the classic "sleeping giants" who had begun to believe that the Albion's long hibernation might well have been terminal.

fields.headline: Unions angry over pay offer
fields.trailText: Union leaders today slammed local government employers after learning that councils in England and Wales are not prepared to offer staff a pay increase of more than 3% next year. Simon Parker reports
fields.body:
Union leaders today slammed local government employers after learning that councils in England and Wales are not prepared to offer staff a pay increase of more than 3% next year.

The figure is less than half the average increase proposed by the unions, who want a flat-rate, across-the-board increase of £1,000 which would establish a minimum local government wage of more than £5 an hour.

Union bosses condemned the council position, saying that authorities can afford to pay more. Unison national secretary Malcolm Wing commented: "Local government staff will be bitterly disappointed and resentful when they learn of the 3% 'offer'. The employers shouldn't miscalculate the effects of that anger and resentment."

He added that recent increases in local government funding, including a 7% boost for the coming financial year, had raised employee expectations: "On the one hand, we're being told that local government has never had it so good and, on the other, that councils can't afford to offer a decent increase this year. It doesn't add up, and it won't do."

The 3% figure, put forward by the local government Employers Organisation, is based on consultation with councils across England and Wales - three-quarters said they could not afford more. The organisation will need to seek a fresh mandate from authorities before they change their position.

Even at 3%, the pay increase will cost around £390m. The union's proposals could more than double that.

An Employers Organisation spokesman said: "The unions made clear their anger and resentment at the response. They don't want a Scottish scenario, but there are very clear problems."

The talks have been adjourned until 20 March.
