fields.headline: No 5. West Bromwich Albion
fields.standfirst: A tour around The Hawthorns with editor of The Baggies newspaper, Glenn Willmore
fields.trailText: What makes Albion so special?
fields.body:
What makes Albion so special?

Traditionally, Albion were always the midlands' top Football Academy. The Villa might win more trophies, the Wolves might have their moments with their trademark long ball approach, but you could rely on the Albion for playing cultured football, scoring goals, and winning the Cup now and then.

As a small town club - don't believe this West-Bromwich-is-in-Birmingham nonsense - Albion have always punched above their weight since they were founder members of the Football League, but the last fifteen years have been the worst in the club's long history. In 1979 Albion, with Ron Atkinson in charge, of Cyrille Regis, Laurie Cunningham and Brendan Batson, were the leaders of the "Black Revolution" in English football, and one of the most attractive sides in Europe. By 1986 they were barely the best team in West Bromwich as they sank, a laughing stock, into the Second Division, dropping into the Third Division for the first time five years later.

Now we're famous for the highest turnover of managers in the whole League - one a year for the past eleven seasons or so, including a record three last season! But things are changing.

The high point

Although only one midlands club has won the FA Cup since Albion last won it in 1968 - and that's Coventry City, who don't count - that's more than a lifetime away for many Albion fans. Instead, they recall with pleasure the one real great occasion of the last thirty years - our Second Division play-off victory against Port Vale at Wembley in 1993. (Although most real fans with say that the home leg of the semi-final against Swansea had more passion.)

The low point

Far too many recently, but the two which struck at the heart of all of us came in the same 1990-91 season. If losing 4-2 at home to Woking in the third round of the FA Cup was not humiliating enough, relegation to the old Third Division for the first time at Twerton Park on the last day of the season really put a cap on it. Had we won that last game, Leicester City would have gone down instead - wonder what's happened to them since?

Our last game

Stockport did not quite roll over and die the way they were supposed to at The Hawthorns last Saturday. In fact, they should have been three goals ahead by the time Albion scored through Jason Roberts, right on the half-time whistle.

Albion controlled the second half without really impressing, but conceded an equaliser - a fabulous shot from Cooper - to lose two valuable points. How much does it matter? Well, none of the top six clubs managed a win either, so in the short term, not a lot.

Our next game

Next Saturday, Albion travel to St Andrews for one of the biggest games of the season, as they take on Trevor Francis's Birmingham City side, just two weeks before they meet Liverpool in the League Cup Final.

Blues have been a problem recently, but they will surely have more on their mind than a west midlands derby, so Albion should buck the trend and come away with at least a point.

Sore point

For so many years, Birmingham City were the butt of Albion fans' humour. They never won anything (well, there was a League Cup in the Sixties, it's rumoured), they never did anything, and they never beat us.

Now they've been taken over by a porn millionaire, things have changed. We haven't beaten them for years, they get to the play-offs every season, and now they've reached the League Cup Final. We can't believe it: it's a distortion of the very bedrock of football in the Midlands, and the sooner it gets back to normal, the better. Especially as we could be meeting them in the play-offs come May.

The chairman

After years of second-raters in the top job, Albion have struck lucky with Barnsley-based businessman Paul Thompson. Traditionally, Albion directors have been local small (and small minded) businessmen and Thompson, recruited through an advert in The Times and with no local links, was initially distrusted by fans.

However, since leaving the club to return in a blaze of glory in December 1999, he has delivered on all of the promises that were continually broken by his predecessors. Not only has he found the money for the manager to build up the best Albion side in fifteen years, he has completed the rebuilding of the ground and purchased the much-needed training ground that the previous regime had been banging on about for over five years.

The club now has a professional approach - on and off the pitch - that was never there before, and although, inevitably, there are still a few things we would like to see improve, Albion fans have nothing but praise for the chairman.

Local rivals

For the first eighty years of the club's existence, at least, the only rivals were Aston Villa - the only other local team capable of winning anything. No other neighbouring clubs can claim to have met one another in three separate FA Cup finals, and the fixture regularly used to attract 60,000-plus gates.

But it's difficult to hate a team you never play, and apart from the occasional Cup drubbing, the teams have been in different divisions for years. Now, a whole new hate-culture has developed, centred on our Black Country neighbours, Wolverhampton Wanderers.

I suppose it's our own fault. Selling them four key players - including their cult hero and record goalscorer Steve Bull back in 1986 - saved the Wolves from going out of business, long before their "Golden Tit" Jack Hayward came on the scene to pour in the cash.

Now the rivalry has reached a unsavoury level unseen anywhere outside Glasgow: a Black Country derby is a true throwback to the bad old days of the Seventies, on and off the pitch - but Albion have only lost a couple in the last seven years. With our neighbours' recent slump, the only thing they've got to look forward to this season is trying to take three points from our promotion run-in when we visit Molineux in March.

Kit

Albion supporters are, thankfully, very conservative on this subject. We're the only club in the League to play in navy blue stripes, the kit's been that way since 1889, and it's going to stay that way. The thickness of the stripes change, and they faff around with the trimmings, but the only real variation we've had in recent years is a bizarre, but very popular, "barcode stripes" design introduced in 1992.

Consequently, great attention is paid to the away strip, which is currently a poor Arsenal yellow and blue copy, but will soon be returning to everybody's favourite - the yellow and green stripes made famous by Atkinson's great side in the late Seventies. And about time too.

Merchandising

It's hard to knock Albion's merchandising: it's so low-key and understated, it's hard to see any. Apart from the ubiquitous replica shirts, the club shop is a waste land of missed opportunity and lack of direction. Better that the Man United overkill, I suppose.

Mascot

There is an Albion mascot, called Baggie Bird. Although the fans' usual nickname for the club is The Baggies - derived from the baggy moleskin trousers of the club's traditional iron-working supporters in the 1890s (honest!) - the club's logo of a thrush also gave them the title of The Throstles. (But call them that in a pub in West Brom and you'd better watch out!)

Current player, no question - it's Black Country lad and life-time Albion supporter Lee Hughes, top scorer here for the past four seasons. Before that it was Super Bob Taylor, who returned, Messiah-like, last March, to score the goals which kept us up on the last day of last season. Add to that The Beast, our huge Danish keeper Brian Jensen, and you've pretty much covered the fans' favourites, although wily old veteran Ruel Fox is fast becoming one.

Of blessed memory: The King, or Jeff Astle, once of Frank Skinner's Fantasy Football programme, but better remembered as one of the best goalscorers of the Sixties; winger Willie Johnston; and Tony Brown, the holder of every club record around, who's still to be seen at every game.

To his credit, Curle took it all very well.

Players we hate

When you're doing as well as we are at the moment, there are few club villains around - especially as Gary Megson off-loaded most of the deadwood in the summer. Even the inconsistent Matt Carbon, transfer-listed last week, has his fans. Possibly James Quinn, who has scored more goals for Northern Ireland - one - than he has done League goals for the club in the past two years.

In the past though, there have been so many hate figures - players and managers. Least popular player was probably Stockport reject (and another Northern Ireland international, God help us) Paul Williams. But the hatred felt for him was as nothing compared to that of the man who threw £250,000 away on him, manager Bobby Gould. Albion fans carried a coffin around the streets of Shrewsbury in 1992 in a bid to get him sacked - it worked!

The most hated player from any other side, now that Steve Bull has retired from Wolves, is undoubtedly former Baggie, Paul "Mr Mercenary" Peschisolido, who only last month maintained his incredible scoring record against us with a goal on his loan debut for Sheffield United. The fact that he is also married to the chairman of Birmingham City, Karen Brady, does not add to his popularity round here.

The ground

The Hawthorns was the first football ground to be built in the 20th century, in 1900 - but with recent stand-building, there's nothing whatsoever left of the original. Also, geographically speaking, the highest ground in the entire League, but don't expect hills and dales - this is the centre of the Black Country.

As we write, a new stand is going up, the old Rainbow Stand having been pulled down a month ago. When it's finished, an already attractive and characterful stadium will have a 27,000 capacity, and will be ready for that Premiership place.

The crowd

Strangely enough, pulling down the Rainbow Stand was the best thing that could have happened for the atmosphere at the ground. Sure, it's eerie the way the sound just floats away out of the ground now, but the resulting sardine-like packing in of what are now guaranteed capacity gates into the other three sides means that the match-day atmosphere is electric - for the first time since Ossie Ardiles was manager in the early Nineties.

Local knowledge

Over the years, the immediate vicinity of The Hawthorns has become a pub-free zone, for away supporters at least. Locals make use of the photocard scheme at The Hawthorns Hotel, or the secret "Freemasons' Knock" which gains entry to the famous Woodman pub, abutting the ground, but away fans are not welcome anywhere nearby. However, just a mile towards the town centre, near the M5 junction, is The Vine, peaceful but incredibly popular because of its great value Baltis and other Indian food. Otherwise, it's another mile towards the town centre, or five miles the other way to Birmingham. Catering inside the ground is a disgrace, in terms of cost, choice and quality.

Links

Being situated midway between Birmingham, Walsall and Wolverhampton, West Bromwich has always had some of the best press coverage in the country, and there is no shortage of opinions on the local sides. The Baggies has its own column every Saturday in the pink Sporting Star, but the Sports Argus is nationally famous as well.

There's the Albion fanzine, the Grorty Dick, and the unofficial website (www.boing.com) which, inevitably, is better than the official site (www.wbafc.com), but best of all is Baggies' lensman Dave Hewitt's matchday photos site on www.dspace.dial.pipex.com/town/park/kcd53/dh
fields.bodyText: What makes Albion so special? Traditionally, Albion were always the midlands' top Football Academy. The Villa might win more trophies, the Wolves might have their moments with their trademark long ball approach, but you could rely on the Albion for playing cultured football, scoring goals, and winning the Cup now and then. As a small town club - don't believe this West-Bromwich-is-in-Birmingham nonsense - Albion have always punched above their weight since they were founder members of the Football League, but the last fifteen years have been the worst in the club's long history. In 1979 Albion, with Ron Atkinson in charge, of Cyrille Regis, Laurie Cunningham and Brendan Batson, were the leaders of the "Black Revolution" in English football, and one of the most attractive sides in Europe. By 1986 they were barely the best team in West Bromwich as they sank, a laughing stock, into the Second Division, dropping into the Third Division for the first time five years later. Now we're famous for the highest turnover of managers in the whole League - one a year for the past eleven seasons or so, including a record three last season! But things are changing. The high point Although only one midlands club has won the FA Cup since Albion last won it in 1968 - and that's Coventry City, who don't count - that's more than a lifetime away for many Albion fans. Instead, they recall with pleasure the one real great occasion of the last thirty years - our Second Division play-off victory against Port Vale at Wembley in 1993. (Although most real fans with say that the home leg of the semi-final against Swansea had more passion.) The low point Far too many recently, but the two which struck at the heart of all of us came in the same 1990-91 season. If losing 4-2 at home to Woking in the third round of the FA Cup was not humiliating enough, relegation to the old Third Division for the first time at Twerton Park on the last day of the season really put a cap on it. Had we won that last game, Leicester City would have gone down instead - wonder what's happened to them since? Our last game Stockport did not quite roll over and die the way they were supposed to at The Hawthorns last Saturday. In fact, they should have been three goals ahead by the time Albion scored through Jason Roberts, right on the half-time whistle. Albion controlled the second half without really impressing, but conceded an equaliser - a fabulous shot from Cooper - to lose two valuable points. How much does it matter? Well, none of the top six clubs managed a win either, so in the short term, not a lot. Our next game Next Saturday, Albion travel to St Andrews for one of the biggest games of the season, as they take on Trevor Francis's Birmingham City side, just two weeks before they meet Liverpool in the League Cup Final. Blues have been a problem recently, but they will surely have more on their mind than a west midlands derby, so Albion should buck the trend and come away with at least a point. Sore point For so many years, Birmingham City were the butt of Albion fans' humour. They never won anything (well, there was a League Cup in the Sixties, it's rumoured), they never did anything, and they never beat us. Now they've been taken over by a porn millionaire, things have changed. We haven't beaten them for years, they get to the play-offs every season, and now they've reached the League Cup Final. We can't believe it: it's a distortion of the very bedrock of football in the Midlands, and the sooner it gets back to normal, the better. Especially as we could be meeting them in the play-offs come May. The chairman After years of second-raters in the top job, Albion have struck lucky with Barnsley-based businessman Paul Thompson. Traditionally, Albion directors have been local small (and small minded) businessmen and Thompson, recruited through an advert in The Times and with no local links, was initially distrusted by fans. However, since leaving the club to return in a blaze of glory in December 1999, he has delivered on all of the promises that were continually broken by his predecessors. Not only has he found the money for the manager to build up the best Albion side in fifteen years, he has completed the rebuilding of the ground and purchased the much-needed training ground that the previous regime had been banging on about for over five years. The club now has a professional approach - on and off the pitch - that was never there before, and although, inevitably, there are still a few things we would like to see improve, Albion fans have nothing but praise for the chairman. Local rivals For the first eighty years of the club's existence, at least, the only rivals were Aston Villa - the only other local team capable of winning anything. No other neighbouring clubs can claim to have met one another in three separate FA Cup finals, and the fixture regularly used to attract 60,000-plus gates. But it's difficult to hate a team you never play, and apart from the occasional Cup drubbing, the teams have been in different divisions for years. Now, a whole new hate-culture has developed, centred on our Black Country neighbours, Wolverhampton Wanderers. I suppose it's our own fault. fields.headline: Brown sets budget day
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown has announced the date of what is expected to be the last budget before the general election  Wednesday  7 March.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown has announced the date of what is expected to be the last budget before the general election  Wednesday 7 March.

Mr Brown set the date in a low-key Commons written answer but the Budget itself is expected to produce a plethora of vote-grabbing measures immediately ahead of a spring election.

Although the exact details of any sweetners or tax breaks will remain secret up until the moment Gordon Brown steps up to the dispatch box, many of the broader sweeps of policy were announced in last November's pre-budget report.

Under pressure following the fuel protests of September and an angry pensioners demonstration at the Labour party conference in Brighton, the chancellor pledged to cut fuel duty and give OAPs an inflation-busting increase in pensions.

Since then, Mr Brown has promised "targeted tax breaks" to help families and low-paid workers - but hinted that there will be no across the board cuts in income tax.

A general election is still widely expected to be called for May 3rd, in order for measures in the budget to have time to trickle through to the electorate.

However recent policy initiatives on education  including a keynote speech from prime minister Tony Blair on the future of comprehensive schools this week  have lead to some speculation that a snap election could be called for April.

Recent polls consistently give Labour a 20-point lead over the Tories.

fields.headline: Perry quits Loaded
fields.trailText: 5.15pm: Loaded acting editor John Perry has resigned following Keith Kendrick's appointment as editor, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Former Loaded acting editor John Perry has resigned following the appointment of Keith Kendrick as editor of the lads' mag.

Mr Perry, who stepped up after the departure of Tim Southwell last year, applied for the editor's position and was turned down.

He threatened to resign last month after the appointment of Mr Kendrick was confirmed but was persuaded by IPC bosses to consider staying on.

Mr Perry was understood not to be happy to continue working under Mr Kendrick after being overlooked for the editorship.

It is thought he does not have a job to go to.

Eric Fuller, publishing director of Loaded, Loaded Fashion and Loaded's website uploaded.com, confirmed Mr Perry had resigned following a two-week period of leave.

"John and I worked together on the magazine for some months," Mr Fuller said.

"He was a very serious contender but in the end and with the best will in the world, he wasn't the very best candidate because we offered the job to Keith Kendrick.

"We would have kept him on at Loaded but he has decided to move his career forward."

IPC approached a number of external candidates for the post before appointing Mr Kendrick.

fields.headline: Tories defend C4 privatisation
fields.trailText: The Tories' media spokesman has denied privatisation of Channel 4 would lead to a 'dumbing down' of its programmes, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Tory media spokesman Peter Ainsworth has refuted the charge that privatisation of Channel 4 would lead to an inevitable "dumbing down" of its programmes.

Mr Ainsworth defended the Conservatives' stated intention of privatising the channel, denying that it would lose either the quality of its output or its risk-taking culture.

"Channel 4's brand is the programmes it produces and I see no reason why if it became a private company they would automatically rush to the bottom of the market," he said at a Broadcasting Press Guild lunch today.

Mr Ainsworth added that a Tory government would be prepared to regulate Channel 4 if it was perceived to be going downmarket.

"If they did decide they wanted to compete with Channel 5, we would of course regulate them."

But Mr Ainsworth also said the British broadcasting industry had "too much" regulation.

He said that a Tory government would reverse what he described as Labour's attempt to "harness the arts", and condemned culture secretary Chris Smith's "timid stab" at setting out a framework for regulating the media in the communications white paper.

Mr Ainsworth singled out for particular criticism the government's stance on the BBC's public service remit.

"The biggest failure of the white paper is the failure to address what the BBC is here to do," he said.

"Almost all the rest of the industry defines itself in relation to the BBC. Until we define that all the other questions are subsidiary."

fields.headline: Profile: Richard Douglas
fields.trailText: Richard Douglas, the new NHS finance director, will have to hit the ground running when he takes up his new job in May.
fields.body:
Richard Douglas, the new NHS finance director, will have to hit the ground running when he takes up his new job in May.

NHS finance faces difficult challenges in the coming months, despite ministers' claims that last year's historic £19bn increase over four years had ended the service's money troubles.

Managers are warning that ministers' demands on the service, laid out in last summer's NHS plan, far exceed the funds allocated to deliver them.

Mr Douglas, director of finance at National Savings, also has a tough act to follow. The incumbent NHS chief Colin Reeves, who leaves this week after nearly seven years at the NHS executive, is widely acclaimed to have done a good job in often difficult circumstances.

The NHS is on course to break even this year for the first time in many years. Mr Reeves successfully secured major resources for the NHS in last year's spending review. And the "biggest ever" hospital building programme is now well under way with funding provided through the private finance initiative (PFI).

Mr Douglas will have to try to emulate his predecessor's street credibility in the NHS. Mr Reeves managed to deliver ministers' policies, which are at times unpopular with the service, while retaining the respect of finance managers in trusts and health authorities.

Mr Douglas is an "outsider" - a career civil servant. Mr Reeves was, to NHS finance directors, "one of us". He was the first NHS finance director at the NHS executive to be appointed from within the health service, a fact seen as a major endorsement of the NHS finance function in general.

Nevertheless Mr Douglas's appointment appears to be a popular one among NHS finance professionals. He is no stranger to the health service, having served two stints at the Department of Health.

He was the NHS executive's head of financial planning and monitoring from 1990-92. Then following four years at the National Audit Office, he returned to the executive in 1996 as Mr Reeves' deputy director of finance and performance.

"It is good to see Richard back," said Mark Millar, chairman of the healthcare financial management association. "We know him in the service and he knows the system and the service. We look forward to an early meeting to discuss matters of mutual interest."

Other finance directors dismissed his lack of service credentials as irrelevant. "His appointment will be extremely well received in the finance profession," said Barry Elliott, director of finance at Barts & the London NHS trust.

"He was highly regarded as Colin's deputy, he knows his way around the department and he is comfortable with ministers."

Others say he has both good technical accounting abilities and the subtler skills needed to work with ministers and politicians.

The high profile finance job, which carries a salary of up to £120,000, will also mean periodic grillings from backbench MPs on the often hostile Commons select committees.

But Mr Douglas is already acquainted with such skirmishes. He accompanied Mr Reeves to give evidence to a health select committee investigation into PFI in 1998.

And last year he appeared before the Treasury select committee to give evidence in the committee's review of National Savings.

His key role, during his last period at the executive, in breaking the log jam in PFI - one of Labour's manifesto commitments - is certain to have impressed ministers and officials who are relying on the initiative to deliver the NHS plan's promise of 100 new hospital schemes between 2000 and 2010.

webTitle: Troublesome tasks ahead for NHS finance director

fields.headline: Troublesome tasks ahead for NHS finance director
fields.trailText: Richard Douglas, the new director of finance of the NHS, faces five major challenges when he takes up office in May.
fields.body:
Richard Douglas, the new director of finance of the NHS, will face five major challenges when he takes up office in May.

Financial difficulties
Despite last year's historic £19bn increase in NHS funding over four years, the service is facing huge difficulties in drawing up budgets for the financial year starting in April.

An eleventh hour £140m increase to local service budgets at the beginning of February, which combined with last November's general allocations and will see health authorities receive an average cash increase of 8.91%, has done little to calm the service's rising concerns.

Managers claim ministers have underestimated the real cost of NHS inflation - covering the rising costs of pay, pensions and new drugs and treatments - leaving too little to deliver the raft of targets and priorities included in the NHS plan.

Historic deficits
The service is on course to break even in 2000/01. But this only means it has spent what it was allocated this year and the NHS still carries accumulated deficits of an estimated £700m. Given the financial pressures already identified for next year, solving this historic problem is daunting.

Private finance initiative
The department has already given the green light to 38 major hospital developments, most of which are funded under the private finance initiative. But delivering the NHS plan's promise of 100 new hospital schemes between 2000 and 2010 will remain a tough challenge.

Staffing
The NHS finance function itself faces major change. The NHS is already investigating running core financial services, such as payroll and accounts payable, from as few as 10 shared service centres across the country. This could lead to significant staff reductions. All finance staff will need to develop or enhance skills such as performance management to stay relevant to the NHS.

New structures
Quietly, NHS services are being restructured with the introduction of new primary care trusts (PCTs). These have responsibility for developing GP services, commissioning hospital care and running community health services. Ensuring financial control is maintained in the face of such a major reconfiguration will be crucial, particularly if ministers' ambitions for PCTs to take on the commissioning of social services are to be realised.

Financial difficulties Despite last year's historic £19bn increase in NHS funding over four years, the service is facing huge difficulties in drawing up budgets for the financial year starting in April. An eleventh hour £140m increase to local service budgets at the beginning of February, which combined with last November's general allocations and will see health authorities receive an average cash increase of 8.91%, has done little to calm the service's rising concerns. Managers claim ministers have underestimated the real cost of NHS inflation - covering the rising costs of pay, pensions and new drugs and treatments - leaving too little to deliver the raft of targets and priorities included in the NHS plan. Historic deficits The service is on course to break even in 2000/01. But this only means it has spent what it was allocated this year and the NHS still carries accumulated deficits of an estimated £700m. Given the financial pressures already identified for next year, solving this historic problem is daunting. Private finance initiative The department has already given the green light to 38 major hospital developments, most of which are funded under the private finance initiative. But delivering the NHS plan's promise of 100 new hospital schemes between 2000 and 2010 will remain a tough challenge. Staffing The NHS finance function itself faces major change. The NHS is already investigating running core financial services, such as payroll and accounts payable, from as few as 10 shared service centres across the country. This could lead to significant staff reductions. All finance staff will need to develop or enhance skills such as performance management to stay relevant to the NHS. New structures Quietly, NHS services are being restructured with the introduction of new primary care trusts (PCTs). These have responsibility for developing GP services, commissioning hospital care and running community health services. Ensuring financial control is maintained in the face of such a major reconfiguration will be crucial, particularly if ministers' ambitions for PCTs to take on the commissioning of social services are to be realised.

webTitle: Asian officer in race case to leave Met

fields.headline: Asian officer in race hate mail case to leave Met with £350,000 payout
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: An Asian officer who was falsely accused of sending race hate mail to colleagues because he had been snubbed for promotion is expected to leave the Metropolitan police this month with £350,000 compensation and an apology from the commissioner, Sir John Stevens, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
An Asian officer who was falsely accused of sending race hate mail to colleagues because he had been snubbed for promotion is expected to leave the Metropolitan police this month with £350,000 compensation and an apology from the commissioner, Sir John Stevens, it emerged yesterday.

Under the terms of a draft agreement due to be signed today, Sergeant Gurpal Virdi, 42, will be awarded £200,000 compensation for the loss of his career and injury to his feelings.

Last year an employment tribunal remedy hearing awarded him £150,000 for being discriminated against on grounds of race. This followed a ruling in August that Mr Virdi, who had 16 years of unblemished service, had been wrongly sacked five months earlier by a police disciplinary panel of three senior officers.

They accused him of sending racist hate mail to himself and other black and Asian staff at Ealing and Hanwell police stations, west London, in December 1997 and January 1998.

The settlement, which was agreed in principle yesterday, should draw a line under an episode which has caused rancour at Scotland Yard.

Although senior officers have accepted that the Met's investigation into Mr Virdi was clumsy, many still believe he was the culprit and have urged the force to fight on.

Mr Virdi was arrested in April 1998 for sending hate mail through the internal post at Hanwell police station.

One of the letters read: "Not wanted. Keep the police force white. Leave now or else." It was signed NF.

Scotland Yard's complaints investigation branch believed the letters had been written on Mr Virdi's computer during a night shift when he was on duty. During a raid at his house officers found envelopes identical to the ones used to post the letters.

Mr Virdi consistently denied the charges. He said he was not at the station when the letters were written and claimed he was set up because he challenged white officers who were apathetic about racially motivated crimes. Backed by the commission for racial equality (CRE), he took his case to an employment tribunal.

It concluded last summer that he was treated differently to a white female officer, PC Jackie Bachelor, who was also a suspect in the investigation.

The Met offered Mr Virdi reinstatement in the racial and violent crimes taskforce run by the deputy assistant commissioner John Grieve.

The CRE yesterday revealed the text of an unsigned letter of apology to Mr Virdi which will form part of the settlement. It said: "The Metropolitan police recognises that you, your family and the local Sikh community have suffered substantially by reason of these unfortunate events.

"Mr Virdi has now been fully vindicated. The MPS is considering what implications this case has for the reform of procedures and awaits the outcome of the Metropolitan police authority inquiry into this case."

Mr Virdi said yesterday he had turned down reinstatement because the Met had refused to reinvestigate the case.

"Sir John Stevens gave me his word that something would be done and nothing has been done. He did not honour his word and that is why I am leaving. A lot of taxpayers' money has been wasted and they have lost a good officer."

The CRE chairman, Gurbux Singh, said: "As long as this sort of case exists then there will be a reluctance on the part of minority communities to see the police force as a viable option."

Scotland Yard said it would comment on the settlement when it was signed.

webTitle: Prisons boss gets hate mail after attack on racism

fields.headline: Prisons boss gets hate mail after attack on racism
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: The director general of the prison service, Martin Narey, revealed yesterday that he had become a target of "extremely offensive" hate mail from prison staff after declaring that the service was "institutionally racist".
fields.body:
The director general of the prison service, Martin Narey, revealed yesterday that he had become a target of "extremely offensive" hate mail from prison staff after declaring that the service was "institutionally racist".

Mr Narey said he had passed the unsigned letters, which contained personal threats to him, to the police. The content suggested that they came from people who were either in, or very close to, the prison service. "We will not be perturbed by them," he said. Mr Narey said he had come across "pockets of malicious racism" within jails in England and Wales.

The prisons chief was giving evidence to a special session of the Commons' home affairs committee after his speech last week threatening to quit unless he received the full backing of the service for his attempt to improve prison conditions.

Mr Narey said most prison governors had backed his stand but there was still a minority who had complained that life was being made too hard for them and that the reform programme was too difficult. He also said that while relations with the Prison Officers' Association nationally had improved there were still "pockets of individual local branches who are very resistant to change".

"We have failed to manage the POA as we might and failed to assert management's right to manage," he said.

Mr Narey admitted he had caused unhappiness by insisting that some governors moved from their jobs or even left the service.

"We are beginning to make a breakthrough by getting the right managers in the right place and by getting our best people in the most difficult places, and we are beginning to see change," he told MPs.

He also criticised the Conservatives' pledge to make every prisoner work, saying there were practical difficulties in finding useful employment for inmates. Mr Narey said he could easily find work for inmates such as folding black plastic bags for charities but it did little to give them skills to find jobs on release.

Mr Narey said he had been on the verge of signing a contract with two supermarket chains in north-west England for inmates to process vegetables but had withdrawn when an MP protested it would take jobs away from local people. He said prisons often competed for contracts with Remploy Ltd and he did not want to take work from disabled people.

fields.headline: St Valentine's Day
fields.standfirst: Corking for couples, hell for single folk, St Valentine's Day is on us again. Here's our guide to the best sites to the 24-hour lurve extravaganza, whether you want to blow out or blow chunks.
fields.trailText: 1. Happy Valentine's Day. Are you celebrating with flowers, champagne and a love-in with your special Snugglebum?
fields.body:
1. Happy Valentine's Day. Are you celebrating with flowers, champagne and a love-in with your special Snugglebum?

2. Birds do it, bees do it, even elephants on heat do it. Let's do it. Let's fall in love.

3. It's the most romantic day of the year, a time for declarations of love, beautiful poetry, perhaps even a marriage proposal.

4. Did you get many cards? Tried to send some but can't think what to write? Don't worry - the work's been done for you. Or you could send a classic Hollywood kiss to the object of your heart's desire.

5. Not sure what to spend on that special gift? Our commitment calculator does the sums for you. And why not check how you measure up in the romance stakes?

6. Or are you alone again this year? There could be a reason. Maybe it's not them - it's you. At least there's one place you'll always get a sympathetic hearing

7. If you're not in on the love-in, take comfort. Today is also national impotence day. And even the passionate Italians are not all they're cracked up to be in the romance department.

8. All this hype originates with St Valentine, martyred in Rome on February 14 in the year 269 for refusing to renounce Christianity. Other legends associate the festival with the Roman fertility festival Lupercalia, marked on February 15.

9. In 1929, February 14 saw the most spectacular mob hit in gangland history: the St Valentine's Day Massacre. Seven people were killed in a failed bid by Al Capone to wipe out rival gangster Bugs Moran.

10. If you feel you need to get away from it all, how about an alpine holiday - in the Independent Principality of Saint Valentine. And if all this schmaltz is making you feel nauseous, remember: you are not alone.

fields.headline: Scent of romance
fields.standfirst: China prepares for Valentine's Day
fields.trailText: A special shipment of 200,000 red roses is being flown in from Colombia to help young Shanghainese celebrate Valentine's Day - known as Lovers' Day in Chinese. Unheard of until the late 1990s, the event has caught on in a big way in China's most westernised city.
fields.body:
A special shipment of 200,000 red roses is being flown in from Colombia to help young Shanghainese celebrate Valentine's Day - known as Lovers' Day in Chinese. Unheard of until the late 1990s, the event has caught on in a big way in China's most westernised city.

"Young people are trying to be more romantic in the western way," said Faye Shen, who runs a marriage and dating website. "Flowers are more subtle than sharkfin soup."

February 14 is the latest in a series of foreign and Chinese events celebrated in China, beginning with Christmas, and continuing through with the western and Chinese New Years to last week's Lantern festival.

"It's good for relationships," a woman buying a belt for her boyfriend on the smart Huaihai Road said. "Lovers' Day is getting more popular all the time."

Last night there was a crush around a stall selling imported cards with pictures of hearts and cats, and messages in English.

Ms Shen sees the romantic demands of Valentine's Day as an opportunity to undermine traditional male Chinese chauvinism - also the target of her 51Marry.com website.

"Too many men think that all they have to do is buy their girlfriend a big meal with lots of dumplings," she explained. "The western way of dating is more romantic, with candles, roses and a kiss."

fields.headline: Henry gives a striking French lesson
fields.trailText:
Lyon 0 - 1 Arsenal
Thierry Henry's goal helped lift Arsenal from bottom of the group and back into serious contention for a place in the quarter-finals.
fields.byline: John Brodkin at the Gerland stadium
fields.body:
Writing off Arsenal has always been a dangerous business and it was obvious why last night. In winning here with a goal from Thierry Henry, Arsène Wenger's side rose from the bottom of the group and back into serious contention for a place in the quarter-finals.

This much-needed victory was built on a sixth consecutive clean sheet, which owed much to three fine saves by David Seaman and also to the determination of a revamped backline and the tireless work of Patrick Vieira.

Arsenal were grateful also for two misses by Lyon after Henry had headed in an Ashley Cole cross to leave them with real grounds for optimism ahead of the return with Lyon next Wednesday.

Wenger was without three key defenders, Martin Keown, Silvinho and Igor Stepanovs, because of injury and ineligibility, and moved Gilles Grimandi to centre-back alongside Tony Adams. The obvious fear was that Sonny Anderson and Steve Marlet might prove too quick and agile.

That danger was soon evident when a long pass from the back caught Grimandi hesitating and left Marlet with a shooting chance from the edge of the area. David Seaman, rushing off his line, did well to get a hand to the ball and deflect it for a corner.

The watching Tord Grip must have been impressed with that, and with Lyon starting in neat, lively fashion it seemed Seaman might be in for a busy night. The French side's use of the flanks and the willingness of Anderson and Vikash Dhorasoo to run at opponents were quickly apparent, and it needed a low save by Seaman to deny Marlet again just after the quarter-hour.

But this was not one-way traffic. Arsenal gradually settled, enjoyed plenty of possession and had the pace to worry Lyon's defence on the counter-attack with Henry back in the starting line-up after injury.

Yet it was Henry's strike partner Nwanwko Kanu, making his first start since New Year's Day, who might have given them the lead when he manufactured for himself a clear chance in the 18th minute.

A dazzling run took the Nigerian past several Lyon defenders but, after drawing the goalkeeper Grégory Coupet, he clipped his shot wide of the far post. His kick at an advertising hoarding told of his frustration.

Although Henry drew a low save out of Coupet shortly after, Lyon twice came close to breaking the deadlock before the interval. Seaman made another sharp stop to deny Dhorasoo and saw another shot drift wide.

Yet as Lyon's threat dissipated as half-time approached, Kanu produced another fine touch from which Henry went agonisingly close in the 45th minute. After flicking the ball into the Frenchman's path, Kanu saw Henry's shot flashed inches wide.

Arsenal went close again not long into the second half. Kanu, having one of his most impressive games of a season interrupted by injury and affected by poor form, was again a central figure.

This time he caught out Edmilson, a player once coveted by Wenger, and advanced into the area before having a low shot smothered by Coupet.

Though Lyon continued to play with pace and flashes of skill, Arsenal were defending with increasing confidence, Grimandi and Ashley Cole epitomising determination.

Still, though, they needed Seaman to rescue them when Lyon carved out their first clear chance of the half. Marlet's clever pass released Anderson and the 37-year-old keeper tipped the Brazilian's shot wide.

The value of that save was highlighted when Henry gave Arsenal the lead two minutes later. Cole burst down the left flank, wriggled past Eric Deflandre and produced a perfect cross for Henry to head in from close range.

 Bayern Munich moved three points clear in Group C last night when Giovanni Elber's goal on 79 minutes broke Spartak Moscow's resistence at the Olympic stadium.

Lyon (4-4-2): Coupet; Deflandre, Edmilson, Muller, Brechet; Dhorasoo (Govou, 74min), Violeau (Malbranque, 74), Foe, Laigle (Delmotte, 83); Anderson, Marlet.

Arsenal (4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Grimandi, Adams, Cole; Lauren, Parlour, Vieira, Pires, (Ljungberg, 69); Henry, Kanu (Vivas, 90).

Referee : U Meier (Switzerland).

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Art gallery woos lovers with singles night

fields.headline: Art gallery woos lovers with singles night
fields.trailText: Salsa dancing in the foyer, rose petals showering from the balcony, the sun setting over the canal and hundreds of people with hope in their hearts and love in their diaries: it could only be St Valentine's night in Walsall.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Salsa dancing in the foyer, rose petals showering from the balcony, the sun setting over the canal and hundreds of people with hope in their hearts and love in their diaries: it could only be St Valentine's night in Walsall.

The town's spectacular New Art Gallery is organising its first singles night tonight, intended as a one-off experiment. But so many people have signed up - 220 by last night - that its director, Peter Jenkinson, is considering making it a monthly event.

"Clubs have them, supermarkets have them - why shouldn't we - as a truly romantic venue, with a great throbbing love story at the heart of the collection - have a singles night too? The response has been amazing," he said.

Mr Jenkinson, who is newly single, will be present himself - "purely in a professional capacity".

Tonight's frolics will include readings from passionate love letters sent by the sculptor Jacob Epstein to Kathleen Garman. He was already a famous - though perpetually cash-strapped - sculptor, married, and 20 years older than she.

The gallery's collection includes a bronze portrait bust, which Epstein is said to have started the morning after they first went to bed together.

They met in the 1920s in a Bohemian cafe called the Harlequin in Chelsea, west London, when she was 21.

"He spotted her, came over and said she just had to model for him, but she refused," the curator, Oliver Buckley, said. "They were obviously really struck, however, because they both went back the next night in the hope of meeting again, and that was it."

They eventually married, and Garman's art collection, including dozens of Epsteins, and works by Monet, Renoir and Van Gogh, was left to Walsall on her death. It was kept for decades, mostly in store in the old library, until the award-winning £21m lottery-backed gallery, designed by Caruso St John, opened last year.

The archive that came with the pictures includes boxes of papers which are only now being unpacked and transcribed. There are more than 100 letters from Epstein to Garman, many of them ardent love letters.

One ends, "Be there Saturday Sweetheart." The words were spelled out in blue neon, replicating Epstein's handwriting, in a piece created for the gallery by the contemporary artist Fiona Banner.

It was installed for a time on the roof of a nearby building, causing considerable local puzzlement.

Given the background of the collection, the director has decided not to worry about whether his guests are all bona fide singles. They can choose between looking at the pictures, dancing in the foyer, or having a romantic meal in the rooftop restaurant with its views across the West Midlands. The gallery closes at 10pm, but the bar next door, also owned by the gallery, is open till 2am.

Staff have been devising artistic chat up lines, to be supplied on cribsheets to tongue-tied guests. Samples include, "Do I Turner you on?", and "Hello, you look lonely; would you like me to help you through your Blue Period?"

Mr Jenkinson said: "This proves it beyond any doubt that Walsall is simply the most romantic town in Britain."

"He spotted her, came over and said she just had to model for him, but she refused," the curator, Oliver Buckley, said. "They were obviously really struck, however, because they both went back the next night in the hope of meeting again, and that was it." They eventually married, and Garman's art collection, including dozens of Epsteins, and works by Monet, Renoir and Van Gogh, was left to Walsall on her death. It was kept for decades, mostly in store in the old library, until the award-winning £21m lottery-backed gallery, designed by Caruso St John, opened last year. The archive that came with the pictures includes boxes of papers which are only now being unpacked and transcribed. There are more than 100 letters from Epstein to Garman, many of them ardent love letters. One ends, "Be there Saturday Sweetheart." The words were spelled out in blue neon, replicating Epstein's handwriting, in a piece created for the gallery by the contemporary artist Fiona Banner. It was installed for a time on the roof of a nearby building, causing considerable local puzzlement. Given the background of the collection, the director has decided not to worry about whether his guests are all bona fide singles. They can choose between looking at the pictures, dancing in the foyer, or having a romantic meal in the rooftop restaurant with its views across the West Midlands. The gallery closes at 10pm, but the bar next door, also owned by the gallery, is open till 2am. Staff have been devising artistic chat up lines, to be supplied on cribsheets to tongue-tied guests. Samples include, "Do I Turner you on?", and "Hello, you look lonely; would you like me to help you through your Blue Period?" Mr Jenkinson said: "This proves it beyond any doubt that Walsall is simply the most romantic town in Britain."

fields.headline: EU passes internet copyright law
fields.trailText: The European parliament today endorsed tougher rules granting artists more copyright protection for their works downloaded from the internet.
fields.body:
The European parliament today endorsed tougher rules granting artists more copyright protection for their works downloaded from the internet.

Backers said the new law will spell the end of music-sharing websites like Napster in Europe - just days after a US court ordered the service to put a stop to the free-for-all swapping of copyrighted material.

The new EU rules tighten the definition of "private copy" and ban commercial use of copied material taken from the internet.

They also allow people to copy music - or any other data from the internet - for their own use and to share with friends provided the rightholder gets "fair compensation".

The bill leaves it to national governments to decide how to implement that. Some have already enacted fees on such things as blank CDs to cover payments to artists.

The bill's author, Italian socialist Enrico Bosselli, said the new rules "were a major step forward for rights holders." The days of Napster-like websites enabling free copying of music without paying royalties are over, he said.

Internal market commissioner Frits Bolkestein, speaking for the EU's executive body, praised the parliament for preserving the bill's "delicate balance of interests". It said it should "bring European copyright rules into the digital age... [to] facilitate the development of electronic commerce and so increase the competitiveness of the European economy."

The vote came after a last rush of conflicting appeals from both music stars demanding better protection of their rights to music and lyrics and telecommunications companies, CD makers and consumers groups urging a more liberal approach.

The music industry, including labels such as EMI, Virgin, Warner and Universal, welcomed Wednesday's vote. The association of European telecommunications network operators said it was pleased that calls for copyright fees for streaming - the technique that lets users see video or hear music on the internet without downloading it - were left unheeded.

webTitle: Bush condemns attack as Israeli seals West Bank and Gaza

fields.headline: Bush condemns attack as Israeli seals West Bank and Gaza
fields.standfirst:
Eight Israelis dead after bus plows into crowd

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel has reimposed a total closure on the West Bank and Gaza Strip, barring Palestinians from entering Israel, Egypt or Jordan. The new restrictions follow today's attack by Palestinian militants, the deadliest in nearly four years.
fields.body:
Israel has reimposed a total closure on the West Bank and Gaza Strip, barring Palestinians from entering Israel, Egypt or Jordan. The new restrictions follow today's attack by Palestinian militants, the deadliest in nearly four years.

Eight Israelis were killed when a Palestinian crashed a bus into Israeli soldiers and civilians standing at a bus stop. At least nine more were injured.

US president George Bush condemned the attack and gave his condolences to outgoing Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak in a telephone call. "I strongly condemn the terrible act of violence in the Middle East this morning," he later told reporters, "I'm urging all parties to do their utmost to end the violence."

Bush refused to take sides, saying the United States would "continue to work with all parties to try to restore calm in the region."

The bus driver, a resident of the Gaza Strip, fled in the vehicle and led police on a high-speed chase over a distance of 22 miles. In the end, police opened fire, seriously injuring the driver who crashed the bus into a truck.

In a call to Israel radio, a man claimed responsibility on behalf of the Islamic militant group Hamas, which has carried out similar attacks in the past. However, relatives of the driver said he had no ties to Hamas.

Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat said the attack came in response to "Israel's military escalation which has a direct effect on the feelings of all the Palestinian people".

Outgoing prime minister Ehud Barak, called the attack an "abominable crime" and said he would bring the perpetrators to justice.

Meeting with US secretary of state Colin Powell, Israeli envoys said it was within Arafat's power to halt the violence. Dore Gold, a former Israeli ambassador to the United Nations, said recent attacks on Israelis originated with the military arm of Fatah, the main body in the Palestine Liberation Organization, and with Arafat's elite bodyguards.

"These are not spontaneous acts of violence," he said after the half-hour meeting he, former Israeli foreign and defence minister Moshe Arens and former ambassador Zalman Shoval held with Powell.

Warning Israel would retaliate, Shoval said: "The Israeli government has a duty and right to protect itself against terrorism."

The hit-and-run attack occurred at about 7.50am (05.50am GMT) at a crowded bus stop in the small town of Azur, south of Tel Aviv.

"The bus was moving slowly and suddenly it speeded up and drove into the soldiers," said Ayelet Cohen-Natan, a bystander. "One of them was thrown up into a tree and fell to the ground ... I saw dead people with arms, legs and heads cut open. It was terrible."

Several bodies covered by blankets and marked by numbers lay by the roadside, as paramedics led away dazed survivors, including two young women soldiers in olive uniforms. Shoes, jackets, backpacks and other personal belongings were strewn across the sidewalk. Many of the casualties were soldiers.

Bodies were later wrapped into black plastic bags and carried away on stretchers.

White-gloved volunteers from an ultra-Orthodox Jewish burial searched the site, gathering body parts into plastic bags. Under Jewish law, every effort has to be made to collect even the smallest body parts for a proper Jewish burial.

The attack was the deadliest since July 1997, when 16 Israeli shoppers and two Palestinian assailants were killed by a suicide bombing in Jerusalem's Mahane Yehuda market.

fields.headline: Spliff decision
fields.standfirst: Just before her son's 16th birthday,  Isabel Loxley discovered that he was smoking cannabis. She confiscated his supply. But what to do next, as a liberal parent - ground him, or just hand the joints back?
fields.trailText: Just before her son's 16th birthday, Isabel Loxley discovered that he was smoking cannabis. She confiscated his supply. But what to do next, as a liberal parent - ground him, or just hand the joints back?
fields.body:
It was his ghostly pallor and refusal to eat supper that gave him away. Adam thought he was sick and suggested he lie down while the others ate. Later, after clearing up, Adam went up to his room - two flights, to the top of the house - to see if he was OK. Forgetting to knock, Adam opened the door to find Joe on his bed, joint alight.

A few days short of his 16th birthday, we were having to deal with our son's cannabis use. It came as a surprise, despite the fact that we know the statistics on teenagers and drugs. There had been no telltale signs: no mood swings, no secretive behaviour, no cash shortages, no enlarged pupils - not even a whiff of smoke. Of course, we had talked about our attitude towards drugs and how we might deal with the issue when it arose. We just hadn't expected it to arise yet. A few weeks earlier, I had confidently, smugly told a colleague that my son was sailing through a trouble-free adolescence.

Of course, we were not alone. Surveys in the 1990s showed that between a quarter and a third of 14- and 15-year-olds had tried drugs; and the number rose steeply after 16. Jack Straw's teenage son was caught offering it for sale. When Ann Widdecombe proposed a crackdown on users, seven shadow cabinet members said they had tried it. Last week, the government announced that police cautions for possession would no longer be part of a criminal record - a sign of changing attitudes to cannabis use.

Adam called me as I was driving home. "There's something you should know," he announced - words guaranteed to sink the heart at the end of a long day at work. Briefly, he told me what had happened. "I've had a mellow chat to him already," Adam joked, making me giggle down the mobile, "but I said we'd talk to him properly together when you get home." We agreed to discuss it alone first to establish a united front.

I had half an hour in the car to work out my response. Adam and I had both smoked dope in the past, and had tried different drugs. But it was mostly in pre-parenthood days. Since that cloak of responsibility had settled on us, we had shared a joint at a party on less than a handful of occasions. We support decriminalisation of cannabis, and we both believe it is less harmful than tobacco or alcohol. We know that almost every teenager will try it, and we don't buy the argument that it leads inevitably to harder, more dangerous drugs.

But this was our son, our baby. Surely that was different? Whenever I had ventured a liberal line on teenagers and dope with family or friends, I had been warned that I would feel a lot less liberal when it came to my own children. In that half-hour in the car, I first waited for an instinctive gut reaction to the news. When none came, I tried out various responses on myself. It felt like testing for pain, prodding and poking at myself, waiting for a sharp jolt that I could label.

Was I shocked? Not really. I knew too much about the prevalence of cannabis smoking among teenagers. Was I angry? Not really. I remembered too much of my own teenage years for that. Alarmed? Sad? Trust betrayed? Not really. Curiously, I felt almost nothing.

When I arrived home, I found Joe lying on the sofa, looking sheepish, with anxious eyes that betrayed his expectation of trouble. Adam was in the kitchen, sitting at the table with five - five! - joints in front of him. On being caught with a lit joint and an open bedroom window, Joe had quickly confessed: he had been smoking for about four months; he bought dope from a friend's older brother; he never smoked anywhere near school. The five spliffs were inside a cassette case lying on a chair next to his bed. Adam spotted them straight away and had brought the evidence to show me.

We looked at the joints, then looked at each other. "He rolls quite a good joint for a 15-year-old," said Adam wryly. "What are we going to say?" Within minutes, we established common ground. Neither of us thought this was a heinous crime, yet we didn't feel that we could give Joe our blessing. As Adam split open one of the joints to see how much dope was inside, I felt - at last - a proper parental response. It was, of course, mostly tobacco - the substance to which Joe had been consistently opposed throughout his adolescence, and one which I felt was far more dangerous and addictive than cannabis. We agreed a number of points to put to Joe, and called him in.

It's a strange thing, being a parent. You remember your own teenage years all too clearly - the injustices, the humiliations, the rows, the bollockings, the slammed doors, the fury - and yet, inevitably, you find yourself 25 years down the line adopting the role of prosecutor, judge, executioner. You ask the same questions - "What time will you be home? Where are you going? Who with?" - that your parents asked you. And you hear your own teenage voice reply - "Don't know. Why do you need to know? Leave me alone." As Joe came in the room, my mind went straight back to similar painful sessions with my own parents, when the last thing you want to do is "talk it through", but you know that is the minimum price you must pay for your transgression.

So the three of us sat round the spliffs and talked it through. Actually, Adam and I did most of the talking. First, it's illegal, we said. You may not agree with that, and we may not either, but that's a fact: if you get caught, you'll be in trouble with the law. Second, if you smoke at school, or have it with you, and get caught, you will be expelled. Third, if you are buying dope from someone, sooner or later that person will offer you something different to try - and that's the point where we might be less tolerant. Fourth, you are more likely to come to harm from the tobacco in the joints than from the dope. Fifth, it's expensive and you have to decide what you want to spend your money on. Sixth, if you ever offer it to your little sister, we will break your legs. And so on.

Joe said little, apart from telling us that "everybody" at his leafy-suburb school smoked dope. Really everybody? He qualified the figure to 90% of his friends and contemporaries.

After 20 minutes of trying to ram home the dangers of harder drugs and tobacco, we asked Joe to go away and think long and hard about what we had said. We stared at each other, and at the spliffs on the table. Had we handled it right? Impossible to say.

After about three minutes, the door opened and Joe's face poked round. "Are you going to give me my dope back?" he asked, tilting his head at the joints. We handed them over.

Did we do the right thing? What is "the right thing", anyway? It's hard to navigate your way through parenthood, to know how much space to give; how protective or how tough to be. For something that so many people do, and so many have done down the years, parenthood has no definitive rules. The compass-points that guided my parents' generation are not necessarily relevant today, but neither does the experience of one's peer group always accurately reflect one's own rational views on a particular issue. So we muddle through, try not to be hypocritical, and hope for the best.

Two weeks after our discovery, Joe doesn't seem any different from the loving, happy, intelligent, well-balanced teenager he was before. That said, when he burst through the door at the weekend, enveloped me then Adam in giant bear hugs, ate two bananas in quick succession, and launched into a long and rambling account of his plans to travel the world in a camper van, Adam caught my eye behind Joe's back.

"He's stoned," he mouthed.

fields.headline: Bygone budgets: March 2000
fields.standfirst:
Chancellor: Gordon Brown
Government: Labour
fields.trailText: Under pressure to meet Tony Blair's rattled promise to Sir David Frost on his Sunday morning TV show that the UK would match European average spending on health care within five years, the chancellor rained resources down on the delighted new health secretary Alan Milburn.
fields.body:
Under pressure to meet Tony Blair's rattled promise to Sir David Frost on his Sunday morning TV show that the UK would match European average spending on health care within five years, the chancellor rained resources down on the delighted new health secretary Alan Milburn.

In one of the shortest budget addresses of recent time (51minutes), and certainly the quickest words-per-minute delivery of all time, the iron chancellor managed nine references to his beloved "prudence" and only a couple to the spectre of "Tory boom and bust"  perhaps a realisation that Mr Brown's fourth budget could no longer blame all ills on the previous administration.

With a bulging warchest from the sale of mobile phone bandwave licences, the chancellor doled out the biggest increase in NHS spending in its 52-year history: £2bn immediately and a 35% real increase in funds by 2004.

Part of this would pay for a huge recruitment drive aimed at bringing in 10,000 extra nurses.

There was also £1bn for education, enabling education secretary David Blunkett to offer secondary school heads a one-off pyment of £50,000 and primary schools £9,000, and £4bn for transport.

Mr Brown also cut the basic rate of income tax by a penny and offered a range of tax incentives to hi-tech internet companies.

The budget was seen as the bursting of the public spending dam after two years of sticking to Tory spending plans by those on the left, but slammed by Conservative leader William Hague as "a panic  chucking money at the Labour heartlands." Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy also accused the chancellor of bribing voters so that Labour could win the next election.

However, it was more for what the budget did not do that it may be remember by history, as Labour's decision to maintain the fuel tax escalator and give pensioners a 75p a week increase in pensions came back to haunt them in the autumn.

Income tax
The chancellor made good his promise of the year before to cut the basic rate of income tax from 23p in the pound to 22p. The threshold at which the 40% tax rate starts remained the same at £28,400. Mortgage tax relief was abolished as was the married couple's allowance, making the average couple £3 a week worse off.

Duty
Smokers were hit with another whopping rise in the cost of packet of fags  up by 25p despite the booming trade in bootleg cigarettes from the continent. Beer went up by a penny a pint and wine 4p a bottle. Spirit prices were unchanged.

Entrepreneurs
In a bid to make the UK the e-commerce capital of Europe, the chancellor introduced a raft of measures to help the one million small British companies he wanted to see go online. They included a pledge for any small firm buying computers or investing in e-commerce over the next three years to be able to write off the whole cost against tax.

VAT
Mr Brown was thanked by a phalanx of Blair's babes on behalf of half the population when he announced that VAT on sanitary products would be cut from 17.5% to 5%.

With a bulging warchest from the sale of mobile phone bandwave licences, the chancellor doled out the biggest increase in NHS spending in its 52-year history: £2bn immediately and a 35% real increase in funds by 2004. Part of this would pay for a huge recruitment drive aimed at bringing in 10,000 extra nurses. There was also £1bn for education, enabling education secretary David Blunkett to offer secondary school heads a one-off pyment of £50,000 and primary schools £9,000, and £4bn for transport. Mr Brown also cut the basic rate of income tax by a penny and offered a range of tax incentives to hi-tech internet companies. The budget was seen as the bursting of the public spending dam after two years of sticking to Tory spending plans by those on the left, but slammed by Conservative leader William Hague as "a panic  chucking money at the Labour heartlands." Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy also accused the chancellor of bribing voters so that Labour could win the next election. However, it was more for what the budget did not do that it may be remember by history, as Labour's decision to maintain the fuel tax escalator and give pensioners a 75p a week increase in pensions came back to haunt them in the autumn. Income tax The chancellor made good his promise of the year before to cut the basic rate of income tax from 23p in the pound to 22p. The threshold at which the 40% tax rate starts remained the same at £28,400. Mortgage tax relief was abolished as was the married couple's allowance, making the average couple £3 a week worse off. Duty Smokers were hit with another whopping rise in the cost of packet of fags  up by 25p despite the booming trade in bootleg cigarettes from the continent. Beer went up by a penny a pint and wine 4p a bottle. Spirit prices were unchanged. Entrepreneurs In a bid to make the UK the e-commerce capital of Europe, the chancellor introduced a raft of measures to help the one million small British companies he wanted to see go online. They included a pledge for any small firm buying computers or investing in e-commerce over the next three years to be able to write off the whole cost against tax. VAT Mr Brown was thanked by a phalanx of Blair's babes on behalf of half the population when he announced that VAT on sanitary products would be cut from 17.5% to 5%.

webTitle: How much can you pay for...a love seat

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: a love seat
fields.trailText: a love seat
fields.body:
The "Inside Outside" ), at £3,200, is a park bench that is neither common nor garden. It has been upholstered with infinite TLC in 80-year-old vintage ribbon fashioned from blue and white satin and velvet. Annabel Rouleaux, founder of Chelsea's VV Rouleaux shop, scours antique markets the world over in her quest for the perfect ribbon - and her years of expertise don't come cheap. A larger option, the "Stork Bench", so named for the wrought-iron storks standing on either side, currently costs £3,609, but that figure could rise by up to a grand when the lucky buyer chooses their own ribbon fabric from Rouleaux's archives. At least you're getting a one-off original bespoke piece of kit for your money. Just don't leave it out in the rain.
From Annabel Rouleaux, 32 Old Burlington St, London W1, 020-7434 3899.

fields.headline: Bristol rejects council tax rise
fields.trailText: Residents in one of Britain's biggest cities have voted against a council tax increase to help pay for additional services. Simon Parker reports
fields.body:
Residents in one of Britain's biggest cities have voted against a council tax increase to help pay for additional services.

The budget referendum, held by Labour-controlled Bristol city council, offered voters four choices - to increase council tax by 2%, 4%, 6% or to freeze it at current levels.

The poll, which cost £120,000, is the first time the voters of a major English city have been asked to make a direct decision on local taxation levels.

More than half the city's residents called for a freeze, which the council has warned will lead to spending cuts of £4.5m, mainly in education.

Less than 20% of the 115,706 voters agreed with the 6% increase, which would have resulted in £2.2m extra spending on schools.

The final decision will be subject to council debate and a vote, but Labour councillors said they intend to follow their residents' wishes.

If they do, band D council tax will remain at £931.53, a figure that has already been frozen for the last two years.

The referendum follows on from a pioneering poll held in Milton Keynes two years ago in which voters supported an increase of nearly 10%. Nearly a quarter of the voters supported an increase of 15%.

Today's results also coincide with the closing date for a council tax referendum in the London borough of Croydon, where residents have been asked to choose a rise of between 2%, 3.5% or 5%.

The Bristol results, which were counted by the Electoral Reform Society in London, were to have been announced at a press conference tomorrow, but leaks to the media forced the council to reveal the figures in advance.

fields.headline: Walking on water
fields.trailText: Outside, London's Tottenham Court Road had ground to a halt. Those who had failed to secure tickets for U2's most intimate show in over a decade were offering £800 for a pair of tickets distributed free to hardcore fans and competition winners. By the close, £800 seemed almost worth it. U2 were simply magnificent.
fields.body:
Outside, London's Tottenham Court Road had ground to a halt. Those who had failed to secure tickets for U2's most intimate show in over a decade were offering £800 for a pair of tickets distributed free to hardcore fans and competition winners. By the close, £800 seemed almost worth it. U2 were simply magnificent.

Madonna tried much the same tack with her show at Brixton Academy and she got away with half an hour of waffle, merely because her audience were delighted to be there.

U2 eschewed irony and cleverness. Ever aware of a chance to grandstand, they showcased their superlative new album All That You Can't Leave Behind. Stuck In A Moment You Can't Get Out Of epitomised all that remains right about them: a beautiful song and a languid, elegiac singalong. By contrast, Beautiful Day was an upbeat shoutalong - even John Hurt at the front of the circle clapped along - and the rumbling New York, all heroic backlighting, was evidence that they can stimulate mind as well as body.

Some of the hits were there too: the opening Until The End Of The World, a swashbuckling Mysterious Ways and even 11 O'Clock Tick Tock and I Will Follow, songs older than many of the fans in the audience.

Bono, part Elvis Presley, part Joe Strummer, part Dublin urchin, still has charisma. He is over-familiar by default, but close-up, when he steps into the crowd, giving all appearances of walking on water, he is mesmerising, interspersing snatches of the Pogues' A Rainy Night In Soho, Craig David's Walking Away, the Monkees' Stepping Stone and a hairs-on-the-back-of-the-neck a cappella Unchained Melody. When he is sincere, there are none better.

Behind him, guitarist The Edge resembled the Village People's construction worker and sang high on Beautiful Day. Bassist Adam Clayton seemed faintly amused and Larry Mullen hit his drum kit, the largest since Keith Moon's, as if possessed.

U2 have been parodied, sneered at, mocked and misunderstood. However, when they are on this form, they are unstoppable. As good as they ought to have been.
