webTitle: New father  Mike Torrance on a life of worry

fields.headline: Holding the baby
fields.standfirst: New father  Mike Torrance finds himself condemned to a life of worry - as well as joy, exhaustion and wonder
fields.trailText: New father Mike Torrance finds himself condemned to a life of worry - as well as joy, exhaustion and wonder
fields.body:
Maybe because I've seen too many movies, or maybe because I'm the sort of person who starts worrying about where I'm going to park before I even start the car, the bit of childbirth I'd always dreaded most was the journey to the hospital: contractions coming thick and fast, and a long walk from a distant parking space juggling suitcase, birthing ball and screaming wife. As it was, the baby was two weeks late, and we duly made an appointment for Jennifer to be induced. Leaving home at 7am sharp with our bags, and not a contraction in sight, it felt more like we were going on holiday - an impression reinforced when our 7.30 appointment turned into a four-hour wait.

After weeks of antenatal classes, learning breathing exercises and probing acupressure points, I soon learned the husband's most crucial role in childbirth: tracking down midwives. None was around to monitor Jennifer after she eventually received her dose of Prostin to bring on labour. By the time we got someone to examine her more than six hours later, she was 5cm dilated and the baby was within two hours of arrival. Then came the other vital part of the husband's role: carrying all those bags (though thankfully not the birthing ball, left in the car boot) up and down the corridor as we searched for a vacant room in the delivery suite.

Of course, those acupressure points and breathing exercises came in useful too. When Jennifer finally got hooked up to the gas and air, she liked it so much that she only wanted to breathe in, and I had to keep yelling "Out! Out!" like a deranged shop steward.

I was immeasurably helped in all this - and more importantly, so was Jennifer - by the presence of her sister. If there is one piece of advice I will be boring prospective fathers with till my dying day, it is this: if you know anyone who is half-decent at massage and does not respond to stressful situations by talking too much, take them along with you. It meant one of us could help Jennifer through her contractions while the other went off on the inevitable midwife hunt. After the event, it also means there is someone else to help you piece together what happened. Jennifer - too wrapped up in pushing - was thankfully unaware of the last-minute panics. With the baby's cord around his neck, and his heart rate plummeting with every contraction, the midwife sent for a doctor with a view to using forceps. But luckily the built-in NHS delay paid off: the baby arrived before the doctor did.

I watched the whole thing from my vantage point by Jennifer's head. This was the optimum position for me: at one remove from the blood and guts, I was perfectly placed to keep chanting my "In . . . Out . . ." mantra into Jennifer's ear (as much for my benefit as for hers, I suspect) and, more surprisingly, to be snogged by her between contractions. Our National Childbirth Trust teacher had warned us husbands about the point in labour when our wives would reject us and abuse us horribly. But Jennifer, as it happened, was completely loved up on Entonox (gas and air); she said later that the whole thing reminded her of a rave, the baby's amplified heart on the monitor supplying an erratic techno beat.

At the time, it all seemed strangely matter of fact: here is his head; there goes his heart rate; is that the resuscitation unit they are wheeling out because it is on the blink? But at 5am the next day I woke up in a cold sweat as everything I had blithely sailed through over the last 12 hours hit me all at once. The baby could have died. Jennifer had a second-degree tear, the very idea of which made me want to cross my legs. Our building had been burgled while I was at the hospital - what if it had been our flat? Had anyone called the police? Oh my God, oh my God, oh my God. I think this is when I realised that I had become a parent, and was condemned to a life of perpetual worry.

In the ensuing week, thankfully, other things besides worry have jostled for prominence in my mind. Joy. A redoubled love for Jennifer, combined with a new sense of awe at her. Exhaustion, as much from the stream of visitors as from sleep deprivation. And wonder, at this little thing in my arms: his head, so heavy it feels like it could drop off in my hand; the ferocity of his appetite for milk (are we all born addicts?); the sensual charge of holding this hot little bundle. Watching his face as new expressions flit across from moment to moment, I wonder if I'll ever get tired of looking at him.

 This is the first of a monthly column on becoming a parent, to be written alternately by Mike Torrance and his wife, Jennifer. All names have been changed.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The question: The Italian supreme court has ruled that a wife's failure to clean her home gives her husband grounds for divorce. Is it right?
fields.trailText: The question: The Italian supreme court has ruled that a wife's failure to clean her home gives her husband grounds for divorce. Is it right?
fields.body:
Jack O'Sullivan Spokesman for Fathers Direct

I've always ended up with messy women - the sort that never put my razor back after using it and leave the bedroom looking like a bombsite. There is some messiness I can't bear. I once went out with someone whose bed was surrounded by half a dozen ashtrays full of fag ends. I left because I'm asthmatic and she would have killed me eventually. But I usually find messy women more creative, interesting and red-blooded. I would not know how to relax with an obsessive who spent her time Mr Muscling everything. I would rather put the Marigolds on myself than live with a skivvy.
Verdict: No

Kay Chapman Spokeswoman for Wages for Housework Campaign

After 50 years - a lifetime - of raising four children and looking after her husband with no pay and probably no thanks, no wonder this woman, like millions of other female pensioners, was fed up and exhausted. She is entitled to the family home, maintenance and payment for her housework. Women on every continent are joining the second global women's strike on March 8 to protest against no pay, low pay and overwork, and to demand wages for all caring work - with back pay. These judges should be sacked and sentenced to 50 years' unwaged housework!
Verdict: No

Trish Heywood President of the Mothers' Union

I think this court ruling is absolutely outrageous. The couple in question have obviously not been communicating for some time and that is one of the reasons why the situation has reached this stage. Any relationship is about communicating, and give and take. I feel that the woman has had a terrible deal out of all this. Obviously, the way the housework is divided up by a couple depends on whether the woman has a job outside the home or not, but ultimately there are more important things in life than keeping your house clean.
Verdict: No

Alison Hayes Partner at the Mishcon de Reya firm of solicitors

A failure to be proficient at housework could be one of the allegations a husband may make, but it would be highly unusual to obtain a divorce on that basis. A ruling in the House of Lords last October said that the courts ought to apply equality between the spouses in making the financial award in a divorce. Solicitors are concerned that divorce courts are going to see a lot more conduct arguments, where a spouse is put down in order to up the other spouse's award. But who says that women should be the ones to do the housework anyway?
Verdict: No

Mary-Ann Stephenson Director of the Fawcett Society

In most modern relationships the man and the woman think housework and childcare should be shared responsibilities. In accepting failure to do the housework as grounds for divorce, this ruling is basically saying that it is a woman's job. Housework has to be done, but it needs to be negotiated between the partners. Even when a woman works full time, the reality is that she does more of the housework. What we need is not a court ruling like this, but a debate that changes the culture and says that housework should be shared realistically.
Verdict: No

Judith Ivers Proprietor of Simply Domestics

It is nonsense that cleaning is women's work. We have a lot of male cleaners on our books and they love their work. Housework takes time, and neither men nor women have that sort of time these days, so they use agencies like ours. A lot of people are better off financially if they spend more time working and pay a cleaner to keep their house looking good. Coming home to a nice clean house after a day at the office is much less stressful than coming home to a dirty place. I think my new company motto is going to be: "Save your marriage, get a cleaner."
Verdict: No

fields.headline: Adventure in logo land
fields.standfirst: Who needs a 'baby bond' with tiny designer must-haves to buy, says Joanna Briscoe
fields.trailText: Who needs a 'baby bond' with tiny designer must-haves to buy, says Joanna Briscoe
fields.body:
My heart resides in Baby Gap. I would never have thought myself capable of writing such a sentence. While pregnant, I was sent, whingeing, to John Lewis, to buy newborn-style essentials. I had to run out of the shop. The lighting, the squalling babies, the strange-looking breast pumps and disturbing ointments made me feel as though I had been herded into a dairy farm. Now, I virtually own the place. I am au fait with the latest buggy models from Maclaren; I hustle passing novices towards the Techno. I buy catering-sized tubs of Sudocrem. I swagger among the safety equipment in a fever of licensed materialism. To add to the fun, within tripping distance, there are several branches of Gap.

Thus my eyes alighted on Tony Blair's second-term manifesto plan for a £1,000 "baby bond" for every newborn in the land. They then widened with avarice. Forget nappies, baby rice, university. Why, with a grand, we could have ribbed summer Babygros in four colours, a wardrobe of fleeces, soft little body warmers, reversible gilets, socks in every colour and the entire sale rail. Then I read the small print: baby bonds are designed to encourage poorer families to save, investing for a child's future with government top-ups. Save? The hell with that.

The orgy of materialism that parenthood inspires has taken me aback. After all, birth engenders the most primitive of emotions - raw, terrifying and ecstatic. And yet a certain spiritual baseness has entered the proceedings. "Quick! Let's buy all his summer stuff from Gap before we read No Logo," said my partner the other day. Indeed, I had already formulated a similar guilty timetable for kitting out our infant.

While my own wardrobe dives steadily downhill, my energies are breathlessly focused on the primary-coloured microcosm our baby inhabits. I cannot do the nursery run without popping into that inevitable high-street chain en route. The Tintin shop diverts me further. Yet I didn't used to be materialistic. This addiction was fostered in me by others and I blame them. His grandmother in Oxford, our chief pusher, goes to the US and returns laden with such colours and such inventive uses of the basic fleece that we become quite frenzied. When she produced his blue Techno with fluorescent strips, a love affair with a buggy was born.

In the first months of parenthood, we received such an unexpected and overwhelming barrage of presents that we became spoilt. On mornings when no parcel arrived in the post, we felt genuinely cross, by then half-expecting the thrillingly recognisable bulk of another Baby Gap gift box. After all, there is a predictable middle-class uniform for babies, and we swiftly tuned into it. When would we receive a knitted strawberry hat? Which godmother would provide his indigo denim carpenter's dungarees? Was a stripy lamb's wool jersey too much to demand, for God's sake?

Emerging from the postpartum period, I needed further hits. However, as current figures show, London nursery fees average £7,000 per year, so my cupidity is more mental rumination than reality.

One is slotted more firmly than ever into a particular socioeconomic group, every sartorial nuance a living cliche. Yes, this new-found materialism is a precise art. It lies somewhere between a Bill Amberg sling and best-for-baby; between miniature cashmere and little bow ties with waistcoats. It means the best of Hennes and the cheapest of Boden.

Subliminal advertising meets genuine need and gets muddled somewhere along the way. There is something delicious and covetable about Pampers baby wipes in their pleasant green packaging. The lighting, the squalling babies, the strange-looking breast pumps and disturbing ointments made me feel as though I had been herded into a dairy farm. Now, I virtually own the place. I am au fait with the latest buggy models from Maclaren; I hustle passing novices towards the Techno. I buy catering-sized tubs of Sudocrem. I swagger among the safety equipment in a fever of licensed materialism. To add to the fun, within tripping distance, there are several branches of Gap. Thus my eyes alighted on Tony Blair's second-term manifesto plan for a £1,000 "baby bond" for every newborn in the land. They then widened with avarice. Forget nappies, baby rice, university. fields.headline: Spliff decision
fields.standfirst: Just before her son's 16th birthday,  Isabel Loxley discovered that he was smoking cannabis. She confiscated his supply. But what to do next, as a liberal parent - ground him, or just hand the joints back?
fields.trailText: Just before her son's 16th birthday, Isabel Loxley discovered that he was smoking cannabis. She confiscated his supply. But what to do next, as a liberal parent - ground him, or just hand the joints back?
fields.body:
It was his ghostly pallor and refusal to eat supper that gave him away. Adam thought he was sick and suggested he lie down while the others ate. Later, after clearing up, Adam went up to his room - two flights, to the top of the house - to see if he was OK. Forgetting to knock, Adam opened the door to find Joe on his bed, joint alight.

A few days short of his 16th birthday, we were having to deal with our son's cannabis use. It came as a surprise, despite the fact that we know the statistics on teenagers and drugs. There had been no telltale signs: no mood swings, no secretive behaviour, no cash shortages, no enlarged pupils - not even a whiff of smoke. Of course, we had talked about our attitude towards drugs and how we might deal with the issue when it arose. We just hadn't expected it to arise yet. A few weeks earlier, I had confidently, smugly told a colleague that my son was sailing through a trouble-free adolescence.

Of course, we were not alone. Surveys in the 1990s showed that between a quarter and a third of 14- and 15-year-olds had tried drugs; and the number rose steeply after 16. Jack Straw's teenage son was caught offering it for sale. When Ann Widdecombe proposed a crackdown on users, seven shadow cabinet members said they had tried it. Last week, the government announced that police cautions for possession would no longer be part of a criminal record - a sign of changing attitudes to cannabis use.

Adam called me as I was driving home. "There's something you should know," he announced - words guaranteed to sink the heart at the end of a long day at work. Briefly, he told me what had happened. "I've had a mellow chat to him already," Adam joked, making me giggle down the mobile, "but I said we'd talk to him properly together when you get home." We agreed to discuss it alone first to establish a united front.

I had half an hour in the car to work out my response. Adam and I had both smoked dope in the past, and had tried different drugs. But it was mostly in pre-parenthood days. Since that cloak of responsibility had settled on us, we had shared a joint at a party on less than a handful of occasions. We support decriminalisation of cannabis, and we both believe it is less harmful than tobacco or alcohol. We know that almost every teenager will try it, and we don't buy the argument that it leads inevitably to harder, more dangerous drugs.

But this was our son, our baby. Surely that was different? Whenever I had ventured a liberal line on teenagers and dope with family or friends, I had been warned that I would feel a lot less liberal when it came to my own children. In that half-hour in the car, I first waited for an instinctive gut reaction to the news. When none came, I tried out various responses on myself. It felt like testing for pain, prodding and poking at myself, waiting for a sharp jolt that I could label.

Was I shocked? Not really. I knew too much about the prevalence of cannabis smoking among teenagers. Was I angry? Not really. I remembered too much of my own teenage years for that. Alarmed? Sad? Trust betrayed? Not really. Curiously, I felt almost nothing.

When I arrived home, I found Joe lying on the sofa, looking sheepish, with anxious eyes that betrayed his expectation of trouble. Adam was in the kitchen, sitting at the table with five - five! - joints in front of him. On being caught with a lit joint and an open bedroom window, Joe had quickly confessed: he had been smoking for about four months; he bought dope from a friend's older brother; he never smoked anywhere near school. The five spliffs were inside a cassette case lying on a chair next to his bed. Adam spotted them straight away and had brought the evidence to show me.

We looked at the joints, then looked at each other. "He rolls quite a good joint for a 15-year-old," said Adam wryly. "What are we going to say?" Within minutes, we established common ground. Neither of us thought this was a heinous crime, yet we didn't feel that we could give Joe our blessing. As Adam split open one of the joints to see how much dope was inside, I felt - at last - a proper parental response. It was, of course, mostly tobacco - the substance to which Joe had been consistently opposed throughout his adolescence, and one which I felt was far more dangerous and addictive than cannabis. We agreed a number of points to put to Joe, and called him in.

It's a strange thing, being a parent. You remember your own teenage years all too clearly - the injustices, the humiliations, the rows, the bollockings, the slammed doors, the fury - and yet, inevitably, you find yourself 25 years down the line adopting the role of prosecutor, judge, executioner. You ask the same questions - "What time will you be home? Where are you going? Who with?" - that your parents asked you. And you hear your own teenage voice reply - "Don't know. Why do you need to know? Leave me alone." As Joe came in the room, my mind went straight back to similar painful sessions with my own parents, when the last thing you want to do is "talk it through", but you know that is the minimum price you must pay for your transgression.

So the three of us sat round the spliffs and talked it through. Actually, Adam and I did most of the talking. First, it's illegal, we said. You may not agree with that, and we may not either, but that's a fact: if you get caught, you'll be in trouble with the law. Second, if you smoke at school, or have it with you, and get caught, you will be expelled. Third, if you are buying dope from someone, sooner or later that person will offer you something different to try - and that's the point where we might be less tolerant. Fourth, you are more likely to come to harm from the tobacco in the joints than from the dope. Fifth, it's expensive and you have to decide what you want to spend your money on. Sixth, if you ever offer it to your little sister, we will break your legs. And so on.

Joe said little, apart from telling us that "everybody" at his leafy-suburb school smoked dope. Really everybody? He qualified the figure to 90% of his friends and contemporaries.

After 20 minutes of trying to ram home the dangers of harder drugs and tobacco, we asked Joe to go away and think long and hard about what we had said. We stared at each other, and at the spliffs on the table. Had we handled it right? Impossible to say.

After about three minutes, the door opened and Joe's face poked round. "Are you going to give me my dope back?" he asked, tilting his head at the joints. We handed them over.

Did we do the right thing? What is "the right thing", anyway? It's hard to navigate your way through parenthood, to know how much space to give; how protective or how tough to be. For something that so many people do, and so many have done down the years, parenthood has no definitive rules. The compass-points that guided my parents' generation are not necessarily relevant today, but neither does the experience of one's peer group always accurately reflect one's own rational views on a particular issue. So we muddle through, try not to be hypocritical, and hope for the best.

Two weeks after our discovery, Joe doesn't seem any different from the loving, happy, intelligent, well-balanced teenager he was before. That said, when he burst through the door at the weekend, enveloped me then Adam in giant bear hugs, ate two bananas in quick succession, and launched into a long and rambling account of his plans to travel the world in a camper van, Adam caught my eye behind Joe's back.

"He's stoned," he mouthed.

fields.headline: Heavy duty
fields.standfirst: More children than ever are overweight. So what should we do about it?  Kate Lowe meets the leader of Britain's first weight-loss camp and some of the children it has helped
fields.trailText: More children than ever are overweight. So what should we do about it? Kate Lowe meets the leader of Britain's first weight-loss camp and some of the children it has helped
fields.body:
Have you been largin' it? Too many of us have, it appears. According to figures just released by the National Audit Office, obesity is costing Britain £1.7bn a year. One in five adult women, and one in seven men, is now classed as obese. If that were not disturbing enough, it seems that weight problems begin early in life: research published in the British Medical Journal last week confirms that the number of preschool children medically classed as overweight or obese has almost doubled in the past decade.

An analysis by Dr Peter Bundred at Liverpool University of health visitors' records for more than 60,000 children found that the proportion of overweight under-fours had risen from 14.7% to 23.6%, while in the same age group obesity had climbed from 5.4% to 9.2%. The findings hold little surprise for Margaret Lawson, head of nutrition at Great Ormond Street children's hospital.

"I've seen the most enormous toddlers put on diets," she says, "although it's important to remember here that it's entirely natural for babies to be fat up until around a year old. After that, it's never too early to catch a child obesity problem. The longer a child remains obese, the harder it becomes to reverse, and the more likely they are to develop into obese adults."

While the new tendency adds an unfortunate new meaning to the phrase "Teletubby generation", the phenomenon is not restricted to toddlers. Measured by body mass index, the rates of overweight and obese primary school children and teenagers are also rising. Child obesity is becoming a daunting problem. What, if any, is the answer?

In the summer of 1999 Paul Gately, a senior lecturer at the school of leisure and sport stud ies at Leeds Metropolitan University, opened the Carnegie International Weight Loss Camp. Irreverently dubbed "Fat Camp" by the media, it remains the only one of its kind in the UK.

Gately argues that the reason why kids are fatter today than 20 years ago has far more to do with declining physical activity than changes in diet. He points to statistics which prove that, over the past 50 years, we have greatly reduced our regular intake of calories and food, yet the national physique continues to swell.

According to Gately, society - and particularly the powerful slimming industry - is to blame for fuelling the popular misconception that eating per se is the central cause of being overweight. "The kids that come to our camp aren't addicted to food," he insists. "What they're addicted to is inactivity - but that's the message you never hear."

Working parents, who have less free time to spend enjoying exercise with their children, have quickly been blamed for the decline of physical activity among today's kids - and the complementary rise in the amount of time they spend, stationary, in front of TV and computer screens. But the truth is not so simple.

Whether it is justified or not, parents' perception that it is no longer safe for children to play alone outside has undoubtedly played a role. So has the fact that physical education and sport have been slowly squeezed out of the national curriculum.

"Children no longer learn to run, throw, jump or catch at primary school," says Gately. "Instead, they're learning football and basketball. Without good core skills, kids are bound to fail at specialist sport later, by which stage they'll conclude, 'I'm no good at this,' which is nonsense. It's not the kids who are failing, but the system."

At the Carnegie summer camp, children - sometimes weighing in excess of 30st (190kg) - are placed on a portion- and calorie-controlled diet and a daily regime of six hours' exercise. Unlike the equivalent establishments in America, however, the priority at Carnegie is not to get children to lose huge amounts of weight. Gately's objective is to kickstart kids into managing their weight effectively by persuading them to make long-term changes to their lifestyle. With this in mind, participants are offered a spectacular variety of activities from which they can constantly choose, in the hope that when the children leave they will want to integrate exercise permanently into their home routine.

Seventeen-year-old Marc Cullen, who has cut his weight from 18st to 14st (114kg to 89kg), will be returning to the camp for a third time this summer. "I genuinely enjoyed the camp - if I didn't I wouldn't go back," he says. "The staff give you the right attitude to exercise because they make it feel like fun. I still eat McDonald's; I eat the same stuff as I did before - but now I run or play rugby three times a week."

A year after attending Carnegie, 15-year-old Gary Hipperson weighs 22st (140kg). He was 25st (159kg). Gary found that being among a sympathetic peer group helped: "The confidence boost is dramatic and comes from the tutors, but also from spending a lot of time talking with other people in the same situation. I've stayed in touch with friends I made at the camp and met my girlfriend there."

The issue of funding vexes Gately. He knows that the camp, at £2,000 for six weeks, is beyond the budgets of many. In Belgium, where child obesity levels are lower than our own, the state runs a residential, year-round centre to treat severely overweight children. But, such is the lack of popular sympathy towards child obesity here, neither government nor private sponsors have been willing to support Carnegie.

Many argue that it is primarily parents' responsibility to prevent their children getting so out of shape in the first place. Yet advice to parents faced with the reality of helping obese children can frequently seem confusing. They are told that children's food intake must be controlled, but that it is also vital to allow them autonomy - otherwise they will rebel. Subtle changes, such as keeping the fruit bowl full and the snack drawer empty, are supposedly the key to modifying an overweight child's environment without being too forceful. But it is easier said than done.

Our children now live in an "obese-genic" environment which subliminally and continually prevents them from being more active. The omnipotent impact of technology and transport has effectively made life so easy that it is beginning to harm their health.

At 15st (95kg), 14-year-old Rochelle McGuire is the only overweight member of her family. Until Carnegie opened, her mother, Linda, spent years taking her to see a series of medical professionals, but got nowhere as Rochelle's weight continued to escalate.

"If a child has anorexia or bulimia, there are specialists queueing up to help," says Linda, "but we refuse to take child obesity in this country seriously. To send Rochelle back to camp this year, it's expensive and I'll have to take on two jobs to fund it.

"Ignoring this problem now will cost the government in 20 years' time, when all these children become obese 35-year-olds with severe health-related problems. It's so shortsighted."

fields.headline: Small Miami agency to launch Mini in US
fields.trailText: 4pm: BMW has decided not to use a large agency to promote the new Mini Cooper to the US public, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
A small US agency was today given the task of advertising the Mini Cooper, icon of "swinging 60s" London, to the American public for the first time in 30 years.

Crispin Porter & Bogusky will be paid around £20m by Mini owner BMW to promote the revamped car as the ultimate accessory for the urban hipster.

It is hoped the compact roadster will win over the hearts of US motorists more used to giant, gas-guzzling Pontiacs and Chevrolets.

Mini's US marketing and communications manager Kerri Martin said she had chosen the Miami-based agency because she wanted the Mini to be marketed as a lifestyle choice, rather than a mass-market car.

"The Mini brand has a unique DNA to it.

"We were looking for a partner that also had that," said Ms Martin.

It has not yet been decided whether the Mini's fashionable London heritage will be the mainstay of the US campaign.

Unlike the innovative original, famously driven by the Beatles, the new Mini Cooper is a four-seat hatchback with a 1.6 litre engine.

BMW, which bought the Mini brand from Rover, aims to build 100,000 of the cars a year.

They will go on sale in the UK and Europe in the autumn.

The car will not be introduced into the US until March 2002.

However, Crispin Porter will develop a £3m teaser campaign to break in the US late this year.

BMW is using London agency WCRS to launch the Mini in the UK.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Lazio are currently flying in Serie A, but their Champions League ambitions look over for another year after they went down 3-2 to Real Madrid at the Santiago Bernabeu last night.
fields.body:
Lazio are currently flying in Serie A, but their Champions League ambitions look over for another year after they went down 3-2 to Real Madrid at the Santiago Bernabeu last night.

The match, watched by new England coach Sven-Goran Eriksson, was a classic. Lazio made the perfect start when Hernan Crespo scored after just four minutes, taking a pass from Lucas Castroman on his thigh and holding off Aigtor Karanka before sliding the ball inside the post.

But for the rest of the half Madrid, inspired by another excellent performance from Steve McManaman, were dominant, and they deservedly equalised when Fernando Morientes connected with Raul's cross just after the half-hour.

The second half was even better, however, with both sides missing chances before the game was settled in a stunning final ten minutes.

Ivan Helguera put Real ahead on 81 minutes when a cross by Roberto Carlos eluded Lazio's defence, only for Guerini Gottardi to equalise a minute later after Iker Casillas fumbled Giuseppe Pancaro's tame cross.

But Gottardi turned villain four minutes later, unnecessarily slashing down Pedro Munitis in the box. Luis Figo did his best to miss the resulting penalty, but his tame shot squeezed past the keeper, inflicting Lazio's first defeat since Dino Zoff replaced Eriksson as coach.

Real now have three wins out of three, and lead Group D by three points from Leeds. Meanwhile, Lazio are now stranded at the foot of the table after three successive defeats.

After the game Zoff was angry with referee Gilles Veissiere, blaming his decisions for the defeat. "I don't agree that Real Madrid were just winners," insisted Zoff, who was making his first visit to the Santiago Bernabeu stadium since lifting the World Cup in 1982. "I don't think the referee was up to a match of this size."

"I wasn't satisfied with our first half performance but after the break there were equal opportunities for both sides," he continued. "Unfortunately, our chances didn't produce results."

Real coach Vicente del Bosque was understandably in better mood. "I have come to talk about a great match between two top-class sides who performed to the limit of their abilities," he said. "We played brilliantly in the first half and dominated completely. The second was more evenly balanced, but the crowd was treated to a great spectacle."

Meanwhile McManaman, aware that he was being watched by Eriksson, admitted afterwards: "I was delighted with the chance to show him what I can do and I was pretty pleased with my performance, even though I was in trouble from midway through the first half with a hamstring injury."

But he was still circumspect about Real's prospects of qualification, claiming: "There are still three matches to go and nothing is decided yet."

A second-half header from Giovane Elber ensured Bayern Munich stretched their lead at the top of Group C to three points with a 1-0 victory over Spartak Moscow.

Bayern dominated in midfield and had the most of possession, but they often appeared clumsy in front of goal and looked unlikely to break through. That was until Elber headed home from close range on 78 minutes, following in after substitute Carsten Jancker had flicked on Bixente Lizarazu's throw-in.

Elber, who got himself in trouble earlier this year by criticising Bayern coach Ottmar Hitzfeld's defensive tactics and hinting at a move to Spain, was the best player on the pitch - a fact recognised by Hitzfeld.

"Elber is an exceptionally gifted player who is very important to Bayern and he proved that again tonight," he said.

Spartak, who had not played a competitive match since losing 3-0 to Lyon in their previous Champions League game on December 5, threatened rarely and coach Oleg Romantsev was not at all satisfied with his side's showing.

"We never found our game and I would rate our performance at 50 percent of what we are capable of doing," he said. "Bayern's victory is a deserved one."

webTitle: UN refugee work in crisis as world ignores Burundi

fields.headline: UN refugee work in crisis as world ignores Burundi
fields.standfirst: International aid switches to newer disasters as war drags on
fields.trailText: Burundian Hutu rebels raided a refugee transit centre in western Tanzania, killing one man and carrying off 36 others to fight in the civil war they had been trying to flee. Half the prisoners later escaped from Burundi and trudged back into Tanzania, free of the war but captive again.
fields.body:
Burundian Hutu rebels raided a refugee transit centre in western Tanzania, killing one man and carrying off 36 others to fight in the civil war they had been trying to flee. Half the prisoners later escaped from Burundi and trudged back into Tanzania, free of the war but captive again.

Every week, a thousand or more Burundian Hutus enter Tanzania to join the half million refugees already in camps there. The seven-year Hutu-Tutsi war shows no sign of ending, so the refugees have no prospect of returning home. And as donors move on to new disasters, the UN's emergency refugee programme is looking dangerously close to collapse.

Buchimi Donacie, 15, was one of the last to make it to western Karago camp in Western Tanzania before it closed its gates last month, overwhelmed by 50,000 refugees from Burundi last year. He fled his village after finding a neighbour decapitated, probably by soldiers of the Tutsi government army in revenge for a Hutu rebel attack.

"There was chaos, a lot of screaming, and everybody started running. I followed some of them, although I did not know where," he said, standing barefoot and shivering after a night in the rain.

Buchimi was desperate to trace his parents, lost in the panic. But first he needed shelter and a decent meal.

After a three-day walk without food, he waited for three days with 30 others at the camp entrance, scavenging by day, rained on at night. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) official claimed not to know they were there, or that the camp's reception centre had lost most of its tarpaulin roof.

"We will have to fix the roof and deal with them tomorrow," he said, asking not to be named.

UNHCR's budget for the refugee camps has been cut by 55% in the past year. At Karago, half-built schools stand empty while bored-looking children - wearing ski salopettes and Playboy socks, the flotsam of the international aid industry - wander listlessly. Strained UN staff are filling two jobs or more.

The Burundi peace talks in Tanzania last near, brokered by Nelson Mandela and visited by Bill Clinton, have done the refugees more harm than good. Most of the Hutu rebel groups were excluded and the initiative has come to nothing. But it was enough to send many donors elsewhere.

"Donors have not been forthcoming because of the peace process," said Hafeeza Bokhari, who oversees the running of five camps from UNHCR's Kibondo field office.

"There's a big question over what will happen. Education is a basic right, but if you don't have money to feed people, you don't educate them."

Because of food shortages, the UN World Food Program me (WFP) was forced to cut the refugees' rations by 40% last June. Now they are back up to 80%.

"If they hadn't gone on reduced rations then, they'd be living on nothing now," Wanja Kaaria, who runs WFP's Kibondo office, said.

"A 60% ration should be enough to keep people alive."

But the most vulnerable refugees are suffering. Beata Donavila, 16, is the head of her family: seven war-orphaned brothers and sisters.

"There is a problem with food here, it makes me very worried," she said, sitting in the smoky mud-hut the children built after fleeing fighting in their village. Beside the hut is an untidy patch of spinach and beans.

"We refuse to be split up because foster parents would steal our food," Beata said. "We will stay together until we can go home. And I will never let my brothers join the fighters when we do."

There is an effective ban on refugees working or trading outside the camps. Some 250,000 Burundian refugees settled in Tanzania in 1972 and the government, overburdened with poor of its own, is keen to avoid a repeat.

The result is a dispirited refugee population with no coping mechanisms to see it through the food crisis, apart from theft. "More and more refugees are leaving the camps to get food, causing serious crime and security problems," Ms Bokhari said.

"The camp people cannot be getting enough food or why would they steal?" said Simeon Ngalema, a villager living outside Karago camp.

The UN Children's Fund (Unicef) representative, Bjorn Lungqvist, says the camps should be moved back from the border and the refugees resettled in Tanzania, . "There is a lot of unused land in this country," he said. "And having so many people close to the border, with potential for Hutu rebels to recruit them, is something the Burundian government considers a very real threat."

In 1999 UNHCR spent less than £25 on each of Africa's 6m refugees - a measure of the funding it receives. In six months of that year it spent around £80 a head on Kosovo's refugees.

"When things fizzle out in terms of CNN coverage, the funding starts to disappear," Mr Lungqvist said. "This situation may have gone on for years, but with half a million refugees here, it is still an emergency."

webTitle: Notting Hill Carnival may get park venue

fields.headline: Notting Hill Carnival may get park venue
fields.trailText: The Notting Hill Carnival, Europe's biggest street party, may be rerouted to one of London's royal parks under plans being considered by the Greater London Authority.
fields.body:
The Notting Hill Carnival, Europe's biggest street party, may be rerouted to one of London's royal parks under plans being considered by the Greater London Authority.

With fears growing for the long-term future of the carnival, the GLA has drawn up other possible routes for the famous procession of floats and sound systems.

The intention is to disperse the huge crowds away from the tight residential streets of west London, where two men were murdered last year. Greg Watson, 21, was stabbed to death on the final evening of the carnival, shortly after Abdul Bhatti, 28, a salesman, was left with fatal injuries by a gang who beat him. There were 11 stabbings over the August bank holiday weekend in Notting Hill, and 132 robberies, up from 13 in 1999.

The rise in violent crime led to claims the carnival was not effectively policed because officers were concerned they would be labelled racist if they used stop and search powers. But an independent review group, headed by Lee Jasper, mayor Ken Livingstone's adviser on race relations, has concluded that a more effective dispersal of crowds would reduce violence.

To this end new routes are being considered including leading floats to Hyde Park or to grounds near Wormwood Scrubs prison, to the north- west of Notting Hill. Options include organising other music events across the capital to draw people away from Notting Hill.

The interim report recommended that while Notting Hill should remain the heart of the procession a non-circular route ending in an open space would help crowd dispersal.

It also recommended a system of stewarding that would allow police to concentrate on crime rather than crowd control. The first day of the event, the Sunday, should be more family friendly, with fewer sound systems and commercial floats.

"The report's findings represent a consensus view of what is needed for Carnival 2001," Mr Jasper said. "It was felt by all that in recent years, carnival has become the victim of its own success. What began as a spontaneous celebration has grown into Europe's largest street festival.

"Our primary concern has been that carnival must be a safe and enjoyable occasion for participants, visitors and residents alike, young and old."

The royal parks agency questioned whether Hyde Park could cope with the crowds, even though it is a regular venue for live music in the summer. William Weston, the agency's chief executive, said: "There are significant hurdles to be overcome. But we are happy to explore, with the review group, how and if these problems might be overcome."

fields.headline: Back to Herat
fields.standfirst: Prue Peart returns to Herat to find the impact of sanctions is still unclear and that displaced people are having to cope with below-zero temperatures
fields.trailText: Prue Peart returns to Herat to find the impact of sanctions is still unclear and that displaced people are having to cope with below-zero temperatures.
fields.body:
I have been trying for almost six weeks to get back to Herat and have been faced with a number of obstacles - the Afghan embassy in Islamabad said that all my papers got lost in Kabul, so, instead of two weeks, it took five weeks to get an Afghan visa. My Pakistani visa ran out at the end of January and it took six weeks for the relevant department to renew it.

While I was in Islamabad, the UN security council introduced new sanctions against the Taliban and many foreigners left the country in case there was some sort of retaliation, but all remained quiet. It is difficult to assess what difference these sanctions will make to the people of Afghanistan, but it gives the Taliban a ready excuse for all problems in the country.

Herat has also made world news, as very cold weather hit the area a couple of weeks ago and the UN reported the death of 480 vulnerable people in the camps. This figure should be treated with caution, as it has never been verified, and the medical agencies monitoring mortality through their clinics and watching for new graves do not feel that this was a realistic number - more like 100 deaths in the week.

As I arrived at the airport yesterday, I met a group of journalists who were on their way home to report to the world on the situation in Herat. It seems that different groups have their own agendas, depending on what they are here to achieve. But, certainly, the news of impending disaster has brought lots of new aid, whether from schoolchildren in Islamabad, collecting old jumpers, or the US government, sending in planes full of blankets and jerry-cans.

So, yesterday, having finally got my passport and all the necessary visas, I departed on a UN flight. As we left, someone at the office said that it was minus seven degrees celsius during the day in Herat - we all grabbed another jumper in preparation for the cold. We landed at Kandahar under bright blue skies and warm sunshine. Another hour's flight over featureless desert and snowy mountains brought us to Herat. Flying over Afghanistan, there is no sign of habitation and, with the rain failures, it looks the same shade of brown everywhere.

It was bright and cold in Herat. The sun is warm, but it is the wind that makes it feel bitterly cold if you are not in a sheltered place. The air feels fresh and unpolluted at the airport, as though on top of a mountain, but in the city it is dusty, as lorries and cars stir up the dirt tracks. At the end of the road that runs to the office there was a large crater, created by a bomb that was planted there last week. No one had been hurt, but the office windows were cracked. Rumours suggest that the blast was aimed at a senior government man. Otherwise, Herat looks very dry and dusty, much as it did when I was last here in December.

I immediately had a meeting with Ajmal Shirzai, Ockenden's country director for Afghanistan, and learned that there was a rush for ideas to be put on paper in time for a meeting with potential new donors. Ockenden International has been building latrines in Mazlagh camp, but most of those living in the camps are not accustomed to using latrines and the standards of hygiene are poor. It has been suggested that we start a health education programme and possibly a traditional birth attendant one, too, in order to address some of the problems.

We discussed plans for the future of the development team - I plan to visit the clinic built by Ockenden and look at some of the health messages being disseminated along with the skills training programme.

Stuart Templeton, Ockenden's relief programme manager, has been incredibly busy during the past fortnight, trying to get the shelters finished and the displaced people moved into them.

Today, I have been busy, as I have tried to gather information for the potential expansion of the relief programme in the camps. I had brought some home-made apricot jam with me, which we ate for breakfast on naan bread, washed down with big mugs of tea (big mugs, brought from Islamabad, because I was tired of drinking tea from small glasses).

My first meeting was with representatives from Médecins du Monde, who told me that they have started health education programmes in Mazlagh camp and are starting traditional birth attendant training next week, along with WHO and Unicef. They feel that they are covering the camp adequately and that for Ockenden International to start more training would confuse matters.

Although Mazlagh camp has grown enormously in the past three months, and will continue to grow as news travels of all the food and goods being distributed, funding has been coming in to meet most of the immediate needs.

I also had a talk with Medecins Sans Frontieres, which is providing health education in Shaidhee camp and running a supplementary feeding centre for malnourished children under five years old.

So, it seems Ockenden International is better off concentrating on the building of latrines and bath-houses, and we may do some more food-for-work projects. The quilt making has been going very well, and is almost finished. But there is little point in extending this, when most of the displaced people have now been given at least four quilts or blankets per family, and the US government is planning to bring in more.

Later in the day, we heard the Japanese government wanted to donate $500,00 to the emergency programme for non-food relief items. So Stuart and I spent a few hours putting together a budget to provide soap, cooking pots and bowls for those families who have not received them yet, plus some plastic sheeting for them to use on the floors.

It has been impossible to get the woman who I interviewed previously to go to the camps because of the government authorities, so her brother has been working as a field officer. But the ministry of planning has suggested another woman to us, and we met today.

She moved to Herat six years ago, after her family home in Kabul was destroyed - her father had been a headmaster there. She has worked in the camps around Herat with Omar, a de-mining NGO, before but has not had permission to work in the past year, until now. She was a pleasure to talk to, and I hope that she will be able to help us with looking at the needs of the women in the camps.

I cannot continue now, as it is getting late and there is pressure on the computer as we all try to meet deadlines.

It seems that different groups have their own agendas, depending on what they are here to achieve. But, certainly, the news of impending disaster has brought lots of new aid, whether from schoolchildren in Islamabad, collecting old jumpers, or the US government, sending in planes full of blankets and jerry-cans. So, yesterday, having finally got my passport and all the necessary visas, I departed on a UN flight. As we left, someone at the office said that it was minus seven degrees celsius during the day in Herat - we all grabbed another jumper in preparation for the cold. We landed at Kandahar under bright blue skies and warm sunshine. Another hour's flight over featureless desert and snowy mountains brought us to Herat. Flying over Afghanistan, there is no sign of habitation and, with the rain failures, it looks the same shade of brown everywhere. It was bright and cold in Herat. The sun is warm, but it is the wind that makes it feel bitterly cold if you are not in a sheltered place. The air feels fresh and unpolluted at the airport, as though on top of a mountain, but in the city it is dusty, as lorries and cars stir up the dirt tracks. At the end of the road that runs to the office there was a large crater, created by a bomb that was planted there last week. No one had been hurt, but the office windows were cracked. Rumours suggest that the blast was aimed at a senior government man. Otherwise, Herat looks very dry and dusty, much as it did when I was last here in December. I immediately had a meeting with Ajmal Shirzai, Ockenden's country director for Afghanistan, and learned that there was a rush for ideas to be put on paper in time for a meeting with potential new donors. Ockenden International has been building latrines in Mazlagh camp, but most of those living in the camps are not accustomed to using latrines and the standards of hygiene are poor. It has been suggested that we start a health education programme and possibly a traditional birth attendant one, too, in order to address some of the problems. We discussed plans for the future of the development team - I plan to visit the clinic built by Ockenden and look at some of the health messages being disseminated along with the skills training programme. Stuart Templeton, Ockenden's relief programme manager, has been incredibly busy during the past fortnight, trying to get the shelters finished and the displaced people moved into them. Today, I have been busy, as I have tried to gather information for the potential expansion of the relief programme in the camps. I had brought some home-made apricot jam with me, which we ate for breakfast on naan bread, washed down with big mugs of tea (big mugs, brought from Islamabad, because I was tired of drinking tea from small glasses). My first meeting was with representatives from Médecins du Monde, who told me that they have started health education programmes in Mazlagh camp and are starting traditional birth attendant training next week, along with WHO and Unicef. They feel that they are covering the camp adequately and that for Ockenden International to start more training would confuse matters. Although Mazlagh camp has grown enormously in the past three months, and will continue to grow as news travels of all the food and goods being distributed, funding has been coming in to meet most of the immediate needs. I also had a talk with Medecins Sans Frontieres, which is providing health education in Shaidhee camp and running a supplementary feeding centre for malnourished children under five years old. So, it seems Ockenden International is better off concentrating on the building of latrines and bath-houses, and we may do some more food-for-work projects. The quilt making has been going very well, and is almost finished. But there is little point in extending this, when most of the displaced people have now been given at least four quilts or blankets per family, and the US government is planning to bring in more. Later in the day, we heard the Japanese government wanted to donate $500,00 to the emergency programme for non-food relief items. So Stuart and I spent a few hours putting together a budget to provide soap, cooking pots and bowls for those families who have not received them yet, plus some plastic sheeting for them to use on the floors. It has been impossible to get the woman who I interviewed previously to go to the camps because of the government authorities, so her brother has been working as a field officer. But the ministry of planning has suggested another woman to us, and we met today. She moved to Herat six years ago, after her family home in Kabul was destroyed - her father had been a headmaster there. She has worked in the camps around Herat with Omar, a de-mining NGO, before but has not had permission to work in the past year, until now. She was a pleasure to talk to, and I hope that she will be able to help us with looking at the needs of the women in the camps. I cannot continue now, as it is getting late and there is pressure on the computer as we all try to meet deadlines.

fields.headline: Lauder victorious in Czech TV legal battle
fields.trailText: 3pm: Billionaire Ronald Lauder has won the first round of his fight with his former Czech TV partner, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Billionaire US cosmetics mogul Ronald Lauder has won the first round of his legal fight with former Czech TV business partner Vladimir Zelezny.

The dispute will shortly be coming to a UK court.

Mr Zelezny has been ordered to repay £18m to Mr Lauder's company, Central European Media Enterprises, by the Paris-based International Chamber of Commerce's arbitration court.

But the stakes will be far higher next month.

In March, Mr Lauder, heir to the Estee Lauder cosmetics dynasty, will begin his attempt to win £350m in damages from the Czech government for its role in the dispute with Mr Zelezny.

The arbitration hearing will be held in London on March 5.

Yesterday, the ICC heard Mr Zelezny had set up a Czech TV station in partnership with CME and was given a stake worth £18m in the company, TV Nova.

He then provided CME with a broadcast licence through his CET 21 firm.

Mr Zelezny later sold his stake in TV Nova, took away the broadcast licence and began operating a rival service with it in the summer of 1999.

Mr Lauder claims the Czech government did nothing to prevent Mr Zelezny's actions and violated a 1991 treaty between the US and the then Czechoslovak Federal Republic.

He wants the Czech authorities to repay the money CME lost on the stock market once it was thrown out of TV Nova - around £350m.

CME said it will pursue the £18m payment from Mr Zelezny, despite the Czech businessman's claims he has sold his assets to prevent creditors from reaching them.

Investors were so rattled by CME's reversal of fortune in the Czech Republic it was delisted from the Nasdaq stock exchange in the US.

Sources close to the dispute said it is vital Mr Lauder's claims are upheld, otherwise foreign investors will shy away from investing in the Czech media sector.

"This whole case is putting off potential investors looking at the Czech Republic," said one source.

"They are wondering where the protection is for companies like CME."

fields.headline: Ministerial scrutiny goes unscrutinised
fields.standfirst:
Backbencher Tony Wright's suggestion that MPs, not anonymous civil servants, should police the ministerial code is hardly likely to get the Downing Street rubber stamp, says Nicholas Watt

Special report: life in parliament
fields.trailText: Backbencher Tony Wright's suggestion that MPs, not anonymous civil servants, should police the ministerial code is hardly likely to get the Downing Street rubber stamp, says Nicholas Watt.
fields.body:
Tony Blair must be kicking himself that he has never promoted the bright Labour backbencher Tony Wright. As chairman of the influential Commons public administration committee, Dr Wright has become something of a thorn in Downing Street's side, with thoughtful proposals on reforming government business.

His latest idea, that MPs - rather than civil servants - should police the ministerial code will horrify Downing Street. For all Tony Blair's rhetoric about trying to be purer than pure, the prime minister has reached for the traditional Whitehall fix when ministers have behaved in a questionable manner.

When Peter Mandelson ran into trouble over the Hindujas' passport application, Mr Blair summoned the cabinet secretary Sir Richard Wilson to preside over the "kangaroo court" which removed the former Northern Ireland secretary from office.

Dr Wright today made a powerful case for allowing MPs on his committee, which is one of the most influential in the Commons, to carry out such investigations in future.

"We do have a situation now where, in a sense, the verdict is pronounced before the investigation takes place," he said. "If [ministers] are charged with something under the code of conduct they should have the chance to have an independent investigation because you have got the media howling for their blood, you have got a great furore inside parliament."

His proposals are unlikely ever to come to fruition because Downing Street will be terrified of opening up the system to greater scrutiny. MPs, for example, would probably take a dim view of the way in which the ministerial code has been stretched by Downing Street in favour of the Europe minister Keith Vaz.

Mr Vaz had a lucky escape. He was allowed to hold talks in his ministerial suite with an insurance company, on behalf of a friend, because the meeting was classified as "constituency business".

Although Mr Vaz's friend does not live anywhere near his Leicester East parliamentary seat, he was classified as a constituent because the Foreign Office said that the Europe minister has a "wider constituency" among Britain's Asian community. They also admitted that the authors of the ministerial code never had such a definition in mind when they drew up the code.

Allowing MPs, from all parties, to police the ministerial code would guarantee an end to such a wide interpretation of the rules. Such a reform may also have saved Mr Mandelson's career.

webTitle: Bergkamp demands respect as human being

fields.headline: Bergkamp demands respect as human being
fields.trailText: Dennis Bergkamp is sick of the "soap opera" surrounding his fear of flying and has demanded more respect as a human being. The Dutchman today also denied a report that his well-documented fear of getting on an airplane had now been joined by a similar unwillingness to travel by train.
fields.body:
Dennis Bergkamp is sick of the "soap opera" surrounding his fear of flying and has demanded more respect as a human being. The Dutchman today also denied a report that his well-documented fear of getting on an airplane had now been joined by a similar unwillingness to travel by train.

"Why has my fear of flying been turned into this soap opera? Surely it isn't such a big deal? I'm sick of it," he said in an outburst on his personal website.

"I've been able to travel to lots of places including Barcelona and Fiorentina in the past so it isn't a huge handicap."

There was also a mild ticking-off too for Arsenal coach Arsene Wenger.

"I know that Mr Wenger was asked today whether I'm scared of travelling by train and he reportedly fell a little short of denying that I have such a fear," Bergkamp said.

"I wasn't party to that conversation but I'm a little bit disappointed that he didn't consult me on this or that I wasn't told by anyone at the club that this suggestion was being made by the press.

"It seems a little odd because Mr Wenger knows I have no problem with trains."

Bergkamp said he had missed Arsenal's 1-0 away victory over French club Olympique Lyon on Tuesday because he had been rested by Wenger, much to the Dutchman's disappointment.

"Surely there are more important things to be said about the Champions League than this? It's a huge competition with Europe's best teams, why just talk about me and planes?!"

Bergkamp summed up: "The problem is just that I'm a little bit tired of the whole drama surrounding my decision to not fly.

"People never seem to tire of going on and on about it and I'm sick of it.

"It isn't a joke - it's my personal decision as a human being. Perhaps people could respect that a little bit more."

 Dennis' homepage can be found at www.icons.com

webTitle: S4C sponsor cashes in new ITC rules

fields.headline: S4C sponsor cashes in new ITC rules
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: A sponsor on Welsh language channel S4C has taken advantage of the ITC's relaxation of rules. By Julia Day.
fields.body:
A new weather bulletin sponsor on Welsh language channel S4C is taking advantage of the relaxation of television sponsorship rules.

Welsh company Adjustamatic Beds has created 10-second response-led adverts around the weather forecasts, the first campaign of its kind on S4C.

The campaign will include a telephone number allowing viewers to contact the company.

The Independent Television Commission recently relaxed TV sponsorship rules to allow the inclusion of a product picture and telephone number, which were previously barred.

The advertising space was bought by the company's media agency Response Advertising Media.

The campaign is based around the strapline, "Adjustamatic - as changeable as the weather".

"Until now, weather forecast sponsorship could only be used as a brand awareness exercise," said RAM head of media Kelly Farrington.

"But these new rules allow us to build in the response mechanism of a telephone number."

S4C's weather bulletins are watched by more than 600,000 viewers a week. The campaign is expected to reach 44% of the Welsh population after three months and 73% after a year.

fields.headline: BBC chalks up first 10pm news victory
fields.trailText: 2.15pm TV overnights: BBC1 won the head-to-head 10pm news battle with ITV for the first time last night, writes Wale Azeez.
fields.body:
BBC1 won the head-to-head 10pm news battle with ITV for the first time last night.

BBC1's Ten O'Clock News victory came on the back of a rare BBC1 peaktime ratings triumph, achieved by a drama line-up of EastEnders, Holby City and Silent Witness.

BBC1's 10pm bulletin had 5.4m viewers and 27% of the audience, against News at Ten's 5m and 25%, according to unofficial overnights.

The Tuesday-night ratings coup for BBC1 began from 7.30pm, as EastEnders captured 13.3m viewers and more than half of the available audience.

From 8pm, Holby City got the better of The Bill on ITV.

The BBC1 medical drama notched up 7.8 viewers and a 33% share, while The Bill had 7.4m viewers.

Next up, at 9pm, Silent Witness retained Holby City's 33%t audience share and brought in 8.1m viewers for the BBC.

At the same time on ITV, Peak Practice slipped to 6.8m - down 1.1m viewers on last Tuesday - and a 28% share.

The strong BBC1 drama performances helped the channel to secure 34.4% of peaktime viewing between 7pm and 10.30pm, compared with ITV's 29.7%.

But this morale-boosting ratings victory cannot hide the fact BBC1's peaktime schedule has been slow out of the blocks this year.

It is now struggling to make up ground lost to ITV.

ITV had a 38.9% share of peaktime viewing in the first six weeks of 2001, more than a percentage point up on the same period last year.

By contrast, BBC1 is lagging three percentage points behind last year's 26% peaktime viewing figure for the same period.

Elsewhere last night, Channel 5's movie the Long Kiss Goodnight proved popular from 9pm.

Samuel L Jackson and Geena Davis teamed up to pull in 2.5m viewers and a 12% audience share.

webTitle: Book by rebel MI6 agent a near sell-out

fields.headline: Book by rebel MI6 agent a near sell-out
fields.trailText: Thousands of copies of the book by the renegade MI6 officer Richard Tomlinson, the Big Breach, were being distributed to bookshops yesterday as government lawyers conceded there was nothing they could do to stop it.
fields.body:
Thousands of copies of the book by the renegade MI6 officer Richard Tomlinson, the Big Breach, were being distributed to bookshops yesterday as government lawyers conceded there was nothing they could do to stop it.

The paperback is being issued by Cutting Edge, a company linked to Mainstream Publishing, an independent firm based in Edinburgh. Bill Campbell, joint managing director, said yesterday the print run of 12,500 copies, for sale at £9.99, had almost sold out.

The Westminster bookshop Politico's sold 50 copies in half a day, said Iain Dale, its managing director. He was not entirely in favour of the book but, since it was available in Moscow and its contents had been published in national newspapers, its sale had become an issue of freedom of speech.

Whitehall lawyers have told publishers that the crown holds the copyright of the book and Mr Tomlinson signed an agreement to that effect in 1997. Mr Tomlinson says he signed under duress.

He has been paid an advance of about £28,000 by the Russian publisher of the hardback edition, but government lawyers will try to ensure he gets nothing from the UK publisher. Whitehall officials said yesterday they would not attempt to prevent the publisher or bookshops from making money from sales.

The book, which MI6 says is damaging, gives an account of Mr Tomlinson's operations and exploits in Russia, as well as the training and tradecraft of Britain's secret intelligence service. Mr Tomlinson has left Italy where he worked in a bar and is now living in Cannes in the south of France. Yesterday he insisted the book was not damaging, and added: "The government and country carries on."

When the government set up its promised special employment tribunal for former members of the security and intelligence agencies he would be the first to demand a hearing, he said.

fields.headline: A contrast in terror
fields.standfirst:
The retaliatory violence in the Middle East shows no sign of coming to an end, says Derek Brown, after news of the bus attack and another assassination attempt

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The retaliatory violence in the Middle East shows no sign of coming to an end, says Derek Brown, after news of the bus attack and another assassination attempt.
fields.body:
The Israeli-Palestinian conflict is spiralling out of control in an orgy of blind hatred. Events of the past 36 hours offer a grisly contrast between the terror methods preferred by each side.

On Tuesday, Israeli helicopter gunships 'took out' Masoud Ayyad, an officer in Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat's elite Force 17 bodyguard, and a suspected Islamic militant.

This morning, a Palestinian bus driver apparently went beserk, ramming his vehicle into a queue of passengers. At least eight were killed and a dozen more were injured, some seriously.

Another new incident is being reported from the West Bank: a Palestinian man shot and seriously wounded, allegedly by an Israeli military hit squad.

At first sight, there is no comparison between these horrible events. On the one hand, crazed fanaticism; on the other, calculated military ruthlessness. However, the contrast doesn't bear examination.

There was nothing cold or calculated about the Israeli mob that gathered at the site of this morning's bus massacre, baying for Arab blood. Nor is there much restraint about a military policy that includes casual assassination.

And, according to the skewed thinking of Palestinians today, there was nothing irrational in the behaviour of Halil Abu Olba, the bus driver who slammed into the Israeli bus queue near Holon, on the outskirts of Tel Aviv. He will be hailed today as a hero, who did his bit for the cause in the best way he could.

Olba is 35 years old and has five children, who he will not see again for a very long time. He was shot and wounded in the police pursuit of his bus, which ended when the vehicle crashed into a truck 10 miles south of Holon, and is now in hospital under police guard.

It is not yet known whether Olba's grotesque action was premeditated or spontaneous. Either way, it has a surreal context that is central to the current bitter relationship between Israelis and Palestinians.

Olba's home is in the Sheikh Radwan district of the Gaza Strip. Since the eruption of the al-Aqsa intifada at the end of last September, the territory has been mostly sealed off from Israel, partly for security reasons and partly as collective punishment.

The 'closure' of the Gaza Strip, and of the West Bank, has caused untold hardship to two million Palestinians. Around 200,000 of them depend on wages earned in Israel, where employers are only too happy to exploit their cheap labour.

In recent weeks the blockade has been eased slightly, to allow some 14,000 daily labourers to cross into Israel. They are supposed to have security clearance and their passage is tightly supervised at military checkpoints. In reality, as everyone in the region knows, thousands of Palestinians from the territories routinely work illegally in Israel.

Olba, amazingly, appears to have been one of those. For five years he was employed by the Israeli bus company, Egged, to transport Palestinian workers from Gaza into Tel Aviv. Company officials have told local reporters that Olba's security clearance was withdrawn two weeks ago.

Nevertheless, he was still at the wheel of an Egged bus this morning. If that seems bizarre, it pales by comparison with a military machine that now routinely assassinates those it suspects of being enemies, with the warm approval of the public and elected politicians.

Col Masoud Ayyad, dispatched by a volley of missiles from a pair of Apache assault helicopters on Tuesday, was the 13th Palestinian to have been summarily executed during the intifada. (The Palestinians say at least 20 men have died in air strikes, or at the hands of Israeli hit squads).

This morning brought news of a fresh shooting: Palestinians said that Iyaad Abu Harb, aged 24, was shot while travelling between Tulkarm and Nablus. They claim Harb, believed to be an activist in Arafat's Fatah organisation, was targeted by Israeli undercover forces in a failed assassination attempt. He is now in a critical condition in hospital.

Last night, Palestinian gunmen rained bullets on the Jewish suburb of Gilo, in occupied east Jerusalem. Today, in the wake of the bus massacre, Israel reimposed its blockade of Gaza and the West Bank. There is, apparently, no end to the mutual madness.

Nor is there much restraint about a military policy that includes casual assassination. And, according to the skewed thinking of Palestinians today, there was nothing irrational in the behaviour of Halil Abu Olba, the bus driver who slammed into the Israeli bus queue near Holon, on the outskirts of Tel Aviv. He will be hailed today as a hero, who did his bit for the cause in the best way he could. Olba is 35 years old and has five children, who he will not see again for a very long time. He was shot and wounded in the police pursuit of his bus, which ended when the vehicle crashed into a truck 10 miles south of Holon, and is now in hospital under police guard. It is not yet known whether Olba's grotesque action was premeditated or spontaneous. Either way, it has a surreal context that is central to the current bitter relationship between Israelis and Palestinians. Olba's home is in the Sheikh Radwan district of the Gaza Strip. Since the eruption of the al-Aqsa intifada at the end of last September, the territory has been mostly sealed off from Israel, partly for security reasons and partly as collective punishment. The 'closure' of the Gaza Strip, and of the West Bank, has caused untold hardship to two million Palestinians. Around 200,000 of them depend on wages earned in Israel, where employers are only too happy to exploit their cheap labour. In recent weeks the blockade has been eased slightly, to allow some 14,000 daily labourers to cross into Israel. They are supposed to have security clearance and their passage is tightly supervised at military checkpoints. In reality, as everyone in the region knows, thousands of Palestinians from the territories routinely work illegally in Israel. Olba, amazingly, appears to have been one of those. For five years he was employed by the Israeli bus company, Egged, to transport Palestinian workers from Gaza into Tel Aviv. Company officials have told local reporters that Olba's security clearance was withdrawn two weeks ago. Nevertheless, he was still at the wheel of an Egged bus this morning. If that seems bizarre, it pales by comparison with a military machine that now routinely assassinates those it suspects of being enemies, with the warm approval of the public and elected politicians. Col Masoud Ayyad, dispatched by a volley of missiles from a pair of Apache assault helicopters on Tuesday, was the 13th Palestinian to have been summarily executed during the intifada. (The Palestinians say at least 20 men have died in air strikes, or at the hands of Israeli hit squads). This morning brought news of a fresh shooting: Palestinians said that Iyaad Abu Harb, aged 24, was shot while travelling between Tulkarm and Nablus. They claim Harb, believed to be an activist in Arafat's Fatah organisation, was targeted by Israeli undercover forces in a failed assassination attempt. He is now in a critical condition in hospital. Last night, Palestinian gunmen rained bullets on the Jewish suburb of Gilo, in occupied east Jerusalem. Today, in the wake of the bus massacre, Israel reimposed its blockade of Gaza and the West Bank. There is, apparently, no end to the mutual madness. email dbrown445@aol.com Useful links Government of Israel Jerusalem Post Ha'aretz Jerusalem Report Palestinian national authority Palestinian ministry of information

webTitle: Kylie to star in Pepsi ad

fields.headline: Kylie to star in Pepsi ad
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: Pop star Kylie Minogue has become the latest singer after Britney Spears and the Spice Girls to star in a Pepsi advert, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Pop star Kylie Minogue has become the latest singer to star in a Pepsi advert.

Ms Minogue, famed for her revealing outfits, will appear in a new 45-second advertisment to be shown initially in her native Australia.

A spokesman for Pepsi said no decision has yet been made whether to bring the ad to the UK.

"It has not been announced that the Kylie ad will be shown beyond Australia yet but it may come to be extended to other territories if it is successful in Oz," he said.

But, in what is likely to be a disappointment for men the world over, Ms Minogue keeps her clothes on in the ad.

"Pepsi is a fine, upstanding brand. We do not encourage our artists to remove their clothes," the spokesman said.

Ms Minogue joins Britney Spears, the Spice Girls, Michael Jackson and Madonna in endorsing the cola brand.

The 19-year-old Ms Spears signed a multi-million dollar advertising deal with Pepsi last week and will star in a new global ad campaign.
