webTitle: Scots under fire for 'scratching surface' with anti-racism plans

fields.headline: Scots under fire for 'scratching surface' with anti-racism plans
fields.trailText: The Scottish executive has come under fire from minority ethnic groups for failing to take on board the key lessons of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry.
fields.body:
The Scottish executive has come under fire from minority ethnic groups for failing to take on board the key lessons of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry.

The criticism came as a steering group, set up by the executive in the wake of the inquiry report two years ago, outlined the progress made during the last year and made a number of recommendations for further action.

The executive accepted most of the Lawrence inquiry's 70 recommendations and unveiled an action plan in July 1999. But two key recommendations - that there should be a new independent body to investigate complaints against police, and that officers should be disciplined after retirement - were not fully backed and are still being considered.

The steering group calls for the development of performance indicators for tackling racism among police and other public sector bodies, and for steps to be taken to ensure officers on the ground understand what is meant by a racist incident, such as a scheme in Lothian and borders where officers use a credit-card-sized aide-memoire.

It also proposes a national code of practice for reporting racist incidents and that the executive should consider setting up a 24-hour hotline for reporting such incidents, similar to the service available for victims of domestic abuse. A Scottish version of English police guidance on combating hate crime should also be produced.

Scottish justice minister Jim Wallace said: "We have come a long way in the past two years and the steering group has made an invaluable contribution to this progress, providing outside scrutiny of the work of the police, crown office and others.

"But it is clear that much remains to be done. The handling of the murder of Surjit Singh Chhokar reminds us starkly of that. The actions laid out in this review provide a challenging list of practical actions which the police, crown office, executive and others can address over the coming months and beyond."

Aamer Anwar, a leading race campaigner and spokesman for the Chhokar family justice campaign, which is calling for a public inquiry into the handling of the case of murdered Asian waiter Surjit Singh Chhokar, slammed the steering group as "toothless" and accused the executive of watering down the recommendations of the Macpherson report.

"It's a superficial exercise going over the easiest parts without dealing with its fundamental aspects, which are about accountability and openness. They don't take account of the fact that officers on the beat have not taken on board the principles of Macpherson and the legacy of Stephen Lawrence," he said.

"You won't find a single racist incident logged against a police officer in Scotland. Either they don't exist in Scotland or there is something wrong with the procedures and they haven't been changed. If racist officers are not sacked, this only increases the confidence of others who are racist."

Mr Anwar said the measures themselves were welcome but failed to reach the heart of the problem. "The Macpherson report was all about was institutional racism - that people are denied access to the system and justice - and they haven't really tackled that. All those issues have been dodged," he said.

Robina Qureshi, director of Positive Action in Housing, which targets racism and ethnic minority homelessness in Scotland, and a member of the steering group, is dismayed that the group has no teeth to back its recommendations.

"Efforts are being made, but not enough to say there is progress. We have no power to make anyone do anything. If they were clear and committed, we would have power behind what we are trying to do. Now, a year and a half later, it is just another report," she said.

Ms Qureshi claimed the review didn't go far enough in tackling institutional racism. "They are afraid to recognise that the problems are at the root of their own system. We would like a programme of radical change to directly address institutional racism. The best way of doing that is to have a multiracial task force in each department - police, judiciary, fiscal and crown office," she said.

Vijay Patel, secretary of the black and ethnic minority infrastructure in Scotland, an umbrella group for black voluntary organisations, said the group's recommendations only scratched the surface of what was required.

"They are pretty weak and I suspect a number of people could have come up with them a year earlier without forming a committee. The nicest thing I can say is at least the executive and criminal justice system are actually speaking to people who understand the issues," he said.

"Unless you understand the values involved, you are on a hiding to nothing. Across the executive, a number of civil servants are struggling with the notion because they don't understand the concept of discrimination. Only when you understand that, can you then think about how to deal with it personally and institutionally."

webTitle: At least 174 dead in Salvador quake

fields.headline: At least 174 dead in Salvador quake
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: An earthquake has struck El Salvador a month to the day after more than 1,000 people were killed by earth tremors.
fields.body:
An earthquake has struck El Salvador a month to the day after more than 1,000 people were killed by earth tremors.

At least 174 people were killed by yesterday's quake, which was centred on several provinces east of the capital, San Salvador. The earthquake, measuring 6.1 on the Richter scale, struck at 8.22am as many Salvadoreans were on their way to work.

More than 1,700 people were injured and many more remain trapped beneath the rubble of collapsed buildings.

President Francisco Flores said that the quake's impact on the affected towns "is greater than what happened on January 13", the date of a 7.6 magnitude quake that officials say killed 844, injured 4,723 and destroyed 278,000 houses. Hundreds more remain missing and are believed dead.

The January quake, centred off El Salvador's southern coast, triggered a landslide that buried hundreds of people in the city of Santa Tecla. The city was not affected by the latest quake.

Hardest hit this time were the provinces of San Vicente, Cuscatlan and La Paz, in the centre of the country east of San Salvador, where at least 167 people were killed, the government said.

Officials said the death toll could sharply increase because of numerous landslides that have blocked highways, preventing immediate access to some communities. The president said the Panamerican highway was heavily damaged by landslides and would be out of service for the foreseeable future.

He also said that San Salvador, which was not affected seriously by the quake, had no drinking water after pipes in the city collapsed.

When the tremors struck, hundreds of thousands of people fled into the streets of the capital - a city jittery from more than 3,200 aftershocks of the January quake.

Even President Flores was displaced by the first quake. With his office damaged, he has been working out of temporary quarters at a fairground.

fields.headline: Behind the Bushisms
fields.standfirst:
Duncan Campbell laments the demise of the gaffes attributed to the new president during last year's US election

Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: Duncan Campbell laments the demise of the gaffes attributed to the new president during last year's US election.
fields.body:
One of the pleasures of last year's presidential election was the number of jokes and stories that floated around the internet about the two main candidates. Every day, a fresh batch would arrive.

Some were a bit juvenile and eventually most people tired of the examination of Bush's mangled syntax - although not enough to stop the publication of two recent books on the subject. Some, however, were sharp and funny and responded to all the twists and turns of the election.

Now, alas, all is quiet. The Bush team is installed so - as the satirist Tom Lehrer said on a different occasion - who needs satire?

What is needed now is for some sociology professor to trace the origin of these stories in the same way that some of our great urban myths have been located. How many of the jokes were original and how many adapted from past political jokes?

I am particularly curious about one that has floated round again and seems to have a long-lasting currency independent of the last presidential round. Apologies to those who have read - or written - it before, but this is how it goes:

A little boy asks his father what politics is. His father tries to explain. "Well, son," he says, "I go out into the world every day and make money - so imagine me as Capitalism. Your mother handles the budget for the house - so you could regard her as the Government. Your nanny, who looks after you and your baby brother, works very hard - so we will call her the Working Class. You are in the midst of all this - so consider yourself as the People. And your baby brother? Look on him as the Future."

That night the boy goes to bed pondering his father's words. In the middle of the night he is woken by his baby brother crying, clearly wanting to have his nappy changed. He goes into his parents' bedroom and sees his mother fast asleep. He is unable to rouse her. He goes to the nanny's room and finds his father and the nanny making love. He tiptoes quietly out without being observed and goes back to bed.

At breakfast in the morning, the boy says to his father: "I was thinking about what you told me and I think I understand about politics now, dad." His gratified father looks up from his toast and asks, "Oh yes, how is that?" "Well," replies the boy, "Capitalism is screwing the Working Class. The Government is asleep. The People are being lied to and the Future is in deep shit."

If anyone could provide the origins of this story, which I have now seen in various forms, I am sure they will respond. As I discovered when writing about the National Rifle Association last week, this is a very responsive site.

fields.headline: Stone to face September retrial
fields.trailText: Michael Stone, whose convictions for the murders of mother and daughter Lin and Megan Russell were overturned last week, will face a second jury on the same charges in September, the court of appeal ruled today.
fields.body:
Michael Stone, whose convictions for the murders of mother and daughter Lin and Megan Russell were overturned last week, will face a second jury on the same charges in September, the court of appeal ruled today.

Three judges rejected submissions on Mr Stone's behalf that he could not have a fair retrial because of "prejudicial" publicity about him following his original trial at Maidstone crown court in 1998.

Mr Stone, 40, of Gillingham, Kent, was not present at the London courtroom as the court of appeal judges gave their reasons for ordering a retrial after quashing his 1998 convictions.

Lord Justice Kennedy, reading from a 15-page written judgment, said that the central question in a new trial - expected to start on September 3 in Birmingham - would not be Mr Stone's character, but whether the evidence of the key prosecution witness could be believed.

He said that, "in justice to the Russell family and the wider community", there should be a retrial to answer that question.

The judge said: "The retrial will not start until nearly three years after the October 1998 publicity, which is the principal target of complaint and people do forget. "Even if they do not forget entirely the passage of time makes it easier for them to set aside that which they are told to disregard."

Mr Stone was given three life sentences after being convicted of the two murders, and the attempted murder of Megan's sister, Josie, near their home at Chillenden, Kent, in 1996.

The judges ruled last week that Mr Stone's appeal "must succeed" on the basis of the unreliability of key prosecution witness Barry Thompson, who gave evidence at Mr Stone's trial alleging he had confessed to the killings in prison.

Lord Justice Kennedy said today that as a result of developments since the trial Thompson's evidence had been shown to be "hopelessly unreliable".

Mr Stone's counsel, William Clegg QC, had argued that he could not have a fair trial because of "prejudicial" material in the media following the original trial.

But Nigel Sweeney QC, for the crown, submitted that a fair trial was possible, saying: "We in the criminal courts invest juries with good sense, good judgment and an ability within the trial to put out of their minds anything they might have heard before."

fields.headline: Transfer talks end in 'agreement'
fields.standfirst: More about the transfer crisis
fields.trailText: Football's governing bodies and the European Commission have agreed some elements of a new player transfer system at a meeting in Brussels and have set an end-February deadline for any deal.
fields.body:
Football's governing bodies and the European Commission have agreed some elements of a new player transfer system at a meeting in Brussels and have set an end-February deadline for any deal.

At today's talks, between Fifa president Sepp Blatter, Uefa president Lennart Johansson and EU Commissioners Mario Monti, Viviane Reding and Anna Diamantopolou, an agreement was reached that players' contracts should be a minimum of one year and maximum of five years.

The EC also accepted, for the first time, that there is a need for "stability of contracts". This is seen as a victory by Fifa and Uefa, who have argued that allowing players to walk out on contracts at three months' notice would destabilise the whole game.

Afterwards the talks were hailed as a success by Fifa president Sepp Blatter, who said: "I am sure this was an historic day today."

"There is now a full agreement by Fifa and Uefa that we are near to a solution which will be beneficial to the whole world of football," he added.

His words who echoed by EC commissioner Monti, who told reporters: "At a meeting today, at the highest level, the European Commission, Fifa and Uefa firmly cemented an agreement on a significant number of issues related to the Fifa rules on the international transfers of footballers."

Monti said the talks set a political commitment to reach a final compromise by the end of the month.

Further "technical" talks between EU officials and football bodies, including players' union FIFpro, will take place in Brussels on Friday.

fields.body:
MR DERBY

Who is the only player to play in the Tottenham v Arsenal, Liverpool v Everton, Manchester City v United and Palace v Millwall derbies? asks Benjamin Wegg-Prosser

Paul Stewart's your man, his lumbering frame having been spotted spilling out of Manchester City, Tottenham, Liverpool and Crystal Palace shirts during local contretemps.

Stewart also yanked a Sunderland strip over his thorax - and no, the stripes weren't very flattering - so he's played in a Tyne and Wear derby as well. Why, he simply can't get enough of them.

HOME COMFORTS

Who are the only league team to have won every single home game in a season? asks Parminder Keilah

In the 1891/92 season, Sunderland were crowned champions after winning 13 out of 13 league games at home.

Their run? They beat Wolves (5-2), Everton (2-1), WBA (4-0), Accrington (4-1), Derby (7-1), Burnley (2-1), Notts County (4-0), Darwen (7-0), Bolton (4-1), Preston (4-1), Aston Villa (2-1), Stoke (4-1) and Blackburn (6-1).

Although they didn't win the Cup that year, they also won both ties staged at Roker, beating Notts County 3-0 and Stoke 4-0.

And you say Manchester United call Old Trafford a fortress?

NOT-SO-BORING DRAWS

"What was the highest ever drawn game in terms of goals scored?" asked Gary Ross.

Last week we dared you to advance on the two 5-5 draws we mentioned - click here - and you did not let us down.

Dave Perrett and Paul Smith both remember Tranmere's titanic 6-6 tussle with Newcastle in the Zenith Data Systems Cup, perhaps the Mickey Mouse of all Mickey Mouse Cup tournaments.

The game saw 12 goals, two hat-tricks (from Micky Quinn and John Aldridge), an amazing extra-time recovery from Newcastle (then managed by one Osvaldo Ardiles) as they came from 5-3 down to 6-5 up, as well as two penalties in the final minute of extra-time (the first to put Newcastle ahead, the next to put Tranmere level) before Tranmere finally won 3-2 in the penalty shoot-out.

This was one of the first games on Sky, and, as a producer at Sky commented after the match, "Things can only go downhill after this."

But Tranmere v Newcastle was only 3-3 after normal time, so for pure 6-6 draws you have to dig deeper into the archives. Patrick Morgan remembers that Arsenal drew 6-6 at Leicester five days before the 1930 FA Cup Final. "David Halliday scored four for the Gunners: some might say it was odd then that he was dropped for the game at Wembley," he says. Meanwhile, Pete Watt points out that in October 1960, Brian Clough scored a hat-trick during Middlesbrough's 6-6 draw at Charlton.

Finally, Paul McDonnell claims that in 1995 he saw an exhibition match between an all-German team and a Rest of the World XI that finished 9-9. "Kevin Keegan, Bobby Charlton, Platini and a very over-sized Eusebio were in the World XI," he says. "And Rummenigge, Gerd Muller and the Kaiser played for Germany.

"If you've ever seen your Dad play football, then you'll have a good idea what this game was like," he continues. "It finished 9-9 with Keegan very close to being sent off. From what I remember, Jean-Marie Pfaff (who had been in goal for the World XI) had to go home, so Charlton went in goals for penalties. I think Germany won."

FASTEST HAT-TRICK EVER

In a previous Knowledge - click here - we talked about the fastest ever hat-tricks in English football. Mark Redding, however, goes one better.

"I take it you know James O'Connor of Shelbourne FC, Dublin holds worlds fastest hat-trick record," he says. "He scored three goals in two minutes and 14 seconds during a league game between Bohemians and Shelbourne in 1967 - and what's more, his feat is recognised by the Guinness Book of Records."

THE (NEARLY) 92 CLUB

Having gone from First to Fourth Divisions in consecutive seasons, just how many of the League's 92 football grounds would a supporter of Wolves and Bristol City have visited if they had travelled to every away game (plus a game at home, of course) during that time? Which grounds would they have missed due to other teams being relegated or promoted at the same time? asks Kevin Chenoweth.

The following assumes that all the poor bastards supporting Bristol City and Wolves stuck around for the Fourth Division campaign, and hadn't previously thrown themselves off a high building.

City fans would have missed games at Leicester, Sunderland, Birmingham, Charlton, Rotherham, Barnsley, Sheffield United, Bradford, Wigan and Bournemouth.

Meanwhile, Wolves supporters would also have visited 81 away grounds out of 91. They missed trips to Chelsea, Sheffield Wednesday, Newcastle, Bradford, Millwall, Hull, Swindon, Chester, Mansfield and Port Vale.

FIRST OFF

"Who was the first footballer to be sent off for a professional foul?" asks Stuart Baxter.

We've had two claims for this dubious honour. Chris West reckons Lawrie Sanchez, scorer of the winning goal in the 1988 FA Cup Final between Wimbledon and Liverpool, was the first to march for blatant cheating. "Playing for Reading in the early 80s, he was sent off for a deliberate handball," he explains.

But John Murray isn't so sure. "I seem to remember at the beginning of the 80's John Lacy of Spurs being sent off at Goodison Park for tripping an Everton player on his way to goal," he writes. "I saw the incident on TV and recall that there was a lot of fuss made about this particular sending-off. Could this be the one?"

John also points out that the decision to award red cards for such fouls "came about largely because of the infamous Willie Young/Paul Allen incident during West Ham's victorious 1980 FA Cup Final appearance, when Young callously tripped Allen after he'd gone past him and was bearing down on the Arsenal goal."

CHANGING CAPTAINS

"After watching the recent Sunderland versus Manchester United game at the Stadium of Light where Sunderland used three different captains (one sent off and the second injured), I was wondering if this was a record or does it happen often? asks Gavin Munro.

Ben Homer says that during the 1986 World Cup game against Morocco, England had three captains in the same game. "Bryan Robson went off injured, Ray Wilkins took over but was sent off, so Peter Shilton took over," he says.

But as John Hudson points out, Sunderland actually used FOUR captains in the recent match against United. "The initial captain, Gray. was replaced by Schwarz after he was sent off (47m)," he says. "Schwarz himself gave way to Thome as part of a reshuffle following Rae's red card (52m). And Thome was then replaced as captain by Makin after quickly picking up an injury (58m)."

CAN YOU HELP?

"Why, if their nickname is The Hornets, do Watford have a moose on their club badge?" asks Martyn Amos.

"At the moment in Italy Christian Vieri's little brother Massimiliano and Roberto Baggio's little bro' Eddy are playing together for Serie B side Ancona. Are there any other younger brothers of big name players attempting to do likewise?" asks Martin Casey.

"Which team has provided the most England international players?" asks James McDonald. "I am told it is Aston Villa."

Send your answers to the.boss@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: News Corp shares soar
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Shares in Rupert Murdoch's News Corp have surged after analysts gave the thumbs-up to a merger with US broadcaster DirecTV. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Shares in Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation have surged after analysts gave the thumbs-up to its proposed merger with US satellite broadcaster DirecTV.

Influential Merrill Lynch analyst Jessica Reif Cohen upgraded the group's rating from "neutral" to "accumulate", following reports that a merger between News Corp's satellite TV operations and DirecTV was imminent.

"If accurate, we believe it would be positive for News Corp shareholders," said Ms Cohen.

News Corp shares rose nearly 4% to 720p in Australia following the issue of Ms Cohen's note.

Although DirecTV owner General Motors claimed a deal was not imminent, sources at News Corp say the merger with DirecTV and its holding company Hughes Electrics has been agreed in principle.

A successful deal will put Mr Murdoch in charge of a global satellite TV company that will include BSkyB in the UK, Star TV in Asia and DirecTV, which has nearly 10m subscribers in the US.

The newly formed company will be called Sky Global Networks.

Why modest PM shunned mighty Hercules

Graphic: see our fake attempt at how the pic might have looked
fields.trailText: He is a celebrated hero of Greek mythology, rendered by one of the renowned masters of baroque painting. But even such status, it seems, is no guarantee of landing a photo-opportunity with Tony Blair.
fields.body:
He is a celebrated hero of Greek mythology, rendered by one of the renowned masters of baroque painting. But even such status, it seems, is no guarantee of landing a photo-opportunity with Tony Blair.

The photographer attending the prime ministerial opening of the Royal Academy's exhibition The Genius of Rome was forbidden from taking pictures of Mr Blair in front of Annibale Carracci's painting Hercules at the Crossroads - because a Downing Street aide brandishing a tape measure ascertained that the prime minister's head would be in direct line with Hercules's penis.

According to the BBC political editor, Andrew Marr, works by Caravaggio were also banned from sharing a frame with Mr Blair because, as an official put it, "the prime minister will not be photographed in front of an androgynous youth".

Photographer James Peltekian was asked by Downing Street only to take group photographs with "art in the background", an academy spokeswoman confirmed. Downing Street spokesman Godric Smith said yesterday: "The prime minister would rather choose not to get into the anatomy of this particular story."

fields.headline: Volunteers or victims?
fields.standfirst: Concern grows over control of drug trials.
fields.trailText: Antonio Salvador Polizzi was a 60-year-old pen salesman with a heart problem. Three years ago, when he woke up in the early hours of the morning with chest pains, his family rushed him to the Pedro Mallo naval hospital, a huge blue edifice studded with portholes in the Buenos Aires suburbs which was supposed to be one of the city's finest.
fields.body:
Antonio Salvador Polizzi was a 60-year-old pen salesman with a heart problem. Three years ago, when he woke up in the early hours of the morning with chest pains, his family rushed him to the Pedro Mallo naval hospital, a huge blue edifice studded with portholes in the Buenos Aires suburbs which was supposed to be one of the city's finest.

Mr Polizzi never left the hospital. Five days later, on January 9 1998, he was dead. The family's distress was made all the more agonising by the fact that the hospital managed to lose his wedding ring, his watch and his clothes.

To the rest of the world rushing through the hospital's corridors it was just another hard-luck story of a man whose time had come. But it was much more than that. The nature of Mr Polizzi's death and the deaths of other heart patients at the naval hospital are at the centre of a scandal which has shocked the Argentinian medical community and raised ethical questions over the explosive growth of the pharmaceutical industry's role in Latin America and the rest of the developing world.

Six months after Mr Polizzi died, his widow, Aida, got a call from a state prosecutor, summoning her to his office. She thought it must be about the ring, but when the prosecutor told her what it was really about, she fainted. He said that her husband had been enrolled in a clinical trial for a new heart drug called cariporide. The family say this was without his knowledge. They have testified that the signature on the consent form was not his, and later tests have proved this according to the prosecutor who is still conducting his investigation.

Forged

"It was not even close. The handwriting was completely different," Andrea Polizzi, the dead man's 26-year-old daughter said.

At the date and time Mr Polizzi - the Argentinian representative for Cross pens - was supposed to have signed, he had been unconscious. He appeared to have had two separate clinical histories: one real, one forged, complete with bogus electrocardiograms which appear to have been taken from other patients' files.

The Corgiolu family have a similar story to tell. Luis Antonio Corgiolu, a 66-year-old technical college instructor, had gone to the hospital with chest pains, and died the next day. The doctors said he had had a hole in his aorta, and there was nothing they could do. Six months later, the Corgiolus got a call from the prosecutor's office and were shown a consent form for the cariporide trial with Luis's name on it.

"But it wasn't his," Martin, his eldest son said. "He always signed with his nickname, Lucho. This was his full name."

When prosecutors looked at the consent forms for all 137 patients at the hospital who had been part of the trial, they found evidence that 80% of them had been forged. The files were also filled with duplicated electrocardiograms. The hospital says it will press charges against the accused doctors.

Doctors had been offered $2,700 (£1,900) for each person they recruited for the trial by cariporide's German-based manufacturers, Hoechst Marion Roussel. The family's claim that in pursuit of the cash, criteria set by the manufacturers for who should be included in the trial were ignored.

At least 13 people included in the trials between 1997 and 1998 died. The chief prosecutor, Lucio Herrera, believes he has sufficient evidence to prove that three of the deaths were caused by the drug or the way it was administered. The evidence is likely to be hotly contested if and when the case finally comes to trial.

No formal charges have yet been made, and there is no suggestion that Hoechst (now part of French-based Aventis Pharma), nor the US contractor it hired to carry out its Argentinian trials, Quintiles Transnational, were in any way responsible. Both Hoechst and Quintiles spotted irregularities in the spring of 1998 and alerted the hospital and the Argentinian authorities.

But the case nevertheless demonstrates the dangers involved in the rapid expansion of clinical trials in Latin America, Africa and Asia. As increasing numbers of experimental drugs are emerging from the laboratories of Europe and the US, amid increasing pressure to deliver instant cures, the pharmaceutical companies are running out of suitable patients to act as guinea pigs in their home countries. The developing world is virgin territory, with millions of potential subjects. And in most cases they are being used to test medicines aimed not at them, but at the lucrative markets of the first world.

In its May 2000 edition, CenterWatch, a newsletter for the burgeoning clinical trials business, published an exuberant article under the title Latin American Fever in which it said the continent "may offer a unique opportunity to reach much larger numbers of study subjects."

The pattern is replicated across the developing world. One of the world's top five drug companies, Eli Lilly, tested 590 patients in 1994 across Africa, the middle east and central and eastern Europe. This year the company expects to run tests in those regions on 7,309 patients.

There are fears that this mushrooming of third world trials is leading to a loosening of the tight regulations that exist in the west. Recent US-government funded studies in Africa designed to show the effectiveness of the anti-Aids drug, AZT, in preventing the transmission of HIV from mother to infant during pregnancy, included a placebo group - a practice that would have been unacceptable in the US or Europe. AZT has been proven to save lives and so the denial of the drug to trial participants would not have been considered ethical.

Concerned doctors attempted to persuade the US National Bioethics Advisory Board last November to establish rules so that US government-funded medical research would have to be overseen by a US review board, but the attempt failed, leaving international controls on the drug trial business patchy.

Clinical trials

In Buenos Aires, Luis Zieher, head of the medical ethics committee, said that eight years ago, his panel used to appraise three to four proposed drug trials a month. Now it examines up to 20 a month.

There were about 200 clinical trials in Argentina last year, each one with up to two dozen different test sites (the naval hospital was only one of 26 Argentinian sites in the cariporide trials). Across Latin America there were more than 1,000 trials, according to Daniel Campos, an Argentinian oncologist whose company, Salud Uno, puts drug companies in touch with doctors interested in conducting trials. He said that number would increase tenfold in the next two years.

"This is reasonable," Dr Campos said. "We have a huge population, in big cities, so it could be done. But we are also developing countries so we have big inefficiencies, so accidents can occur."

The appearance before Christmas of a report on the scandal in the Washington Post caused outrage in Buenos Aires.

Norberto Pallavicini, a senior official at Anmat (the National Administration of Medicine, Food and Medical Technology) which oversees clinical trials, pointed out: "Our medical facilities are recognised as the most important in Latin America. The trials are coming here because Argentina has credibility and the highest level of medical knowledge."

Anmat has 30 full-time medical inspectors who have the reputation of being the best on the continent, but even he con cedes that his organisation is facing an "explosion" in the number of trials: "We are not going to be able to supervise all the trials on a permanent basis."

The doctor supervising the cariporide trials, Luis Garre, has been sacked by the hospital, but claims that he is innocent. In an interview with the Guardian at his flat, he said: "I've been morally and professionally devastated.I've been left without work, and I've had to take the blows."

Dr Garre denies cariporide was responsible for any deaths. It had been intended to limit damage to the heart after episodes of angina or bypass surgery, but the worldwide tests, involving more than 11,500 patients in 23 countries, showed little benefit.

They also showed it to be safe when administered to patients with the targeted conditions.

An Aventis spokeswoman, Lori Kraut, said that although the trials were called off, "there were no safety issues in the discontinuation of the drug". It is currently being tested for other possible medical uses.

She insisted that doctors in the developing world were no more likely to break the rules than their counterparts anywhere else.

Tomorrow: How drug companies bestow their favours on British doctors - the last in the series.

In its May 2000 edition, CenterWatch, a newsletter for the burgeoning clinical trials business, published an exuberant article under the title Latin American Fever in which it said the continent "may offer a unique opportunity to reach much larger numbers of study subjects." The pattern is replicated across the developing world. One of the world's top five drug companies, Eli Lilly, tested 590 patients in 1994 across Africa, the middle east and central and eastern Europe. This year the company expects to run tests in those regions on 7,309 patients. There are fears that this mushrooming of third world trials is leading to a loosening of the tight regulations that exist in the west. Recent US-government funded studies in Africa designed to show the effectiveness of the anti-Aids drug, AZT, in preventing the transmission of HIV from mother to infant during pregnancy, included a placebo group - a practice that would have been unacceptable in the US or Europe. AZT has been proven to save lives and so the denial of the drug to trial participants would not have been considered ethical. Concerned doctors attempted to persuade the US National Bioethics Advisory Board last November to establish rules so that US government-funded medical research would have to be overseen by a US review board, but the attempt failed, leaving international controls on the drug trial business patchy. Clinical trials In Buenos Aires, Luis Zieher, head of the medical ethics committee, said that eight years ago, his panel used to appraise three to four proposed drug trials a month. Now it examines up to 20 a month. There were about 200 clinical trials in Argentina last year, each one with up to two dozen different test sites (the naval hospital was only one of 26 Argentinian sites in the cariporide trials). Across Latin America there were more than 1,000 trials, according to Daniel Campos, an Argentinian oncologist whose company, Salud Uno, puts drug companies in touch with doctors interested in conducting trials. He said that number would increase tenfold in the next two years. "This is reasonable," Dr Campos said. "We have a huge population, in big cities, so it could be done. But we are also developing countries so we have big inefficiencies, so accidents can occur." The appearance before Christmas of a report on the scandal in the Washington Post caused outrage in Buenos Aires. Norberto Pallavicini, a senior official at Anmat (the National Administration of Medicine, Food and Medical Technology) which oversees clinical trials, pointed out: "Our medical facilities are recognised as the most important in Latin America. The trials are coming here because Argentina has credibility and the highest level of medical knowledge." Anmat has 30 full-time medical inspectors who have the reputation of being the best on the continent, but even he con cedes that his organisation is facing an "explosion" in the number of trials: "We are not going to be able to supervise all the trials on a permanent basis." The doctor supervising the cariporide trials, Luis Garre, has been sacked by the hospital, but claims that he is innocent. In an interview with the Guardian at his flat, he said: "I've been morally and professionally devastated.I've been left without work, and I've had to take the blows." Dr Garre denies cariporide was responsible for any deaths. It had been intended to limit damage to the heart after episodes of angina or bypass surgery, but the worldwide tests, involving more than 11,500 patients in 23 countries, showed little benefit. They also showed it to be safe when administered to patients with the targeted conditions. An Aventis spokeswoman, Lori Kraut, said that although the trials were called off, "there were no safety issues in the discontinuation of the drug". It is currently being tested for other possible medical uses. She insisted that doctors in the developing world were no more likely to break the rules than their counterparts anywhere else. webTitle: Saudis open a can of words

fields.headline: Saudis open a can of words
fields.standfirst: Cracking down on corruption can produce a host of new problems, as Brian Whitaker explains
fields.trailText: Cracking down on corruption can produce a host of new problems, as Brian Whitaker explains.
fields.body:
Many people in Dubai were shocked this week by news that the Gulf emirate's head of customs had been arrested on corruption charges, along with two of his most senior aides.

The shock is not that the three men are accused of systematically creaming off tens of millions of dollars in bribes but that the crown prince, after a two-year investigation, has cracked down on such prominent officials.

Dr Obaid Saqr bin-Busit, the customs chief, is not only a well-known figure in Dubai, but also a man of some standing internationally: last July he was elected chairman of the Brussels-based World Customs Organisation for a three-year term.

In the Middle East, people are accustomed to a certain flexibility when it comes to customs duties and almost any other kind of government-imposed restrictions.

People who belong to important families often regard themselves as above the rules, while others with less influence but sufficient money can have the rules bent by paying officials.

Occasionally, however, something disrupts this cosy little system.

Last summer, for instance, customs officials in Bahrain searched the cargo of a plane that was about to leave for Saudi Arabia. It belonged to a Saudi prince and, by the rules of Gulf etiquette, the officials had no business prying.

Apologies followed and the plane took off, somewhat later than scheduled.

But what the customs officials had found was interesting: 200 cases of whisky that, in the puritanical kingdom, could be sold under the counter for around $300,000 (£206,033).

In most countries, customs officials would probably not insist on kings, presidents, popes and prime ministers opening up their bags for inspection, but in Saudi Arabia and much of the Gulf, the number of VIPs who expect special treatment is enormous.

There are, for a start, about 5,000 Saudi princes. It is difficult to see why they should all be entitled to royal privileges and why anyone should be spared the indignity of a search simply because they are in the entourage of someone who happens to be 4,723rd in line to the throne.

The justification for these privileges is closely linked to the concept of honour - an essential part of Arab culture. To check a VIP at an airport for concealed weapons or contraband is to call into question his honour, even though there is ample evidence that such privileges are sometimes abused.

The hijacking of a Saudi plane to Baghdad last October may be a case in point.

Although the details are still unclear, it appears that the hijackers took advantage of the double standards applied in security checks to get their weapons on board.

A further window into this murky world of privilege and bribery has been opened up by the arrest in Saudi Arabia of some 15 foreigners who are variously accused of alcohol offences, terrorism and murder.

Three men - a Briton, a Belgian and a Canadian were recently paraded on Saudi television confessing to two car bombings last November that killed one Briton and injured several others.

Five Britons and four Americans (including one with intelligence connections) are among the others detained for alleged alcohol offences.

With the possible exception of three Americans, all appear to know each other and to have been involved, one way or another, in a series of illicit drinking dens in the capital, Riyadh.

The Saudi interior minister, Prince Nayef, has been at pains to point out that no Saudis are involved.

The basic outline of the case (according to the Saudis) is that here were a group of foreigners engaged in illegal alcohol activities who got into some dubious business transactions - buying and selling stakes in their drinking dens - then fell out and started attacking each other.

The televised confessions were certainly odd enough to cast doubt on their veracity but, either way, there is plainly a lot more to the story than has so far been disclosed.

Prohibition of alcohol - as the US found in the early years of the 20th century - is extremely difficult to enforce, even in a puritanical country such as Saudi Arabia.

The country's economy depends on foreign workers - labourers from poor countries in Asia and Africa, but also skilled westerners. Many of the westerners are happy to go there, attracted by generous tax-free salaries, or seeking to escape debts or personal problems back home.

There are around 25,000 Britons living and working in the kingdom. Discouraged from mixing with the Saudis, they live in compounds with other expatriates and quickly become bored, drinking to pass the time.

Possibly the illegality of alcohol in the kingdom adds a certain frisson of excitement that is not to be found by visiting a pub in Britain.

The Saudis, meanwhile, recognise that it's necessary, up to a point, to tolerate these western habits.

Although the religious police (the mutawwa) take a much tougher line than the ordinary police, the general approach is not to persecute drinkers who keep their activities to themselves and don't attract attention.

But this raises the question of how to keep such large numbers of foreigners supplied with illegal alcohol. At one level, there is home brewing and some distilling, but that is basically a cottage industry and not enough to meet the demand.

Smuggling of spirits - mainly whisky and gin - has become big business and most of it is said to pass through customs under the protection of royal privilege.

Successful smuggling also depends on the existence of a distribution system and retail outlets - all of them technically illegal in the kingdom.

What began with private drinks parties in people's homes therefore developed, eventually, into commercial-scale establishments resembling what, in Britain, would be regarded as pubs or clubs.

The man credited with turning illicit drinking dens into a business is a Briton called Gary Dixon (also known as Gary Lyons and Gary O'Nions), who has just completed a short jail sentence in Dubai for crossing the border illegally and is now awaiting extradition back to Saudi Arabia.

Although his Empire Club in Riyadh was busted three times by the religious police over a period of six years, Mr Dixon appears to have led something of a charmed life in Saudi Arabia.

Former members of the club believe this was because his Saudi sponsor and a senior police officer received a share of the profits from the club.

During his enforced leisure in Dubai, Mr Dixon wrote a book about his exploits on scraps of paper which have now been smuggled back to Britain, and he is looking for a publisher.

This may well cast light on matters reaching far beyond Saudi Arabia's expatriate community.

In the meantime, Prince Nayef's claims that the alcohol-and-bombs affair involves only foreigners is beginning to look a little thin. The arrests have certainly opened a can of worms.

The question now is whether the prince will proceed to a more far-reaching clean-up, with all the embarrassment that that entails, or whether he will take the easier course and slam the lid back on.

fields.headline: Jobs axed in Puremix restructure
fields.trailText: 1pm: Internet radio start-up Puremix is being brought under the wing of its parent group Chrysalis, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Internet radio start-up Puremix is being brought under the wing of its parent group Chrysalis in a move that is expected to lead to the loss of more than 20 jobs.

Lisa Gordon, chief executive of Chrysalis New Media, confirmed that Puremix was to be integrated into the larger umbrella group.

"We are not stepping back from our investment. But we want to integrate it into a more centralised infrastructure in order to minimise costs and share resources," Ms Gordon said.

Insiders said 20 of the 31 Puremix staff have been put on three-month redundancy notice.

Ms Gordon confirmed that "a number" of jobs would be lost but said it would be "unfair" to comment on individual employee circumstances.

"We are going through a consultation process with staff to see where there is duplication with the Chrysalis group," she added.

Ms Gordon denied the consolidation had been precipitated by Puremix's failure to attract second-round funding.

"We were talking to some strategic investors on the marketing and business development side, but these had no impact on Chrysalis' decision," she said.

She added that the Puremix technology had been a success and said Chrysalis was committed to developing it.

Puremix, which launched late last year, utilises internet personalisation technology to choose the radio stream closest to the user's preference.

In addition to Puremix, Chrysalis's new media businesses include black music site Darkerthanblue.com and sports site rivals.net.

Next month it is due to launch local information portal citypages.com.

http://www.societytheguardian.com

News: Anger over paedophile sentences

Leading children's charities have united to condemn the leniency of sentences handed down to members of a global child pornography ring for distributing more than 750,000 images of child sex abuse.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/voluntary

Local government: Crisis council 'the next Hackney'

An Essex council has been branded "the next Hackney" in the wake of a damning auditor's draft report.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/localgovt

Health: NHS finance director appointed

Former senior Department of Health finance manager Richard Douglas is the new NHS director of finance.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/health

Social care: Judges order jail death inquest

The family of a young paranoid schizophrenic who hanged himself with his shoelaces while on remand in Wandsworth prison won an order for a new inquest yesterday. The prison was criticised for failing to take steps to prevent his death.

More social care news: National charity to administer £70m anti-poverty fund

The Community Foundation Network has been given the job of administering the £70m anti-poverty local children's fund network, the government announced today.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/socialcare

Careers: Ministers to scrap retirement age

The over-60s will be able to escape the poverty of old age under anti-discrimination laws which will make it illegal to ban them from working as long as they like.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/careers

Mental health charities have called for a wider range of employment schemes to help service users into work, after a report warned that people with mental health problems are further isolated by poverty.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/socialcare

Health: Marlboro may end Formula One backing

The government has received a massive symbolic boost to its anti-smoking campaign after one of the world's biggest tobacco brands suggested it may withdraw from Formula One sponsorship.

http://www.societytheguardian.com/health

William Hague was last night forced to admit to making misleading claims that he distributes the profits from public speaking engagements to a charitable trust which has never actually been estalished in law.

webTitle: The making of The Emperor's New Groove

fields.headline: Llama drama
fields.standfirst: It took six years, two directors and starred a talking llama. No wonder Disney's latest film is a disaster, says Danny Leigh
fields.trailText: It took six years, two directors and starred a talking llama. No wonder Disney's latest film is a disaster, says Danny Leigh
fields.body:
For children across America, Christmas 2000 came tied in and branded. Whether Santa delivered a Rugrats "snuggle blanket", a 102 Dalmatians-themed salt shaker or a plastic waffle toaster bearing the lurid imprint of The Grinch, something tacky and movie-related would routinely be sitting under the tree. Unless, that is, they expected spin-offs from The Emperor's New Groove, a boisterous animated comedy set in a mythic South American province. Because, in a business where success is measured in merchandise, Disney's latest cartoon romp barely even registered. No snuggle blanket; no waffle toaster. Just a computer game, storybook and soundtrack - the last (in essence) half a new album by Sting.

Not, sadly, that anyone wanted them anyway. Despite a release date of December 17 - with the promise of repeat visits by fractious kids during the school holidays - The Emperor's New Groove had, by Christmas day, already bombed. And then it bombed some more. And now, two months later, there is a $20m shortfall on its $100m budget, cementing the film's status as the present the American public didn't bother opening. This has a particular bathos, for the film was in development for six years, during which executives dithered, directors broke down, pop stars fumed, and a work-in-progress lay discarded in the cutting room, leaving observers wondering if Disney had finally lost the plot.

Amid the bungling, even the title - that meaningless, off-putting title - was a botch, selected only as the least awful of the alternatives. Disney had already got rid of the original title Kingdom of the Sun, when the film began to resemble less and less its original conception, a loose reworking of Mark Twain's The Prince and the Pauper, set among the ancient Incas.

But back in early 1995 the movie had looked the very safest of bets, particularly when veteran animator Roger Allers signed up as director. After all, Allers was a man with a name for commercial hits, the man who had recently taken a moribund screenplay called The Lion King and turned it into a massive success story.

Which may be why Disney's then chairman Michael Eisner gave Allers such an unusually free rein with both the casting and the storyline. The movie was to be punctuated by eight musical offerings from Sting (hired on condition that his film-maker wife Trudie Styler could document the process), and Twain's story remained central to Allers's vision, its main characters the arrogant young royal Manco (voiced by comic actor David Spade) and humble lookalike Pacha (the fast-rising Owen Wilson). From there, however, the film took some distinctly arcane turns, veering into an involved sub-plot concerning an evil sorceress named Yzma and a self- consciously allegorical plan to steal the sun. Manco, by this stage, had turned into a talking llama. Obviously.

The response at test screenings was tepid. Yet the mantra echoing through Disney's Burbank headquarters appeared to be: "Remember The Lion King". Busily sealing tie-ins with McDonald's and scheduling a release in the far-off summer of 2000, Disney remained convinced that, given enough time, Allers would turn up trumps once more.

Until, inevitably, it changed its mind. It was now 1998. Allers was crawling towards completion; and, most importantly, Disney's follow-ups to The Lion King (the inane Pocahontas and ill-fated Hunchback of Notre Dame) had flopped. The studio had certainly done well in the meantime - but only thanks to its distribution deal with the recently formed Pixar, the company whose debut was the inspired Toy Story. It was decided that Allers's team needed an infusion of the zany. Enter Mark Dindal, a fresh-faced animator with a yen for slapstick. And so, over the next few weeks, the pair worked in tandem - Allers piling on the portent, Dindal churning out sequences as peppy as his colleague's were sober. The relationship couldn't last.

The end came late that summer, when an executive strode into producer Randy Fullmer's office, held his thumb and index finger a quarter of an inch apart, and muttered - with the warmth studio executives are famous for - "Your film is this far away from being shut down". Shaken, Fullmer called Allers. Equally shaken, Allers demanded a deadline extension. The request was denied, and he quit the project. Upon hearing the news, an apoplectic Eisner gave Fullmer two weeks to prove the movie was viable.

In a state of panic, Fullmer and Dindal set to work. They eviscerated Allers's screenplay, keeping in what test audiences had liked and abandoning what they didn't. And, mostly, what they didn't like was the whole thing. A fortnight later, Dindal re-emerged with the outline of a mildly hip buddy movie, in which Pacha was now a slobbish yokel voiced by John Goodman and the sun stayed firmly where it was. Manco, meanwhile, had been renamed Kuzco following Fullmer's horrified discovery of the Japanese slang term omanco (polite translation: vagina). He still turned into a llama. Eisner, with $25m already sunk into the film, swallowed his reservations and gave it the green light. Again.

The fun didn't end there. It would take another six months to get the retitled Emperor's New Groove back in production. A deadline extension was now granted to Dindal, with Disney's prehistoric epic Dinosaur yanked forward to summer 2000 to compensate. And then there was the Sting problem - that, with most of the original movie gone, all his songs except one were suddenly surplus to requirements. The call was not one Fullmer was looking forward to. He would surely have looked forward to it even less had he known Trudie Styler would be filming her husband just as the phone rang. The subsequent exchange soon became the centrepiece of Styler's documentary The Sweatbox, about to open in the US and prove for the record which is more tempting to audiences: an "angry and perturbed" Sting being dispatched, or a talking llama.

And finally the film was ready. The reviews, unexpectedly, were good. Since it was released in direct competition with Disney's own 102 Dalmatians, the box office receipts were not. At the end of its opening week, The Emperor's New Groove banked just over $9m. The Grinch, by comparison, made $55m in its first seven days. It was the studio's worst-performing animation in four years. The last holder of that record, Hercules, had cost $30m less to make.

Which only leaves the post-mortems. Within days of the film's opening, the industry was alive with whispers that the wrong Kingdom of the Sun had been given the go-ahead; that both versions were doomed by the incompetence of middle- management; and that the real reason Allers's grandiose vision was ditched had nothing to do with release dates and everything to do with smaller budgets.

And, most damagingly, the perfectionist, money-no-object Disney, which revolutionised movie animation with Fantasia and its ilk, was discredited. So, as The Emperor's New Groove arrives in the UK, spare a thought for Roger Allers, for Mark Dindal, and even for Sting. And be sure to listen out for Uncle Walt spinning furiously in his grave.

fields.headline: Gerbeau sets Dome bid deadline
fields.standfirst: Special report: Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Former Millennium Dome chief executive Pierre-Yves Gerbeau today gave the government a 48-hour deadline to consider his plan to use the attraction as an international entertainment venue and world class visitor attraction.
fields.body:
Former Millennium Dome chief executive Pierre-Yves Gerbeau today gave the government a 48-hour deadline to consider his plan to use the structure as an international entertainment venue and world class visitor attraction.

He made his announcement as ministers continued to dither on a final decision about the £125m bid by the Legacy Consortium, who plan to turn the Greenwich site into "Knowledge City", a hi-tech business centre.

Mr Gerbeau called on the government to make the choice on business-based criteria. He told GMTV: "I think the government need to look at this as a business. Let's stop the political story around the dome, this has dragged on far too long."

He said the situation reminded him "of the British Rail story - a quick, cheap sale, and then you turn around and regret it".

He continued: "We are frustrated about the way it's going on, and it is now time to reopen the bid process and give the dome a real chance."

Mr Gerbeau and his backers were talking to promoters who were excited about the concept of staging boxing matches, such as Lennox Lewis against Mike Tyson, he said. "It could be a top international entertainment venue, and, during the day, a world class visitor attraction."

He confirmed that he would only wait two days for a government decision. "I have to look at other opportunities, I've been very happy to be the dome man for a long year, but I am a business person and have to look at business opportunities."

It had been expected that ministers would set a deadline of today to agree the Legacy bid but Downing Street yesterday denied this. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, Mr Gerbeau criticised this inefficiency as not part of the "normal commercial environment".

Liberal Democrat dome spokesman Norman Baker said: "The government is skating on thin ice by dragging out is discussions with the Legacy consortium. Until now, it has been assumed that Pierre-Yves Gerbeau will be there to pick up the pieces if Legacy pulls out of the proposed deal."

"In the light of Mr Gerbeau's comments it is now vital that the cabinet sticks to the original timetable for the Legacy deal. Otherwise it faces the prospect of an empty dome come election day."

webTitle: Pepsi out of Premier League bidding

fields.headline: Pepsi rules itself out of Premier League sponsorship race
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Pepsi is out of the bidding to be the new sponsor of the Premier League, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Pepsi has confirmed it is out of the bidding to be the new sponsor of the Premier League.

"While the Premier League is a great property, we are not involved in the bidding," a Pepsi spokesman said.

"We are already well-covered in that sector by our partnership with Manchester United and our association with global stars like David Beckham who appears in our upcoming advertisements."

The news will come as another blow to the Premier League after Anheuser-Busch brand Budweiser, seen as a front-runner to take over the £20m title sponsorship from Carling, confirmed it was also not bidding. Carling pulled out of negotiations to renew its deal a month ago, blaming "protracted" negotiations. But the company has since expressed interest in going back to the negotiation table.

The Premier League maintains it is in the final stages of negotiating a deal and that five companies are involved.

The body denies speculation within the sports marketing industry that some of the league's top clubs are opposed to a title sponsor.

Sources said some of the league's member clubs believe a title sponsor clashes with their own sponsorship deals from which they can raise significant amounts of money.

Clubs split the Premier League title sponsorship money equally.

fields.headline: Tiberio Mitri
fields.standfirst: Italian boxing hero whose second career in films failed to save him from a tragic end
fields.trailText: Italian boxing hero whose second career in films failed to save him from a tragic end
fields.body:
Boxing champions all too frequently fall on hard times once the sound of the crowd has faded, yet the grim decline of Tiberio Mitri, the former European middleweight champion, who has been killed aged 74 after being run over by a train, was particularly tragic.

The elegant Italian, whose suave good looks earned him a role in the 1959 Hollywood blockbuster Ben-Hur, as well as the hand of a former Miss Italy, never recovered from the deaths of his son and daughter, suffered severe financial hardship and was living in squalor among Rome's homeless community at the time of his death.

The one-time "Trieste Tiger" had suffered from Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases, as well as hearing problems, and may never have heard the approaching train which killed him. Yet half a century ago he was the toast of his countrymen after surviving 15 hard rounds against "the Bronx Bull", Jake La Motta, in a world middleweight title challenge at New York's Madison Square Garden.

As far as British fans are concerned, Mitri, who lost just six times in a 99-fight career, will best be remembered for his 65-second annihilation of Randolph Turpin at Rome's Stadia Torino in May 1954. Turpin, who had captured the European crown with a first-round knockout of the Dutchman Luc van Dam three years earlier, was himself poleaxed by Mitri's first punch - a booming left hook to the head.

According to one observer, the champion "fell like a log", striking his head hard on the boards and, despite struggling desperately to regain his balance, eventually had to be rescued by the referee. The 27,000-strong crowd, which had anticipated a hard-fought contest, appeared similarly dazed.

A month later, Mitri travelled to London and was surprisingly outpointed by Bristol's Gordon Hazell in a non-title contest. Soon afterwards, he gained revenge by stopping Hazell in six rounds in Rome. The westcountryman, by strange coincidence, died last week at the age of 72.

In July 1950, Mitri secured that unexpected world title shot against La Motta, after the Frenchman Marcel Cerdan died in an air crash on his way to a return match with the legendary New Yorker. Although Mitri was outpointed, he was a good enough fighter to twice hold the European middleweight belt, which he first seized by outpointing the Belgian Cyrille Delannoit. He was also remarkably resilient, his 1954 third-round stoppage defeat against Frenchman Charles Humez being one of only two occasions he failed to go the distance.

Yet the gallant loss against La Motta was to have dire repercussions for Mitri. He weathered the champion's fiercest onslaughts, only to suffer his most crippling blow outside the ropes. He had been accompanied to the US by his wife Fulvia Franco, a former beauty queen who herself harboured ambitions of a Hollywood career. When he lost, she left him, and Mitri was inconsolable.

Having ceded his European crown to Humez, Mitri fought on until 1956, by which time his own budding film career held more appeal. After Ben-Hur (1959), he appeared with David Niven in The Best of Enemies (1961), and featured in the all-star cast of the second world war epic, Anzio (1968), as well as countless Italian films.

Although he remarried, and continued to enjoy modest success in the film world during the 1960s, personal happiness proved elusive. His son Alessandro died of a drugs overdose, and his daughter Tiberia also died young. He developed a drink problem and often failed to recognise old friends.

By now a shadow of his former self, Mitri saved his most poignant screen appearance until last. In Pugili (Boxers, 1995), he played an aged former boxer reflecting on the high and lows of his career.

John Francis Lane writes: Tiberio Mitri appeared in 30 or so films between 1952 and 1995. Blond and blue-eyed, like many in his native Trieste, he had the makings of a romantic hero, but in most of his early films he was a pirate or a boxer. When Michelangelo Antonioni wanted him to play the lead in Il Grido (the part taken by Steve Cochran), he turned it down, saying: "I don't like the idea of playing a cuckold."

In the 1950s, Mitri app-eared in many films, mostly Italian potboilers, though he played small roles in Charles Vidor's A Farewell to Arms (1957), Wyler's Ben-Hur and Mario Monicelli's Venice Golden Lion winner, La Grande Guerra (1959). He was a fringe player in the Roman dolce vita scene, but in Un uomo facile (An Easy Man, 1959), he was back in the ring with a popular Roman macho star of the moment, Maurizio Arena, who stole the limelight.

Mitri never became a star himself, even though he appeared in films directed by Martin Ritt, Michael Cacoyannis, Bernard Wicki and Mario Bava, among others, and tried every genre made in those years, from spaghetti westerns to peplum spectaculars. His last film, Pugili, a touching directorial debut by the actor Lino Capolicchio, focused on two teenagers who want to become boxers and are trained by a veteran - played by Mitri.

Tiberio Mitri, boxer and actor, born July 12 1926; died February 12 2001

fields.headline: Trinity Mirror considers IC24 sell-off
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Trinity Mirror is conducting a review that could lead to the sale of its internet provider IC24, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Trinity Mirror is reported to be conducting a group-wide strategic review, which could lead to the sale of its internet service provider IC24.

Shareholders are believed to be concerned that the new media arm, Trinity Mirror Digital Media, has not yet delivered on its new media strategy.

This is despite being on the receiving end of a £150m three-year investment.

But analysts have cast doubt on a sale of the IC Network, which houses IC24 and websites such as ICBirmingham and ICShowbiz.

Nicola Stewart, media analyst at Commerzbank, said this was an illogical move because it was still very early days for the IC Network.

"IC24 is a very sensible strategy, particularly with its regional content," she said.

"It makes no sense to sell off valuable assets that build on Trinity Mirror's core services."

Trinity Mirror is thought to be looking at different options for spinning off IC24, which has almost 700,000 subscribers.

The ISP has become something of a cash drain.

It became locked into the provision of free internet calls and has been questioned by shareholders for being inconsistent with the accepted new media strategy of a newspaper group.

Trinity Mirror has to prove to analysts that it has bedded down after it was formed from the merger of Trinity and the Mirror Group 18 months ago.

The ongoing strategic review will be presented to the board in mid-March.

It is also expected to look at potential acquisitions and divestments to revive Trinity Mirror's flagging share price.

Potential options are thought to include the disposal of its trade magazines and exhibitions business.

It is also considering forming commercial ties with other media companies, particularly those focused on regional radio.

webTitle: Bannister returns with DJ talent agency

fields.headline: Bannister returns with DJ talent agency
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Former BBC marketing chief Matthew Bannister has resurfaced heading up a talent agency for dance music DJs, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Matthew Bannister, the former Radio 1 controller and BBC director of marketing, has resurfaced as the chairman and chief executive of a new talent company for dance music DJs.

Mr Bannister, who left the BBC late last year after quitting his senior marketing post, will work alongside Lynn Cosgrave, the former vice-president of Sony Music UK, to launch Trust the DJ early this summer.

Trust the DJ was co-founded by Ms Cosgrave and Tammy Smulders and has already signed 60 DJs, including the Dreem Team, Goldie, Brandon Block and Gilles Peterson.

The company will act as a talent management company, as well as producing DJ compilations, setting up websites for the DJs on its roster and delivering dance music via the internet.

"Trust The DJ is an exciting new company, which will use online and offline media to spread the dance message worldwide," Mr Bannister said.

"A brilliant roster of DJs and a young creative team will give us the edge in developing the music and DJs into new areas and markets."

Ms Cosgrave added: "Matthew has already led a successful revolution at Radio 1 and I know working together we can do the same for dance music."

Mr Bannister's departure from the BBC four months ago prompted speculation about his reasons for quitting the corporation, but he has always insisted it was simply time for a change.

He held a diverse range of jobs during a 22-year career at the corporation, from overseeing the relaunch of Radio London as GLR, to controller of Radio 1 and chief executive of BBC Production.

He was also one of the candidates for the BBC director general's job that went to Greg Dyke in June 1999.

Mr Bannister's departure from the BBC four months ago prompted speculation about his reasons for quitting the corporation, but he has always insisted it was simply time for a change. fields.headline: 'Anna' email virus wreaks havoc
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Anna Kournikova, the 19-year-old Russian tennis player, succeeded yesterday where countless hackers had failed, bringing chaos to large parts of the internet in the form of a highly infectious computer virus.
fields.body:
Anna Kournikova, the 19-year-old Russian tennis player, succeeded yesterday where countless hackers had failed, bringing chaos to large parts of the internet in the form of a highly infectious computer virus.

Twice as many email users were tempted by a message purporting to contain a photograph of Kournikova, but in reality a cover for a virus, than were taken in last year by a similar virus masquerading as a love letter.

The Kournikova virus, which caused logjams in corporate email systems throughout the US and Europe yesterday, presents itself as an email containing the message "Hi: Check This!", along with what appears to be a picture file.

When users attempt to open the non-existent picture on systems using the Microsoft Outlook email program, the virus copies itself to every name in their email address book, causing no permanent damage but slowing the transmission of emails to a crawl.

Inexplicably, the virus also automatically connects infected computers to a Dutch shopping website every January 26.

Alex Shipp of MessageLabs in Gloucester, which specialises in battling viruses, said the virus was spreading twice as fast as the Love Bug, which last year deleted files belonging to 100m internet users. His company had intercepted 12,778 copies of the virus from 3,087 email addresses, 2,020 companies and 29 countries. The virus is thought to be derived from a script written by a notorious Argentine hacker, codenamed Kalamar.

"We're looking at many millions of people affected in the US and at least a million in Europe," said David Perry, a technologist at the computer security firm Trend Micro.

"This virus is clever - not just because it promises to show Anna Kournikova, but because it was released on a Monday when everyone was going back to work - which is where the big email address lists are."

webTitle: Mayor avoids talking to the Hands

fields.headline: Mayor avoids talking to the Hands
fields.trailText: Greg Hands is an ambitious man. He's only been a councillor since 1998, yet already he harbours dreams of running the London borough of Hammersmith and Fulham. Attacks on the work of the Labour administration and its executive mayor, Andrew Slaughter, are all part of his strategy.
fields.body:
Greg Hands is an ambitious man. He's only been a councillor since 1998, yet already he harbours dreams of running the London borough of Hammersmith and Fulham. Attacks on the work of the Labour administration and its executive mayor, Andrew Slaughter, are all part of his strategy.

Summing up his objections to the current regime, Mr Hands comments: "The Labour council in Hammersmith and Fulham is disastrous for the people of the borough. They have one of the highest council taxes in London, they deliver very poor services and oversee massive waste and inefficiency."

The roots of this particular bust-up lie three years ago, when Mr Slaughter became the first person in the country to take on the "executive mayor" job title. The move was part of a wave of political reform implemented in advance of legislation that failed to become law, so Mr Slaughter's job is closer to that of a high-powered council leader than a directly elected US city mayor. His decisions have to be ratified by a cross-party committee, and he was elected by fellow councillors, who unanimously voted him an annual allowance of £37,500, which he claims while holding down a part-time job as a barrister.

The whole process was the political equivalent of sticking a target on Mr Slaughter's back, and Mr Hands certainly took aim.

The Tory leader attacked the level of the council's allowances, said the administration was open to cronyism and called on local government minister Hilary Armstrong to "defend" the people of the borough from the Labour administration's reforms.

Mr Hands currently receives allowances of £22,500 a year from the authority, which he donates to local and national charities - a practice he says is cleared through the council's legal service to avoid any appearance of impropriety. A former derivatives trader, the 35-year-old group leader admits to being wealthy, and so may not need the money anyway. He says of his present state of employment: "I'm currently more or less a full-time councillor."

Council tax has also been a flash point between the two leaders. Shortly before the borough's final rates were announced last year, Mr Hands claimed that the council was about to set the highest average tax in London. Average council tax is a little-used measure, and there are several ways of working it out. Nearly all councils instead use the band D figure when judging how high increases are. Mr Slaughter has spent a good deal of time denying the story, and the administration claims the Tories simply got their figures wrong.

Mr Hands now says: "On any basis Hammersmith and Fulham is one of the highest taxers in London I'm prepared to accept it might not be the first." In fact, the borough's band D figure last year was around the fifth highest in the capital.

But the fight is not all one way. The Hammersmith and Fulham Gazette's Mike Parkinson has covered the council for 10 years. "Andrew Slaughter was a bit surprised when this new young Tory came up sniping at his policies, because he was used to a more gentlemanly way of doing business. He's adapted to it by giving as good as he gets," he says.

Mr Slaughter would not agree to be interviewed for this article, but his spokesman commented: "The mayor doesn't actually know Hands in person. He says they've never had a personal conversation."

The spokesman added: "They (The Tories) spend a lot of time and energy putting out trivia That has to be challenged when it generates publicity, and he (the mayor) thinks that brings the political process into disrepute."

Whether these spats actually affect the council's performance is a moot point. A report on Hammersmith and Fulham released last year by the local government Improvement and Development Agency was largely positive, and the council has been ranked among the 19 best education authorities in the country.

These facts have not stopped the characteristically combative Mr Hands from attacking Labour, or diverted him from his aim of taking control of the borough by May 2002, despite currently being 21 seats behind on the 50-strong council. In the face of self-belief like that, Andrew Slaughter had better look out.
