webTitle: United could be Waterloo for Cuper troupers

fields.headline: United could be Waterloo for Cuper troupers
fields.trailText: Yesterday the temperature here reached the 80s and for Manchester United, after a fog-delayed flight from England, Valencia could have been on another planet. When Sir Alex Ferguson and his team disembarked it was like stepping into a warm bath.
fields.body:
Yesterday the temperature here reached the 80s and for Manchester United, after a fog-delayed flight from England, Valencia could have been on another planet. When Sir Alex Ferguson and his team disembarked it was like stepping into a warm bath.

Just so long as United's renewed Champions League aspirations do not get into hot water when they resume acquaintance with Hector Cuper's ambitious, accomplished side in the Mestalla stadium here this evening.

For United, who lead their second-round group with maximum points from two games, a draw would be an acceptable result against opponents unbeaten at home in Europe for eight years. And Ferguson emphasised: "We don't want to lose, that's for sure".

With Valencia boasting the best defensive record in this season's Champions League - only four goals conceded in eight matches - a repeat of last year's scoreless encounter when these teams met at a similar stage is a possibility. The circumstances, however, are somewhat different.

Last March a point apiece guaranteed both teams a place in the quarter-finals. Tonight the Spanish are in more urgent need of a win, with Panathinaikos still strong contenders for one of the top two places.

Since Miguel Angel Angulo, the Valencia striker quoted over the weekend as saying that last season the teams agreed to play out a draw, has denied that this is what he meant, the matter is best forgotten. Nevertheless Ferguson did recall yesterday that the players virtually declared a truce in the closing 15 minutes of that match, a common occurrence in such situations but not one likely to be repeated now.

With a fortified defence, refurbished midfield and extra pace and power up front, Valencia will hope to recall to United's minds the unexpectedly decisive defeats the English champions suffered in Eindhoven and Brussels in the first round, when PSV and Anderlecht beat them 2-1 and 3-1 respectively.

Now that Jaap Stam, who missed the entire opening phase, has been restored to fitness and form, United's defence should be better able to withstand a similarly stringent test of its resilience this evening. Or as Ferguson put it yesterday: "I bloody hope so."

This time the danger to United will come from the combination of speed and aggression that John Carew can give the Valencia attack. An additional threat may come from Pablo Aimar, the 21-year-old Argentine midfielder for whom Valencia have paid River Plate £14m. And there will still be a need to curb the creative threat of Gaizka Mendieta, Valencia's inspiration in reaching last season's final.

Ferguson expects another tight encounter. "Whoever scores the first goal could win it," he said yesterday, and with Teddy Sheringham, rested at Chelsea on Saturday, due to rejoin Andy Cole up front it is hard to believe that United will not get at least one.

Fabien Barthez, recovered from a hamstring problem, will resume in goal. So Ferguson's choice should be the familiar one, with Roy Keane the binding force, David Beckham the delivery boy and Ryan Giggs, who did not train yesterday as a precaution because he has a slight ankle strain, the man most likely to unravel Valencia's tightly knit defence.

Manchester United (4-4-2, probable): Barthez; G Neville, Brown, Stam, Silvestre; Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs; Sheringham, Cole.

fields.headline: Oscars thumbs-up for Gladiator
fields.standfirst: Ridley Scott's epic does battle with Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon after being listed in 12 categories
fields.trailText: Ridley Scott's epic does battle with Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon after being listed in 12 categories
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles and Fiachra Gibbons
fields.body:
The battle for Oscar glory threw up a straight scrap yesterday between Gladiator and the martial arts high-kicking of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. British director Ridley Scott's sprawling Roman epic - the first since the genre fell from favour in the 60s - in which a leafy corner of suburban Surrey passes for the wild barbarian frontier, took 12 nominations in all, closely followed by Ang Lee's surprise Chinese arthouse hit with 10, the highest ever number for a foreign language film.

Scott, whose Hannibal is currently taking the US box office by storm, said: "Sadly, I lost my mum this week but obviously she is still looking after me. Thanks mum and the academy. Twelve nominations is fantastic. Needless to say, I am absolutely thrilled."

Stephen Daldry's heart-warming Billy Elliot, about a miner's son who wants be a ballet dancer, always had its work cut out to muscle in on such heavyweight macho company, but the Royal Court man did match his fellow theatre director Sam Mendes's coup by picking up a best director nomination for his first film.

There was joy too at the best actress nomination for Julie Walters, who played the boy's dance teacher, and best screenplay nod for Lee Hall, the Newcastle writer best known for Cooking With Elvis and his radio play Spoonface Steinberg.

The celebrations were soured, however, by the fact that Jamie Bell, the film's 14-year-old star, missed out. "It's terribly disappointing for him. We are all sad about it," said Walters, who was pipped at the post herself for Educating Rita. "It's a shame, but he's only 14 - he's got the whole of his life ahead of him. And if you win an Oscar at 14 what have you got to look forward to? Everything's going to be a disappointment."

Superior weepie

Hall also felt for Bell. "Jamie was so fantastic in the film. I think he's fallen foul of the politics of these things. The fact that we have been nominated is as much a testament to him as it is to ourselves."

There was better news for the veteran Albert Finney, who was picked out for his supporting role in Erin Brockovich - the fifth time he has been nominated - while Judi Dench confirmed her popularity in Hollywood with another nomination for the superior weepie Chocolat, her third in three years.

However, Welsh actress Catherine Zeta Jones's fairytale few years - motherhood, stardom and marriage to Michael Douglas - did not have the much-hyped happy ending of a nomination for her performance in Traffic.

The most intriguing battle, however, could be in the best director category where many see Britain's best chances lying. As well as Daldry, Scott and Ang Lee, Steven Soderbergh has been nominated both for Traffic and Erin Brockovich.

But it was the name Javier Bardem which prompted the one unsuppressed cheer of the morning when the nominations were announced to press at 5.30am at a storm-lashed Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to catch the east coast breakfast headlines.

The Spanish actor, best known for his sex-charged performance in Jamon Jamon, won plaudits for portraying the late Cuban gay writer Reinaldo Arenas in Before Night Falls. He will be competing with two-times winner Tom Hanks (Cast Away), Russell Crowe (Gladiator), Geoffrey Rush (Quills) and Ed Harris (Pollock).

There was no surprise that Julia Roberts should be nominated for Erin Brockovich and her fellow nominees were also those who had been most heavily tipped: Juliette Binoche (Chocolat), Ellen Burstyn (Requiem for a Dream), Joan Allen (The Contender) and Laura Linney (You Can Count on Me). Though not nominated for her remarkable performance in Lars Von Trier's Dancer in the Dark, Bjork does feature in the best song category for the song she co-wrote, I've Seen It All. Bob Dylan (Wonder Boys) and Randy New man (Meet the Parents) are also listed.

Missing in action was Michael Douglas, who had been tipped for nominations as both best actor and best supporting actor for Wonder Boys and Traffic. He lost out to Ed Harris whose portrayal of painter Jackson Pollock has won critical acclaim. Marcia Gay Harden won a best supporting actress nomination for her role in the same film and will be competing for votes with Julie Walters, Judi Dench, Kate Hudson and Frances McDormand.

 Best Picture Chocolat; Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon; Erin Brockovich; Gladiator; Traffic

 Best Actor Javier Bardem (Before Night Falls); Russell Crowe (Gladiator); Tom Hanks (Cast Away); Ed Harris (Pollock); Geoffrey Rush (Quills)

 Best Actress Joan Allen (The Contender); Juliette Binoche (Chocolat); Ellen Burstyn (Requiem for a Dream); Laura Linney (You Can Count On Me); Julia Roberts (Erin Brockovich)

 Best Supporting Actor Jeff Bridges (The Contender); Willem Dafoe (Shadow of the Vampire); Benicio Del Toro (Traffic); Albert Finney (Erin Brockovich); Joaquin Phoenix (Gladiator)

 Best Supporting Actress Judi Dench (Chocolat); Marcia Gay Harden (Pollock); Kate Hudson (Almost Famous); Frances McDormand (Almost Famous); Julie Walters (Billy Elliot)

 Best Director Stephen Daldry (Billy Elliot); Ang Lee (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon); Steven Soderbergh (Erin Brockovich); Ridley Scott (Gladiator); Steven Soderbergh (Traffic)

 Best Foreign Film Amores Perros (Mexico); Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (Taiwan); Divided We Fall (Czech Republic); Everybody Famous (Belgium); The Taste of Others (France)

 Best Film Editing Almost Famous; Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon; Gladiator; Traffic; Wonder Boys

 Best Makeup The Cell; The Grinch; Shadow of the Vampire

 Best Animated Short Film Father and Daughter; The Periwig-Maker; Rejected

 Best Live Action Short Film By Courier; One Day Crossing; Quiero Ser (I want to be); Seraglio; A Soccer Story (Una Historia de Futebol)

 Best Visual Effects Gladiator; Hollow Man; The Perfect Storm

webTitle: Fight the power: Monbiot and Klein take on corporate takeover

fields.headline: Putting the demo back in democracy
fields.standfirst: In this exclusive essay from the London Review of Books, Paul Foot considers George Monbiot's Captive State and Naomi Klein's No Logo, and puts both books to the 'blood boiling in veins' test
fields.trailText: Paul Foot feels the blood boil in his veins after reading George Monbiot's Captive State and Naomi Klein's No Logo
fields.body:
Captive State: The Corporate Takeover of Britain by George Monbiot. Macmillan, 430 pp., £12.99, 25 September 2000, 0 333 90164 9
Buy it at a discount from BOL

No Logo by Naomi Klein. Flamingo, 501 pp., £8.99, 15 January, 0 00 653040 0
Buy it at a discount from BOL

For an old Red like me, bowed down by years of Thatcher, Reagan, Clinton and Blair, these two books are full of exhilaration and hope. George Monbiot writes mainly about Britain in a terse investigative style that I had feared was out of date. Naomi Klein, based in Canada, ranges all over the world and writes infectiously with verve and passion. Again and again their themes converge. Both contemptuously reject the view, which seemed supreme after the collapse of the Berlin Wall and what used to be known (quite wrongly) as communism, that the world is now set fair on a course to libertarian capitalist prosperity. Instead of the torch of freedom, Klein writes, "it seems that it may be the torch of authoritarianism that is being carried by those determined to go global." Both identify the chief menace of the modern world as the multinational corporations and their unelected boardrooms. Both suggest that the power and greed of these corporations is rapidly overtaking what is left of the power and responsibility of elected governments. Both revel in the growing anger against this menace, from the spontaneous protests against antisocial roads and supermarkets to the demonstrations which over the last two years have taken London, Seattle, Prague and Nice by storm and threaten every future international meeting of trade ministers.

"The struggle between people and corporations," Monbiot writes, "will be the defining battle of the 21st century"; and he sets out to prove his point by telling a series of shocking stories from contemporary Britain: the scandal of the toll bridge over the sea to Skye whose financiers - originally the Bank of America - will pocket £88m in tolls from a bridge which originally cost someone else (mostly the British and European taxpayer) £25m; the profit-based ramp known as PFI which now dominates almost all government construction policy, the most glaring example of which is the building of new hospitals at public expense for private gain (with the resulting loss of thousands of hospital beds); the flouting of planning regulations by house-builders and supermarket chains; the wresting of control of the food and drug industry by the big food and drug companies, especially those making genetically modified foods; the surrender of academic objectivity to corporate greed in the universities, led by the proudest and oldest. He lists eight professorships at Cambridge named after and financed by big corporations: Shell, BP, ICI, Glaxo, Unilever, PricewaterhouseCoopers, Marks and Spencer. He records that the Committee of Vice-Chancellors decided in 1998 to stop taking money for cancer research from the tobacco industry, but notes that before the ban was imposed Cambridge accepted £1.6m from British American Tobacco to establish a Chair of International Relations named after BAT's former chairman, Sir Patrick Sheehy. Though he is chiefly concerned with Britain, Monbiot sees what is happening here in a wider context, recognising that international "trade agreements have become the greatest threats to representative government." He describes how groups of businessmen meeting in secret under the auspices of shadowy international organisations such as the European Round Table and the Transatlantic Business Dialogue are setting up their own regulatory system, which makes boycotts of oppressive regimes such as that in Burma, for instance, almost impossible. They enforce this new concept of the rule of law by trade boycotts of their own, which are far more powerful than sanctions imposed by recognised international organisations under the United Nations.

Two factors are crucial: confidentiality and the shrivelling power of elected governments. Whereas governments pretend that their decisions are open and subject to debate, and scientists publicly insist that progress depends on sharing and publicising information, corporations seek to protect themselves, their decisions and their funds from public scrutiny. Thus the inhabitants of Skye, confronted with a bill for costs connected with the toll bridge, "have no means of discovering whether or not the costs are fairly incurred. Indeed, as Miller Civil Engineering won't tell them, they are unable to discover how much nearer they are to paying off the bridge than they were when it opened." As for the current obsession with privately built roads, there are two conflicting official stories. The Government's Highways Agency, deeply influenced by the private roads lobby, announced that private roads were 15 per cent cheaper than those funded by the state. Whoops! The National Audit Office conducted a detailed investigation into the first four privately built roads and found that two were more expensive than they would have been had they been publicly funded. Who was right? When the campaigning group Transport 2000 tried to find out, they were told by the Highways Agency that the figures were "commercially confidential". As for science, Monbiot writes: "While openness has long informed the ethics of science, corporations demand confidentiality. Information that the companies find uncomfortable can be withheld, even when it arises from projects half-funded by the government." Again and again the sponsors of such projects disguise their costs from the people who are partly, often mostly, funding them. This new craze for commercial confidentiality has not been in the least affected by the government's new Freedom of Information Act which, unlike its counterpart in the US, will prove absolutely useless in busting open the padlocks so firmly clamped on these important statistics.

As for the dwindling power of elected governments, Monbiot started his book in May 1997, the month Labour was elected to office with an impregnable majority. He gives no clue as to what he expected from the new ministers, and certainly there is no trace of any ideological commitment that would have set him against them. But what he has written emerges, almost incidentally, as the most sustained indictment of the Blair administration yet published. As the ministers' names fluttered past my eyes, I found myself remembering each of them in their days as radical reformers: Brian Wilson, once abrasive editor of the West Highland Free Press and socialist champion of the Scottish Highlands, now defending the government's policies on the bridge to Skye; Nick Raynsford, whom I recall coming to see me at the Daily Mirror to seek more publicity for the single homeless people in whose interests he was then battling, now as Planning and Construction Minister swanning round the world with executives from the construction industry, including (several times) Balfour Beatty, the potential privatisers of the London tube and the company which holds the record for the biggest fine ever imposed under health and safety legislation, even before the authorities have fully investigated its crucial role in track maintenance at Hatfield; Jack Straw, radical campaigner for public enterprise from Barbara Castle's former seat, who in May 1996 told the Prison Officers Association that privatisation of the prisons was "morally unacceptable - this is one area where a free market does not exist," and promised to take any privatised prisons back into public ownership "as soon as contractually possible", now as home secretary negotiating with yet more big corporations for the privatisation of yet more prisons; 'bluff John' Prescott, the authentic voice of proletarian old Labour, who made it "crystal clear" to the 1993 Labour party conference that a Labour government would renationalise the railways if the Tories privatised them, and promised, for instance, that the Birmingham relief road would be built "only over my dead body", now, as Huff and Puff John, presiding over the privatised railways during their most disastrous period since before nationalisation fifty years ago - as well as giving the go-ahead for the Birmingham relief road. John P's soul may be mouldering in the grave but his body goes marching on.

The list of ministers once critical of the corporations but now slavishly supporting them goes on and on throughout the book: Geoffrey Robinson who, as paymaster general, defended the PFI proposals (and the loss of beds) for Walsgrave Hospital in his constituency, and then, when he lost office, rediscovered his opposition to the plan; Alastair Darling, who in opposition denounced the failure to disclose taxpayers' contributions to PFI projects as "inexcusable" but who has not objected to the same failure to disclose PFI figures under his stewardship of the Department of Social Security; Stephen Byers, who as former chair of the Council of LEAs again and again denounced the Tories for the privatisation of education but has stood solidly in support of privatisation and deregulation as trade and industry secretary; and last but by no means least, the genetically modified science minister himself, Lord Sainsbury of Turville, who has achieved the all-time record for a serving minister donating private money to the party which made him a minister - in his case at least £4m.

The Blair government is now almost entirely servile to its masters in big business. Any minister who for a moment threatened the corporations - David Clark on freedom of information, Nigel Griffiths on consumer influence, Mark Fisher on the arts - has been summarily sacked. Meanwhile, corporation tax and capital gains tax have been cut to ribbons, but income tax has stayed the same. The theoretical regulators of corporate power have become its champions.

Naomi Klein's book takes off when she reflects on her college obsessions with gender and race discrimination. "Our criticism, focused on women and minorities, assumed an atmosphere of plenty . . . class fell off the agenda . . . we were too busy analysing pictures on the wall to notice that the wall had been sold." This worried her and her worries led her to the places where 'branded' goods are made, especially to the 'industrial slums' of the Philippines, where half a million people, most of them women, are hoarded into free trade zones and obliged to work in conditions which hark back to the darkest years of industrialisation in the US and Britain. At Cavite in the Philippines she found three vital ingredients required by the contractors to the big US clothing and computer corporations: "tax breaks, lax regulations and the services of a military willing and able to crush labour unrest". Here was everything a corporate executive dogged by regulations and recognised trade unions at home could wish for: not just luxury housing, golf courses and an ample supply of cheap domestic servants (they could get most of these back home) but rules against talking and smiling in the factories similar to those contested in Lancashire and Cheshire a hundred years ago. The workers in Cavite are shovelled into stinking dormitories, scratch out a living on starvation wages and are warned every day of the terrible sanctions awaiting anyone who talks to a union organiser. These chapters about exploitation lead Klein on to what she calls the "bad mood rising", the discontent which first raged in Seattle in November 1999. The corporations, she argues, "are stunting human development . . . what good is an open and accountable parliament if economic policy is unchanged?"

Shelley wrote that some atrocity on the part of the wealthy set "the blood boiling in indignation in my veins". Ever since I first read that, I've subjected any new political analysis to a BBIV (blood boiling in veins) test. Do these two books pass? The unequivocal answer in both cases is 'yes'. The blood boils all right, both at the corporate exploiters and the politicians who dance to their tune. But as the blood boils, so the mind casts around for a solution. Both authors anticipate this yearning, but they deal with it unsatisfactorily. Both have rejected conventional arenas for political dissension - councils, parliaments etc - and both champion the admirable protests of organisations like Reclaim the Streets. But that seems the limit of their advice. Monbiot concludes that "corporations are powerful only because we allow them to be" and will cease to be so when "people reassert their control" (when did we ever have this control?). He goes on: "Our strength lies in our citizenship, in our ability to engage in democratic politics." This means, he concludes, "putting the demo back in democracy". Klein ends her book in much the same way. "We will find our way out as citizens on our own. Political solutions deserve another shot." These optimistic formulae come at the end of analyses which prove in devastating fashion that the corporate power that rules our lives and our parliaments is backed by the most enormous resources of economic wealth. This power can be shaken and even deflected by vigorous mass protest such as took place at Seattle and at Nice. But if it is to be defeated and transformed, there has to be a power on our side big enough to hurt the corporations where they hurt most, in their pockets; and go on hurting them there.

At the end of her book Klein describes a discussion about international codes of business conduct among a gang from the Workers Assistance Centre in Rosario in the Philippines. One worker, Zernon Toledo, pounded the table. "These documents," he bellowed, 'are written by the transnational corporations, so that they will only serve the transnational corporations - haven't you read Marx?" This seemed to me a fair question, if a little patronising. The indignation which these books ignite needs more food for its flames than vague appeals to citizenship.

fields.headline: Somerfield gambles £500m on price cuts
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Somerfield has announced £500m in price cuts over the next 12 months, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Somerfield has taken a gamble to establish itself as a value retail brand by announcing £500m in price cuts over the next 12 months.

The consumer giveaway, called Megadeals, dwarfs recent price-cut announcements by rivals Asda and Tesco, which have respectively announced £52m and £70m limited period price-cutting campaigns.

Somerfield said the Megadeals scheme, which replaces its long-running Price Check promotion, will save shoppers £26m in the first two weeks alone.

The move is a gamble for Somerfield because it does not enjoy the buying power of the UK's biggest supermarket Tesco, or Adsa, which is backed by US giant Walmart.

"Megadeals offers more high-value discounts than any other supermarket and ones that will make a real difference to people's shopping bills," said Richard Smith, associate marketing director at Somerfield.

The initiative also sounds the death-knell for Somerfield's Premier Points loyalty card scheme, although customers will still be able to redeem points at Argos stores until at least next February.

Asda, the supermarket most famous for its value brand message, has always eschewed loyalty cards in favour of price cuts.

In the six months to November 11, like-for-like sales at Somerfield supermarkets fell by 5.3%.

fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are pairing up and a-smoochin'
fields.trailText: Newcastle's transfer-listed defender Alain Goma is a target for Chelsea. Bobby Robson hopes to persuade Goma that his future is on Tyneside, but if the centre-half, recently recalled to the French squad, does decide to leave, Newcastle will look to recoup the £4.5m they paid Paris St-Germain for him two years ago.
fields.body:
Newcastle's transfer-listed defender Alain Goma is a target for Chelsea. Bobby Robson hopes to persuade Goma that his future is on Tyneside, but if the centre-half, recently recalled to the French squad, does decide to leave, Newcastle will look to recoup the £4.5m they paid Paris St-Germain for him two years ago.

Another transfer-listed star, Bradford goalkeeper Matt Clarke, could be set for a move to Leicester, according to the Mirror. The paper suggests Peter Taylor is ready to spend £2m on the man he sees as the long-term successor to Tim Flowers.

Bayern Munich are rumoured to be interested in taking Liverpool defender Christian Ziege back to Germany. The left-back has struggled to make an impact on the Anfield first team since his move from Middlesbrough.

fields.headline: Express puts Woolfenden on gardening leave
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Commercial director Paul Woolfenden is thought to be the latest victim of Richard Desmond's cost-cutting, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Express Newspapers commercial director Paul Woolfenden is on gardening leave, amid speculation he is to be the next victim of Richard Desmond's cost-cutting drive.

Mr Woolfenden, who oversaw marketing for the Daily Express, Sunday Express and Daily Star, is believed to be in negotiation with lawyers over severance terms.

Express Newspapers insiders said he was asked to resign at the end of last week by the new management of the group because his £140,000 salary was considered too high.

Mr Woolfenden was unavailable for comment.

Mr Desmond is looking to make savings across the board at the Express titles and has already cut at least 60 sales, marketing and support staff.

Since his takeover, a number of high-profile journalists have quit the paper.

These include editor Rosie Boycott, her deputy Chris Blackhurst and columnists Peter Hitchens, Mary Kenny, Ros Wynne Jones and Topaz Amoore.

It is believed Mr Woolfenden's duties are to be shared between joint managing directors Stan Myerson and Martin Ellice.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Car rental rip-offs

Car owners, hit by soaring insurance premiums and extortionate residents' parking permits, look with envy at those who rely on the occasional hire deal for their transport. For while the cost of buying a vehicle remains high, the cost of renting one is falling as companies attempt to shunt each other out of the market. We, the unencumbered, can therefore afford a new people carrier for a family get-together, clock up a thousand miles and return it, soiled, to the rental company for them to deal with. No maintenance. No AA premiums or licence renewal fees.

But there is a dark side to this carefreedom. Shaun O'Connell, Susan Greenberg and Peter Doherty are united by the fact that each rented a vehicle from Easyjet's new sister company, Easyrentacar; each returned it in what they insist was immaculate condition and each later discovered their accounts had been debited by up to £150 because of alleged damage. In Greenberg's case, she was charged for a scratched hubcap, even though the damage had been noted by the rental office before she collected the car. O'Connell didn't know what the extra charge was for until he rang the company's premium rate phone line. "You can email the company, but they don't reply, so you have to phone them on a 25p-a-minute line and they tell you someone will investigate and get back to you, which they don't."

Easyrentacar also helped themselves, unannounced, to £100 from Josh Sims' account, claiming "minor damage" to his rental vehicle. When he queried it, he was told the "damage" was the removal of the company's advertising stickers on the side of the car. But, Sims protested, there hadn't been any stickers. Easy's defence was that he'd checked the vehicle before hiring it and signed a form confirming its condition. "But the form says nothing about checking for stickers," he says.

One consolation for this unhappy quartet is that they're not alone. So many complaints about Easyrentacar have reached the Consumers' Association that they have begun an enquiry. "Most complaints have been about mysterious charges which are either unexplained or for things like unexpected cleaning," a spokeswoman for the Consumers' Association says. "In all the cases we've looked into, Easyrentacar have held up their hands and refunded the money, sometimes without explanation and sometimes only after several premium rate phone calls." A call from Consumer secures an automatic, unexplained refund for O'Connell and Sims; Greenberg and Doherty achieve one by their own efforts. "We are a no-frills operation," says chief executive Andrew Fitzmaurice about the charges. "We run on a tight budget." One problem is many companies neglect to advise customers to be present when the car is inspected, so the customer has no way of proving any alleged damage was not caused by them. After a scolding from the Office of Fair Trading about unfair trading practices, Easy says it now asks customers to witness the inspection and/or sign a form confirming their refusal.

Easyrentacar is by no means the only culprit. Dan Peirson of Nottingham appealed to Consumer after Holiday Autos overcharged him by a day. He'd already paid for an extra day in order to return an hour later than specified; he was told the charge was because he'd collected 20 minutes early.

Eventually the company admits a mistake was made. "Our clients have an hour's leeway either side of the agreed rental period, so we'll be refunding the customer," a spokeswoman says.

Steve Rose of London made an internet booking with car hire firm Alamo, but when he arrived at the airport, there was no record of his reservation and he was obliged to fork out again. His laments to Alamo elicited no reply.

Again, Consumer coaxes out a confession. "There was a problem with our computer lines on the date Mr Rose made his reservation, so it was never received," a spokeswoman says. He has now been refunded the difference between the online hire fee and the airport price, and given a coupon for two days' free car hire.

Bob Fisher of Dewsbury faced a similar predicament when he tried to collect a vehicle, hired through Autos Abroad, at Rimini airport. After five hours of phoning, he had to rent with another company; he received no response to his request for a refund. Autos Abroad is none other than Hire For Lower whose customer service practices filled Consumer postbags last summer.

Hire for Lower sound confused but promise to refund the hire fee and expenses. "What went wrong?" we ask a spokeswoman. "Dunno," she answers unreassuringly.

As the car rental industry grows, so must the temptation to cut corners. Easyrentacar's problem is that its upfront hire fees are perilously cheap and it compensates with a rigorous policy of penalty charges. "When customers hand over their bank details, they are giving companies a blank cheque," says a Consumers' Association spokeswoman. But there is some hope for the consumer. The British Vehicle Rental and Leasing Association (BVRLA) issues an award-winning code of practice to all members who have to pass rigorous quality controls. The BVRLA says it has encouraged Easyrentacar to apply for membership, but that the company has so far refused.

"We are members," Andrew Fitzmaurice says, before consulting with his fleet manager, then backtracking.

"This is the difficulty," the BVRLA says. "Some customers think Easyrentacar is a member, so they feel reassured. Our advice is to check for our logo, then you know you've got somewhere to turn if things go wrong."

webTitle: Emma Thompson hints at retirement from acting

fields.headline: Emma Thompson hints at retirement from acting
fields.trailText: The double Oscar-winning British star has hinted that she wants to spend more time working on scripts and with her family
fields.body:
Emma Thompson has hinted that her latest film Wit, the story of an English Literature teacher's fight with cancer, could be her last acting role and that her future lies behind the camera.

The 41-year-old British actress, who once auditioned for the Sharon Stone role in Basic Instinct, told peoplenews: ''I know I should get back to acting, but I have a baby and I'm in love with her and I want to spend time with her."

Thompson, who won Academy Awards for her performance in Howard's End in 1993 and her screenplay for Sense and Sensibility in 1996, is currently receiving rave reviews in the US and at the Berlin Film Festival for Wit which she helped to adapt from Margaret Edison's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel. At the film's US premiere she told reporters: "I am writing a lot, I'm working on a biography and a children's film at the moment."

The former Mrs Kenneth Branagh is also co-writing a script called Fast Forward with High Fidelity author Nick Hornby. "I did a treatment that was sent to Emma in an actress capacity," he said in November. "She liked it and wanted to talk about it - so much so that I suggested we wrote the script together. It's an amazing experience, because she is just so smart."

fields.headline: Sweet and serious
fields.standfirst:
Grunge guru's shades of Chanel

Special report: London Fashion Week 2001
fields.trailText: With Marc Jacobs's catwalk show for autumn/winter 2001, New York Fashion Week finally got down to the serious business of setting trends.
fields.body:
With Marc Jacobs's catwalk show for autumn/winter 2001, New York Fashion Week finally got down to the serious business of setting trends. Jacobs might not have the heavyweight media presence of designers who make glitzy Oscar gowns or go in for headline-grabbing catwalk stunts, but he has an impeccable pedigree as a fashion leader.

A 41-year-old native New Yorker, Jacobs found notoriety in the early 90s as the man who invented grunge.

At the very end of the decade, he came full circle by turning a blue-blood Parisian luggage label, Louis Vuitton, into an ultra-hip clothing brand and launching a craze for logomania in the process. The most significant message from his latest own-name collection is that Jacobs seems to be growing tired of the 80s obsession that has coloured his Paris and New York shows in recent seasons.

Paraded before an ice-cool front row, which included the actor Hilary Swank and musicians from Debbie Harry to the latest MTV favourite, Matchbox 20, this was a collection with the unmistakable flavour of Coco Chanel - not a woman who we can imagine going in for drainpipe jeans and legwarmers.

There is a naive, teenage enthusiasm to Jacobs's designs that sings out among the unimpeachable, identikit sophistication of much of New York fashion. Large buttons have become a signature of this label, and this season they had grown to the size of cupcakes. With patch pockets and Peter Pan collars, they transformed simple knee-length coats, particularly the lemon yellow version in sequinned mohair.

Models were made up in the Chrissie Hynde mould, with tousled hair and heavy black kohl, and stomped down the catwalk at a rather unladylike full pelt, but the clothes they wore looked as though they were for Sunday school: high-waisted satin tea dresses with cap sleeves, pleated georgette blouses and boiled twill suits, Bermuda shorts and sailor coats. Organdy tops were trimmed with ribbon to create trompe l'oeil collars and lapels.

The assembled fashion throng, braving the New York sidewalks in Prada's new cone-heeled shoes, were relieved to see the style given the stamp of Jacobs's approval on the catwalk.

webTitle: Bypass sparks new battle of Hastings

fields.headline: Bypass sparks new battle of Hastings
fields.trailText: The construction of two bypass schemes that will cut through unspoilt areas near Hastings has been approved by the south-east England regional assembly in the name of regeneration, but the decision has caused a stir.
fields.body:
The sense of space and stillness hits you at once. When you look up from the valley towards the hilltops there are only trees and fields in sight. You can hear little but birdsong. The occasional rumble of a train on the embankment provides the only interruption to this quiet corner of East Sussex.

It is hard to imagine a more perfect image of the English countryside than here at Doleham in the Upper Brede valley. For many residents it is even harder to imagine why someone would want to rip it all up.

But today's expected approval by the south-east England regional assembly (Seera) of two bypass schemes that will cut through the heart of this and other unspoilt areas near Hastings could herald the beginning of a big change.

The bypasses are designed to flank Hastings, described as the most deprived district in the south-east. Supporters - including the local Labour MP, Michael Foster, anxious to hang on to his key marginal seat - say the roads will help to regenerate the seaside town. But they are set to become the most controversial road building schemes since Newbury and Twyford Down.

The decision to go ahead lies ultimately with the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, but since he was a key proponent of the regional assembly he is unlikely to overturn one of Seera's first big decisions.

Proponents argue that taking traffic away from the town centre could provide opportunities for development of greenfield sites farther afield, as well as unclogging the narrow streets in the Victorian town.

Mr Foster said yesterday that he believed towns such as Hastings "needed a hand-up not a handout".

"We have all the natural resources in terms of where we are, but almost everybody says it's the infrastructure which defeats many of our objectives, both road and rail," he said.

He outlined plans to improve rail links to London and develop a metro link within the town, but added: "That is not enough. The bypasses and improvements to the A21 remain integral to the confidence of people investing in the town."

He said around 80% of residents were in favour of the bypasses, and while acknowledging that there were environmental implications he added: "The urban environment and the economic gains are so substantial that they outweigh the unfortunate loss to the rural environment."

There is no argument over the need to regenerate the once proud seaside resort - it ranked 28th in the list of poorest towns in Britain, with higher than average unemployment and lower than average wages. But environmentalists and some local residents believe there are other ways of making this happen.

A decision in favour of the scheme could help Labour to retain the seat, gained from the Conservatives in 1997 with a 2,560 majority.

Julian Bargery, a resident and campaigner from the Wishing Tree area of Hastings, said: "How else could you explain the government considering a scheme which has no strategic national benefit? If the bypass went ahead Mr Foster would regard it as a feather in his hat. He would make great political capital out of the fact that he got it through."

Mr Foster, who appears to be one of the few people who do not expect a decision before the general election, said: "All three parties support this... Where does that leave me room for political manoeuvre?"

A protest campaign has worked hard to prevent what protesters fear will be the destruction of three of Britain's finest wildlife sites, as well as damaging an area of outstanding national beauty.

Opponents argue that the construction would be in direct contravention of the government's environmental policy. In Doleham plans for the eastern bypass involve levelling out the valley to enable the road to pass above the Hastings-Ashford railway line.

As part of the farm stewardship scheme, which works to encourage wildlife to stay and breed, the area is home to rare species of plants, and the streams provide vital breeding grounds for sea trout. These streams will be encased in concrete culverts underground if the plans go ahead.

The valley will be transformed. Plans for the bypass to the west of Hastings include a 12-metre concrete viaduct running through Combe Haven, a wildlife reserve and a potentially important archaeological site.

Campaigners fear that some of the sites for the roads lie on flood plains, which could create serious problems in an area which in the past three months has suffered some of the worst flooding in its history.

They also argue that a report by government consultants casts doubt on whether the new roads would help to regenerate the town. The report said road traffic in Hastings would actually increase.

The environment agency has also expressed "serious concerns" about the flood plain and the effect on biodiversity and wildlife.

The bypass proposals appear to contravene recent Department of the Environment guidelines on development and flood risk, which state that building on functional flood plains should be "wholly exceptional - and limited to essential infrastructure".

Mr Foster said yesterday he believed government policy was "totally consistent". "The policy is: do not build a road unless there is absolutely no alternative. There is absolutely no alternative to these roads. They should have been built 30 years ago. We are just trying to catch up with the world."

fields.headline: Gold Council seeks marketing muscle
fields.trailText: 11.15am: The World Gold Council is hiring new global marketing and PR chiefs in the run-up to a £50m advertising campaign. By Julia Day.
fields.body:
The World Gold Council is hiring new global marketing and PR chiefs in the run-up to a new £50m advertising campaign.

The move is part of an internal restructure at the WCG as it attempts to change perceptions of gold and the organisation, which represents gold mines worldwide.

The body last month hired London advertising agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty to handle an estimated £50m global campaign.

Branding consultancy Wolff Olins has already created an image for gold and BBH is now working on creative TV, cinema and press executions that will launch in April.

The WGC is now seeking a marketing manager to convey the brand to consumers globally via advertising, PR, the WCG website, conferences and events.

The marketing chief will be responsible for developing the gold branding initiative and adapting it to local needs by working with advertising, branding and PR agencies.

It is also anticipated that joint marketing initiatives will be signed with other companies.

The new head of corporate communications will generate a new corporate image for the WGC, working closely with chief executive Haruko Fukuda and corporate directors to develop the image and positioning of the WGC around the world.

Both positions will report to WCG corporate director Kerr Cruikshanks.

"The perception of what we are as an organisation is vague," Mr Cruikshanks said.

"Much of the publicity about us in the past focuses on market reports, data and lobbying about the central bank gold reserves.

"But we are a marketing organisation and spend the bulk of our money on marketing gold."

fields.headline: Vivendi 'set to reach growth targets'
fields.trailText: 11.5am: Vivendi Universal has said it is on course to meet its ambitious growth targets, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Newly merged media giant Vivendi Universal has said it is on course to meet its ambitious growth targets after posting strong full-year revenues for 2000.

The group was formed by the £50bn merger between French company Vivendi, owner of pay-TV channel Canal Plus, and Canadian rival Seagram, which controls Universal Music and Universal Studios.

Although today's figures only included 23 days' revenues from the Seagram companies, which formally merged with Vivendi in December, total revenues surged from £18bn in 1999 to £25bn in 2000.

"This new company is off to a fast start and we are very confident that we will meet the very aggressive growth targets we have set for ourselves both at the revenues and EBITDA levels," said Jean-Marie Messier, chief executive of Vivendi Universal.

The world's second largest media company has forecast growth in EBITDA, or consolidated earnings, of 35% between 2000 and 2002. The company also expects a 10% annual rise in revenue over the same period.

Analysts point to the potential of Vivendi's Vizzavi mobile internet service and the huge amount of content the company can deliver over pay-TV and wireless platforms, but they want to see progress on knitting the newly merged company together.

"The sales figures are bang in line with expectations, but we want to see what will be going on in terms of synergies between the different parts of the group. The market is very sceptical about the level of synergies that can be achieved," said Commerzbank analyst Marc Loneux.

fields.headline: Romance under siege
fields.standfirst: All is not well in the land of love, reports Rory Carroll, with single Italians proliferating and St Valentine's resting place an industrial eyesore
fields.trailText: All is not well in the land of love, reports Rory Carroll, with single Italians proliferating and St Valentine's resting place an industrial eyesore.
fields.body:
It may seem somewhat greedy that the land of sunshine and beauty, Romeo and Juliet, charm and seduction, should also bag St Valentine, but it is not. Italian romantics need all the help they can get.

Postmen today will groan under tonnes of letters, mobile networks will jam from millions of messages, florists will make a killing. It won't be enough.

Believe the papers (why not?) and a malaise is sweeping Italy. Couples are just not getting it together. From hamlets to cities, the cry of loneliness swells.

Everybody's seeking but nobody's finding the perfect partner. Settling for a mediocre one might seem a solution but only to unromantic Anglo-Saxons. Italians are not unromantic Anglo-Saxons.

Enter Giuseppe Corazziere. His official title is mayor of San Valentino Torio, a small town near Salerno. It does not do him justice. His true title is the love doctor.

Mr Corazziere has sent an SOS to potential husbands on behalf of his town's 500 "excess nubile females". Aged between 25 and 45, they have been unable to find men.

In honour of the saint after which the town is named, Mr Corazziere took it upon himself to advertise their plight in newspapers, throwing in a free honeymoon on the Amalfi coast to successful applicants. The town hall's switchboard has been lit up ever since.

"We are being swamped with calls from men of all sorts - widowers, young men, professional men, all claiming to have honourable intentions. I never knew there was so much loneliness in the world," sighed the love doctor.

Other mayors have blazed a similar trail. So concerned was Carlo Moscardini about the number of broken relationships in Lastra a Signa, a town near Florence, that he offered a rent-free "love nest" to young couples who had trouble finding privacy.

The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano branded it "a sneaky, sickeningly demagogic ploy... that distorts the significance of marriage".

The ageing bachelors of Vastogirardi, a hamlet on an Abruzzo hilltop, were catapulted to infamy after mayor Vincenzo Venditti issued an ultimatum: marry, or pay a singles' tax.

Hunched over beers in Bar Central, a group of friends confessed that hunting boar, fishing and football was more attractive than settling down with the hamlet's numerous spinsters. Some of the men have been engaged to the same women for more than 20 years.

Franco Sccochera, 62, cooks for himself and has never had a serious girlfriend and doesn't intend to acquire one anytime soon. His eyes glint: "Tell you what, if you have a sister, give me her number. I'll give her a call."

The situation seems desperate. Enter Terni, a town north of Rome where St Valentine is buried. Quite why the 3rd century martyr is the patron saint of lovers is a mystery.

Maybe because he gave a flower to a young couple, supposedly guaranteeing eternal love, or maybe because his festival falls at the start of spring, supposedly the cue for birds to mate.

Either way Terni styles itself the capital of love and stages an annual festival of romance at the saint's basilica. Couples are invited to come and exchange vows.

One catch. Terni shares Umbria's famed valleys and olive groves with Assisi and Spoleto, but it happens to be ugly. An industrial mass of concrete and steel plants without a heart, it is probably the region's only blot.

Bouquets are tacked to shopfronts and some couples will indeed arrive today. The Soviet Union's last president, Mikhail Gorbachev, will come Saturday to commemmorate his late wife Raisa.

But even locals suspect the festival is a lost cause. Italians may crave romance but they know better than to come here to find it. The love doctor has his work cut out.

fields.headline: Building a Roma media
fields.standfirst: Gypsy journalists across central Europe are creating a media for their people, explains Kate Connolly
fields.trailText: Gypsy journalists across central Europe are creating a media for their people, explains Kate Connolly.
fields.body:
As the countries of central and eastern Europe enthusiastically pursue their goals to become fully-fledged members of the European Union in the next few years, the continent's fastest-growing ethnic minority - the Roma or Gypsies - are quietly but quite distinctly beginning to take advantage of the momentum for change to find their own voice.

"We should work out our own strategy," insisted Nicolae Gheorghe, a prominent Gypsy from Romania, who is working for Roma and Sinti issues within the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe.

"We need to have our own policies and not sit around crying," he added.

The comments came last summer, at the fifth world congress of International Roma held in Prague, where representatives of the region's 12m Gypsies announced that they would push to be recognised as a non-territorial nation.

The undertaking is an ambitious one, but many believe it can work. Inspired by the suggestion, one man at the congress, Zoran Dimov, a young and fiery TV journalist from Macedonia, leapt onto the stage.

"Roma are only written about, they never speak for themselves in the press," said the man who who set up the first 24-hour Roma news channel, BTR Nacional.

Then he passionately declared that a practical method to unite a 'nation' that shares a common tongue, but whose dialects have become different enough that translators were needed at the congress, should create its own transglobal newspaper.

He stressed that a common understanding of what it meant to be a nation - albeit a nation whose members are scattered about the world - demanded certain criteria.

"If you know what your brother or sister is doing in Norway, if you can click on a button and find out about a Roma choir in Macedonia or a Roma fire brigade in Russia."

He was sharply criticised and accused of calling for Gypsies to assimilate in a gajde or non-gypsy world. But Zoran argued that the gajde's tools - like the internet - should be fully taken advantage of to empower Roma to seek chances beyond lives that have become increasingly miserable and neglected since the fall of communism.

Last week, just seven months after his ground-breaking speech, Zoran saw the seeds of his ambitious dream take fruit with the launch of the world's first Romani language daily, the Roma Times, in his native Skopje in Macedonia.

The paper is written primarily in Romani, but around 30% of articles will appear in Macedonian, and 10% in English - to open it up to a wider audience.

Roma Times aims to cover politics, culture, and local and international news, with a special emphasis on Roma living in Macedonia and beyond, and it is soon to go online.

"This is a historical time for Roma people in the Republic of Macedonia, as it is for Roma throughout the world," Zoran said. "We want Roma Times to be commonplace in every Roma family, so that, through their own language, they can feel empowered."

The Romani language is the foundation of the identity of the modern Gypsy.

Spreading their own tongue and message might just enable the Gypsies of central and eastern Europe in particular to find real emancipation for the first time in over a thousand years of repression and discrimination.

And the media outlets are growing. From Croatia to Kosovo, Romania to Bulgaria, newspapers, websites and broadcasting outfits are being born.

Last week, Hungary's first independent Gypsy radio station, Radio C, went on the air, funded by the EU's eastern European reconstruction fund.

It hopes to reach the 100,000 strong community living in and around Budapest, and later the plan is to expand nationwide.

"We want to show our fellow Gypsies a way out of their difficult lives," said station manager Gyoergy Kerenyi. "We think this can give them a major boost."

As in the rest of the region, the majority of the country's 700,000 Gypsies live in terrible conditions, with a lack of health care provisions and appalling diet.

They have been the societal group hardest hit by the transition from communism to a market economy, most of them having lost their low-skilled, low-paid employment.

However, a team of 40 young, Roma journalists at Radio C has begun producing a range of features from issues such as mixed marriages to 'breaking out' of the cycle of living on the dole as the only means of survival.

Gypsies have been invited to pitch their own ideas, as well as to bring their own music to add to the station's tiny archive.

But Gyoergy points to the vicious circle that, all too often, either prevents such ventures from getting off the ground, or causes them to fold. Advertisers have yet to discover Roma as consumers.

Bulgarian journalist Rumyan Russinov has battled for years with similar problems in his attempts to set up Romani broadcasts within the mainstream networks in Sofia.

A major part of his goal is to increase the acceptance of Romani journalists in the mainstream media in order that a significant change in the public perception of Roma can take place.

He is motivated as much by the wish to counterbalance the mass of denigrating articles about Gypsies full of the old stereotypes in the Bulgarian media as he is to create an open space for Roma within the public sphere.

"Roma have been absent from the media of the countries of central and eastern Europe for decades," he said. "Although in some ways they have always been there, but portrayed as the negative epitome of their societies."

Zoran Dimov is one of a growing number who believe all that is about to change.

webTitle: Bolton grateful to Hansen and the deadly Ricketts

fields.headline: Bolton grateful to Hansen and the deadly Ricketts
fields.trailText: Portsmouth 1 - 2 Bolton
fields.body:
It was mission accomplished for Bolton last night, and in the end it was comfortable enough. Two second-half goals of differing quality pushed them nine points ahead of Blackburn in second place, a fact they will no doubt be reminding their Lancastrian rivals of when they meet in the FA Cup fifth round on Saturday.

The best goal, however, came from the losing side. Michael Panopoulos's late consolation, struck over the goalkeeper Steve Banks with the outside of his right boot, gave the home fans a memory to savour, but by then the match was lost.

Portsmouth are the division's draw specialists but even a point looked unlikely for them against a Bolton side who have moved clear in second place thanks to a particularly impressive away record.

Home hopes were also hit by the absence through injury of their captain Darren Moore and goalkeeper Aaron Flahavan, meaning a league debut for Chris Tardif.

Bolton were boosted by a debut of sorts from Colin Hendry, who has just made his loan move from Coventry permanent. Perhaps it was out of an unusual understanding, or simply a spirit of generosity, that in a first half of great industry and attacking menace neither side forced a save worthy of the name from the two understudy stoppers.

Both teams came close but Portsmouth tended to delay the shot, Bolton to strike too soon. Neither tactic proved profitable though the away side attacked with greater menace and would have taken the lead had Ricardo Gardner not struck the bar on 42 minutes after Michael Ricketts had led a break of blinding pace.

Within three minutes of the break Bolton had solved their problem and taken the lead. Bo Hansen had already forced a fine save out of Tardif before Ricketts took advantage of a moment of good fortune to score the first goal.

Jason Crowe lashed a clearance from the edge of his area into his team-mate Nigel Quashie, leaving Bolton's top-scorer a simple chance from the rebound. It was bad luck for Quashie, who had missed Portsmouth's best chance in first-half stoppage time.

The second was all of their own making, Gardner's sublime curling cross finding Hansen's run and the Dane coolly poked past Tardif.

fields.headline: Ekoku keeps Wednesday afloat
fields.trailText: Sheff Wed 1 - 0 Tranmere
fields.body:
Sheffield Wednesday had awoken in crisis yesterday to the uncompromising tones of Joe Ashton, the Labour MP and their most unforgiving fan. "Not all of them are rubbish, but most of them are," was Ashton's verdict on the scant playing resources inherited by Wednesday's caretaker manager Peter Shreeves following the sacking of Paul Jewell.

But that Wednesday would sleep soundly was undeniable as Shreeves's appointment brought immediate success. Efan Ekoku's goal 13 minutes from time against Tranmere, companions in distress, took them off the bottom of the First Division and clear of the bottom three.

It was a decent goal to cap a passionate performance: Trent Soltvedt slicing through the right of the area, and Ekoku finishing with confidence. Wednesday's new septegenarian chairman, Geoff Hulley, probably needs a good reason to stay up late these days, and there it was.

Paul Jewell was "a young lad with an almost impossible mission ... he did it to the best of his ability ... I have every confidence in his ability to be a top-class manager of the future." Accolades never sound more hollow than immediately after a manager's sacking, but if the opinion of Peter Shreeves, Wednesday's caretaker manager, was truly encapsulated by his programme notes, he must have been wondered quite why he had been temporarily offered Jewell's job. Instruct any manager to sell half a side (and the best players in a bad side to boot) and seven wins in 31 matches is about as good as can be expected.

But that was yesterday. Losses running around £80,000 a week and debts of £18m are widely quoted figures that Wednesday must now somehow rise above. Shreeves at least pulled off the first trick of any canny caretaker: he made immediate changes, persuading Gilles De Bilde to commit himself again to the cause, completing Jewell's negotiations to bring Trond Soltvedt on loan from Southampton and adding the leggiest old Wednesday warhorse in the land, Carlton Palmer, on loan from Coventry.

For all that, it was Tranmere who made all the running. Wednesday might have fallen behind twice in the first nine minutes as Andy Parkinson's dash towards goal was quelled at the last by Ashley Westwood, and Clint Hill headed high from Jason Koumas's corner. By the time Kevin Pressman pushed aside Paul Rideout's 25-yard dip, familiar rumbles were beginning to reappear.

De Bilde, the disgruntled Belgian, has complained that Wednesday have not facilitated his transfer request, but his attitude and form has hardly made him a marketable commodity. Wednesday's best chance of the half fell to him after Westwood's shot had been blocked, but his header was a timid one.

Palmer, too, discovered that a hero's welcome from the terraces was only half the battle. His timing, never perfect, had hardly been honed by a spell in Coventry's reserves and a late tackle on Graham Allen brought an angry Tranmere reaction, and a booking. Steve Harkness, capturing the mood, was then booked for hacking at Richard Hinds and Wednesday stomped off at half-time energised by an imaginary sense of injustice.

Wednesday should have gone ahead soon after the interval when Alan Quinn failed to finish Ekoku's pass, but it was the deliverer who finally delivered.

fields.headline: Virgin Mobile bags peaktime interactive ad
fields.trailText: 11am: Virgin Mobile has bought a peaktime interactive ad on ITV to be screened during this month's Brit Awards, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Virgin Mobile has bought the first peaktime interactive ad on ITV, to be screened during the Brit Awards later this month.

Manning Gottlieb Media, Virgin Mobile's media agency, said it would use the opportunity to measure the effectiveness of interactive TV advertising.

Viewers with ONdigital boxes will be offered £20 off Virgin Mobile phones when they enter an interactive site created for two ITV peaktime programmes.

The first is Count Down to the Brits on February 26 and the second is the awards ceremony itself the following day.

Consumers clicking on a Virgin strip advert will be given details about Virgin Mobile and a number to call to buy phones at a discount rate.

The site, which can be brought up as part of the ITV screen, has been created by Carlton Active.

People can use the site to find details of Brits nominees, enter competitions and buy CDs.

Last year, SmithKline Beecham took out an interactive TV ad for kids' toothpaste Milk Teeth during ITV's Baby Baby programme.

But the Virgin ad is expected to be the first to be screened during peaktime.

webTitle: Forgers send Tintin to sleazy bars of Bangkok

fields.headline: Forgers send Tintin to sleazy bars of Bangkok
fields.trailText: Tintin, the boy reporter of comic strip fame, has been caught up in a new adventure and the Belgian police are not best pleased. About 650 forged copies of "Tintin in Thailand" - a lewd tale of Tintin touring sleazy bars in Bangkok - have been confiscated and at least three people arrested, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Tintin, the boy reporter of comic strip fame, has been caught up in a new adventure and the Belgian police are not best pleased. About 650 forged copies of "Tintin in Thailand" - a lewd tale of Tintin touring sleazy bars in Bangkok - have been confiscated and at least three people arrested, it emerged yesterday.

In Belgium, where the comic strip character with the quiff is something akin to a national hero, the episode has attracted considerable attention, and has been condemned as inbeing poor taste as well as illegal.

Tintin's Belgian creator, Hergé, dreamed up 24 separate adventures for the roving foreign correspondent and his white fox terrier Snowy, but none involved a trip to Thailand and all were considered suitable for children.

In the unauthorised Tintin in Thailand album, however, Tintin is seen with his friends Captain Haddock and the absent-minded Professor Calculus drinking beer at a lap dancing bar in Bangkok.

He has abandoned his schoolboy vocabulary for a more colourful one inappropriate for young children.

In another scene that is likely to anger fans of the comic strip, Tintin is pictured in a gay escort bar called "Sexy Boy", where he is propositioned by two male Thai hosts.

The album also contains graphic scenes of sodomy involving Snowy and Tintin's Chinese friend Chang.

A police unit which spe cialises in investigating counterfeiting mounted an elaborate sting operation in which officers posed as potential buyers and chatted with smugglers in the town of Tournai, near the French border, before revealing their true identities.

Two men were arrested, and a third from Antwerp, after they confessed to having produced around 1,000 copies of the unauthorised tome in Thailand for resale in Belgium.

Ironically, unscrupulous Thai forgers decided to copy the copy and produced thousands of fake albums which investigators claim are of superior quality to the Belgian version.

Tintin first appeared in print in 1929 and the stories of his hair-raising adventures have sold more than 175m copies around the world.

fields.headline: Extra-strength Dons end Venables run
fields.trailText: Wimbledon 3 - 1 Middlesbrough
fields.body:
Wimbledon's never-say-die spirit won them the remaining place in the last 16 last night and finally burst the bubble that Terry Venables blew at Boro in mid-December. Five minutes into extra-time Jason Euell rounded off a double exchange with Peter Hawkins by blasting in his 16th goal of the season.

Ugo Ehiogu, who had flung himself to stop Euell's first attempt, was sent off moments later for laying out Mark Williams in the jostling at a Boro free-kick. By the time Jonathan Hunt scored another the game was up for Boro, and Wycombe's manager Lawrie Sanchez will have the pleasure on Saturday of entertaining the side for whom he scored the Cup final winner in 1988.

This was the first time Venables had been back to Selhurst since, as manager of Crystal Palace, he departed in a puff of melodramatic smoke and familiar suspicion. Now he came trailing clouds of glory, unbeaten in a dozen games as Boro's emergency saviour. He also came without a fair number of first-team regulars, most notably Christian Karembeu suffering an eye injury. Alen Boksic, nursing a groin strain, started on the bench.

But Venables still had a solid-looking back three and it is the defensive discipline he has drilled into the side that has turned morale and results round. They needed it from the outset as Wimbledon came at them strongly. Gianluca Festa was forced into a sequence of diving headers to clear crosses.

Wimbledon had passed their time since earning the goal-less draw at the Riverside last week sharpening their sights with four goals on Saturday that disposed of Sheffield Wednesday, manager and all. They had also disposed of the man, John Hartson, whose penalty knocked Boro out of the Worthington Cup on Halloween. But that was when Bryan Robson was in charge.

Boro had a couple of bright moments at the start, first when Hamilton Ricard turned near the penalty spot only to meet a firm tackle by Williams as he was poised to shoot. Then Brian Deane dummied past Darren Holloway on the left, making room for a run and cross. But there the brightness died.

The pitch quickly became poached and neither side found it conducive to constructive play. In fact, both resigned themselves to the hopelessness of playing decently on it. One-touch foot ball ruled - one touch by Wimbledon, one by Boro.

Just past the half-hour there was a flurry of excitement after a stunning block by Ehiogu that saw Damien Francis carried off. Before he was replaced, Curtis Fleming centred for Phil Stamp to head firmly at Kelvin Davis, and in the next minute Gareth Ainsworth provided Mark Schwarzer with his first taste of action.

The breakthrough owed most to Paul Ince's determination to win a bouncing ball 25 yards out. He slipped it to Ricard, who found the top corner of the net from 20 yards.

The goal not only brought a storming response from Wimbledon, who mustered three corners in succession straight after the interval and saw Gianluca Festa again at the heart of the resistance, it also persuaded Boro that the air was not the only way to progress.

It was looking as if their new policy might pay off but with 16 minutes to go and Wimbledon throwing men forward, Ehiogu pulled back Euell, Neil Ardley converted the penalty and the game was level again.

• You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Dismay at paedophile sentences
fields.standfirst:
Dismay at child porn terms

Special report: Child protection
fields.trailText: Leading children's charities yesterday united to condemn the leniency of sentences handed down to seven members of a global child pornography ring for distributing more than 750,000 images of child sex abuse.
fields.body:
Leading children's charities yesterday united to condemn the leniency of sentences handed down to seven members of a global child pornography ring for distributing more than 750,000 images of child sex abuse.

The men, all members of an international ring of 180 paedophiles known as the Wonderland Club, were jailed for between 12 and 30 months. They were spared the three-year maximum jail term the law allows because they pleaded guilty to the charges. Only two of the men were placed on the sex offenders register for life.

Seven children's charities, including the NSPCC, Barnardo's and the Children's Society, said they were "deeply disappointed" by the sentences handed down by Judge Kenneth Macrae at Kingston crown court. He told the men that despite "pandering to the basest interests of man" they would have to be given credit for pleading guilty to conspiracy to distribute indecent images of children.

John Carr, internet consultant with NCH, formerly known as National Children's Homes, said child sex abuse was always a serious issue, but yesterday's sentences sent out a "contrary message" to child sex offenders who use the internet. "The leniency displayed today seems to say that this type of child sex abuse will be tolerated by today's society."

However, detectives involved in the case said they were satisfied the judge had awarded the longest terms he could under the law.

Last month the law was changed to increase the penalty for distributing child pornography to a maximum of 10 years, but it cannot be applied retrospectively.

The seven men were arrested on September 2 1998 as part of Operation Cathedral, one of the largest international police operations ever carried out, involving raids across three continents. The investigation began after US customs officers arrested internet paedophiles in 1997 and discovered that they were swapping images of child pornography with Ian Baldock, 31, an Oxford University Press computer consultant from St Leonards, East Sussex.

When Sussex police seized Baldock's computer they discovered he belonged to an international club named Wonderland, a global 24-hour internet library containing, in the words of the prosecution lawyer, "some of the worst images of child abuse ever seen".

The club, which police believe had been operating for at least five years, was protected by powerful gatekeeping and encryption devices and had a rule book providing tips on how to avoid detection by police. Members, who police said regarded themselves as the elite of world paedophiles, had to provide 10,000 new images of child pornography as an entry fee.

Officers tracked down the internet service providers being used by the men logging on to the site so they could trace their names and addresses.

Police discovered that more than 1,263 children featured in the pictures and videos, many of whom suffered appalling injuries and were seen sobbing uncontrollably as they were sexually violated. So far only 17 have been identified - six in the UK, seven in the US, one in Portugal, one in Chile and one in Argentina.

The investigation resulted in 50 convictions worldwide while 22 men are still awaiting trial.

Baldock, along with David Hines, an unemployed man from Bognor Regis who used the name "Matt's Nutts" in the Wonderland Club, were both jailed for 30 months and placed on the sex offenders register for life.

Ahmed Ali, 31, a taxi driver from Tulse Hill in south London who called himself "Caesar"; Andrew Barlow, 25, from Milton Keynes who was known as "Mix", and Gavin Seagers, 29, a computer consultant and sea cadets youth leader nicknamed "Spank Daddy" from Dartford, Kent, were sentenced to two years and placed on the sex offenders register for seven years.

Antoni Skinner, from Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, who used the pseudonyms "Uhura" and "Satan", and Frederick Stephens, 46, a taxi driver from Hayes, west London, nicknamed "Guess Who" and "Me Again", were jailed for 12 months and placed on the register for seven years.

As the seven men stood in the dock the judge told them: "You used your computer skills to commit crimes decent people find unimaginable. Whether directly or indirectly, you exploited the most vulnerable. Not protected by adults, they were degraded and submitted to acts of great depravity. The photographic record is proof of your perversity."

He ordered that they should serve at least half their sentences and remain on licence for the remainder.

Outside court the officers of the National Crime Squad who led the two-year investigation spoke of their relief. DCI Alex Wood said their work had brought changes in the policing of paedophiles around the world, including the UK's harsher sentencing.

"This has been driven to some extent by the Cathedral inquiry. Paedophiles appearing in court today will receive much more severe sentences because of this legislation.

"A number of countries have introduced legislation as a result of this inquiry and our investigation has been on the worldwide stage."

Detective Superintendent Peter Spindler, who was in overall charge of the operation, said the convictions were a victory. "We had to take on the operation to highlight the level of appalling behaviour on the internet. It has contributed to change."

webTitle: 'TiVo for radio' set for UK launch

fields.headline: 'TiVo for radio' set for UK launch
fields.trailText: 10.45am: New digital radio technology being billed as 'TiVo for radio' will launch in the UK this year, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
New digital radio technology allowing listeners to pre-programme and record their favourite shows from different stations will launch in the UK before the end of the year.

Capital Radio and the MXR digital radio consortium, which includes Chrysalis, Capital, Jazz, and Guardian Media Group, have signed up to develop personalised services based on the new technology, which is being billed as TiVo for radio.

The US firm behind the technology, Command Audio, is also planning to sign deals with manufacturers to ensure its software is pre-installed in all digital radio receivers.

The Command Audio software, which could end up being installed in car radios, Walkmans and digital radio boxes, can store eight hours of content.

Capital Radio and commercial radio services group UBC Media have set up a joint venture with Command Audio, called Command Audio UK, to set to up a licensing body and produce on-demand interactive programmes using the new technology.

"Command Audio UK will enable digital broadcasters to deliver a truly new media experience that will clearly differentiate their services from conventional FM radio," said Don Bogue, co-founder and chief executive of Command Audio.

Command Audio has also signed a deal with MXR, which owns the regional digital radio multiplex licences for the north-east and south Wales/Severn estuary and is bidding for other franchises around the country.

MXR has committed to carry Command Audio services on all its regional digital multiplexes.

After spending four years developing the software in the US, Command Audio is positioning itself as the added value component of a digital radio box in the UK.

The company said it was talking to all radio operators and manufacturers and is on target to launch its first programming service by Christmas.

In the US, Command Audio has been running an analogue service for the past 10 months, working with publications including the Wall Street Journal, Business Week, Fortune, Time, USA Today and TV shows such as Nightline and The NewsHour to produce audio broadcasts.

Digital radio promises to reshape the industry, offering new data services combined with better quality reception.

The only drawback at present is that the roll-out of the technology has been hampered by the high cost of digital radio sets, which are currently on sale at around £300.

Broadcasting minister Janet Anderson last week called on digital radio manufacturers to cut prices in a bid to stimulate consumer interest.
