Seven children's charities, including the NSPCC, Barnardo's and the Children's Society, said they were "deeply disappointed" by the sentences handed down by Judge Kenneth Macrae at Kingston crown court. He told the men that despite "pandering to the basest interests of man" they would have to be given credit for pleading guilty to conspiracy to distribute indecent images of children. John Carr, internet consultant with NCH, formerly known as National Children's Homes, said child sex abuse was always a serious issue, but yesterday's sentences sent out a "contrary message" to child sex offenders who use the internet. "The leniency displayed today seems to say that this type of child sex abuse will be tolerated by today's society." However, detectives involved in the case said they were satisfied the judge had awarded the longest terms he could under the law. Last month the law was changed to increase the penalty for distributing child pornography to a maximum of 10 years, but it cannot be applied retrospectively. The seven men were arrested on September 2 1998 as part of Operation Cathedral, one of the largest international police operations ever carried out, involving raids across three continents. The investigation began after US customs officers arrested internet paedophiles in 1997 and discovered that they were swapping images of child pornography with Ian Baldock, 31, an Oxford University Press computer consultant from St Leonards, East Sussex. When Sussex police seized Baldock's computer they discovered he belonged to an international club named Wonderland, a global 24-hour internet library containing, in the words of the prosecution lawyer, "some of the worst images of child abuse ever seen". The club, which police believe had been operating for at least five years, was protected by powerful gatekeeping and encryption devices and had a rule book providing tips on how to avoid detection by police. Members, who police said regarded themselves as the elite of world paedophiles, had to provide 10,000 new images of child pornography as an entry fee. Officers tracked down the internet service providers being used by the men logging on to the site so they could trace their names and addresses. Police discovered that more than 1,263 children featured in the pictures and videos, many of whom suffered appalling injuries and were seen sobbing uncontrollably as they were sexually violated. So far only 17 have been identified - six in the UK, seven in the US, one in Portugal, one in Chile and one in Argentina. The investigation resulted in 50 convictions worldwide while 22 men are still awaiting trial. Baldock, along with David Hines, an unemployed man from Bognor Regis who used the name "Matt's Nutts" in the Wonderland Club, were both jailed for 30 months and placed on the sex offenders register for life. Ahmed Ali, 31, a taxi driver from Tulse Hill in south London who called himself "Caesar"; Andrew Barlow, 25, from Milton Keynes who was known as "Mix", and Gavin Seagers, 29, a computer consultant and sea cadets youth leader nicknamed "Spank Daddy" from Dartford, Kent, were sentenced to two years and placed on the sex offenders register for seven years. Antoni Skinner, from Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, who used the pseudonyms "Uhura" and "Satan", and Frederick Stephens, 46, a taxi driver from Hayes, west London, nicknamed "Guess Who" and "Me Again", were jailed for 12 months and placed on the register for seven years. As the seven men stood in the dock the judge told them: "You used your computer skills to commit crimes decent people find unimaginable. Whether directly or indirectly, you exploited the most vulnerable. Not protected by adults, they were degraded and submitted to acts of great depravity. The photographic record is proof of your perversity." He ordered that they should serve at least half their sentences and remain on licence for the remainder. Outside court the officers of the National Crime Squad who led the two-year investigation spoke of their relief. DCI Alex Wood said their work had brought changes in the policing of paedophiles around the world, including the UK's harsher sentencing. "This has been driven to some extent by the Cathedral inquiry. Paedophiles appearing in court today will receive much more severe sentences because of this legislation. "A number of countries have introduced legislation as a result of this inquiry and our investigation has been on the worldwide stage." Detective Superintendent Peter Spindler, who was in overall charge of the operation, said the convictions were a victory. "We had to take on the operation to highlight the level of appalling behaviour on the internet. It has contributed to change."

webTitle: Letters: Richard Branson on the lottery

fields.headline: Branson: I'll give the money to charity
fields.trailText: In a letter to the Guardian Sir Richard Branson assures he will not reduce the amount of money "going to good causes".
fields.body:
I haven't spent 15 years of my life campaigning to see the lottery run with 100% of its profits going to good causes to end up "reducing the amount of money going to good causes"

We were a day from taking over the lottery when the commission's lawyers acknowledged they had made a mistake. As a result it cost us millions to keep the show on the road. Our legal advice is that we have very good grounds for compensation.

There are those who are mischievously suggesting (to deter us from making a claim, I believe) that compensation should come out of the Good Cause Fund rather than from the Treasury.

The Treasury makes billions from the lottery in a special lottery tax. That is where any compensation should come from.

However, since our action is about principle rather than money, I assure you that if the government does insist that the money comes from the Good Cause Fund, then any costs I do retrieve I would either give to charity or (if Camelot's sales keep falling and subject to laws permitting) use it to set up a rival lottery with 100% of profits going to good causes.

Richard Branson
The People's Lottery

webTitle: Mel stays on top with Women at UK box office

fields.headline: Mel stays on top with Women at UK box office
fields.trailText: The Mel Gibson romantic comedy What Women Wants makes it two weeks at number one and The Adventures of Rocky and Bullwinkle has a suprisingly strong opening weekend
fields.body:
What Women Want has retained the number one slot at the UK box office for the second week in a row by taking a further £2.5m, according to figures from Screen Daily.

The closest competitor to Mel Gibson's romantic comedy was the American teen pic Dude, Where's My Car which earned £943,442 to take second place. The Oscar-nominated Traffic continues to do well, retaining the number three position. However, all three films are expected to be eclipsed next week by the arrival of Hannibal in UK cinemas on Friday.

Surprisingly, the much hyped Cameron Crowe rock flick Almost Famous only managed to take sixth position, grossing just over £500,000 over its opening weekend. Even more unexpected was the success of the much-slated The Adventures of Rocky and Bullwinkle which took a healthy £709,299. Expectations for the film, featuring Robert de Niro and Renee Russo, were low after it failed to set box offices in the US or Australia alight, but with UK schools on half term next week, the film is expected to continue to do well.

Other openers last week included Denzel Washington's football saga Remember the Titans which reached ninth position with £275,000 and Michael Winterbottom's Thomas Hardy adaptation The Claim which earned £38,000 to make number fourteen.

webTitle: Sane and Mind - a relationship on the mend

fields.headline: Sane and Mind - a relationship on the mend
fields.trailText: The campaign for a new Mental Health Act is doing much to reunite two mental health charities renowned for their very public discord.
fields.body:
The campaign for a new Mental Health Act is doing much to reunite two mental health charities renowned for their very public discord.

Mind (the National Association for Mental Health) and Sane are now campaigning together as part of the mental health alliance. The alliance wants a mental health act that will include a legal right to treatment as well as reducing the use of compulsory powers.

This agreement suggests a major move forward for the two charities, which are famous for attacking each other in the past.

Their differences stem from fundamental disagreements on how people with mental illnesses should be treated.

Sane says it promotes a "holistic" approach to treatment, and advocates the use of anti-psychotic and anti-depressant drugs as part of that. Its chief executive, Marjorie Wallace, has said the drugs can "offer very many sufferers a stability and quality of life which would otherwise be denied them".

In contrast, Mind believes these drugs are over-used and that not enough attention is paid to their possible side-effects. The charity's yellow card scheme encourages people taking medication to report their own suspected adverse drug reactions to the committee on safety of medicines via Mind.

The two organisations also differ on their views about mental hospitals. Since its creation in 1946, Mind has campaigned for a move away from Victorian mental hospitals and towards community-based care.

Sane has campaigned against the scrapping of mental health hospital beds, and argued that asylums can be a haven for those unable to cope. The charity does support the concept of community care, but says it must be adequately funded, and that there must be a backstop of in-patient care.

These differences came to a head in a very public dispute in 1995. Mind produced a fundraising circular playing upon the adverse effects of drug treatment. Its message contradicted Sane's campaigns. The leaflet asked: "What if we died from the drugs prescribed? Unthinkable? For most of the population, yes. But for people diagnosed severely mentally ill the answer is not clear cut."

In response, Marjorie Wallace, chief executive of Sane, wrote a letter to a number of MPs and newspapers expressing her concern that the leaflet was "designed to scare" those suffering from mental illness. She accused Mind of "crude propaganda " which would "feed paranoia".

However, the situation is now much more harmonious. Mind say its relationship with Sane has improved dramatically over the past three years.

Mind's policy director, Melba Wilson, said: "We've moved on from that bit of history. Mind's purpose is to work for a better life for the mentally ill. We are not out to pick fights."

Ms Wallace said: "Sane has never believed that medication and beds alone are the answer. Although we consider that both can form an important part of treatment for some people with serious mental illness, we have always advocated a holistic approach which takes full account of the person's psychological, emotional and social needs. Sane has never advocated 'tranquillising' drugs."

She added: "Sane and Mind have a different history, emphasis and perspective. There will continue to be differences of emphasis and approach, but through our joint working and shared membership of the mental health alliance we both campaign for rights and treatment, less compulsion and improved safeguards for the individual. These shared aims unite us far more than past differences."

The mental health alliance represents a united focus to fight for the issues that matter across the mental health industry.

It seems that this is one much publicised "bust-up" that looks likely to be transformed into a "love-in".

fields.headline: Hague misled Commons over charity
fields.trailText: William Hague was last night forced to admit to making misleading claims that he distributes the profits from public speaking engagements to a charitable trust which has never actually been estalished in law.
fields.body:
William Hague was last night forced to admit to making misleading claims that he distributes the profits from public speaking engagements to a charitable trust which has never actually been estalished in law.

The Conservative party issued a statement in the wake of an investigation by Channel 4's Mark Thomas Product and the Daily Mirror. It highlighted discrepancies between the Tory leader's claim in the Commons register of MPs' interests and the absence of any official record of the William Hague Charitable Trust.

MPs are expected to declare earnings in excess of £500 for appearances, even if the money is given to a designated charity. In the US, where disclosure laws have long been in place, it is a notorious field of contention.

There was no immediate indication of how much money was involved in the speeches the Tory leader may have make - though such an accomplished after-dinner performer as Mr Hague could be expected to command up to £10,000 for prestigious commercial events.

According to the Commons register in 1999 and 2000, Mr Hague declared: "Any fees received as a result of speaking will be paid into the William Hague Charitable Trust.

"Donations from this trust will be distributed by an independent board of trustees to charitable organisations in my constituency."

But this week's investigation establised that the trust does not exist, though its existence had been logged with the Commons register in advance.

Conservative Central Office said in a statement: "Since the trust has not been set up, it will not be included in future registers of members' interests. Any speaking fees, etcetera, are therefore given to local charities."

Labour's Fraser Kemp and the senior Liberal Democrat MP Malcolm Bruce, a member of the parliamentary standards and privileges committee, were both critical of Mr Hague, who has not previously fallen foul of rules governing disclosure of MPs' private financial interests, imposed in the post-Nolan anti-sleaze era.

Mr Kemp told BBC2's Newsnight: "If people are receiving large amounts of money from speaking and are indiating that they are giving it to charity, then I think that should be in the public domain. I think the public deserve and expect nothing less."

Mr Bruce was equally forthright on the same programme. "Anybody reading the entry would assume that Mr Hague was anticipating and presumably getting substantial sums of money from speaking outside parliament and was using that money to give to charity."

The row may intensify private complaints, widespread among Tory MPs, that the leader's office is badly run despite Mr Hague's past career as a management consultant with the cult firm of McKinseys.

Echoing Mr Kemp's demand for greater disclosure, Mr Bruce added: "To leave the register running for more than two years without any change is, frankly, extraordinary for the leader of the main opposition party.

"One would assume that he would have gone out of his way to make sure that his entry was cleared and correct."

fields.headline: Judges order jail death inquest
fields.trailText: The family of a young paranoid schizophrenic who hanged himself with his shoelaces while on remand in Wandsworth prison won an order for a new inquest yesterday. The prison was strongly criticised for failing to take steps to prevent his death.
fields.body:
The family of a young paranoid schizophrenic who hanged himself with his shoelaces while on remand in Wandsworth prison won an order for a new inquest yesterday. The prison was strongly criticised for failing to take steps to prevent his death.

Two senior judges at the high court in London ordered a fresh inquest into the death of Keita Craig, 22, son of the Culture Club bass player Mikey Craig. He was one of seven inmates who killed themselves at the south London prison last year. Lord Justice Keene and Mr Justice Penry-Davey ruled that the Westminster coroner, Paul Knapman, was wrong in law to deny the inquest jury the option of a verdict that neglect had been a factor in the death.

There was evidence of "a gross failure" on the part of the prison, Mr Justice Penry-Davey said. Mr Craig hanged himself with his shoelaces at the prison in February last year. They had been removed from him at the magistrates court, but he was given them back in prison even though staff were warned he was a suicide risk.

What was striking was the substantial amount of knowledge the prison had about Mr Craig's condition, Lord Justice Keene said. "This was a young man already diagnosed as a paranoid schizophrenic who killed himself in the Wandsworth prison health-care centre while, as the inquest jury found, the balance of his mind was disturbed. The fact that he suffered from that mental illness was known to those who were responsible for him at Wandsworth prison."

Mr Justice Penry-Davy said: "The restoration of shoelaces to the deceased combined with the failure to keep the deceased under proper observation resulted in his death, and in my judgment there was evidence of gross failure to provide medical attention where the mental state of the deceased obviously called for such attention."

Last April the inquest jury returned a verdict that Mr Craig killed himself while the balance of his mind was disturbed. Dr Knapman had told the jury that the ingredients for neglect "were not present" and barred them from including a finding of neglect in the verdict.

"But there was evidence on which they could properly conclude that such a verdict was justified. In those circumstances the coroner was wrong not to leave such a verdict to the jury," Lord Justice Keene said.

Mr Craig had been arrested over street robbery allegations, and Richmond magistrates had remanded him to Wandsworth while a place was found for him in a psychiatric unit. His solicitor and a social worker expressed concern for his well-being and Tracey Lowe, a probation officer, was alerted.

Ms Lowe faxed the prison making it clear that Mr Craig was a suicide risk. She also spoke to a deputy prison governor. A concerned Securicor guard ordered Mr Craig's shoelaces to be taken away. At the prison Mr Craig underwent a five- to seven-minute medical examination. A form for those at risk of self-harm was not properly completed and nursing staff were not made aware or given special instructions.

He was seen by a 73-year-old prison doctor, Somasunderam Pothalingam, who had also assessed two remand inmates at Brixton jail in south London who hanged themselves two months before Mr Craig. Dr Pothalingam told the inquest into the Brixton prisoners' deaths this month: "It's not practical to spend more than a few minutes with each patient."

fields.headline: Toymaker releases 'smart bugs' into the UK
fields.trailText: 10am: Hasbro is launching a new range of toys designed to mimic the behaviour of real bugs, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
If you have a phobia about insects, it will be best to avoid a new range of toys from Hasbro which are designed to mimic the behaviour of real bugs.

Hasbro's range of BIO - bio-mechanical integrated organisms - Bugs will be launched in the US later this year and arrive in the UK early next year.

They use "nervous network" robot technology to react to external stimuli - walls, people, other bugs - in the way real insects would.

"BIO Bugs decide what they do because they are just like real bugs only without the tissue, with a battery as a heart and nervous technology acting as its brain," said Peter Yanofsky, president of Hasbro's Wow Wee division, which developed the range.

The bugs will be sold in four colours, with each colour representing a different species with its own characteristics.

A green bug has the ability to operate over a rough terrain, while a yellow bug prefers smooth surfaces.

The range is aimed at children six and above but is not recommended for avid readers of William Burroughs's novels.

webTitle: The problems of illegal fly posting

fields.headline: Taking a pasting
fields.standfirst: Walls plastered with tattered posters don't fit the government's 'urban renaissance' image. But as big business profits from illegal fly posting, is there a way to cut councils' clean-up costs? By Paul Humphries
fields.trailText:
As big business profits from illegal fly posting, is there a way to cut councils' clean-up costs? By Paul Humphries.
SocietyGuardian.co.uk
fields.body:
Big business and local government are spending millions of pounds each year on fly posting. The difference is, companies are pocketing a massive profit from illegal advertising while councils are left to pick up the bill for keeping the streets clean.

There is no city or large town that has not seen streets blighted by the sight of peeling wall posters overlaid with the latest news of a record release or a band on tour. For people in the music business, and other companies wanting to hit the young and hip, fly posting reaches a specific market and gives the brand the instant image of street credibility.

But if using the streets to get the message across rings the corporate cash tills, there is also the cost to the local authority and its council tax payers. The Tidy Britain Group estimates that £340m of public money is spent each year on clearing up litter and a good proportion of this is used to combat fly posting. In a survey of city centres, it found fly posting on 12% of the streets it looked at.

Now the government is urging local authorities to clamp down and sweep illegal advertising off the streets. With its sights firmly fixed on an "urban renaissance", and with millions of pounds being poured into urban regeneration, it wants local government to act against illegal fly posting, which it believes blights an area and is symptomatic of urban decay.

One of the problems is that fly posting is a relatively cheap form of advertising. The Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions (DETR) estimates that a company is charged £1.50 for each poster used in its campaign. For a large record company, seeing 50,000 of these posters on the streets promoting a band's album is money well spent. With 250,000 posters going up in a good week, it is also a big earner for the handful of fly posting companies that control the distribution business throughout Britain. No one is going to go without a fight.

For years, cash-strapped local authorities have been weighed down by the cost of cleaning up fly posting. Camden council, in north London, estimates it spends £100,000 a year. It has street cleaning teams out removing posters; covers lamp posts with textured paint which cannot be glued to; builds timber strips on hoardings to make them unusable for fly posting; and spends time advising owners of derelict and empty properties how to keep their sites clean. The council attempts to pursue offenders through the courts and has four cases listed at Highbury magistrates court next month, with 30 in the pipeline.

Legal action can be taken through the courts in a number of ways. The main route is section 224 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, and there are also provisions in the Highways Act of 1980. Authorities can prosecute when people are caught fly posting red-handed, but more often action is taken against the beneficiaries - the people and organisations whose products are advertised.

Camden council takes these on, rather than individuals who fly post, but the fines are small. When the authority successfully prosecuted Creation Records over fly posting for the Oasis album Stand By Me, the company received a fine of £1,800 and was ordered to pay costs of £2,000. When the authority tried to prosecute Boo.com in November for stickers allegedly placed on lamp posts, the US-owned company refused to give an address where papers could be served and the council was unable to proceed with its action.

Taking the opposite approach, Birmingham city council has been granted a court injunction against a persistent fly posterer, who has been prosecuted eight times in the past six years. Richard Smith appeared before Birmingham crown court a fortnight ago and was banned from fly posting in the city. His court appearances have seen him fined a total of £2,110, with costs of £901. Legal proceedings are currently being considered against him for further incidents that allegedly took place last year. And if he breaches the injunction, he could face prison.

Down the years, Birmingham council has brought more than 250 prosecutions against record companies and fly posterers. But it has been successful in only one case in nine. Fines have totalled £75,000, yet it costs the authority at least £25,000 a year just to remove the posters and stickers. The council thinks it is becoming a victim of its own success in marketing Birmingham as a "night time economy", making it a particular target for fly posters advertising records, clubs and events.

But it is not only the music business that uses fly posting to reach the punters. Political campaigns of right and left have for centuries used the medium to get across their message. And mainstream media - including, in the past, the Guardian - have started to experiment with unauthorised street promotions. Last year, even Britain's most popular "soap" jumped on the bandwagon when a street poster campaign was run to promote a particular episode of Coronation Street. Bills publicising the murder trial of Street villain Jez Quigley went up on walls, roadside junction boxes and bus stops in London and Manchester. They were removed only after Manchester city council threatened legal action.

Alan Woods, chief executive of the Tidy Britain Group, says: "We feel that those businesses that use fly posting to advertise are letting the community down badly." His views are echoed by Alan Tallentine, of the Association of Town Centre Management, who argues: "Fly posting can be not only unsightly, but, in conjunction with high levels of litter and lack of street maintenance, it can be viewed by many people to indicate an area that is not safe to be in, fuelling the fear of crime and - in serious cases - the actuality of crime."

Yet fly posting may be coming in from the cold. A recent DETR report, The Control of Fly Posting: A Good Practice Guide, says a number of local authorities - Bradford, Manchester, Nottingham and Sheffield are cited - have struck agreements over what it calls "formalised sites". These are sites owned by the local authority where, by agreement, a set number of posters can go up on a regular basis and the fly posterers themselves will keep the site clean and monitor it for "rogue" posters.

Martin Pagel, deputy leader of Manchester council, is enthusiastic about the idea, which first emerged from discussions in the city five years ago. Under Manchester's version, fly posters have been allowed to mount boards on identified council proper ties. The next step, says Pagel, is to bring private property owners on board and extend the scheme throughout the city. The "official" fly poster operators would police the city, monitor the sites and clamp down on "rogues" continuing to create litter.

"We are trying to find a way of working with responsible fly posterers and we believe we are succeeding," says Pagel. "We are not against posters going up; it's just where they go that matters. These groups are running businesses and want to be seen to be part of the business community. By working together, we can all achieve something that will be for the good of the community."

Brushing up on the law

Britain is out of step with the rest of Europe in its punitive attitude towards fly posting, according to a solicitor who represents several contractors engaged in the placing of unauthorised advertisements.

Peter Dovey, of London-based Peter Dovey & Co, says local authorities need to adopt a more "enlightened" approach. Amicable and practical agreements between authorities and the fly poster industry are "clearly in the best interests" of both sides.

In Dublin, Dovey points out, there have been licensed fly posting sites for more than 10 years. These are managed by a committee made up of local authority officers and representatives of companies which distribute posters.

Such schemes have started in some British cities, including Manchester, Cardiff, Leeds and Glasgow. Where they are working, Dovey says, the spirit of realism and compromise shown by the local authorities is being reciprocated by responsible fly poster contractors.

fields.headline: De Bono turns to troubleshooting
fields.trailText: Saatchi & Saatchi and Shine Communications are setting up a business development consultancy with Edward de Bono and Ernst & Young, write Julia Snoddy and John Cassy.
fields.body:
Edward de Bono, a man who believes he is a more powerful visionary than Plato, is setting up a consultancy to assist businesses develop. Its methods will be more from the old school of trouble-shooting than the discipline of lateral thinking that Mr de Bono fathered.

He is teaming up with a group of accountants, PR men and advertising executives to form what is being billed as "a unique idea-generation, idea-implementation and idea-communication entity."

The Applied Creativity Triangle (ACT) Consortium will be launched today in partnership with Saatchi & Saatchi, Ernst & Young and PR company Shine Communications.

"There is the opportunity to harness the creativity that exists within an organisation and externally to think outside of the box and not do things in the traditional manner," said Maurice Abell, UK chief executive officer of Cap Gemini Ernst & Young.

The information that ac companies the formation of the new venture hints at what will be on offer. Itsays: "The ACT is like a car with an engine and wheels. Other 'think tanks' lack either the engine or the wheels. Or both.

"Where the usual 'think tanks' allow you to paddle around, Edward de Bono's methods get you swimming fast towards a clear destination."

Mr de Bono will provide the methods and inspiration for creative thinking, Cap Gemini Ernst & Young will manage the initial research and implement the ideas, Saatchi & Saatchi will provide the communications ideas and Shine will deal with public relations.

"We are doing it because it is interesting, groundbreaking and because there is a clear link between what a brand is in a real world and how that brand is communicated," said Derek Bowden, Saatchi & Saatchi's European chief executive officer.

Mr Bowden admitted that the exercise was an experiment for everyone involved. The group has not disclosed any fees it will charge.

webTitle: Boy George to join Kiss FM

fields.headline: Boy George to join Kiss FM
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Boy George is understood to have been signed up by Kiss FM to replace outgoing DJ duo Bobby and Steve. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Boy George is understood to have been signed up by Kiss FM to replace the outgoing DJ duo Bobby and Steve.

The former Culture Club frontman, who has been a club DJ for some years, is expected to take over on the Kiss FM decks after the pair depart their slot at the beginning of March.

Bobby and Steve have been DJs on the dance music service since it first launched as a legal radio station in 1990.

They are among the last of the station's original line-up to depart, leaving only David Rodigan, Brandon Block and Alex P.

Sources said the departure of Bobby and Steve from the station was amicable. They are going to do a slot at the Ministry of Sound.

This is the first big signing for Kiss FM since it was embroiled in a scandal over alleged racism when it purged its production team over a year ago.

Former DJ Steve Jackson took Kiss parent company Emap to a tribunal, which found that he had been unfairly dismissed, though not on racist grounds.

However, pundits claim that black music has been marginalised on the station.

fields.headline: Crusading Indian firm takes on might of Glaxo SmithKline
fields.standfirst: Cipla is offering anti-Aids drugs at a fraction of rivals' prices
fields.trailText: Cipla is offering anti-Aids drugs at a fraction of rivals' prices.
fields.byline: Luke Harding in New Delhi and Sarah Boseley
fields.body:
Indira Gandhi decided 30 years ago that her country would go it alone, undercut the international drug giants, refuse to honour their patents and make its own cut-price versions of their medicines. Now India's leading drug company, Cipla, is at the centre of the battle for cheap medicines elsewhere in the developing world, and it is taking on the British giant Glaxo SmithKline.

Cipla is offering a three-drug anti-Aids cocktail of stavudrine, lamivudine and nevirapine for just $600 (£430) to governments and $350 to Médecins sans Frontières, the volunteer doctors who have set up Aids clinics in sub-Saharan Africa. The drug cocktails sell for between $10,000 and $15,000 in the west.

The offer puts pressure on the five big producers of Aids drugs, including Glaxo SmithKline, that have offered to discount their prices by up to 85% for African states.

Glaxo SmithKline has warned Cipla off from selling its cheap copy of Combivir - a combination of AZT and 3TC (lamivudine) - in Ghana and Uganda, saying it has patent rights in those countries. But Cipla's offer, particularly to MSF, risks wrong-footing the drug giants.

Sir Richard Sykes, chairman of Glaxo SmithKline, says the generic companies are "pirates". He claims the price of medicines is not the only reason why millions of people with HIV/Aids are dying. The political will to spend money on medicines is sometimes lacking, and developing countries do not have the clinics and doctors that are vital to ensure that Aids drugs are properly used, he says.

India exports vast quantities of cheap generic drugs to the Middle East, Latin America and Africa. Yet Cipla faces new patent legislation enforced under trade deals which threaten its export business.

Dr Yusuf Hamied, Cipla's chairman, says the bargain price he has now placed on the table is a response to the massive disaster that Aids represents. Unlike last month's Indian earthquake, Aids is an "entirely predictable tragedy", he says. "In this disaster there is room for everybody."

Cipla can afford to undercut its western rivals because, in common with India's 23,000 drug firms, it spends almost nothing on research and development.

As soon as a new drug hits the market, Indian scientists break down its molecular structure, helped in their task by the internet, where pharmaceutical formulas are freely available.

Dr Hamied says without cheap generic drugs, millions of poor would have no access to medicines. "We have never been against patents. We have been against monopoly, because monopoly leads to higher prices," he says.

fields.headline: Ministers to scrap retirement age
fields.trailText: The over-60s will be able to escape the poverty of old age under anti-discrimination laws which will make it illegal to ban them from working as long as they like.
fields.body:
The over-60s will be able to escape the poverty of old age under anti-discrimination laws which will make it illegal to ban them from working as long as they like.

The government will today announce a working group to iron out the details of the law which will ban compulsorary retirement at any age by 2006.

Business leaders and campaign groups for the elderly will be consulted.

Ministers are determined to eradicate a set retirement age - currently 60 for women and 65 for men - while ensuring the law is workable. "We want to ensure we get it right," a Department of Employment spokesman said.

The measure, to be signalled by the junior employment minister, Margaret Hodge, in a Commons committee hearing today, is being brought in to comply with a European Union directive agreed last year.

The directive seeks to outlaw discrimination against people at work on the grounds of religion, age, disability or sexual orientation in the next six years.

A third of men and women aged 50-65 - 2.8m people - are no longer employed.

Last year, a cabinet office report recommended unemployed men over 60 should lose their benefits unless they proved they were looking for jobs.

The cost of economic "inactivity" among the over-50s is estimated to be at least £26bn.

Age Concern, which welcomed the measure, predicted many people would wish to defer their state pensions and continue working.

"Most people are still fairly active into their 70s and we know from anecdoctal evidence that many want to work," said spokesman Rhian Beynon.

"For some, it's because they want the recognition and stimulation of working but for some it's because they can't afford to retire on the basic state pension."

Just 60% of workers have an occupational pension on top of the £67.50 state pension, and of these half gain no more than an extra £55 a week.

Patrick Gratton, of Help the Aged, added: "This is good for employers, the economy and individuals and it does not present a problem for employers as two thirds of men do not work right up until the retirement age anyway."

The Tories said flexible retirement chimed with the responsible society they wished to create.

The Liberal Democrats' social security spokesman, Steve Webb, said: "There is a real waste of talent when people are forced to retire when they do not want to. Businesses should also welcome this."

But the Confederation of British Industry insisted "flexibility - not a 'one size fits all' solution" had to be "the name of the game.

"Doing away with contractual retirement ages without consulting employers is not the solution," said the CBI director-general, Digby Jones.

webTitle: Service users call for real job opportunities

fields.headline: Service users call for real job opportunities
fields.trailText: Most mental health service users want to hold down demanding jobs but are only offered confidence-boosting training that ill equips them to return to a competitive job market.
fields.body:
Most mental health service users want to hold down demanding jobs but are only offered confidence-boosting training that ill equips them to return to a competitive job market.

Pioneering mental health professionals want the NHS to end this by promptly employing users in existing posts within trusts, rather than putting them in supervised workshops for weeks or even months. This will show other employers that users can hold down competitive jobs.

Research published in the British Medical Journal last month confirmed that prevocational training - from sheltered workshops to confidence- building programmes - rarely leads to employment.

Peter Huxley, professor of social work at the Institute of Psychiatry, and colleagues found supported employment schemes, which place service users in work without lengthy preparation, were far more likely to lead to competitive jobs.

After 12 months, 34% of people with severe mental health problems in such schemes were in work - compared with 12% of those in prevocational training.

Several NHS trusts are employing service users in competitive jobs. south-west London and St George's mental health trust established a supported employment programme in 1995, which to date has helped 43 service users into existing posts within the trust.

Clinical psychologist Dr Rachel Perkins, clinical director of rehabilitation services, said the scheme had a 90% success rate. "We realised if we were going to be asking other employers to take on people with mental health problems we needed to set our own house in order," she commented.

The trust has drawn up a charter of employment that says experience of mental health problems is desirable in employees. "About 16% of the staff we took on last year had such experience," said Dr Perkins.

The psychologist said the trust was now piloting a scheme to find jobs for service users with other employers. "We have an employment specialist attached to the community mental health team. Last year 35% of the 55 clients she helped went on to employment elsewhere."

Dr Perkins said vocational services needed to become an integral part of each service user's care plan. "The national service framework says enhanced care plans should include occupational help but that is not widespread practice yet," she said.

North Birmingham mental health trust has set up its own supported employment service called Tempo based on the London model. Director of adult services Jo Beale said traditional workshops, which only offered packing jobs, had failed to move people into meaningful employment.

Service user Susan Smith was employed as a secretary by the trust after joining Tempo in 1999. "I'd been a sales manager before I got depression in 1994. But after five years in the system, I felt like a vegetable. I asked the trust how could employers be expected to take me on if they wouldn't?"

However, Mrs Smith believes Tempo has prepared her for work outside the trust. "I'd handled several accounts in my old job. I knew what I could do, I just needed the opportunity. It can still be daunting when someone gives me a difficult job to do but it's restored my faith in my own abilities."

 Service user's name changed by request

webTitle: More money for secure mental health

fields.headline: Place of safety
fields.standfirst: More money for secure mental health
fields.trailText: More money for secure mental health
fields.body:
Some 320 new places are to be provided in prisons and hospitals for the assessment and treatment of "dangerous" people with severe personality disorder, home secretary Jack Straw has this week announced.

The scheme includes a new specialist treatment project at the high security Whitemoor prison, Cambridgeshire, which will develop a range of new therapeutic treatments, and a new unit at Frankland prison, Co. Durham, which will provide 100 assessment and treatment places. A 70-place unit is also being built at the high security Rampton hospital, with opening scheduled next year. A further 70 places are to be made available within the NHS.

The announcement represents the second phase of the government's programme to deal with this group.

The first pilot schemes, unveiled last September and located at Whitemoor and Rampton, are designed to research a rigorous assessment tool to help identify those to be included.

Straw says £126m is being made available over the next three years.

fields.headline: ASA slams 'misleading' British pork adverts
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Three government-funded adverts for British pork have been criticised as 'misleading' by the ASA, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
Three government-funded press advertisements promoting British pork have been rapped as "misleading" by the Advertising Standards Authority.

It is the thirteenth time in five years the advertising watchdog has ruled against the Meat and Livestock Commission, which represents the UK meat producing industry.

The MLC's latest £4.6m campaign portrayed pig farming standards in the UK as superior to those in continental Europe.

One advert featured a photograph of a pig's snout with an arrow pointing to the edge of the frame. The strapline read, "The longest walk some pigs can ever look forward to."

The campaign set out to convince consumers that by buying pork with the British Meat Quality Standard mark, they would not be supporting such cruel farming practices.

But animal welfare groups, the Danish Bacon and Meat Council and members of the public complained that the adverts - paid for jointly by the MLC and the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food - were untrue.

The ASA upheld complaints against three of seven adverts and agreed the pictures would lead the public to believe most pigs were farmed outdoors, which is not the case.

It asked the MLC to withdraw the offending adverts and take greater care not to mislead in the future.

Animal welfare group Vegetarian International Voice for Animals criticised the ASA for taking so long to act.

The MLC was carpeted by advertising watchdogs five years ago at the height of the BSE crisis for claiming British beef was safe to eat.

fields.headline: TV drama loses plot as leisure shows thrive
fields.standfirst:
With the two main networks increasingly reliant on soaps, the ITC warns that Britain's cultural interests must not be forgotten

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: With the two main networks increasingly reliant on soaps, the ITC warns that Britain's cultural interests must not be forgotten.
fields.body:
TV viewers are being fed an increasingly meagre diet of soaps, quizzes and leisure shows. Over the past 25 years, peak-time drama on BBC1 has nosedived in favour of programmes such as Ground Force and Changing Rooms, while the two main TV networks have become increasingly reliant upon the likes of Coronation Street and EastEnders.

Warning that BBC1 must continue to be the bedrock of quality television if public service broadcasting is to survive, the independent television commission said its peak-time schedules were concentrated on a narrow range of programmes.

The only consolation in this bleak picture is that most of today's programmes are made in Britain. The days when Dallas and Dynasty dominated the listings magazines are long gone, according to research commissioned by the ITC.

An analysis of the peak-time schedules on BBC1 and ITV in November - the heart of the competitive autumn season -showed that both networks relied upon on a narrow range of shows. Over the past 25 years on BBC1 and ITV together, soaps have increased by 150%.

Drama on BBC1 has halved to 11%, replaced by "hobbies and leisure, quiz shows and features" which have shot up from 3% in the 1970s to 27% last November. By contrast, the range and diversity of programmes on BBC2 and Channel 4 remained consistent.

Patricia Hodgson, the chief executive of the ITC and a former BBC policy chief, said the corporation must remain true to its public service tradition as competition increases in the multi-channel age. "The BBC is the basis of the system and BBC1 the core. ITV must compete with it and BBC2 and Channel 4 complement it. When BBC1 moves, so will the rest. So BBC1 must provide a sure foundation if public service is to survive."

Her remarks come as the government considers the future of communications regulation, and at a time when the BBC is reorganising its TV channels. BBC1 will continue to be a broad-based channel, but its peak-time schedule is likely to concentrate even more on entertainment and drama. While ITV is forced to show a wide range of programmes across clearly defined genres, the BBC's system of self-regulation is not so strict.

Ms Hodgson said while competition was healthy, the government's proposed communications super-regulator, dubbed Ofcom, must continue to ensure that Britain's cultural interests were not forgotten. Ms Hodgson said the new regulator - which she is tipped to lead - must continue to protect public service values on TV. "For Ofcom to be successful, parliament must set down guidance on key issues and most particularly, on the balance that society expects between commerce and culture," she said in a speech delivered to the ITN European Media Forum in London.

A BBC spokesman said BBC1 would continue to be the standard-bearer for public service broadcasting: "According to Barb, the independent audience researchers, the BBC pro vides quality programming across a wider range of programmes in peak time than any other UK broadcaster. The BBC governors are focused on this issue and have approved changes that will ensure BBC1 remains the gold standard for variety and diversity in UK public service broadcasting, and that includes extra commitment to news, drama, entertainment and regional programming."

ITV said it would continue to provide a wide range of programmes. A spokeswoman said: "Diversity on ITV is protected by regulation. We are required to provide a set amount of programmes across nine different genres from current affairs to drama and arts and religion. The actual bal ance of programmes, of course, shifts over time but there is certainly more UK-produced drama in ITV's peak schedules than ever before, which is great for viewers and the creative industry in Britain."

webTitle: Calls for windfall tax after BP's record profit

fields.headline: Calls for windfall tax after BP's record profit
fields.standfirst: Special report: The petrol crisis
fields.trailText: BP yesterday reported the highest ever profits by a British company and immediately faced calls for a windfall tax and further fuel protests.
fields.body:
BP yesterday reported the highest ever profits by a British company and immediately faced calls for a windfall tax and further fuel protests.

The world's third largest petroleum group made nearly £3bn in the last three months of 2000 - nearly £24,000 a minute or £400 a second - almost double what it made in the same time last year.

Sir John Browne, BP's chief executive described the profit performance of the company as "outstanding" but Dump the Pump campaigners dubbed it a "disgrace".

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, was under pressure last night from his own back benchers to take action against BP, as well as its rival, Shell, which last week reported record profits.

Lindsay Hoyle, Labour MP for Chorley, said he had put forward a Commons motion designed to bring an end to motorists being ripped off by the petrol companies. "We witnessed the effectiveness of a windfall levy on the privatised utilities which covered the cost of the New Deal project, resulting in an extra 1m jobs being created. I believe this can be done again," he said.

The revenue from a tax on the oil companies would be passed directly to the motorist through further cuts in duty and a package of measures under the MP's plan.

BP said government taxes were to blame for the high price of petrol in Britain and insisted it was earning almost nothing from its network of 1,500 petrol stations.

Sir John said it would be illegal for BP to cross-subsidise the pump price with money earned from elsewhere. He insisted the price at the pump in Britain was the lowest in Europe, before taxes, although he understood the worries of consumers.

"The price of gas and petrol has been higher than it has been in the past and that is a source of concern to a lot of people who drive. You would have to be blind not to see that people are concerned," he added.

Sir John said he had made the chancellor aware that BP's only role was to try to reduce its costs further and make itself more efficient but it was up to his namesake to decide what level of tax to impose. "This is a choice by a government and governments are, of course, both able to and permitted to choose. We have no special standing on this issue."

A Downing Street spokesman said: "We understand people's concerns about fuel prices, which is why we have listened and proposed a raft of measures in the pre-Budget report to help motorists and hauliers. The government continues to believe that any reduction in oil prices should be passed on to the consumer."

He said the government was continuing to monitor whether changes in world oil prices were being passed on and would not make "short-term" decisions on the issue.

The BP explanation for their profits cut little ice with fuel campaigners who last year urged motorists to boycott petrol forecourts. Garry Russell, organiser of the Dump the Pump movement, said Britain could expect another wave of protests. "Last week it was Shell, now it is BP, and it is downright disgraceful. It is high time the chancellor looked at the oil producers because the consumer does not have a choice in this."

The Road Haulage Association also attacked BP saying that it had earned a "horrendous amount of money". But a spokeswoman also believed it was time for the chancellor to reduce the size of tax take. "The big problem here is still fuel duty. Out of a £3.60 gallon of diesel, £2.71 goes to the chancellor."

The level of BP profits also angered environmentalists who said the huge sums being generated from oil compared with the "miserly" investment in renewable energy.

Stephanie Tunmore, climate campaigner at Greenpeace, said: "These obscene profits are being generated at the expense of the world's climate. We will all eventually pay the price as more frequent floods, storms and extreme weather events take their toll. This money should be ploughed straight back into expanding renewable energy to mitigate climate change."

Some financial analysts believe oil companies should sell their station forecourts and concentrate on bringing the oil out of the ground where they are making most money now.

North sea prices averaged $28.50 per barrel in 2000 compared with $17.95 in 1999.

"The price of gas and petrol has been higher than it has been in the past and that is a source of concern to a lot of people who drive. You would have to be blind not to see that people are concerned," he added. Sir John said he had made the chancellor aware that BP's only role was to try to reduce its costs further and make itself more efficient but it was up to his namesake to decide what level of tax to impose. "This is a choice by a government and governments are, of course, both able to and permitted to choose. We have no special standing on this issue." A Downing Street spokesman said: "We understand people's concerns about fuel prices, which is why we have listened and proposed a raft of measures in the pre-Budget report to help motorists and hauliers. The government continues to believe that any reduction in oil prices should be passed on to the consumer." He said the government was continuing to monitor whether changes in world oil prices were being passed on and would not make "short-term" decisions on the issue. The BP explanation for their profits cut little ice with fuel campaigners who last year urged motorists to boycott petrol forecourts. Garry Russell, organiser of the Dump the Pump movement, said Britain could expect another wave of protests. "Last week it was Shell, now it is BP, and it is downright disgraceful. It is high time the chancellor looked at the oil producers because the consumer does not have a choice in this." The Road Haulage Association also attacked BP saying that it had earned a "horrendous amount of money". But a spokeswoman also believed it was time for the chancellor to reduce the size of tax take. "The big problem here is still fuel duty. Out of a £3.60 gallon of diesel, £2.71 goes to the chancellor." The level of BP profits also angered environmentalists who said the huge sums being generated from oil compared with the "miserly" investment in renewable energy. Stephanie Tunmore, climate campaigner at Greenpeace, said: "These obscene profits are being generated at the expense of the world's climate. We will all eventually pay the price as more frequent floods, storms and extreme weather events take their toll. This money should be ploughed straight back into expanding renewable energy to mitigate climate change." Some financial analysts believe oil companies should sell their station forecourts and concentrate on bringing the oil out of the ground where they are making most money now. North sea prices averaged $28.50 per barrel in 2000 compared with $17.95 in 1999.

webTitle: Francis Wheen: Satirical fiction is becoming Blair's reality

fields.headline: Satirical fiction is becoming Blair's reality
fields.trailText: The most influential books are always those that are not read. So says Michael Young, and he should know. His classic The Rise of the Meritocracy, published in 1958, endowed the language with a word which has been misinterpreted ever since.
fields.body:
The most influential books are always those that are not read. So says Michael Young, and he should know. His classic The Rise of the Meritocracy, published in 1958, endowed the language with a word which has been misinterpreted ever since. As he pointed out recently, hardly anyone seems to realise that the book is a satire, and that the society it envisaged is a doomed dystopia.

"I wanted to show how overweening a meritocracy could be," Young explained, "and indeed the people generally who thought they belonged to it, including the author to whom the book was attributed." Silly old sausage: didn't he realise that irony and satire will always be taken literally by at least half the people who read it, and by a far higher percentage of those blithering bratwursts who haven't read it at all but base their inferences on the title alone?

One such, I suspect, is our own prime minister. But this hasn't inhibited him from holding forth on the subject: "We are light years from being a true meritocracy" (July 1995); "I want a society based on meritocracy" (April 1997); "The Britain of the elite is over. The new Britain is a meritocracy"; (October 1997); "The old establishment is being replaced by a new, larger, more meritocratic middle class" (January 1999);"The meritocracy is built on the potential of the many, not the few" (October 1999); "The meritocratic society is the only one that can exploit its economic potential to the full for all its people" (June 2000).

Despite the obvious and comical contradictions - how could something that was "light years away" in 1995 have arrived a mere two years later? - Blair is at least consistent in never using the M-word pejoratively. Last week, however, a small caveat appeared for the first time. "In the past, the idea of meritocracy has been attacked," he declared in his Enfield speech. "But creating a society that is meritocratic is not wrong, it is just insufficient." But the qualification seems to be largely rhetorical: even if meritocracy is not enough, according to Blair, it is still "an indispensable part of building a decent and prosperous society" by "breaking down the barriers to success".

To Tony Blair, meritocracy is synonymous with equality of opportunity - and who could object to that? Well, Michael Young, to name but one. "I thought equality of opportunity, the way it was thought of and the way it is still thought of, was a baneful thing," he said a few years ago, in a radio interview marking the 40th anniversary of The Rise of the Meritocracy. "I saw the meritocracy as becoming less and less concerned with the main body of people, establishing a sort of culture of their own, an elite culture with a good deal of arrogance in it. These things have largely happened . . ."

Or, as he put it in his book, equality of opportunity tends to mean, in practice, equality of opportunity to be unequal. Lo and behold, the prime minister used the phrase again on Monday when presenting his plan to reintroduce a two-tier system of secondary schools. Far from "breaking down the barriers to success", meritocracy erects daunting new hurdles. Anyone who doubts this should read The Big Test: The Secret History of the American Meritocracy, in which Nicholas Lemann reveals how the Scholastic Aptitude Test (SAT) was used to select the ruling class of post-war America.

In the days of aristocratic dominance, there were at least some in the upper class who felt insecure in their hereditary power, and many in the lower classes who refused to accept the legitimacy of their rule. But when merit alone reigns, and is almost universally accepted as the fairest arbiter, those in the elite entertain no doubts at all: they are there because they bloody well deserve to be. Those who lose out are condemned to helpless despair, stigmatised by their own alleged inadequacy.

And the new order soon becomes as stratified as the old. As TS Eliot, who was not exactly a loony lefty, wrote in his Notes Towards the Definition of Culture: "An elite, if it is a governing elite, so far as the natural impulse to pass on to one's offspring both power and prestige is not artificially checked, will tend to establish itself as a class." One obvious way of introducing an "artificial check" would be to challenge the influence of the public schools, but this Labour government - like all its predecessors - has no intention of doing so.

In Young's book, the British meritocracy eventually provokes an uprising of "populist" democrats opposed to a system which evaluates people only according to their intelligence, education, occupation and power, with little account given to qualities such as imagination, courage or generosity. Could there be a similar backlash against Blair's New Jerusalem?

Certainly not: Young's book was a satirical fantasy, as the author admits. It imagined a meritocratic society of huge and widening inequalities, with a technocratic superclass at the top and a sullen underclass below. It suggested that the new British elite would be not only unrepresentative but also more interested in consolidating its own power than in improving the common weal. It also predicted that by the 21st century the Labour party would have rebranded itself with a more "modern" name, and would set about abolishing comprehensive education. ("To us the failure of comprehensive schools does not seem to require explanation. We can hardly conceive of a society built upon consideration for the individual regardless of his merit, regardless of the needs of society as a whole.")

Even more absurdly, it envisaged a "progressive" government which stripped hereditary peers of their parliamentary privileges - only to replace them with life peers chosen from among the most eminent members of the new privileged class. "Skipping all the intermediate stages of democracy (as some countries have jumped straight from railways to rockets), an instrument of the aristocracy was by one brilliant stroke made an instrument of the meritocracy."

Pure fiction, thank God.

Look who's playing at star wars

At his press conference with Tony Blair last week, Jacques Chirac, the president of France, described the national missile defence system (NMD) as an "incitement to proliferation". Ever since men began waging war, he said, there has been a race between the sword and the shield. The more improvements that are made to the shield, the more improvements are made to the sword, "and history shows that the sword always wins". Blair made no comment; Robin Cook, who listened intently to Chirac's remarks, was seen to shake his head.

The only British minister who has publicly opposed this ridiculous American boon- doggle is Peter Hain. When asked about NMD on Newsnight last March, he replied: "I don't like the idea of a star wars programme, limited or unlimited." But in an interview with the Guardian last weekend, Hain said that although he still pays his annual CND subscription: "I happen not to agree with CND's line on the nuclear [sic] missile defence."

Oh well, if you say so. A rightwing French president is willing to denounce the greatest modern threat to nuclear disarmament, but a Labour government stuffed with former or current CND supporters - including Messrs Blair, Cook and Hain - won't say a word against it. If this is New Labour, give me a good old Gaullist any day.

Sun turns pale pink

Now I've seen it all, having read Monday's editorial in the Sun. "Here at the Sun we are not (surprise, surprise) Marxists, but we understand why old Karl got so angry. It's 153 years since the communist manifesto came out. In some ways, little has changed since then."

In tomorrow's Sun, a leader-writer will use Heisenberg's uncertainty principle to explain why it is impossible to give simultaneous accurate measurements of the position and momentum of stunning Melanie Cotton's breasts. And don't miss an exclusive series next week: Occam's Razor - The Solution to Problem Nasal Hair?

webTitle: A tragic accident that killed the family cat

fields.headline: How could I tell the children?
fields.standfirst: Marina Cantacuzino on a tragic accident that killed the family cat
fields.trailText: Marina Cantacuzino on a tragic accident that killed the family cat
fields.body:
Last Tuesday started out much like any other day as I slotted the odd domestic chore in alongside the ongoing requirements of work. At 10am I loaded the washing machine with a white wash. Since it wasn't quite full, I went upstairs to collect a few more things, made a couple of phone calls and then went back downstairs to switch it on. An hour and a half later I unloaded the machine, wondering as I did so how my daughter's black fleece had managed to end up in there.

But it wasn't my daughter's fleece. I realised almost immediately that somehow our beloved six-month-old black cat, Mossy, had crawled into the machine for a bit of warmth and peace. I'd clocked her prowling round the kitchen that morning, but then forgotten to check.

I don't think anything has upset me quite so much. It was such a shock to discover this creature, whom I adored and who trusted me so implicitly, lying there in among the wet laundry, a heavy, limp, saturated lump.

Unable to delve any further into the washing, I fled upstairs to make a hysterical phone call to my husband, who couldn't believe what I was telling him. Ten minutes later, when Dan came home, I heard him from the upstairs bedroom take Mossy in his arms and sob. Later he dug a hole in the garden ready to bury her that evening.

For hours I stayed upstairs, agonising over what to tell the children. They had always seen my habitual vagueness and clumsiness as a health and safety hazard, and I had proved them right.

The irony was that Dan and I had been totally opposed to getting this cat and had only succumbed after a year and a half of relentless pestering from our eight-year-old daughter. In the end, we had adored her as much as the children had. Having always been indifferent to cats, I found ours endlessly fascinating, marvelling at how she would rugby-tackle Dan as he walked down the corridor or lie on my knee for hours on end while I tapped away at my keyboard.

My first instinct was to lie to the children about what had happened, not to save my own skin, but because the way she had died was just too gruesome. My mother-in-law was all for pretending that Mossy had simply disappeared. But how could we go through with the pretence of putting up posters or watch the children anxiously guarding the catflap in anticipation that she might suddenly dart through?

By 2pm, knowing they would soon be home from school, I rang the Child Bereavement Trust in desperation, presuming that the same advice must apply to pets as to people. A soft-voiced counsellor advised me that children need to hear the truth from their parents. "They would never forgive you if one day they found out from someone else how their cat had died," she said.

I told everyone who called that day about Mossy - even the woman from BT - because in my incoherence it was all I could think and talk about. I was amazed at how many similar ghastly tales I heard: a friend's brother, who had come down from a ladder and crushed his cat; my cousin, who had rolled over on his hamster; and three other people who had accidentally run over their pets. I even heard of a woman who had unknowingly shut her cat in the washing machine and switched it on. Except she was blind.

I left it to my husband to break the news to our three children - Phoebe, 11, Flora, eight, and Reuben, three. Of course, they were utterly distraught; yet after that first evening of shock, disbelief and tears, they seemed to rally. Reuben has barely noticed Mossy's absence; Flora, after 24 hours of acute misery, has taken comfort in the thought of getting another cat, particularly as I have now said that this one can have kittens (as she pointed out, "you owe us a life"). Only Phoebe is still sad, her emotions intensified by the fact that she won't tell her friends about the incident. When I asked why, she said: "Because if they asked how it happened, I couldn't bear to tell them."

Recrimination and blame have, of course, come my way, though in a surprisingly matter-of-fact manner. On that first day, seeing how distraught I was, Phoebe limited herself to one accusation: "Why are you so careless?" Since then there has been the occasional "cat killer", "mass murderer"-type dig. And yesterday, when I apologised for mistakenly turning off the lights in Phoebe's room while she was still in there working, I heard her say through gritted teeth: "You make too many mistakes."

Most people I have told have been both horrified and sympathetic. Only one woman came up to me in the playground and said, "I know it's very sad, but . . ." and proceeded to burst out laughing. She soon stopped, realising that while the cartoon image of the pet in the washing machine may be hilarious to some - a macabre materialisation of an urban myth - for me it could never be a laughing matter. Had Mossy been human - and she had seemed to be sometimes - I would have been charged with manslaughter. And lately, when it comes to working out the exact events leading up to my criminal act, I seem to be suffering from a kind of accused's amnesia. Sometimes I think Iactually saw Mossy get into the machine.

But perhaps, as some people say, pets are here to teach us something. Mossy certainly taught our family about love and death. And, as I went round the house yesterday removing every matchbox in sight to combat my three-year-old's increasing pyromaniac tendencies, I thought that perhaps, after all, there was a purpose to our cat's untimely death.

fields.headline: At this price?  Reuters
fields.trailText: At the height of the dot.com boom in the early part of last year, one traditional media company after another announced plans to spend vast amounts on the internet. Most have retrenched, feeling the pressure from floundering share prices.
fields.body:
At the height of the dot.com boom in the early part of last year, one traditional media company after another announced plans to spend vast amounts on the internet. Most have retrenched, feeling the pressure from floundering share prices.

Reuters, the financial information group, announced one of the largest headline figures - it would spend £500m migrating its business online. Yesterday, accompanying its full year results, Reuters bucked the trend and underlined its commitment. "The collapse of the valuation bubble around internet stocks has not affected our strategy which goes forward as we stated last year," said chief executive Peter Job.

Reuters' shares have fallen from more than £16 at their internet-fuelled peak and have come back with the rest of the sector. For Reuters, the internet is less a bottomless pit at which to throw money than a meaningful way of making its existing business more efficient, reach more people and lower costs.

The group reported a 15% rise in revenues to £3.6bn for the year to the end of December. Pre-tax profits, following the rise in investment in the internet, were down by 23% to £457m. It spent £139m last year and expects to spend £150m this.

By 2003 the company claims cost savings from moving its business online will be £150m a year.

Instinet, the group's online broking business, powered the revenue growth, increasing turnover by 53% to £804m. The business will be partially floated by the summer.

Reuters is also displaying a healthy dose of caution. It has prudently shelved plans to enter the risky retail end of the online broking market and is looking at reducing its stake in its internet investment fund, the Greenhouse Fund, to a minority position.

Shares in the company climbed more than 5% to £10.74 suggesting a reassessment has begun. Buy.

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.standfirst: Special report: Life in parliament
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Downing Street's website. Number 10 relaunched nine months ago has received more than 99m hits, according to Tony Blair yesterday.

Bad day

Ministers. Commons Speaker Michael Martin demanded an inquiry into how details of government measures to improve workers' skills appeared in papers before their official publication yesterday. The inquiry followed a protest by the shadow trade secretary David Heathcoat-Amory that the contents of the white paper were "in this morning's newspapers, including direct and accurate quotes from the text"

Today

Commons: Cabinet Office questions. PM's questions. Health and social care bill, remaining stages. Westminster Hall: Backbench debates include Aids, Cyprus, and Wandsworth prison.

Lords: Debates on increase in asylum seekers, and on strengthening role of parliament. Parliamentary referendum bill, committee.

Commons Speaker Michael Martin demanded an inquiry into how details of government measures to improve workers' skills appeared in papers before their official publication yesterday. webTitle: Analysis: code of conduct for ministers

fields.headline: Ain't misbehavin' ... publicly
fields.standfirst:
People do not have much faith in the code of conduct for government ministers. Is there a better way to ensure accountability?
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: People do not have much faith in the code of conduct for government ministers. Is there a better way to ensure accountability?
fields.body:
Today's Commons' report on the code supposed to govern the conduct of government ministers* could hardly be more timely. Last year the prime minister said "no one will be better governed through fine tuning the ministerial code". Yet closer study of this document might have saved him much grief.

The code used to be called Questions Of Procedure For Ministers and was first published by the Major government. Its contents go back to Clem Attlee's time, when ministers were ceasing as a matter of course to be gents who could be expected to know the rules (though Gladstone's share dealings on the back of insider knowledge were active, to put it mildly). Today's document is a compendious mix of high principle and practical advice on avoiding trouble. It is on the Cabinet Office website at www.cabinet-office.gov.uk/ central/1997/mcode/index.htm

Its cardinal rule is giving parliament "accurate and truthful information" while - relevant in the Mandelson case - "correcting any inadvertent error at the earliest opportunity". There are sections on gifts, ministers' private interests, lobbyists, constituency dealings: few of the Mandelson and Keith Vaz events, real or alleged, are not covered by it at least in outline. "Ministers must scrupulously avoid any danger of an actual or apparent conflict of interest between their ministerial position and their private financial interests."

Gifts worth up to £140 each may be kept, otherwise they have to be handed over to civil servants and sold off or "displayed" in a Whitehall glass case. Ministers must not use knowledge which brings "benefit (or could arouse reasonable suspicion of this) in relation to their private financial interests".

Tony Wright and fellow members of the public administration committee want the code better known, perhaps aligned with the rules for other public officials and put under the supervision of a codefinder-general. It is a moot point whether ministers are schooled in their ethical obligations with sufficient rigour. Did the permanent secretary at the Trade Department thrust a copy into the hands of for example, Peter Hain on his recent transfer there? There are bound to be energy industry interests wanting to sup with him. The MPs suggest recording all lobbying episodes. If that had happened over the ministers' relationship with the Hinduja brothers there would at least be less room for disagreement about facts.

But tinkering with the code would not address a central problem in the way we govern ourselves. The code itself relies on uncodified powers wielded by civil servants and, especially, the prime minister. Labour has promised a civil service act, putting permanent officialdom on a statutory footing for the first time and has enacted new ethical codes for politicians in local government. But much of our governance still relies on aristocracy - the system relies on the state's toffs intrinsically to know right and wrong. As a matter of fact, they do behave rather well. Peculation is remarkably absent from British public life. But recent events show how little faith the public has in such self- regulation.

But where do we start writing down the ineffable elements of the British constitution? The obvious place is Number 10. The ministerial code belongs to the prime minister and is put into effect by the prime minister. He is judge and jury on breaches, as Peter Mandelson complains. What the prime minister does not know, the cabinet secretary is there to tell him. But the Aitken and Robinson affairs showed how ill-equipped is Whitehall's head prefect to handle politicians. Besides, quis custodiet? If in principle the prime minister is bound by the same rules as his colleagues, to whom does Sir Richard Wilson report his receipt of hospitality? Paragraph 128 of the code says ministers receiving food, drink (and hotel rooms) from sources that might "reasonably be thought likely to influence ministerial action", should make a declaration in the Commons register of interests. Sir Richard's problem is that he is the conscience and alter ego of the system; and a similar problem of ultimate unaccountability would beset an independent custodian of public ethics.

We need, it seems, to invent mechanisms to call the prime minister better to account for his handling of his immediate colleagues. An obvious one is the Commons, but are we ready for such a radical recalibration of the powers of executive and legislature or what it would mean for political parties?

A holding answer seems to be more detailed specification of duties and responsibilities - the substitution of rules for discretion. Sometime soon we are going to have to go back to first principles and set out in black and white just what it is ministers (and their departmental officials) exist to do. Look at the chart: is that variable performance in answering MPs a legitimate sign of ministerial ineptitude? At present there are no objective measures of how well a minister heads a department, delivers policy targets or sustains cabinet government. The code tells ministers to put cabinet business before all else but neglects to say what cabinet government - as opposed to prime ministerial autocracy - is meant to look like. To say a minister is effective in office might be no defence against a charge of corruption but it might put things in proportion.
