webTitle: Bypass sparks new battle of Hastings

fields.headline: Bypass sparks new battle of Hastings
fields.standfirst:
Ecoprotesters gear up for war as valley awaits decision on road schemes

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Ecoprotesters gear up for war as valley awaits decision on road schemes.
fields.body:
The sense of space and stillness hits you at once. When you look up from the valley towards the hilltops there are only trees and fields in sight. You can hear little but birdsong. The occasional rumble of a train on the embankment provides the only interruption to this quiet corner of East Sussex.

It is hard to imagine a more perfect image of the English countryside than here at Doleham in the Upper Brede valley. For many residents it is even harder to imagine why someone would want to rip it all up.

But today's expected approval by the south-east England regional assembly (Seera) of two bypass schemes that will cut through the heart of this and other unspoilt areas near Hastings could herald the beginning of a big change.

The bypasses are designed to flank Hastings, described as the most deprived district in the south-east. Supporters - including the local Labour MP, Michael Foster, anxious to hang on to his key marginal seat - say the roads will help to regenerate the seaside town. But they are set to become the most controversial road building schemes since Newbury and Twyford Down.

The decision to go ahead lies ultimately with the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, but since he was a key proponent of the regional assembly he is unlikely to overturn one of Seera's first big decisions.

Proponents argue that taking traffic away from the town centre could provide opportunities for development of greenfield sites farther afield, as well as unclogging the narrow streets in the Victorian town.

Mr Foster said yesterday that he believed towns such as Hastings "needed a hand-up not a handout".

"We have all the natural resources in terms of where we are, but almost everybody says it's the infrastructure which defeats many of our objectives, both road and rail," he said.

He outlined plans to improve rail links to London and develop a metro link within the town, but added: "That is not enough. The bypasses and improvements to the A21 remain integral to the confidence of people investing in the town."

He said around 80% of residents were in favour of the bypasses, and while acknowledging that there were environmental implications he added: "The urban environment and the economic gains are so substantial that they outweigh the unfortunate loss to the rural environment."

There is no argument over the need to regenerate the once proud seaside resort - it ranked 28th in the list of poorest towns in Britain, with higher than average unemployment and lower than average wages. But environmentalists and some local residents believe there are other ways of making this happen.

A decision in favour of the scheme could help Labour to retain the seat, gained from the Conservatives in 1997 with a 2,560 majority.

Julian Bargery, a resident and campaigner from the Wishing Tree area of Hastings, said: "How else could you explain the government considering a scheme which has no strategic national benefit? If the bypass went ahead Mr Foster would regard it as a feather in his hat. He would make great political capital out of the fact that he got it through."

Mr Foster, who appears to be one of the few people who do not expect a decision before the general election, said: "All three parties support this... Where does that leave me room for political manoeuvre?"

A protest campaign has worked hard to prevent what protesters fear will be the destruction of three of Britain's finest wildlife sites, as well as damaging an area of outstanding national beauty.

Opponents argue that the construction would be in direct contravention of the government's environmental policy. In Doleham plans for the eastern bypass involve levelling out the valley to enable the road to pass above the Hastings-Ashford railway line.

As part of the farm stewardship scheme, which works to encourage wildlife to stay and breed, the area is home to rare species of plants, and the streams provide vital breeding grounds for sea trout. These streams will be encased in concrete culverts underground if the plans go ahead.

The valley will be transformed. Plans for the bypass to the west of Hastings include a 12-metre concrete viaduct running through Combe Haven, a wildlife reserve and a potentially important archaeological site.

Campaigners fear that some of the sites for the roads lie on flood plains, which could create serious problems in an area which in the past three months has suffered some of the worst flooding in its history.

They also argue that a report by government consultants casts doubt on whether the new roads would help to regenerate the town. The report said road traffic in Hastings would actually increase.

The environment agency has also expressed "serious concerns" about the flood plain and the effect on biodiversity and wildlife.

The bypass proposals appear to contravene recent Department of the Environment guidelines on development and flood risk, which state that building on functional flood plains should be "wholly exceptional - and limited to essential infrastructure".

Mr Foster said yesterday he believed government policy was "totally consistent". "The policy is: do not build a road unless there is absolutely no alternative. There is absolutely no alternative to these roads. They should have been built 30 years ago. We are just trying to catch up with the world."

webTitle: Voters back referendum on electoral reform

fields.headline: Voters back referendum on electoral reform
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats' desire for an alternative to the first-past-the-post voting system was given fresh impetus yesterday after a poll found voters overwhelmingly want a referendum on the issue.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats' desire for an alternative to the first-past-the-post voting system was given fresh impetus yesterday after a poll found voters overwhelmingly want a referendum on the issue.

The ICM telephone poll found 67% wanted a referendum with 26% against. Labour voters are as likely to want a referendum as the Tories although, unsurprisingly, support is highest among Lib Dem voters at 53%. The poll of 1,000 adults, for the voting reform group Make Votes Count, was commissioned amid speculation that Labour may leave the pledge of a referendum out of its manifesto.

Last night the party insisted it remained committed to a referendum on the voting system for MPs. But the Labour decision to support the non-proportional alternative vote system, which retains the links between MPs and constitutencies and was proposed by the Jenkins commission, has led to fears that the pledge of a referendum may be dropped.

The poll suggests that, should the prime minister do this, LibDem supporters prepared to vote tactically would withdraw their support. Mr Blair's personal standing could also suffer, with 20% being less likely to trust him on other promises.

The Labour peer Lord Lipsey, chairman of Make Votes Count, said: "This poll shows that Tony Blair would abandon electoral reform at his party's peril."

In a referendum, only 35% would want to retain the first-past-the-post system, the poll showed, while 50% would vote for a more proportional system.

webTitle: Comment: Polly Toynbee on a Tory comeback

fields.headline: Labour is simply going to guarantee a Tory comeback
fields.standfirst:
Blair thinks he can do without Lib Dems. So progressives stay split
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Blair thinks he can do without Lib Dems. So progressives stay split
fields.body:
Imagine this. In about two years the politics of this country may have changed profoundly. Tectonic plates at Westminster often shift fast even if myopic politicians behave as if everything will always stay as it is now for ever. If all goes well, this is how things will be: the referendum on the euro has been hard fought and won - just - by Tony Blair. The campaign was a shrieking, terrifying business when every wild thing came out of the caves to fight for the last gasp of Olde Englande. King Arthur with all his knights was summoned up to save the nation by the Telegraph, Mail, Sun and Times who all went completely mad, with foaming front pages spewing forth euro-hatred. But on the last day all were vanquished. The old Tory party is no more, spontaneous combustion burned it into a smouldering pile of steaming ash. (William Hague, Liam Fox and Ian Duncan-Smith all took lucrative City jobs, never to be heard of again, while the editors of the Mail and Telegraph were removed by their owners to make way for more modern thinkers.)

From these ruins arises the phoenix New Tory. Maybe Michael Portillo is leader, maybe not, but there are already stirrings in the undergrowth around him and independent of him whispering to one another about what New Tory might look like, come the day. Compassionate conservatism moves on to the centre ground to challenge Labour. Euroscepticaemia purged from its blood, 21st century Tory looks for solid alliances with ruling Christian Democrats across the channel - Spain's Jose Maria Aznar for example - to restore an impression of responsible internationalism. New Tory cleaves to the public sector in schools and hospitals - and not one off-message New Tory MP ever dares contemplate mad-cap private insurance schemes. New Tory is quick to seize chances Labour let fall: women are one of its surprising new issues, offering childcare for all and a genuine choice for mothers of under-threes to stay at home. New Tory is now a social libertarian, embracing gay issues as if Baroness Young never was. Sex is no longer a weird fetish for them. New Tory is very enthusiastic about the virtues of local government, which it largely controls, advocating the devolving of much power to the little people, pointing up Labour's weakness for central control of every paper clip.

Otherwise (on the surface) it manages to look not too different to New Labour - that is the plan. Just as New Labour stalked John Major, so New Tory will stalk a Labour government, by then rather more weary and less shiny. New Tories look quite competent, sober and credible. Like patient crocodiles, they will just wait for the government to make some fatal errors, grow too complacent, fractious or tired. Sooner or later their chance will come and they will snap power back.

So where will Tony Blair's progressive century be then? True, New Labour will have made the Tories more moderate, bleeding Thatcher out of their system. Heathism, or the Butskellism that dominated until the Thatcher revolution, will be restored. But though less extreme, New Tories will still be very clearly old Tory underneath - taxing less, spending less, favouring the haves against the have-nots, happy to let the public sector slide back again to a squalor seen nowhere else in Europe. New Tories will still hanker after American not European social policies, business as usual.

New Tory will come back just as Mrs Thatcher always did - with a majority voting against it. Many more will have voted Labour or Liberal Democrat than voted Tory. But with the progressive forces still split into two parties, once the Tories are sane the future will be largely theirs again. The next century will be the same story as this, shuttling between the two great coalition parties, most voters unable to express their views beyond opting for one big block or the other. For a while Paddy Ashdown thought Tony Blair was serious about the progressive century: perhaps he was, briefly. Now he is at best indifferent: "unconvinced" as before.

On Monday evening Charles Kennedy met Tony Blair for nearly an hour, amid speculation that the already weak commitment to proportional representation will be dropped altogether from Labour's next manifesto. The formula thrashed out at Labour's policy forum in Exeter is so minimal as to be invisible - if there were to be PR there would be a referendum - and that is not enough to keep the Lib Dems on board. All-out war would follow, with the Tories reaping the benefit: there would be none of the tactical voting that helped capture so many Tory seats (Enfield, Romsey) for both Labour and Lib Dems. The prime minister would prefer to keep the Lib Dems happy, but it is only a mild preference: those about him snort with derision at the gnat-sized importance of these piffling fair-weather allies. They sneer at Lib Dems promising more of everything, easy-peasy policies with no hard choices - a partly fair accusation. But hubris is in the air. Labour's private polls show voters think Hague is a Billy Bandwagon Wally, and that's it. Charles Kennedy's a Wally too, they imply. Who cares anyway? Labour is going to win big-time, forget the pre-1997 first-night nerves that projected a jumpy Labour leader into Paddy Ashdown's arms. Now John Prescott is set free to rampage up and down the country stirring up the local party tribes with jibes against the Lib Dems, vowing that PR will only come in over his dead body, (which may one day be prophetic). It is all very macho: real men laugh at Lib Dems, eat them for breakfast. And that is how Labour foolishly ensures the Tories get back some day, against the will of most voters.

Once, long ago, Tony Blair had a vision of uniting the ancient split in the forces of progress. Now he thinks Labour's own strength alone can win for election after election. But irritating though their presence may be, Liberals have a maddening staying power. They survived without a whiff of government for a century, repository for the confused, undecided and malcontent, a bit greener and more liberal than New Labour. In Scotland's PR coalition, Lib Dems create a more radical political blend that is probably preferable to most Labour party members. But at Westminster their only power is to damage Labour and let the Tories in whenever the two big parties are neck and neck. That is why Labour rank and file hate them. That is why Labour rank and file and top brass have to find an accommodation to make sure it never happens again. That requires a modest degree of PR, enough to ensure the will of the voters always wins and an unrepresentative right is never again foisted on the country because of a petulant and petty split in the left. Tony Blair should be a bigger man than this.

For a while Paddy Ashdown thought Tony Blair was serious about the progressive century: perhaps he was, briefly. Now he is at best indifferent: "unconvinced" as before. On Monday evening Charles Kennedy met Tony Blair for nearly an hour, amid speculation that the already weak commitment to proportional representation will be dropped altogether from Labour's next manifesto. The formula thrashed out at Labour's policy forum in Exeter is so minimal as to be invisible - if there were to be PR there would be a referendum - and that is not enough to keep the Lib Dems on board. All-out war would follow, with the Tories reaping the benefit: there would be none of the tactical voting that helped capture so many Tory seats (Enfield, Romsey) for both Labour and Lib Dems. The prime minister would prefer to keep the Lib Dems happy, but it is only a mild preference: those about him snort with derision at the gnat-sized importance of these piffling fair-weather allies. They sneer at Lib Dems promising more of everything, easy-peasy policies with no hard choices - a partly fair accusation. But hubris is in the air. Labour's private polls show voters think Hague is a Billy Bandwagon Wally, and that's it. Charles Kennedy's a Wally too, they imply. Who cares anyway? Labour is going to win big-time, forget the pre-1997 first-night nerves that projected a jumpy Labour leader into Paddy Ashdown's arms. Now John Prescott is set free to rampage up and down the country stirring up the local party tribes with jibes against the Lib Dems, vowing that PR will only come in over his dead body, (which may one day be prophetic). It is all very macho: real men laugh at Lib Dems, eat them for breakfast. And that is how Labour foolishly ensures the Tories get back some day, against the will of most voters. Once, long ago, Tony Blair had a vision of uniting the ancient split in the forces of progress. Now he thinks Labour's own strength alone can win for election after election. But irritating though their presence may be, Liberals have a maddening staying power. They survived without a whiff of government for a century, repository for the confused, undecided and malcontent, a bit greener and more liberal than New Labour. In Scotland's PR coalition, Lib Dems create a more radical political blend that is probably preferable to most Labour party members. But at Westminster their only power is to damage Labour and let the Tories in whenever the two big parties are neck and neck. That is why Labour rank and file hate them. That is why Labour rank and file and top brass have to find an accommodation to make sure it never happens again. That requires a modest degree of PR, enough to ensure the will of the voters always wins and an unrepresentative right is never again foisted on the country because of a petulant and petty split in the left. Tony Blair should be a bigger man than this.

fields.headline: Ministers to scrap retirement age
fields.trailText: The over-60s will be able to escape the poverty of old age under anti-discrimination laws which will make it illegal to ban them from working as long as they like.
fields.body:
The over-60s will be able to escape the poverty of old age under anti-discrimination laws which will make it illegal to ban them from working as long as they like.

The government will today announce a working group to iron out the details of the law which will ban compulsorary retirement at any age by 2006.

Business leaders and campaign groups for the elderly will be consulted.

Ministers are determined to eradicate a set retirement age - currently 60 for women and 65 for men - while ensuring the law is workable. "We want to ensure we get it right," a Department of Employment spokesman said.

The measure, to be signalled by the junior employment minister, Margaret Hodge, in a Commons committee hearing today, is being brought in to comply with a European Union directive agreed last year.

The directive seeks to outlaw discrimination against people at work on the grounds of religion, age, disability or sexual orientation in the next six years.

A third of men and women aged 50-65 - 2.8m people - are no longer employed.

Last year, a cabinet office report recommended unemployed men over 60 should lose their benefits unless they proved they were looking for jobs.

The cost of economic "inactivity" among the over-50s is estimated to be at least £26bn.

Age Concern, which welcomed the measure, predicted many people would wish to defer their state pensions and continue working.

"Most people are still fairly active into their 70s and we know from anecdoctal evidence that many want to work," said spokesman Rhian Beynon.

"For some, it's because they want the recognition and stimulation of working but for some it's because they can't afford to retire on the basic state pension."

Just 60% of workers have an occupational pension on top of the £67.50 state pension, and of these half gain no more than an extra £55 a week.

Patrick Gratton, of Help the Aged, added: "This is good for employers, the economy and individuals and it does not present a problem for employers as two thirds of men do not work right up until the retirement age anyway."

The Tories said flexible retirement chimed with the responsible society they wished to create.

The Liberal Democrats' social security spokesman, Steve Webb, said: "There is a real waste of talent when people are forced to retire when they do not want to. Businesses should also welcome this."

But the Confederation of British Industry insisted "flexibility - not a 'one size fits all' solution" had to be "the name of the game.

"Doing away with contractual retirement ages without consulting employers is not the solution," said the CBI director-general, Digby Jones.

fields.headline: RUC recruitment delay worries chief
fields.trailText: The RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, said yesterday that he could not wait much longer to begin taking on recruits for the revamped police service, amid fears of senior officers leaving.
fields.body:
The RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, said yesterday that he could not wait much longer to begin taking on recruits for the revamped police service, amid fears of senior officers leaving.

The Northern Ireland Office security minister, Adam Ingram, revealed in a parliamentary question that almost three-quarters of senior commanders could take early retirement or redundancy by the end of the year. A third of the 161 superintendents and chief superintendents are due to leave by the end of March and a further 68 could go in the next few months, as the force is gradually shrunk from 13,500 to around 7,500.

An independent agency was due to launch a recruitment drive on a 50/50 Protestant/ Catholic basis on Friday, but Sir Ronnie has sanctioned a short delay while efforts continue to secure nationalist support for changes.

The SDLP and Sinn Fein have not agreed to nominate representatives to the new police board because they feel the police bill watered down Chris Patten's recommendations too much.

Policing is a major factor, along with decommissioning and demilitarisation, in talks on the political impasse.

Sir Ronnie said: "I have an absolute need for new recruits on the streets by next spring, and it will take six months to identify a pool of new officers and five to six months to train them."

fields.headline: Ombudsman 'should police minister code'
fields.trailText: Breaches of the ministerial code should be investigated by the parliamentary ombudsman, ending the discredited investigatory role of the cabinet secretary, a committee of MPs said yesterday.
fields.body:
Breaches of the ministerial code should be investigated by the parliamentary ombudsman, ending the discredited investigatory role of the cabinet secretary, a committee of MPs said yesterday.

At present the ombudsman, Michael Buckley, looks into complaints of maladministration made by MPs on behalf of their constituents. The public administration committee also recommended that ministers should be able to seek advice on potential conflicts with the code from the parliamentary commissioner for standards, Elizabeth Filkin. The proposals follow complaints that ministers alleged to have breached the code have been investigated by the cabinet secretary or by their departmental permanent secretary.

The proposed system might have protected Peter Mandelson from being pressed to resign as Northern Ireland secretary before all the facts of his alleged misdemeanours had been established. Assurances given by ministers who were subsequently discredited, such as Jonathan Aitken, have later proved to have been poorly investigated by civil servants.

webTitle: MPs want to see rail cash figures accounts

fields.headline: MPs want to see rail cash figures accounts
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Parliament must get sweeping new powers to investigate the finances of public bodies from the BBC to private train operators like Virgin Trains, a powerful committee overseen by Andrew Smith, chief secretary to the Treasury, recommended yesterday.
fields.body:
Parliament must get sweeping new powers to investigate the finances of public bodies from the BBC to private train operators like Virgin Trains, a powerful committee overseen by Andrew Smith, chief secretary to the Treasury, recommended yesterday.

The changes - the biggest for more than 20 years - would give MPs for the first time the right to examine whether the BBC is good value for money and check how it has spent the £104 licence fee.

Virgin Trains are among thousands of organisations which would come under parliamentary scrutiny if the report is accepted by the government.

Altogether 2,000 housing associations, 25 train operating companies, 130 other private companies and thousands of private finance initiative schemes would be examined by MPs as the result of the proposed changes. Examples of other bodies that would be covered for the first time include the housing corporation, the student loan company and the environment agency. Particularly important would be new powers to examine the accounts of train operating companies, to see how they had spent state subsidies and whether they gave good value for money for rail customers. The firm that ran the Millennium Dome would also be covered.

The changes are recommended by a committee under Lord Sharman of Redlynch, set up last year. Its findings are a victory for backbench MPs who were furious that the Treasury would not extend parliament's ability to scrutinise the spending of public money if it was handed over to private companies or some quangos.

Ministers' refusal to agree this led to a Commons revolt headed by David Davis, chairman of the Commons public accounts committee. The issue was taken up by peers who threatened to sabotage a government bill unless ministers held an inquiry into the issue. This led to a Treasury concession which set up Lord Sharman's inquiry.

Last night Mr Davis said it was vital that parliamentary scrutiny of public spending "keeps pace with the changes in the way government works".

The Treasury will consider the report soon. It will not require new legislation to implement the changes.

fields.headline: Orange turns off the traders
fields.trailText: The launch of Orange's multi-billion euro float was undistinguished yesterday, with traders turning away from telecoms in droves and dragging down market heavyweights like Vodafone and BT.
fields.body:
The launch of Orange's multi-billion euro float was undistinguished yesterday, with traders turning away from telecoms in droves and dragging down market heavyweights like Vodafone and BT.

While managers from parent France Télécom were hailing a success, the City offered its own verdict, one analyst describing it as "a public relations disaster". "I think France Télécom would have pulled the IPO if they hadn't needed the money," said one corporate financier. "The market knew that and had them by the throat."

The shares, which closed at €9.4 (£5.99), 6% below the issue price of €10, were already "priced to sell," as one of the company's advisers put it. France Télécom had cut the price by 18% just days before the float, valuing once high-flying Orange at €45bn.

The offering was 2.6 times subscribed, with 1.3m people lining up to take advantage of a 5% discount offered to retail investors. France Télécom raised €6.3bn, well below the €14bn it owes Vodafone for the purchase of Orange.

"This is really a triumph for France Télécom," said Orange deputy chief executive Graham Howe. "We are a very high quality offering from the market's point of view."

Howe warned investors not to be put off by a lacklustre first day's trading. "We're considered a quality stock and one people must hold," he said.

But while retail investors in Paris took profits on the back of the 5% discount, with 250m shares changing hands in four hours, UK punters will be left holding the shares.

The London Stock Exchange, unlike Paris, does not have an electronic method of informing investors of their allocation, so those without a broker will be waiting for tomorrow's post before they can begin trading. Over the weekend, Orange spokesmen dismissed suggestions this would put off investors, saying most saw the stock as a long-term buy.

"We're collectively pleased to achieve this in this market," said Tim Shacklock, deputy chairman of Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, one of three global co-ordinators. "To have the deal 2.6 times over subscribed is a testament to the product. Conditions are extremely difficult."

Other analysts were less convinced: "It was not a very heav ily subscribed issue," said one. "In hindsight, it may have been better to price it at €9.50. It was supposed to have been priced to sell. The market has been bad today, and it is very hard to stand out as an IPO in a down market. Sentiment is very negative."

France Télécom's shares were down 6% on the day to €78, despite taking advantage of the world press attention to make an earnings announcement two days early.

Earnings for 2000 were up 23.7%, with nearly a quarter of its revenue now coming from Orange. Chairman Michel Bon said yesterday he had been torn in recent days between postponing the IPO or cutting the initial €11.5 to €13.5 price, opting for the IPO to alleviate the debt to Vodafone.

With mixed sentiment on the offering and a staggering €60bn in debt, France Télécom is keeping one eye on Orange share prices, and another on credit rating agencies.

Orange founder Hans Snook, in a statement released yesterday, said: "My own belief is that in the years to come, people will look back and marvel that they did not see more clearly the growth potential, which we have only just begun to exploit."

webTitle: QXL stays in hunt for a partner

fields.headline: QXL stays in hunt for a partner
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Online auction house QXL Ricardo yesterday said it was starting to stem its heavy losses and admitted that a link-up with a bigger partner remained a distinct possibility.
fields.body:
Online auction house QXL Ricardo yesterday said it was starting to stem its heavy losses and admitted that a link-up with a bigger partner remained a distinct possibility.

The chief executive, Jim Rose, said: "We continue to have dialogue with a number of players about potential strategic partnerships and if a deal is presented that makes sense to shareholders obviously we'd be open to doing it."

QXL Ricardo recently attempted to damp down speculation that it was seeking a white knight investor after a slump in its share price by unveiling a complex financing deal that gives it up to £67.5m in cash.

Mr Rose said QXL had final say on whether it needed to use £25m of that facility and if it strikes a strategic partnership it was unlikely to need to.

Reports that the world's biggest internet auction house, eBay, was attempting to boost its European presence by taking over French rival iBazar has put QXL back in the spotlight.

Mr Rose said the potential deal was evidence of how difficult eBay was finding it to grow organically in Europe and QXL was more than capable of competing on a level footing.

"We kill those guys in many markets," he said.

Some analysts believe that eBay's apparent willingness to mop up smaller European players could be a source of salvation for QXL shareholders.

QXL has spent much of the past year buying European rivals and then attempting the tricky task of integrating them into its core business. That process is now largely complete and eBay may see QXL, valued at just £62m, as a relatively cheap and painless way of growing its European offering.

In the three months to December 31 QXL losses narrowed from £67m to £41m. After write downs it is burning around £10m per quarter, Mr Rose said.

Turnover - the amount of commission it makes on sales - was £4m, leading to a gross profit of £733,000 which was substantially up on the previous month.

webTitle: Toadnode to take leap into Napster gap

fields.headline: Toadnode to take leap into Napster gap
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: In the time it takes to read this article, several thousands songs will be downloaded from the web.
fields.body:
In the time it takes to read this article, several thousands songs will be downloaded from the web.

A US court dealt Napster, the online song-swapping service, a potentially fatal blow this week, but growth in the use of its service and others like it suggests that the phenomenon is here to stay.

Several analysts believe that, while Napster itself may be unable to continue, the "napsterisation" of entertainment has just begun. As evidence they cite the volume of downloads during the company's travails. Since the court first decided that Napster was violating copyright laws last July, its membership base has almost doubled to some 61m users.

Webnoize, an online monitoring group, estimates that 250m songs were downloaded using Napster in the two days before Monday's ruling. Napster's user base has grown beyond students and techies to include middle-aged men downloading copies of no longer available 78rpms and musicians who have no other outlet.

Most of the users in online chatrooms yesterday asked two questions: how long could they continue downloading and what other services could they use.

The answer to the first question is likely to be next week at the earliest, when Judge Marilyn Hall Patel is expected to refine the injunction she issued last year. This was being seized on by users yesterday as evidence of the gap between the internet and the law.

Napster has become one of the fastest growing businesses of all time. Some die-hard fans of free downloads were quick to point to alternatives such as Gnutella, Freenet, Splooge and Toadnode. Lutfam5 boasted on news.com: "Believe me! There are other places to go - I have downloaded over 1,000 MP3s and ripped nearly 200 myself - I have never used Napster!" Gnutella posted a simple statement on its all-white home page which read: "It's all ok."

Research by Webnoize last year suggests consumers will accept a monthly subscription of as much as $15 to download music online. The furore over this week's ruling suggests it may take some time for existing users to accept such a charge, however.

Slamtilt wrote: "Over-priced CD albums and CD singles is [sic] what has driven the popularity of shared music and Napster is a cybersuccess that the music industry should be utilising rather than trying to destroy."

Such comments are unlikely to deter the music industry, or the entertainment business generally, which is closely watching events. Noah Stone, of Artists Against piracy, which represents acts including Bon Jovi and Christina Aguilera, insisted: "Artists' rights must be respected online."

Napster itself, although promising to appeal, is expected to work harder with its partner Bertelsmann, one of the world's largest record labels, to produce a subscription-based service by the middle of this year.

Few in the industry believe things will return to the way they were before an 18-year-old student founded Napster in May 1999. As Nobuyuki Idei, chief executive of Sony, said this year: "The internet is a kind of power shift. Now the consumer has more power than the company."

Europe's music industry yesterday made a last ditch effort to ensure that song-swapping sites are regulated out of existence this side of the Atlantic with an EU directive extending copyright protection to the internet.

Few in the industry believe things will return to the way they were before an 18-year-old student founded Napster in May 1999. As Nobuyuki Idei, chief executive of Sony, said this year: "The internet is a kind of power shift. Now the consumer has more power than the company." Europe's music industry yesterday made a last ditch effort to ensure that song-swapping sites are regulated out of existence this side of the Atlantic with an EU directive extending copyright protection to the internet.

webTitle: Lucent a notch away from 'junk bond' tag

fields.headline: Lucent a notch away from 'junk bond' tag
fields.trailText: Lucent Technologies is bracing itself for the loss of a $1bn deal a day after its credit rating was cut by two agencies.
fields.body:
Lucent Technologies is bracing itself for the loss of a $1bn deal a day after its credit rating was cut by two agencies.

The world's largest telecom equipment maker is on the verge of losing out on contracts worth $1.8bn to build a mobile phone network in China.

Newspaper reports in China yesterday said that Qualcomm would win the contract to build the next generation wireless network for China Unicom and Nortel would build a small portion of the network for $32m.

Lucent, once the favoured player in the market, won no part of the project.

Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Service both cut Lucent's credit rating on Monday, bringing its shares down nearly 12% to $13, an 80% fall from its 52-week high.

The agencies attributed the rate cut, which puts Lucent "a notch above junk-bond status", to the $1bn loss the company reported in the first fiscal quarter of 2001.

Lucent has repeatedly missed analysts' earnings projections over the past year, and its accounting practices are the subject of an investigation by the US securities exchange commission.

As contracts for telecom networks become harder to come by, Lucent has been forced to extend loans to customers to entice them to purchase its equipment, a practice that is eating into its bottom line.

fields.headline: Elateral risks going to market
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The fragile software and internet services sector could be about to see its first flotation of the year after Elateral, a five-year-old Farnham based firm said it would brave the stock market to try to raise £30m.
fields.body:
The fragile software and internet services sector could be about to see its first flotation of the year after Elateral, a five-year-old Farnham based firm said it would brave the stock market to try to raise £30m.

The planned listing on the London stock exchange will be closely watched by sector professionals for signs of whether investor appetite for hi-tech shares is returning after the heavy sell-offs seen last year.

"A good company can still succeed because it is very rare that the market is shut to a good company," an analysts said yesterday.

Elateral, which says its software improves communication and marketing, has attempted to minimise its dependence on market conditions by withholding a firm date for its float, saying only that it hopes to list before the end of June. Cazenove, the firm that floated Freeserve, has been appointed to handle the issue.

Elateral's licence revenues grew by more than 100% from the second to third quarters of the year to the end of March 2001.

fields.headline: Fresh boost for poorer regions
fields.trailText: The government yesterday announced steps to close Britain's gaping north-south divide as ministers set out to win back support in Labour's traditional manufacturing heartlands for the expected spring election campaign.
fields.body:
The government yesterday announced steps to close Britain's gaping north-south divide as ministers set out to win back support in Labour's traditional manufacturing heartlands for the expected spring election campaign.

Admitting that the poorest regions have slipped further behind the booming south-east, trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, and the education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, announced a raft of measures to encourage business start-ups, stimulate innovation and improve skills in the worst affected areas.

"It is impossible to have economic success with a divided society," said Mr Byers. "If we manage to raise growth by 0.5% in the worst performing regions we could see a £20bn increase in GDP."

The joint DTI and Department for Education and Employment white paper is the government's last chance to lay out a distinctive agenda on industrial policy with the start of the election campaign expected within weeks.

New initiatives announced yesterday include business- sponsored university innovation centres, a £75m start-up fund, new technology institutes that will equip 10,000 adults a year with IT skills, and a £30m fund to get households hooked up to digital TV.

"The measures we are setting out today will mean that our companies can compete in the global marketplace," Mr Blunkett said.

webTitle: World Bank president backed by staff

fields.headline: World Bank president backed by staff
fields.trailText: World Bank staff have sprung to the defence of their president James Wolfensohn, accused in a memo last month of presiding over a climate of fear at its Washington headquarters.
fields.body:
World Bank staff have sprung to the defence of their president James Wolfensohn, accused in a memo last month of presiding over a climate of fear at its Washington headquarters.

A letter sent to Mr Wolfensohn on behalf of more than 1,000 staff describes his critics as "disgruntled and self-centred", and praises him for his "strong and visionary leadership".

In a memo leaked to the Guardian earlier this month, staff in the Bank's Middle Eastern and North African division blamed Mr Wolfensohn's leadership style for the morale crisis at the bank, accusing him of "not welcoming criticism or tolerating dissent".

Morale at the bank has plummeted after nearly 300 staff were made redundant to cut costs. Some of those facing the axe blame top management for failing to see the budget crunch coming.

But staff in the bank's 1,200 strong Africa Club disagree. A letter from the club's chairman, Sidi Jammeh, says there is unanimous support for Mr Wolfensohn, praises his commitment to focusing the bank on poverty reduction, and describes the attack on him as "mean spirited and destructive".

webTitle: Why Sir Eddie should be praying for inflation

fields.headline: Why Sir Eddie should be praying for inflation
fields.standfirst: Notebook Price rises at lowest since 1976
fields.trailText: Having helped to man the barricades at Threadneedle Street during the two oil crises of the 1970s, Bank of England governor Sir Eddie George is firmly one of the old school of central bankers still having sleepless nights about another inflationary surge of energy prices.
fields.body:
Having helped to man the barricades at Threadneedle Street during the two oil crises of the 1970s, Bank of England governor Sir Eddie George is firmly one of the old school of central bankers still having sleepless nights about another inflationary surge of energy prices.

Yet, in the current circumstances, he might be relieved if the price of oil continues to hover around yesterday's relatively high level of $29 a barrel. The reason? Well, judging by January's inflation figures, rebounding oil prices are just about the only thing that will prevent Sir Eddie being forced to write to the chancellor to explain why the rate of price increases has dropped below 1.5%.

The data showed underlying inflation falling perilously close to that level at 1.8%, the lowest since the series began in January 1976.

There is evidence that the monetary policy committee has failed to gauge the extent to which technology and global competition have permanently improved the trade-off between growth and inflation, allowing the economy to operate safely at lower interest rates.

Today's Bank of England inflation report will be read more carefully than most for signs of a shift in thinking.

Rolls' bankroll

Labour's new industrial policy was unveiled by Stephen Byers and David Blunkett yesterday. It committed the government to "world class university innovation centres", technology institutes, a £75m incubator fund, a manufacturing advisory service, support for clusters, an action plan to "drive up ICT skills", a job transition service and measures to promote take up of digital TV. This was a white paper for those who think that joblessness is now an aesthetic issue and that all that stands between an unemployed claimant and a job in the glittering new service sector economy is a Paul Smith suit and a stick of roll-on deodorant.

Happily for those unable to wade through page after page of the white paper's vacuous verbiage, Labour's real industrial policy had been announced some hours earlier. Instead of paying for Rolls-Royce workers to have a stylish new haircut, the government came up with a more direct approach. It would pay the company £250m towards the cost of developing two new engines, the Trent 900 and the Trent 600.

For all the talk in the white paper about it not being the job of Whitehall to "pick regional winners", Mr Byers has turned the clock back three decades to when a loss-making aero engine company was bailed out by the government and taken into the public sector. A Conservative government, as it happens.

Ethics optional

Sir Stanley Kalms has always had a special ability to baffle friends and foes. He has done it again with a statement that the Dixons chairman had "entered into a stock loan agreement in relation to 3m Dixons ordinary shares and into a hedging transaction over Dixons shares which does not commit him to sell any shares at a future date".

The trick here is in the words "does not commit him to sell." Clearly, a rinky-dinky derivatives deal with an unnamed bank also gives him the right to sell at some stage - say three months hence - at a prearranged price. So we can speculate that Sir Stanley has already decided to offload some his Dixons stock in a way that minimises his tax bill.

The bank behind this synthetic deal is handing to Sir Stanley any upside in the shares while the loan is in place. By definition, another bank client, at the other end of the deal, is short of Dixons.

So the chairman is not only selling stock and avoiding tax, he is also helping the market's bears. Perhaps other investors in Dixons should consider a bit of "estate planning" of their own.

Profit pumping

BP has joined Shell to bang on about what a thankless, unprofitable task it is pumping out petrol on their forecourts.

Last Friday Shell told us that it had not made money out of its filling stations for six years. Yesterday BP, bulging with a record £9bn profit, said it too found it tricky to break even at the pumps. Shell is conducting a three year review into the future of its retailing business . No risk of a hasty decision there, then.

These companies witter on about how they must have forecourts to maintain their market share and their brand.

Absolute nonsense. These are not reasons to own the ultimate retail outlet of a consumer commodity. There is always the suspicion that zero profits at the pumps is rather handy PR.

If not, and they are truly no good at running petrol stations, they should stop wasting shareholders' cash and leave it to independent retailers and supermarkets - who are obviously more efficient.

fields.headline: Byers puts cash into Rolls-Royce
fields.standfirst: £250m for superjumbo risks US anger
fields.trailText: Rolls-Royce yesterday launched its £1bn engine production for superjumbo airliners after securing a controversial £250m investment from the government.
fields.body:
Rolls-Royce yesterday launched its £1bn engine production for superjumbo airliners after securing a controversial £250m investment from the government.

The public money will safeguard 7,000 jobs, many around the Derby area, over the next couple of years but will not reverse 1,300 redundancies planned for the Coventry plant, which have been met with a strike.

The government support must be cleared by the European commission, and Rolls-Royce could face criticism from competitors such as General Electric in the US and Snecma of France. The US government has in the past attacked similar investments by European governments in the aerospace sector.

Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, said the payments proved government's "commitment to help hi-tech, high skilled companies in the UK to compete on a world stage". Rolls-Royce and aerospace supplier BAE Sys tems had been provided with similar aid before. Investment schemes were operated in other European Union countries while the US funded its own research and development projects, though the money was channelled through Nasa.

Mr Byers said World Trade Organisation rules permitted this kind of support. "If people want to complain, well its for them to do so."

A Department of Trade spokesman said aerospace companies found it difficult to raise money for long-term projects with uncertain payback dates without public support. The government would obtain a commercial rate of return as dictated by the EU but he could not say exactly what it would be. "It depends on market conditions and how many engines are sold eventually."

Rolls-Royce chairman John Rose said moving ahead with the Trent programme would "provide a further stimulus to technology acquisition and high technology manufacturing in Britain." He said 7,000 direct and indirect jobs would be secure in Britain though a spokesman later added that 70% of Rolls-Royce engines were sourced outside the company and at least 20% of the content of an engine package historically came from the US.

Rolls-Royce will use the investment, with more it hopes to attract from the private sector, to develop two engines in its successful Trent family: the Trent 900 and Trent 600 for the Airbus A380 and Boeing 747X respectively. Airbus has obtained orders for 60 A380s with Rolls-Royce engines from airlines such as Virgin Atlantic and Singapore Airlines. Boeing has no contracts for the 747X and some analysts suspect the scheme could run into trouble.

Rolls-Royce shares, which have seen a renaissance over the last 12 months, remained stable at 199.75 .

Last week the company was hit with its first strike in 20 years at the Coventry plant which is primarily engaged in building propulsion systems for the marine and energy sector. Attempts are being made to prevent further disruption by offering better severance arrangements and relocation.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a panel accompanying our report, Bleak new world, as seen by the MoD, page 3, February 8, we stated that, according to the ministry of defence "by the middle of the century two-thirds of the population of the EU will be over 65, 'not economically active'."
fields.body:
In a panel accompanying our report, Bleak new world, as seen by the MoD, page 3, February 8, we stated that, according to the ministry of defence "by the middle of the century two-thirds of the population of the EU will be over 65, 'not economically active'." We should have said that, according to the MoD, by the middle of the century, the percentage of the population of the EU over the age of 65 is expected to rise to 34% "meaning that around two-thirds of the population of European countries will not be 'economically active', " the rest accounted for by the young or unemployed.

In our front page report, Gene code opens new fields of medicine, February 12, we said, "The genome reveals that the human chromosome carries only about 30,000 genes..." We should have said "The genome reveals that human chromosomes carry..."

In our report about the spacecraft that has landed on the asteroid, Eros, page 16, yesterday, our science correspondent described the object as "a lump of builder's rubble left over from the making of the planets". This was edited to become "builder's rubble left over from the Big Bang". The two events are separated by billions of years (Big Bang first).

In our account of the Game Spirit Chase at Newbury, page 10, Sport, February 12, all references to Foundry Lane should have been made instead to Function Dream.

In a caption on page 3, G2, yesterday, we said that Gwyneth Paltrow was the winner of last year's Best Actress Oscar. In fact, it was Hilary Swank for Boys Don't Cry.

Contrary to what we said in a report headed Few tears as books chain chief quits, page 11, yesterday, Waterstone's do not have a branch in Piccadilly, Manchester. They have two branches in Manchester, one in Deansgate and the other in St Ann's Square.

On page 8 of Education, February 6, we asked the following question: "Do you have a problem with your childs education?"

The education green paper as described on page 6 yesterday applies only to England.

The readers' editor was wrong to say in his Open Door column, page 7, Saturday Review, February 10, that the cartoonist David Low joined the Guardian in the period after the first world war. He did not really join the paper as a regular contributor until after the second world war, although isolated examples of his work appeared in the paper earlier.

fields.headline: City diary  Richard Adams
fields.trailText: • How delightful that yesterday's flotation of Orange was such a success. True, the share price slipped 5% or so, but that's a small price to pay for the back end of those annoying new-ageish ads involving small children frolicking around sandcastles. There is a similar sense of relief doing the rounds at Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, one of the "global co-ordinators" for France Télécom's benighted sell-off. Staff working on the IPO have been forced to wear ghastly bright orange ties, and deluged with other garish bits of PR rubbish. Once yesterday's launch press conference was out of the way, the brokers were quick to rip the wretched things from their necks. "If I see another orange logo I'm going to jump off the 21st floor," announced one on his way out. So the float may not be a complete loss.

 How delightful that yesterday's flotation of Orange was such a success. True, the share price slipped 5% or so, but that's a small price to pay for the back end of those annoying new-ageish ads involving small children frolicking around sandcastles. There is a similar sense of relief doing the rounds at Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, one of the "global co-ordinators" for France Télécom's benighted sell-off. Staff working on the IPO have been forced to wear ghastly bright orange ties, and deluged with other garish bits of PR rubbish. Once yesterday's launch press conference was out of the way, the brokers were quick to rip the wretched things from their necks. "If I see another orange logo I'm going to jump off the 21st floor," announced one on his way out. So the float may not be a complete loss.

The market for computer hardware has been soggy recently, but new export markets seem to be opening up for Sun Microsystems. An organised crime gang in Scotland has half-inched more than £1m worth of hi-tech gear, including £100,000 worth of Sun chips and motherboards last weekend. According to a police source quoted by the Edinburgh Evening News: "The feeling is the boards are shipped to a third-world country and then on to Iraq". Which suggests a cunning plan to topple Saddam Hussain: perhaps he has been pursuaded to start a dot.com.

Last week's Index on Censorship awards ceremony was a glittering event, full of celebs (and Harold Pinter). Compere Jon Snow had some withering comments about one large media organisation, which has refused to financially support the anti-censorship campaigning organisation. Snow says he won't reveal the identity of the skinflint ... unless it doesn't cough up next time.

Meanwhile, some excellent news that Gerald Kaufman (a great fan of the Guardian) is - like Saddam - getting to grips with new technology. webTitle: Slow death of a cancer cure

fields.headline: Slow death of a cancer cure
fields.standfirst: Marimastat was the drug that was to make British Biotech's name. That, it managed, but nothing else
fields.trailText: British Biotech, the fallen angel of the drug development industry, has sounded the death knell for marimastat, the onetime cure for cancer that was over-hyped to such a degree that it triggered one of the most acrimonious boardroom rows of the 1990s.
fields.body:
British Biotech, the fallen angel of the drug development industry, has sounded the death knell for marimastat, the onetime cure for cancer that was over-hyped to such a degree that it triggered one of the most acrimonious boardroom rows of the 1990s.

After nearly a decade of research, the company yesterday admitted that marimastat was a flop, after failure in its sixth successive clinical trial - this time, on patients with small-cell lung cancer. Chief executive Elliot Goldstein said: "It hasn't worked. We're moving on."

Marimastat had already failed to help patients with pancreatic, gastric, ovarian and brain cancer. British Biotech's shares, which touched 300p at the height of enthusiasm about marimastat in 1996, fell 1p yesterday to 26p.

To the company's executives, the news was more of a relief than a disappointment. Finance director Tony Weir said he had been keen to leave marimastat behind for months: "Any negative result is disappointing, but as far as British Biotech's concerned, marimastat has dominated the way people have looked at us, sometimes inappropriately."

The debacle fulfilled predictions made three years ago by former clinical research chief Andrew Millar, who became a cause célèbre among whistle-blowers when he was sacked by British Biotech for expressing concerns to shareholders.

The dissident scientist's disclosures led to the departure of the company's entire board, a parliamentary inquiry, regulatory investigations on both sides of the Atlantic and a plunge in share prices throughout the biotech industry.

Marimastat's origins lie in work carried out by scientists in the early days of British Biotech, at a former carpet warehouse on the outskirts of Oxford in the late 1980s. Using computer models, they were designing drugs which would attack cancer in a new way.

British Biotech was trying to break out of the mould of cancer care - traditional drugs irradiated fast-dividing tumour cells, preventing the disease's spread but causing unpleasant side effects. The new company, founded by former Searle pharmaceuticals executive Keith McCullagh, wanted to target matrix metalloproteases - enzymes in the body which enable tumour cells to get into the blood and move around.

The idea was just the beginning of a dream for Dr McCullagh - he wanted to create a multinational drugs corporation rivalling Glaxo Wellcome. British Biotech's team came up with hundreds of different chemical compounds which would inhibit these metalloproteases. Among the most promising was marimastat, which did well enough in early trials to encourage investors to stump up for a £151m stockmarket flotation in 1992.

As trials progressed, British Biotech's market value soared. Former development director Peter Lewis described the results of phase two studies as "about the best possible at this stage in development".

By 1996, British Biotech was worth more than £2bn and teetering on the edge of the FTSE-100 index. The firm moved into a sparkling new building. But less than a year later, problems began to emerge.

Andrew Millar, then head of clinical research, recalls that he first became concerned when a doctor involved with the most exacting round of trials, phase three studies, phoned him to highlight possible side effects among a few patients.

Worried that Dr McCullagh could be over-hyping an unsafe drug, Dr Millar took a controversial decision to "unblind" the studies. This involved examining data to compare those on a placebo against those taking marimastat. It was a breach of the usual convention, which is to wait until trials have been completed.

He discovered that although side effects were modest, the drug was not working - just as many people were dying on marimastat as on placebo. Neither was another key product, pancreatitis treatment Zacutex.

Dr Millar maintains that he was anxious that investors were being misled about the drug's prospects. Having been bawled out by Dr McCullagh for looking at confidential data, he revealed his concerns to an analyst, Jane Henderson of Goldman Sachs, and to a shareholder, Neil Woodford of fund manager Perpetual.

He spelled out his fears at a secret lunch in an Oxfordshire pub in early 1998. Along with Mr Woodford, he hatched a plan to oust Dr McCullagh, and instal himself as chief operating officer of British Biotech.

This plan came unstuck when the pair tried to recruit the support of the company's broker, Kleinwort Benson. The merchant bank tipped off Dr McCullagh.

Dr Millar was suspended by British Biotech. In a dramatic fightback, he revealed that the US Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating allegedly over-optimistic press releases from British Biotech about marimastat, and the stock exchange was looking into large share sales by directors at a time when they were aware that the drug's progress was equivocal.

Recruiting the support of the British Medical Association, he won an out-of-court settlement for wrongful dismissal, and the board of British Biotech resigned en masse.

Dr Millar still believes marimastat had a chance of working, had the company adjusted trials to concentrate on delivering large doses to patients with small tumours. Opinions are still divided on whether Dr Millar's actions were appropriate in looking early at the data from clinical trials.

Even under new management, British Biotech has struggled to rebuild its reputation. The company has six drugs in the early stages of clinical trials, including treatments for leukaemia, arthritis and multiple sclerosis. As of last October, British Biotech had £61m of cash in the bank, and many believe the firm is likely to be swallowed in a merger or takeover.

Finance director Tony Weir said: "We're very open to corporate transactions in any form - whether through partnership, joint ventures, acquisitions or mergers."

There are few winners from the marimastat story - Dr Millar now runs a start-up firm called Oxford Gene Technology.

Dr McCullagh's dream of creating the next Glaxo Wellcome is over, and Kleinwort Benson has lost its place as one of the leading advisers to biotechnology companies. Worst of all, cancer sufferers had their hopes raised, then dashed.

British Biotech's current boss, Elliot Goldstein, hates talking about marimastat. However, he conceeds that there are lessons to be learned for all drug development firms - British Biotech's mistake, he says, was to put all its eggs in one basket.

1986 Former Searle drugs executive Keith McCullagh founds British Biotech

July, 1992 It is the first biotech company to float in London, valued at £152m

May, 1996 Marimastat achieves "best possible" phase two clinical trial results

Late 1997 Research chief Andrew Millar examines confidential trial data, amid concerns about side effects

April 1998 Millar sacked for "bitching" to outsiders

May 1998 McCullagh resigns as chief executive

February 1999 Marimastat is no better than existing medicines in trials on pancreatic cancer

February 2001 Marimastat is abandoned

Other disasters

 Scotia Holdings went into administration last month after rejection of its Foscan treatment for head and neck cancer. It burned the arms of South African backpackers who volunteered to try it

 Glaxo Wellcome withdrew Lotronex , a drug for irritable bowel syndrome, last year after spending £350m. Three patients died while taking it

The market value of Stanford Rook fell from £104m to £29m in less than an hour when the biotech firm (now SR Pharma) abandoned a tuberculosis drug in 1997. It offered no benefit over existing treatments

 Celltech's medicine for septic shock failed in final stage trials three years ago, knocking £226m off the company's value

 Cantab Pharmaceuticals was put up for sale last year after its genital warts vaccine proved ineffectual

fields.headline: Kalms to slash Dixons stake
fields.standfirst: Bank holds 3m of chairman's shares in controversial loan deal
fields.trailText: Ebullient Dixons chairman Sir Stanley Kalms has slashed his £20m holding in the electrical retailer by more than 35% - without selling a single share.
fields.body:
Ebullient Dixons chairman Sir Stanley Kalms has slashed his £20m holding in the electrical retailer by more than 35% - without selling a single share.

Sir Stanley entered into an unorthodox stock lending arrangement with a bank in relation to 3m of his 7.9m shares. He has also entered into a hedging transaction over Dixons shares, but the deal does not commit him to sell any shares at any point in the future.

A spokeswoman for Dixons - whose high street outlets also include Curry's, PC World and The Link - yesterday refused to provide details of the stock loan deal. She said it was a "perfectly straightforward" arrangement and a private transaction which Sir Stanley, 69, had entered into for "estate planning" reasons. Such stock loan deals are quite commonplace in the US, although they are still regarded as controversial.

Sir Stanley has handed over the certificates relating to the shares on loan, so his holding has been reduced to 4.9m shares. But the spokeswoman said he had the option to have the shares back or to sell them at a later date.

The company refused to say how long the stock loan was for or whether it was an indefinite arrangement, but said the deal would allow Sir Stanley to benefit from any increase in the group's share price while protecting him from any downturns.

Stock loans are normally provided by financial institutions and taken out by banks which have found themselves short of stock.

Analysts said the 3m shares had been loaned in return for a monthly fee which could equal 0.5%-1% of the £8m value of the shares.

It is also understood to be tax advantageous.

Sir Stanley's unusual arrangement was revealed as three other Dixons directors sold shares in the group.

It is the first time since 1997 that the Dixons' chairman has offloaded shares and the directors' deals came just after Dixon's shares hit a six month peak. The company said the four deals came together because negotiations about the merger of Dixon's Freeserve internet service provider with France's Wanadoo, together with results and trading statements, had left the group's directors "effectively in a close period and unable to deal for the last nine months".

Analysts were split on the implications of the directors' dealings and the chairman's stock loan. "You would rather they kept the shares, but they were looking to sell," one said. "I think the outlook is still pretty good."

But another leading analyst was less impressed, commenting: "Stock lending is not what I expect from the chairman of a company. It is perfectly legal, but personally I think they should get on with running the company and not play about with financial instruments".

David Gilbert, chief operating officer of central operations, sold 46,457 shares at 272.5p, netting £126,500 and cutting his holding to 146,849 shares.

David Hamed, chief operating officer of retail operations, unloaded 36,417 shares, raising £99,000 to reduce his stake to 105,084 and finance director Ian Livingstone sold shares worth some £94,000. His holding is now 62,353.

webTitle: CSFB's secret sell note on Invensys stirs up row

fields.headline: CSFB's secret sell note on Invensys stirs up row
fields.trailText: Credit Suisse First Boston, the blue-chip investment bank, has been quietly circulating an aggressive "sell" note on Invensys, the engineering and software group, among its institutional clients, while telling the company and the outside world that it rates the shares a "buy".
fields.body:
Credit Suisse First Boston, the blue-chip investment bank, has been quietly circulating an aggressive "sell" note on Invensys, the engineering and software group, among its institutional clients, while telling the company and the outside world that it rates the shares a "buy".

The disclosure is likely to provoke a fierce row between Invensys and CSFB - the latest in a string of disputes between companies who feel they are being badly treated by the City and the investment banking analysts charged with producing insightful corporate research.

The circumstances surrounding the CFSB note, which was produced on Monday after a confidential meeting between the bank's engineering analyst Dan Manor and Invensys executives last Friday, will reignite the debate over the selective briefing of analysts, who may receive price-sensitive information before the rest of the stock market.

Last Friday, shares in Invensys fell 9% in exceptionally heavy trading as rumours that CSFB had downgraded the stock and slashed its profits forecast swept through the market.

The investment bank swiftly responded with a categoric denial. "There is no rating change. It (Invensys) is still a buy with a 250p target price," a spokeswoman said at the time.

Yet this week Mr Manor began emailing institutions with a 2,000-word assessment of Invensys's trading position, with a summary which concluded: "We maintain our cautious stance; we would look to sell the stock from current levels and would start buying again only at the 140p [up to 150p] levels,"

The note also queries the health of the company's cash position and speculates that unless Invensys enjoys exceptionally strong trading over the next month or so it will fail to meet the City's profit expectations.

On Friday shares in Invensys stood at 180p, while last night the price closed at 161p. Last September, when the company issued a profits warning, the stock fell a third on one day.

Both CSFB and Invensys declined to comment on the matter, though one source close to the company, which has been struggling to transform itself from an old-fashioned engineer into a software and controls business, said: "This is very much for CSFB to explain their contrary actions."

The affair echoes last week's row between Autonomy, the software group, and investment bankers Merrill Lynch, where a "sell" note by an equity trader provoked the wrath of Autonomy's chief executive Mike Lynch and a complaint to the financial services authority, the City watchdog.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: News in Brief
fields.body:
Greenspan lifts markets

Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan gave a more upbeat assessment of the US economy yesterday but warned that "downside risks predominate".

In his biannual address before the Senate banking committee, he said that a "substantial slowdown" was likely this year after the growth of the past decade. However, once the temporary glut had been worked out, he suggested there would be "an implicit strengthening of activity".

US shares welcomed the optimism and the suggestion that the Fed was minded towards cutting rates. The Nasdaq composite index rose almost 2% to 2,529 and the Dow Jones made gains.

Unions in final plea to Corus

The government yesterday asked Corus to reconsider plans to cut more than 6,000 jobs ahead of talks over the future of the steel industry. Today union leaders will present a rescue package to the company to stop the cuts, which Corus is planning in several areas, including Wales and the north-east.

Online cars war hits Brussels

Britain's two largest internet car retailers, Virgin Cars and Direct Line's Jamjar.com, took their fight for lower car prices to Brussels yesterday.

They told the European commission that the car industry's "block exemption" from normal EU competition rules means British consumers pay too much for cars and have less choice. Rules governing car sales are due to expire in September 2002 and the EC is in the process of deciding whether to scrap or modify them. They take no account of online or supermarket sales, and price differentials as high as 65% persist within the EU.

Pensioners fight Grid move

Power industry pensioners yesterday sought to persuade the House of Lords that an attempt by privatised electricity companies to plunder billions of pounds of pension funds should be ruled illegal.

The pensioners believe the companies wrongly used £350m of pension fund surpluses from the £18bn electricity supply pension scheme to pay off redundant workers at the time of privatisation.

They argue that the funds should have been used to boost payments to pensioners and their widows on low incomes.

National Grid is urging law lords to overturn a court of appeal ruling that the company acted unlawfully in taking £46.3m in surpluses from the industry pension scheme in 1992. The hearing continues

Medical House starts trials

Medical House, the surgical products supplier, is to start trials of a new diagnostic device which identifies, by analysing the breath, a bacteria believed to cause stomach ulcers. Sources close to the company said tests on the hyperlyser will take place at Bristol's University of the West of England. Shares in the company, which is listed on the AIM, stood at 30p last night, below its 65p year high.

fields.headline: Bush fills foreign and defence ranks with cold war veterans
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: President George Bush is rapidly putting his own stamp on the US presidency, but his recent lower-level appointments show that the substance of the new team in Washington is overwhelmingly from of the era of his father and Ronald Reagan.
fields.body:
President George Bush is rapidly putting his own stamp on the US presidency, but his recent lower-level appointments show that the substance of the new team in Washington is overwhelmingly from of the era of his father and Ronald Reagan.

The return of the Reaganites is particularly evident in the areas of foreign and defence policy, where Mr Bush has just appointed Richard Armitage deputy secretary of state under Colin Powell. Mr Armitage is a Pentagon veteran of the Reagan and Bush Sr era, during which he played a key role as a Middle East policy expert.

His role in the Iran-contra arms smuggling scandal was sufficiently important to force George Bush Sr to withdraw his the nomination as army secretary in 1989.

Mr Armitage worked closely with Colonel Oliver North in the secret Reagan White House effort to trade arms to Iran and syphon some of the profits to Nicaraguan contra rebels in defiance of an arms ban.

Last week Mr Bush appointed another Reagan era veteran, Paul Wolfowitz, to the number two job in the defence department under Donald Rumsfeld.

Mr Wolfowitz was a key policymaker at the state department during the Reagan years and is the administration's most senior Asian policy expert. He is expected to be the arbiter of any attempts to place deploy US missile defences in Japan, South Korea or Taiwan.

Other appointments of cold war era officials have included Dov Zakheim as under-secretary of defence, a more senior version of the departmental planning role he played at the Pentagon in the Reagan years.

Mr Bush has also brought back Richard Haass as head of policy planning at the state department. Last week he put Grant Green, a Reagan national security council official, in charge of management policy in the state department.

The appointments replicate the pattern of continuity that was striking in Mr Bush's cabinet choices for foreign and defence posts.

With Mr Powell already at the state department and Mr Rumsfeld at the Pentagon, the new administration's foreign policy is indisputably in the grip of experienced experts who learned their trade in the final years of the cold war.

So far there has only been one appointment in the foreign policy field which does not fit the pattern, that of the career diplomat Marc Grossman as head of political affairs at the state department.

As the administration takes shape, the key man in both domestic and foreign policy is still clearly the vice-president, Dick Cheney.

This week he was reported to be trying to tighten his conservative grip on foreign policymaking by taking charge of the White House's "principals" committee, in which cabinet members hammer out policy options to be put to the president.

In the past this role has been played by the national security adviser, a post now held by Condoleezza Rice, who tutored Mr Bush on foreign policy during the election campaign.

Newsweek magazine alleged this week that Mr Cheney waspressing his claim to chair the committee, and trying to push Ms Rice aside.

In addition, he was reported to be hiring his own team of foreign policy staff and to be building "the nucleus of an alternative national security committee".

To many observers the crucial question in the early weeks of the administration is the extent to which the more liberal Mr Powell will be able to get his way in the event of a policy disagreement with the more conservative Mr Cheney and Mr Rumsfeld.

Mr Powell has distanced himself from Mr Bush's decision to cut off US funding to international bodies which provide or support abortion services, and has adopted a more favourable stance than Mr Rumsfeld towards EU for plans for a military rapid response force.

fields.headline: City plays down BP record
fields.standfirst: Chairman denounces fuel protesters' case
fields.trailText: Chairman denounces fuel protesters' case.
fields.body:
BP yesterday claimed to have broken the British corporate profits record in the last quarter but its shares slumped 19p to 590p as the City worried about oil and gas output growth tailing off.

The world's third largest oil group reported record replacement cost profits, adjusted for special items, at $4.09bn (£2.9bn) compared to $2.1bn a year ago while the final year figure came in at $14.2bn compared with $6.2bn for 12 months previously.

Sir John Browne, chairman and chief executive, described the results as "outstanding" and said they were built round strong commodity prices and continued cost-cutting after its wave of takeovers.

He admitted there had been a slowdown in oil output over the year but said this would be rectified by a string of new and exciting field developments.

Capital expenditure for 2001 would be raised to nearly $13bn, back up to the level of three years ago.

Meanwhile BP would still be able to help its bottom line by taking out more costs. It had cut $4.9bn off its overheads by the end of 2000 since 1998 when the wave of acqusitions starting with Amoco began. But BP intended to take out a further $800m of costs in 2001. The takeover of Arco nine months ago had brought considerable benefits with that company showing a minimum of 14% increases in earnings and volume growth.

Sir John's words on oil and gas output failed to appease the investment community which was concerned that production growth estimates had been reduced from an earlier figure of 7% to a more likely level of 5.5%. Analysts said BP's underlying like-for-like increase could be as low as 3% this coming year.

Fourth quarter upstream volumes had increased 9% on a year ago but, stripping out acquisitions and divestments, volumes declined by 4%. The complexity of oil company accounting also made some question whether it was appropriate to compare BP's financial figures with those of the non-energy sector.

Sir John believed that the BP last quarter result had only ever been beaten outside of the UK by General Electric and ExxonMobil.

BP's very strong financial performance also led to protests from the fuel lobby. Sir John rejected their arguments insisting that the sales and marketing arm of BP was making very low profits in Britain.

He said that the real reason why petrol cost so much was taxes.

He said there was no justification for taxing companies which were successful.

A quarterly dividend of 5.25 cents per share was declared by BP and total dividends for the year amounted to 20.5 cents per share.
