webTitle: Battered Clinton seeks refuge in Harlem

fields.headline: Battered Clinton seeks refuge in Harlem
fields.standfirst: Move may still the squall over his Manhattan office pricetag - but not the storm about his presidential favours
fields.trailText: Move may still the squall over his Manhattan office pricetag - but not the storm about his presidential favours
fields.body:
Bill Clinton did yesterday what he has so often done before: threw himself on the support of black Americans in an attempt to deflect attention from his latest troubles.

Beset by some of the worst publicity he has faced since the impeachment crisis of 1998-99, he went to Harlem to announce that he wants to put his post-presidential office there rather than in the much more expensive Manhattan site he had chosen earlier.

"I have decided to locate my office in this building if we can work it out," he told a cheering crowd outside 55 West 125th Street.

Smiling and waving, Mr Clinton proceeded to offer a reprise of one of the things he does best, a walkabout, during which he shook hundreds of black and white hands in the crowded streets of New York.

The latest twist in the story that looks like taking Mr Clinton from the White House to the heart of the most celebrated black district in the United States was executed with the kind of theatre - and with several of the same cast - that has marked the ups and downs of his career.

Mr Clinton said he had decided to try to move after consulting his old golfing friend Vernon Jordan, as well as the Harlem congressman Charlie Rangel and the junior senator for the state of New York, his wife Hillary.

"She loved it," he said.

If he agrees a Harlem tenancy, Mr Clinton will not be paying the $738,700 (£505,950) annual rent he would have had to pay if he had gone ahead with renting the 56th floor of the Carnegie Hall Tower on West 57th Street, just south of Central Park.

Estimates put the top floor of the 14-storey Harlem office building at about $210,000 (£143,800) for 7,000 sq ft (650 sq metres)

He will sacrifice the delights of the Russian Tea Room near the Carnegie building, but gain the Bayou Cajun restaurant and a new branch of a big coffee chain.

Mr Clinton had asked the US government to pay the whole of the rent of the suite in the Carnegie building, but protests caused him to scale down his request last week to just over $330,000 a year, the Clinton presidential library fund making up the rest.

In Harlem his claim on federal funds will be significantly lower than that made by his immediate White House predecessors.

In addition to sparing taxpayers a big rental bill, he clearly hopes that moving to Harlem will win him some desperately needed good publicity, because several of his acts at the very end of his presidency last month are getting him into ever hotter political and legal water.

Yesterday might have been good for him in news management terms, but he is in particular trouble for unconditionally pardoning he fugitive financier Marc Rich on January 20, just before handing over to George Bush.

A Senate committee is due to open inquiries today into whether this pardon was properly given in accordance with the rules governing presidential powers. The justice department, for instance, says it was kept in the dark because it would have strongly opposed the pardon.

The committee chairman, Senator Arlen Specter, created further headlines at the weekend by saying that Mr Clinton could face impeachment charges arising from the pardon, even though he has left office.

"I'm not suggesting it should be done, but President Clinton technically could still be impeached," he told Fox News on Sunday.

A separate House of Representatives' inquiry into the Rich pardon is also well under way. Yesterday officials of the House committee on government reform issued several subpoenas for further evidence on the issue, including one to the White House secret service for logs of Mr Clinton's visitors in January.

The House committee, headed by a frequent Clinton nemesis, Congressman Dan Burton, is expected to offer immunity this week to Mr Rich's former wife Denise, who has given a great deal of money to the Democratic party, in return for her testimony.

Last week Mrs Rich invoked her constitutional right not to testify to the committee, a decision which increased the suspicion that she has damaging information about the negotiations that led to the pardon.

This week's issue of US News & World Report magazine carried a claim that Mrs Rich had donated at least $10m (£6.8m) to Mr Clinton's presidential library foundation. Other sources are reported to put the sum at $450,000.

Mr Burton has said he has not yet ruled out calling Mr Clinton himself to testify.

fields.headline: The rake's progress
fields.standfirst: Lover, writer, soldier, spy - Casanova was many things. Now he's come back as an art dealing Scot.
fields.trailText: Lover, writer, soldier, spy - Casanova was many things. Now he's come back as an art dealing Scot.
fields.body:
So renowned is Giacomo Casanova (1725-1798) for his sexual exploits that we now tend to forget the man, the historical character, and talk only of a philandering type, still alive and well more than two centuries later. But the original Casanova - the inspiration for Suspect Culture's new play opening tonight, appropriately - was far more than simply a Venetian Mr Lover-Lover.

Soldier, diplomat, writer, adventurer and spy for Louis XV, he also introduced the concept of a lottery to Paris in 1757 before settling down to pen his 28-volume memoir, from which we get our image of him as an insatiable Lothario. Like many men since, he isn't the most reliable narrator of his own sexual history, but we do know he seduced 132 women, had his first sexual experience at 11 and his second, with two sisters, very soon after. His greatest love, Henriette, was a cross-dresser who passed herself off as a castrato. At one point, he seduces and nearly marries the offspring of one of his ex-lovers. She turns out to be his own daughter.

With this kind of track record, scandal and venereal disease were Casanova's constant companions. In later life, after one too many bouts of the pox, imprisonment and exile, he took up the quiet life, working as a librarian in a Bohemian castle and penning his life story. Too late, he realised the value of a good woman, Elise von der Recke, who sent him soup and wine when he was poorly. "Real love is the love that sometimes arises after sensual pleasure," he wrote, souped-up and soppy. "If it does it is immortal; the other kind inevitably goes stale, for it lies in mere fantasy."

Though transposed to the present day, Suspect Culture's Casanova is still inspired by the historical figure. Their smooth-talker might be a modern-day Scottish art dealer breaking hearts across the international art scene, but the point is to show how little has changed in the way society regards the figure of the sexually promiscuous man. "We're looking at the Casanova type, the rake, the libertine," explains writer David Greig. "What we're trying to bring out about our Casanova is that he is successful in seducing women because he really does like them. It's a shocking thing that heterosexual men very often don't like women very much."

The production's style, inspired by 18th-century French comedies by Molière and Marivaux, is a long way from Suspect Culture's trademark experimentalism, seen in Candide 2000, Mainstream and, most recently, The Golden Ass. "The inspiration from the French playwrights is the way in which stock figures - the rakish lover, a cuckolded husband, the wealthy widow - are put together to debate morality."

As evidence of our complicated response to Casanovas, Greig cites comments from the workshop stage of the project, after which he wrote the script. For men, he says, Casanova was a figure to fear, to feel threatened by; women, however, were not as disapproving as he had expected. "They say, 'At least he's honest - you know what you're getting, no strings attached, and you know he'll be good at it.' "

That's why Bill Clinton remained popular with female voters even after the Lewinsky revelations, says Greig. "The people who pursued him were not hordes of angry women, but hordes of angry men. He had tended to promote issues pertinent to women's lives, had promoted women in his government, and you never got the sense he was a misogynist."

Not interested in portraying their Casanova as hero or villain, Suspect Culture are instead exploring what our reactions to the philanderer tell us about ourselves. Gone is the feeling that the flames of hell wait for such men, as would have been the belief in Giacomo's day. Instead, a concern with well-being, for the love rat and his victims, takes centre stage. "A promiscuous man will be thought sad and lonely; it will be assumed he has unresolved issues," says Greig. "Monogamy is associated by contrast with moral health. In the play, though, it's monogamy, if anything, that gets a hard time, because as ever the devil has the best tunes."

fields.headline: Cholera township clear out stirs apartheid memories
fields.trailText: It bore all the hallmarks of apartheid: desperate black residents fighting to defend their rickety homes from destruction while a dozen or more lorries waited in the background to carry them off once the police had quelled resistance with teargas and rubber bullets.
fields.body:
It bore all the hallmarks of apartheid: desperate black residents fighting to defend their rickety homes from destruction while a dozen or more lorries waited in the background to carry them off once the police had quelled resistance with teargas and rubber bullets.

Some described yesterday's operation to relocate the first of 3,500 people from Alexandra, Johannesburg's oldest township, as a forced removal reminiscent of the past.

The government defended it as a lifesaving measure, removing squatters from the edge of the Jukskei river, which has tested positive for cholera during an outbreak in which almost 46,000 people have been infected in South Africa and more than 100 have died.

The banks of the Jukskei are crammed with corrugated iron and wooden shacks, many of which seem about to tumble into the water. The river is the main source of water for drinking, cooking and washing. Each year a few homes are washed away by floods.

The government says the area is a a deathtrap, but suspicious residents say that the cholera outbreak is just an excuse for the authorities to do what they planned long ago.

"They want us out of here so they can sell the land to other people. We have jobs here. Who will pay for my transport?" Zolile Mtengwane said.

A private security company was called in do the work. It hired casual labour without telling the men the nature of the job, and gave them uniforms and crowbars.

Only when they arrived in Alexandra did they realise that they would have to demolish homes.

By then residents had barricaded the road with trees and stones, and about 100 people threw stones at the workers until the police responding by firing teargas and rubber bullets, wounding at least one man. Several of the labourers walked away from the job.

But many of the residents accepted that they would have to move."I have lived here for 11 years, but now I have to move just because someone says there is cholera," said Collen Mohale.

Cholera is infecting about 1,000 people every day, the worst outbreak in South Africa for20 years. The health ministry says the number may double before the outbreak is brought under control.

The World Health Organisation has praised Pretoria for limiting the death rate: at 23 deaths for every 10,000 infected, the rate is substantially lower than that in similar outbreaks in Africa.

But the government has failed to stop it spreading to all but one of its nine provinces, largely because millions lack clean water and good sanitation. Only last month the minister of water affairs, Ronnie Kasrilspromised to accelerate the delivery of such services to poorer communities.

That is cold comfort to the bewildered families forced out of Alexandra yesterday, loaded on to lorries with what remained of their possessions, and dumped in Diepsloot, north of Johannesburg. Diepsloot is already crowded with squatters, some of whom are themselves being removed to make room for the new arrivals from Alexandra.

All that the new arrivals were given was an open space and the remnants of their previous dwellings - iron sheets, planks and a few pieces of furniture - with which to build a new home by nightfall. There was little evidence of adequate water supplies, either.

Other are destined for Soweto, where they qualify for free homes. That has not made them popular with existing residents, who say the newcomers are jumping the housing queue.

Pretoria is to expropriate a white-owned farm for the first time, after its owner refused to accept an independent review of its value. The agriculture ministry intends to give the 1,270-hectare (3,100-acre) farm to people robbed of land under apartheid. Its owner refused 840,000 rand (£7,400) compensation, saying it was not sufficient to buy another farm. He plans to sue.
fields.bodyText: It bore all the hallmarks of apartheid: desperate black residents fighting to defend their rickety homes from destruction while a dozen or more lorries waited in the background to carry them off once the police had quelled resistance with teargas and rubber bullets. Some described yesterday's operation to relocate the first of 3,500 people from Alexandra, Johannesburg's oldest township, as a forced removal reminiscent of the past. The government defended it as a lifesaving measure, removing squatters from the edge of the Jukskei river, which has tested positive for cholera during an outbreak in which almost 46,000 people have been infected in South Africa and more than 100 have died. The banks of the Jukskei are crammed with corrugated iron and wooden shacks, many of which seem about to tumble into the water. The river is the main source of water for drinking, cooking and washing. Each year a few homes are washed away by floods. The government says the area is a a deathtrap, but suspicious residents say that the cholera outbreak is just an excuse for the authorities to do what they planned long ago. "They want us out of here so they can sell the land to other people. We have jobs here. Who will pay for my transport?" Zolile Mtengwane said. A private security company was called in do the work. It hired casual labour without telling the men the nature of the job, and gave them uniforms and crowbars. Only when they arrived in Alexandra did they realise that they would have to demolish homes. By then residents had barricaded the road with trees and stones, and about 100 people threw stones at the workers until the police responding by firing teargas and rubber bullets, wounding at least one man. Several of the labourers walked away from the job. But many of the residents accepted that they would have to move."I have lived here for 11 years, but now I have to move just because someone says there is cholera," said Collen Mohale. All that the new arrivals were given was an open space and the remnants of their previous dwellings - iron sheets, planks and a few pieces of furniture - with which to build a new home by nightfall. webTitle: A kabarett interpretation of the Teletubbies

fields.headline: Eh-oh! Life is a cabaret
fields.standfirst: As German 'kabarett' turns 100,  Kate Connolly  finds that even the Teletubbies are getting in on the act
fields.trailText: As German 'kabarett' turns 100, Kate Connolly finds that even the Teletubbies are getting in on the act
fields.body:
Guten Tag, Dipsy!" "Eh-oh! Tinky Winky! Did you know, Tinky Winky, that it is easier for the individual to follow the group than to think for himself?"

"Oh, that's interesting, Dipsy!"

You probably didn't realise it, but we have a lot to thank German kabarett for, not least because in Berlin a troupe of kabarett artistes has transformed the Teletubbies from gurgling, dippy blobs into fluent reciters of Brecht. The performers, Dresden-based Herkuleskeule, are among the many German troupes caught up in celebrations for the centenary of kabarett or performed satire.

The story behind kabarett provides an entertaining insight into recent German history, spanning the Weimar republic, the rise of Nazism, the communist era and the post-reunification period. It is perhaps best known to the outside world through the Liza Minnelli film Cabaret, but aficionados claim there is far more to it than that.

Kabarett was born on January 18 1901 with the opening of the first kabarett theatre. Inspired by evenings spent in Paris at Chat Noir, an artists' cafe that promoted socially critical "cabaret artistique" where poets and entertainers would do a turn on the stage in return for free beer, Ernst von Wollzogen decided to build his own theatre in Berlin.

He intended to produce high-quality artistic entertainment as a counterweight to the trashy music hall fare that dominated the city's stages at the time. But the German model immediately diverged from the French cabaret, as Wollzogen drew satirical magazine writers, composers and out-of-work actors to his stage to perform their often subversive songs. Soon they were developing the sharp individual style that typifies Berlin kabarett to this day. (It wasn't until the 1930s that the social commentator Kurt Tucholsky "Germanised" the word cabaret, derived from the French word for a tavern, thus making the distinction between the two forms - the frivolous and erotic versus the serious, intellectual and darkly humorous.)

Audiences and potential performers both caught on quickly. In kabarett's first year of life, 40 groups applied for licences to start performing in Berlin. They were diverse in style, some following the French model, while others were more political in content.

"Initially," says Peter Sprengel, professor in early German literature at Berlin's Free University, "there was a utopian idea that people could be educated and taught a sense of taste, but before long those aims were forgotten and commercial interests were dictating the programme."

Women had an important role from the start. A leading female light was Marya Delvard, who with her husband Marc Henry took kabarett to Vienna in 1906. After the first world war a pair of women, Rosa Valetti and Trude Hesterberg, injected new life into Berlin kabarett with their respective groups, Great Delusion and Wild Stage. Bertolt Brecht performed at the latter in 1922, causing a scandal with his anti-militaristic songs.

"It's one of kabarett's great strengths that it's so flexible," says Joanne McNally, a research fellow at the University of London. "The three elements that make up kabarett - political and social criticism, entertainment, and the artistic aesthetic - can all shift according to the political climate, the ethos of the group or their location," she says.

She cites the group Die Wespen ("the wasps"), for which Brecht and Eric Muhsam wrote, and which at the end of the Weimar period used to play up the erotic elements as a cover for their hard-hitting political criticism.

Die Katakombe, another group which had its heyday at the end of the Weimar republic, had to employ very indirect criticism. One of its members, Werner Finc, developed a style where he would deliver taboo words with a deliberate stammer or by immediately retracting what he'd said, suggesting he'd made a mistake. Words such as "Dachau" were delivered in an off-hand manner as performers left the stage, to alert audiences to the existence of the concentration camps. "Fincisms" were later used to great effect under communism in east Germany.

Very little survived the Nazi clampdown in 1935, when many performers, particularly Jews, were forced to flee. Yet in the last place kabarett might have been expected to have any life, it thrived, albeit briefly. In the concentration camps it provided a few hours of light relief. "The subject matter was less political," says McNally. "It focused on the inmates' daily concerns, such as hoping for a food parcel or a better future."

Volker Kühn, a cabaret writer who has made a documentary film about kabarett in the con centration camps, says: "It seems absurd, but so were the times, and the locations were far removed from reality," he explains. "Kabarett became a survival strategy for the performers."

In some camps kabarett was banned, in others it was tolerated, but in Westerbork transit camp in the Netherlands, the camp commander was a huge fan and ordered a performance at least once a week. In Theresienstadt 40,000 would typically attend, and it wasn't unusual for three or four performances to be listed every day.

It was not until the 1950s that kabarett became a political force again. But stability has never been a typical feature of the environment in which kabarett has thrived. Soon Berlin was in two halves, separated by a wall. Eastern and western kabarett almost became two different art forms during the 40 years of division. But realising its importance to the people, the communist authorities ordered regular kabarett performances.

Die Distel ("The Thistle"), still Berlin's most famous kabarett theatre, was the east's first professional kabarett house. The first programme was wryly titled: "Humour is part of the overall plan." But there were strict rules. Solo performers were not allowed and texts were strictly controlled and could not be changed once the stamp of approval had been given.

As a result, eastern kabarett had a very rigid structure. "It was up to the audience to do a lot of reconstruction," says McNally. "Strategic ambiguity was adopted where the audience had to supply the critical content."

Absolute taboo subjects were GDR leader Erich Honecker and the Stasi, so a subtle form of language was developed to compensate. Thus Honecker was referred to as "the supreme clown". But clever intonation, a pause at a key moment, or delivery of a punchline in a mumble was enough to radically change a text from its meaning on the page.

After the fall of the Berlin wall, with nothing left to satirise, it was feared that kabarett would not survive. Audiences drifted away, but by 1992 the public was knocking on the door again. "After the fall of the wall we felt we didn't need satire any more, but then we realised that it was maybe even more necessary," says Helge, an easterner, on a night out with her girlfriends at Die Distel, where I found most of the audience to be from the west. Die Distel was privatised in 1991 and it is no mean feat that, in the brutal world of capitalism, all 12 of the former GDR's cabaret groups have survived the transition. There's now increasing evidence of eastern and western audiences mixing, as well as a crossover between writers and performers.

So just why is it such a Berlin artform? "It would be too subtle for the Americans," says Sprengel. "But Berlin has experienced many political variations, and that keeps kabarett on its toes, although how much it changes things is debatable."

It certainly shows no sign of going out of fashion. McNally uses it for advanced language teaching, the Bundestag has its own posse of kabarett artistes, and it is even used as a way of improving employer-employee relations and production levels in German companies.

And you thought the Germans didn't know how to laugh?

webTitle: On why the CD swindle has to stop

fields.headline: The price is wrong
fields.standfirst: It's been a bad week for music fans - but a good week for the industry.  Adam Sweeting on why the CD swindle has to stop
fields.trailText: It's been a bad week for music fans - but a good week for the industry. Adam Sweeting on why the CD swindle has to stop
fields.body:
The trade paper Music Week has reacted indignantly to news that the office of fair trading is to launch a new investigation into the pricing of CDs in Britain. The OFT appears to have been prompted to take action after finding "reasonable grounds" to suspect that the major record labels have banded together to restrict parallel imports of CD releases - in other words, cheaper copies from other EU countries. In particular, the companies' ploy of releasing "UK only" versions of albums, featuring extra tracks in an attempt to justify the UK's high retail prices, seems to have triggered the OFT's suspicions.

As a trade magazine dependent on record company support, Music Week doesn't have much alternative but to support the poor, put-upon multinational conglomerates that choose to honour British consumers with their unscrupulous marketing practices. But it's probably not even worth moaning about it - previous price-fixing investigations have gone on for months, cost millions of pounds and ended up giving the impression that even if the record business is up to its ears in corruption, there's nothing the British government or the expenses-fiddling jobsworths in Brussels can do about it.

However, you won't find any punters in the street claiming that a price of £15.99 for a CD is a jolly good thing. Even if they are still grudgingly prepared to pay it for an album they feel they must own, they know very well that the Americans and many of our European confrères are paying about four quid less. But in the same way that a combination of the internet, EU regulations and mounting consumer indignation has belatedly delivered a wounding blow to the price-fixing racket in the UK motor industry, record companies and music retailers have arrived at a watershed. Either prices will fall or people will find other ways of gaining access to music. In fact they're going to do so whether prices fall or not, so the question is how much the industry can slow the process down and limit the damage to its profits.

All eyes in the pop biz have been on this week's court of appeal ruling in California to determine the fate of the internet music company Napster, and its potential impact on the future of internet music delivery. Metallica, one of the world's most obscenely wealthy rock acts, are crowing triumphantly about the court's decision that Napster must prevent copyrighted material from being exchanged over its network. But this merely emphasises how much the band have changed since their early days as renegades of New Metal.

The biz has a long and notorious record of trying to demonise any new technological development as a threat to its well-heeled existence. Having moaned about the threat that FM radio posed to their financial well-being, the record companies tried to persuade their learned friends that home taping would destroy the industry, when in fact both developments only helped to boost music's global profile. Having reaped an incalculable financial harvest from re-releasing everything ever recorded via CD, the industry has never shown any gratitude to consumers, only spite and paranoia when it decides the music-buying public is trying to get something for nothing. Whatever Napster's fate, internet delivery of music is assuredly coming. What remains to be decided is how much control the labels can maintain over it, and how much they will charge users for the privilege.

Techno-terror aside, how much does the 21st-century record industry have to be proud of? It likes to portray itself as a great British success story and a driving force in the UK economy (shame it can't sell any records to the Americans, but never mind, it's only the world's largest market). But the self-evident truth is that the UK industry has lost the knack of finding acts that will appeal to a broad international market indifferent to the UK's insular fixation with zero-quality pop nonentities.

The listless inertia of UK consumers - surely the most important factor in the way multinationals have been able to take us for a ride for so long - guarantees that the charts will remain stuffed with prefabricated idiocy for the foreseeable future. For proof, look no further than the success of ITV's breathtakingly cynical Popstars. The series carefully dismantles the sordid process of manufacturing a pop group while being designed to generate fat profits for a PR company and Polydor Records - as well as guaranteeing ballooning prime-time ratings for ITV. If anything, the top priority of the OFT should be to take a close look at this pernicious little conspiracy of self-promotion, but instead Popstars has become a popular success and a tabloid sensation. Apparently the public has got what the public wants.

fields.headline: Whitehall education head to quit
fields.standfirst: Education site
fields.trailText: Sir Michael Bichard announced unexpectedly yesterday that he is to stand down as the top civil servant at the Department for Education and Employment.
fields.body:
Sir Michael Bichard announced unexpectedly yesterday that he is to stand down as the top civil servant at the Department for Education and Employment.

His departure at the end of May at 54, six years before the mandatory retirement age, was seen by some as confirmation that the education secretary, David Blunkett, is to move to another cabinet post if Labour wins the election.

Sir Michael has been permanent secretary for more than five years, and oversaw the merger of the separate departments of employment and education under the Tories.

He and Mr Blunkett have worked very closely on an ambitious programme of "cradle to grave" education reform unprecedented in recent legislative history. "It could be that Michael feels he has done what he had to do. If David Blunkett is definitely moving on, then there may be limited scope within the job," said one Whitehall source.

The announcement came a day after Tony Blair launched a plan to remodel secondary schools, billed as ending the "bog standard" comprehensive.

A department spokeswoman said yesterday that the timing was "pure coincidence".

Sir Michael, who began in local government and rose to be chief executive of the London borough of Brent, is highly regarded in senior government circles. He was once tipped as a possible chief executive for the NHS and even a future cabinet secretary. He said his time as head of the employment department and then head of the merged departments had been the most exciting of his career.

"I have been privileged to play a part in the reform of the education system from early years to adult learning, and in the way we support the unemployed back into work," he said, adding: "I do believe that organisations benefit from a change of leadership from time to time, and equally that individuals should seek out new challenges, which is what I intend to do after a short break."

Mr Blunkett, who has privately told Mr Blair he would like to take over at the Home Office, said: "I have been fortunate that Michael Bichard has shared with me a commitment to radical modernisation and change, and a determination to implement the government's initiatives in education and employment.

"His departure will be a great loss to the civil service, and I want to say personally how much I have valued his contribution."

fields.headline: The big players dig in
fields.standfirst:
Napster has them worried. With reason

More net news
fields.trailText: A judgment in a California appeals court about the Napster file-sharing website could have widespread effects on the future of the internet. Like the efforts of the pharmaceuticals to suppress cheap competition, it is all about corporations exploiting intellectual property rights.
fields.body:
A judgment in a California appeals court about the Napster file-sharing website could have widespread effects on the future of the internet. Like the efforts of the pharmaceuticals to suppress cheap competition, reported in the Guardian this week, and US companies trying to profit from discovery of the map of the genome, it is all about corporations exploiting intellectual property rights.

Napster is an ingenious piece of software that enables users to swap files from the hard disks of their computers. If you want, say, a rare Frank Sinatra track, you type it into Napster's search facility. It scours member-computers all over the world and comes up with a list of available recordings, ready to be downloaded for nothing. It was last year's unexpected Big Thing on the internet and over 50m people have now downloaded the software.

At one level, as when people swap rare recordings long since out of production, it is harmless. But what worries the companies is that no one will buy CDs in the shops if they can download recent recordings from Napster or its imitators. Most of these are much safer from the law because, unlike Napster, they do not use a central computer. They go straight from one hard drive to another.

In principle the ability to swap files instantly with anyone is one of the finest achievements of the internet's mutual principles. But clearly artists, whether film makers or musicians, deserve royalties for their work. A recent survey found that 70% of Napster's users would be willing to pay something. The question is to whom.

The Californian case was brought by the five biggest record labels, who control about 90% of popular music. The prospect of such awesome market power trying to squash a fledgling company is one reason why so many users feel it is fair game to copy files to each other. They would not mind if more modest royalties went mainly to the users, rather than to intermediaries who make money from controlling the intellectual property rights of performers.

Interestingly, this so called peer-to-peer technology still offers a genuine chance of legally cutting out intermediaries. The first person to devise a globally acceptable way for artists to get a direct royalty from music and other files swapped over the net will open up a new, cheaper era for the music industry - but it will not necessarily include the big five. No wonder they are treating this case as a fight to the death.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: In the 1980s, a caller to Steve Wright's Radio 1 show was asked "who's mad?" each day. "Who's mad?" he replied, "I'll tell you who's mad. Mr X, he's raving mad, pal. And that ****, she's mad ..." Anyone in the news, it seemed, was mad.
fields.body:
In the 1980s, a caller to Steve Wright's Radio 1 show was asked "who's mad?" each day. "Who's mad?" he replied, "I'll tell you who's mad. Mr X, he's raving mad, pal. And that ****, she's mad ..." Anyone in the news, it seemed, was mad.

Now Steve Wright and his posse have shuffled off to Radio 2, and we have Alastair Campbell instead. Barely had New Labour won power before Ali resurrected the Soviet tactic of labelling all opponents as insane, ill, or mentally enfeebled. Mandy is the latest in a long line, and today, as a tribute to the subtlety of Ali's technique and the variety of his euphemisms, we relive the highlights.

 In October 1997, "a Downing Street source" briefed that David Clark, who'd been rash enough to propose a freedom of information bill with teeth, would be out in the next reshuffle since he "has totally lost it" and was the "despair of his civil servants". A relentless campaign ensued until he went a year later.

 The neo-Brezhnevite era's first high point came in January 1998, when the Observer was briefed that Gordon Brown was "psychologically flawed". Others have been implicated, but who else at Number 10 had the authority to sanction delivery of so explosive a package to a newspaper?

 Meanwhile, transport secretary Gavin Strang was not only "weak" and "not quite up to it, but so lavishly demented as to be quite unaware of the serious kidney disorder that would, hacks were briefed in early 1998, soon enforce his departure. Even though he thought himself "the fittest member of the cabinet", he soon went. Well, he had to. He was a bit, you know, up top.

 When Aberdeen scientist Dr Arpad Pusztai revealed that lab rats fed on GM potatoes had developed weak immune systems, hacks were told the doctor was "a bit of a nutter".

 By June 1999, Harriet Harman ("incapable of joined-up thinking") and Frank Field ("a complete joke") had gone, when TUC boss John Monks blamed the euro elections fiasco on disdain for traditional support. A "senior Labour source" voiced icy surprise that the modernising Mr Monks had become "muddled ... he has simply failed to understand Blair's strategy". Of course he has. Raving mad, pal.

 In January 2000, record company boss Alan McGee was branded "ill" by one of Ali's munchkins when, thoroughly sick of New Labour, he backed Malcolm McLaren's mayoral campaign. Peter Kilfoyle's resignation over disdain for core voters drew, from an unnamed source, a pithy "he's been spending too long in the bars". And yet this was merely an aperitif for the uniquely repugnant cocktail to come ... "a senior government aide's" suggesting that Mo Mowlam's illness had left her "without the intellectual rigour" for her job; and another nameless "adviser" was "dismayed at her erratic behaviour".

 Ken Follett's attack on Number 10 for briefing against former friends proves a self-fulfilling prophecy. "Ken has always been good at fiction, hasn't he?" says a Downing Street source. "Serious people will treat his outburst with the derision it deserves." Of course.

 Now it's Mandy's turn to be briefed as a cross between Stan Collymore and Caligula. And yet, and yet ... can you guess who alone of the above is known to have received psychiatric treatment? It was of course Alastair Campbell, who in 1986 required emergency hospitalisation for a drink-related breakdown. Call it "projection" if you will, we prefer simply to recall that the character who rang Steve Wright was in fact called Mr Mad.

webTitle: Leader: Clinton approach in Israel ditched

fields.headline: The US pulls back
fields.standfirst:
The Clinton approach has been ditched

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Having seen off Ehud Barak at the cost of Ariel Sharon's resurrection, the Palestinians wait for the US cavalry to ride to the rescue. But when secretary of state Colin Powell arrives in the Middle East next week, he is unlikely to bring the relief they seek.
fields.body:
Having seen off Ehud Barak at the cost of Ariel Sharon's resurrection, the Palestinians wait for the US cavalry to ride to the rescue. But when secretary of state Colin Powell arrives in the Middle East next week, he is unlikely to bring the relief they seek. Mr Powell does not want to get involved in peace process specifics; he prefers the "regional context" viewed through the prism of US interests. Nor will there be a special peace envoy to replace Dennis Ross.

Mr Powell says he wants "a hard-headed recognition that the parties themselves must make the peace". But his top priority is stability, not justice. While reaffirming US support for Israel's security and the Palestinians' "legitimate aspirations", his principal message to Israel's new leader and Yasser Arafat will be: end the violence.

Back in Washington, George Bush's people are focusing on broader, big picture concerns such as Iraq, Iran and oil. They believe Bill Clinton was pursuing over-ambitious goals in Palestine. Lacking inspiration and will, they seem happy to settle for vague promises of incremental change.

This approach will suit Mr Sharon very well. Like Binyamin Netanyahu and Yitzhak Shamir before him, he does not want the Americans constantly on his case. And Mr Powell's laissez-faire diplomacy will seal the fate of the ground-breaking but uncompleted Taba negotiations. The Likud leader has already sent envoys to assure Washington that he is doing all he can to halt the killing; that Mr Barak and people like Shimon Peres (shame on him) are ready to join his national unity government; and that he is willing to talk.

But in place of Labour's hated concessions, he offers only "long-term interim agreements". Jerusalem and land transfers are off his agenda. Mr Powell should in fact be pressing Mr Sharon to continue the Oslo process and prepare for an historic compromise. That he does not intend to do so is the Bush administration's first big foreign policy blunder, a watershed setback for Mr Arafat, and reason enough why Europe should now step into the breach.

Mr Powell's instinct for disengagement may serve his country better when it comes to Iraq, a likely topic as he tours Egypt, Kuwait and Syria. Even Washington now acknowledges the sanctions policy is in ruins. As Donald Rumsfeld's Pentagon conducts a review of options, timely intelligence "leaks" tell of allegedly rebuilt chemical and biological weapons facilities and expanded SA-6 missile defences. Vice-president Dick Cheney, defence secretary in the Gulf war, has old scores to settle with Saddam.

Back in the frame, too, is arch-hawk and Desert Storm strategist Paul Wolfowitz. But amid renewed talk of bolstering the ineffective opposition Iraqi National Congress and escalating military pressure, Mr Powell may prove more receptive to proposals to tighten (and persuade Arab and former Soviet bloc countries to enforce) the embargo on arms and dual-use technology. In this scenario, UN weapons inspections are resumed while all remaining sanctions are simultaneously lifted. If Mr Powell is not in favour, he should be - and he should be rallying his Arab hosts to help him end the Iraq stand-off peacefully.

Israel and Iraq apart, Arab leaders and the Bushmen have two shared interests. One is continuity of oil supply (for which regional stability is a prerequisite); the other is a visceral fear of "rogue" Iran and its Russian-aided weapons programme. Mr Powell is not going to Tehran, where a critical reform struggle is under way. Why not? Here is a chance to make a real difference in the Middle East. But that would mean getting involved.

webTitle: Judges order new jail death inquest

fields.headline: Judges order new jail death inquest
fields.trailText: The family of a young paranoid schizophrenic who hanged himself with his shoelaces while on remand in Wandsworth prison won an order for a new inquest yesterday. The prison was strongly criticised for failing to take steps to prevent his death.
fields.body:
The family of a young paranoid schizophrenic who hanged himself with his shoelaces while on remand in Wandsworth prison won an order for a new inquest yesterday. The prison was strongly criticised for failing to take steps to prevent his death.

Two senior judges at the high court in London ordered a fresh inquest into the death of Keita Craig, 22, son of the Culture Club bass player Mikey Craig. He was one of seven inmates who killed themselves at the south London prison last year. Lord Justice Keene and Mr Justice Penry-Davey ruled that the Westminster coroner, Paul Knapman, was wrong in law to deny the inquest jury the option of a verdict that neglect had been a factor in the death.

There was evidence of "a gross failure" on the part of the prison, Mr Justice Penry-Davey said. Mr Craig hanged himself with his shoelaces at the prison in February last year. They had been removed from him at the magistrates court, but he was given them back in prison even though staff were warned he was a suicide risk.

What was striking was the substantial amount of knowledge the prison had about Mr Craig's condition, Lord Justice Keene said. "This was a young man already diagnosed as a paranoid schizophrenic who killed himself in the Wandsworth prison health-care centre while, as the inquest jury found, the balance of his mind was disturbed. The fact that he suffered from that mental illness was known to those who were responsible for him at Wandsworth prison."

Mr Justice Penry-Davy said: "The restoration of shoelaces to the deceased combined with the failure to keep the deceased under proper observation resulted in his death, and in my judgment there was evidence of gross failure to provide medical attention where the mental state of the deceased obviously called for such attention."

Last April the inquest jury returned a verdict that Mr Craig killed himself while the balance of his mind was disturbed. Dr Knapman had told the jury that the ingredients for neglect "were not present" and barred them from including a finding of neglect in the verdict.

"But there was evidence on which they could properly conclude that such a verdict was justified. In those circumstances the coroner was wrong not to leave such a verdict to the jury," Lord Justice Keene said.

Mr Craig had been arrested over street robbery allegations, and Richmond magistrates had remanded him to Wandsworth while a place was found for him in a psychiatric unit. His solicitor and a social worker expressed concern for his well-being and Tracey Lowe, a probation officer, was alerted.

Ms Lowe faxed the prison making it clear that Mr Craig was a suicide risk. She also spoke to a deputy prison governor. A concerned Securicor guard ordered Mr Craig's shoelaces to be taken away. At the prison Mr Craig underwent a five- to seven-minute medical examination. A form for those at risk of self-harm was not properly completed and nursing staff were not made aware or given special instructions.

He was seen by a 73-year-old prison doctor, Somasunderam Pothalingam, who had also assessed two remand inmates at Brixton jail in south London who hanged themselves two months before Mr Craig. Dr Pothalingam told the inquest into the Brixton prisoners' deaths this month: "It's not practical to spend more than a few minutes with each patient."

fields.headline: Modern romance
fields.trailText: EastEnders | Silent Witness | Blood On The Carpet | Coronation Street
fields.body:
A day of joy and celebration looms. Always in EastEnders (BBC 1) a reason to take to the hills.

St Valentine's Day is, of course, less critical than Christmas, which regularly detonates with such brio that debris is still descending in soft flakes in spring. But there are few more ominous sights than a gangster who hasn't had a Valentine's card, and Phil Mitchell is fuming. On the day when traditionally all the little birds begin their courtship, he has not got a bird. Lisa has flown. Admittedly, not far. My own inclination, if I left Phil Mitchell, would be to take up residence in a small submarine somewhere off North Uist, but Lisa is hiding close by.

Phil has been flinging himself at assorted doors, growling like a pit bull trying to get in a cat flap. Or imagine Albert Square as a snooker table and Phil as a bald, red ball trying all the pockets. There, that wasn't difficult, was it?

Since she took up with Phil, Lisa has looked like a bag of broken biscuits. Once quite a custard cream, the woman's now in crumbs. According to Phil she frowed a moody. "I've looked after 'er for months. She's moaned and whined, that's all she's done. She's made a right mug out of me." And, suiting the action to the word, he flung his mug at the wall.

Let us turn, hopefully, to more level heads. Phil's mother, Peggy, and Roy are drowning their sorrows in single malt. He tells her about his impotence and she tells him about her mastectomy. Roy is sympathetic: "The next time you have a moan, come to me and we'll bore the pants off each other." Peggy unwisely interprets this literally and Roy, a shy second-hand car dealer, exits stage right as if pursued by a bear.

Henry (Anthony Head) in Silent Witness (BBC 1) is the reddest herring ever waved under my incredulous nose. Henry is gentry, but what a bounder, and never more so than when blowing suavely on his snooker cue tip. He has fathered a child with his own daughter ("In our family, a generation or two back such behaviour was de rigueur"), and plies the nubile daughters of the peasantry with Moët and Chandon ("Put a couple more on ice!") The phrase is particularly unfortunate, as murdered girls keep turning up in snowfields and deep freezers. Scotland Yard lollop along after this fishy distraction with their ears blowing in the wind. Fortunately, the fair Miss Formaldehyde (Amanda Burton) is on the job and spots it is the chauffeur.

The ever entertaining Blood On The Carpet (BBC 2) did not tell us how Wavy Gravy got his name. Though I felt myself yanked back to Railway Cuttings as if on elastic and heard Tony Hancock saying resentfully that his mother couldn't cook but at least her gravy moved around the plate a bit. Ten to one, Wavy Gravy has forgotten how he got the name. He helped to run the Woodstock rock festival in 1969 and he can't remember a thing about that either. A sure sign of the 60s. Wavy was in charge of security at Woodstock. He gave the matter some serious thought and hired a bear suit and a rubber shovel. "Should some hippie build a stupid fire, I could leap out of the bushes in my bear suit and wave my shovel at them."

When the second Woodstock was held in 1999, Wavy was there with bells on and a fish on a leash.

Don't worry about it.

It began promisingly. Wavy said, "All the kids would recognise me and get me to sign their head or their girlfriend or they'd pat my fish." But eventually the heat, the price of hot dogs and an incendiary band called Limp Bizkit inflamed the crowd. And a supply of free candles inflamed anything else that would burn. Wavy did his hippie best. He stood on the stage wafting sage and reciting a mantra. In view of the crowd's ugly mood, one can only be grateful he was not wearing his bear suit.

In the words of Limp Bizkit, "Motherfucker, it's just one of those days." Astonishingly, it took five people to write that number. One more than it took to write, "Horsey, keep your tail up. Keep the sun out of my eyes." On balance I prefer Horsey.

"Can I watch telly?" The first words of Adam, Mike Baldwin's long lost son, arriving in Coronation Street (Granada). All his relations agreed at once that he must be deeply concussed. "He's still very groggy and confused."

But eventually the heat, the price of hot dogs and an incendiary band called Limp Bizkit inflamed the crowd. And a supply of free candles inflamed anything else that would burn. Wavy did his hippie best. He stood on the stage wafting sage and reciting a mantra. In view of the crowd's ugly mood, one can only be grateful he was not wearing his bear suit. In the words of Limp Bizkit, "Motherfucker, it's just one of those days." Astonishingly, it took five people to write that number. One more than it took to write, "Horsey, keep your tail up. Keep the sun out of my eyes." On balance I prefer Horsey. "Can I watch telly?" The first words of Adam, Mike Baldwin's long lost son, arriving in Coronation Street (Granada). All his relations agreed at once that he must be deeply concussed. "He's still very groggy and confused."

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: The summer ghosts
fields.trailText: The summer ghosts
fields.body:
Wenlock Edge

It is a mild wet morning and the birds are singing with an early spring energy. There is such clarity that the spaces between each bird's song can be felt - poignant spaces edged with sharp notes rolling between the wet and dripping trees. I am returning to the wood where I found the snowdrops last weekend. It was an unsettling experience and I am drawn back there because of a mystery. When I first started to explore this recolonised limestone quarry wood on a summer morning about three years ago, I came across sounds of children playing and dogs barking. Realising that I was blundering into the back garden of a family home I backed off, and have avoided that area of the wood ever since.

Only now, on a cold wet February morning, with gaunt hawthorns dripping onto a secret garden of brilliant green moss, does the true realisation dawn on me. There is no garden and no house. In fact there has not been a house or garden in this place for very many years. What remains are overgrown walls, brick rubble and a few trees of a long deserted garden.

However, not all the ghosts of that garden have fled with summer shadows. Dotted around are the clumps of eerily beautiful snowdrops. Although these are plants of the common snowdrop, Galanthus nivalis, they are a cultivar, with a more rounded shape and a complex of double petals in the centre. Their faint hyacinth-like fragrance makes them even more mysterious. It is not only the eeriness of the flowers which is striking but a kind of stubborn indifference which bridges seasons, years and reality. Through them the intractable year has truly turned. But to what?

fields.trailText: Fake ID Club
fields.body: Fake ID Club 9.30pm, MTV Sickening or heartening, depending on your own age, this pop doc looks at the power-players who have conquered their various worlds before most of us have had time to sit around wondering what to do with our lives. Yup, it's time to marvel at the over-achieving under-21s, like Beyonce from Destiny's Child, Britney Spears, Shawn Napster Fanning, and Venus and Serena Williams. The only comfort for those who have passed this sell-by date may be that, as Americans, none of them are old enough to drink.

fields.headline: Crushed by a juggernaut of jargon
fields.standfirst: Special report: Life in parliament
fields.trailText: I still get a thrill sitting in the Commons press gallery. It was, after all, in this assembly, if not on these very benches, that MPs heard Cromwell thunder: "In the name of God, go!", listened rapt to Lloyd George, were stirred and heartened by Churchill in wartime.
fields.body:
I still get a thrill sitting in the Commons press gallery. It was, after all, in this assembly, if not on these very benches, that MPs heard Cromwell thunder: "In the name of God, go!", listened rapt to Lloyd George, were stirred and heartened by Churchill in wartime, and - well, all right, there weren't so many great speeches, but there were a few, and why on earth do we have to put up with what we get now?

Yesterday afternoon Hilary Armstrong, the minister for local government, rose to a question about "local strategic partnerships", whatever they are. She answered thus:

"Mr Speaker, local strategic partnerships will provide a single overarching local co-ordinated framework which will enable local stakeholders [Who on earth are they? Are they people who go out at night looking for vampires to kill?] to address issues that really matter to local people. They will prepare and implement local community strategies and local neighbourhood renewal strategies. They will allocate local neighbourhood renewal funds which will double to £200m next year, and rationalise local partnerships working to deliver better services."

By the time she had reached the end, the Tories had cottoned on to the fact that this was no mere parliamentary reply: it was a juggernaut of jargon, a banquet of blather, a cornucopia of cliche. They were laughing heartily.

But the MP who had asked the question, Joan Humble of Blackpool North, did not share their levity. Indeed she appeared to be grateful. "I thank my rt. hon. friend for that reply," she said gravely, and the Tories began to giggle dementedly, like schoolboys who have been driven to the brink and who are shortly going to stuff their ties into their mouths to stop themselves from braying like sexually excited donkeys.

Ms Humble went on: "Can she confirm that the successful existing partnerships Blackpool has developed can form the basis for the new local strategic partnerships and that this very welcome additional investment can be effectively targeted?"

Another pod person! They seemed to understand each other perfectly. The sound resembled the noise which comes out of your computer when it hooks up, through a modem, with another computer. Only computers can comprehend it. Squeak! Squeeeeeek! Blip! Squack!

Nothing would stop Ms Armstrong. Eagerly welcoming her colleague's encomia, she went on: "As cross-sector, cross-agency umbrella partnerships, LSPs offer real opportunities for streamlining existing partnership arrangements and to make them more effective by making better connections between individual initiatives."

Sir Patrick Cormack, usually the most courteous of men, rose and rumbled. "Will the rt. hon. lady put her first answer into plain English?"

Plain English? What's that? I doubt that Hilary Armstrong would recognise plain English if it came on a silver platter with a coulis of framboise and an avocado garnish.

"I'm sorry that the hon. gentleman couldn't hear because of the way his front bench were behaving," she began, mendaciously implying that it was merely background noise which had baffled him. She did try to put it into something resembling the language of Milton and Shakespeare, but failed, as if St Paul's were to be replaced by a pile of breeze blocks. Again we were awash with "identifying strategic priorities ..." and the rest of this Pelion of platitude.

Stop press: I have just learned that Ms Armstrong used to teach at a school in Kenya, where she learned the local language. Perhaps it sounds better in the original Swahili.

webTitle: Bush's UK envoy is a friend of the Queen

fields.headline: Bush's UK envoy is a friend of the Queen
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: President George Bush has chosen as ambassador to Britain a millionaire Texas investment banker and horse-racing mogul who has hosted four of the Queen's private visits to the United States.
fields.body:
President George Bush has chosen as ambassador to Britain a millionaire Texas investment banker and horse-racing mogul who has hosted four of the Queen's private visits to the United States.

Will Farrish will succeed Philip Lader, a Clinton appointee, later this year. The job, traditionally a reward for campaign contributions, comes with one of the most attractive tied houses in London, in the heart of Regent's Park.

Mr Farrish, a noted anglophile, is a longtime Bush family friend who hosted Mr Bush's visit to the Kentucky Derby, the blue riband of the racing calendar, last summer. His horse, Secret Status, won last year's Kentucky Oaks.

Mr Farrish was in charge of George Bush Sr's blind trusts during his 1989-93 presidency, and has been a lifelong confidant of the family.

His millions, his impeccable Republican credentials, and his close ties to the Bush family will mark a wholesale change.

Mr Lader was a Clinton donor and adviser from South Carolina whose most celebrated qualification for the ambassadorship was that he regularly hosted the Clintons' "renaissance weekends" at his Hilton Head estate on the Atlantic coast.

It is Mr Farrish's role as one of the prime movers in the Kentucky bloodstock industry that will make him one of the most congenial appointments the house of Windsor could have wished for.

The Queen has stayed four times as Mr Farrish's private guest at his Kentucky stud farms, lending him a social cachet for which he waived his stud fees for his royal visitor.

Though he lives in Kentucky, Mr Farrish is by birth a Texan and owns a ranch there, at which Mr Bush Sr has gone quail hunting.

fields.headline: The walking sausage lives again
fields.trailText: A sausage-sized stick insect believed to have died out 83 years ago has been rediscovered living on a rock in the Pacific Ocean, more than 600km (370 miles) east of Australia.
fields.body:
A sausage-sized stick insect believed to have died out 83 years ago has been rediscovered living on a rock in the Pacific Ocean, more than 600km (370 miles) east of Australia.

Scientists found three female Lord Howe Island stick insects, which they likened to "walking sausages", after scrambling up a cliff in the dark on Balls Pyramid, a volcanic rock 23km (14 miles) from Lord Howe Island.

The nocturnal insect, once native to Lord Howe Island, evolved into a 15cm-long wingless giant, with a reddish brown body 1.5cm thick, because it had no predators.

For thousands of years, the remote island was home to only one mammal species - a bat - and two species of reptile. But the stick insect, known locally as the "land lobster", became extinct after rats colonised the island from a shipwreck in 1918.

Rumoured sightings of sausage-shaped carcasses by rock climbers on Balls Pyramid in the 1960s encouraged the latest expedition by Australian scientists, who found the three specimens of Phasmid Dryococelus Australis feasting on tea-tree bushes.

"I was lost for words, except for the odd expletive," scientist Nicholas Carlile told the Sydney Morning Herald. "We couldn't jump for joy for fear of falling off the 60-degree slope."

The scientists, who also found a number of eggs, believe there could be just 10 adults surviving on the desolate rock. They hope to re-establish a breeding colony on Lord Howe Island.

The island, home to dozens of unique species, is thought to have been untouched by humankind until European navigators settled there in 1834.

The invasion of rats in 1918 led to the disappearance of five endemic bird species. A bounty of 6d per rat was introduced to encourage residents to kill them. After 20,000 corpses were collected, it was discovered that locals had been breeding rats to earn themselves a steady income.

Today, the fragile island is home to 300 permanent residents, while only 400 visitors are allowed at a time. The island's Lord Howe woodhen was recently saved from near extinction by a captive breeding programme.

fields.headline: Inflation at new low
fields.standfirst: Bank is under pressure to cut interest rates again
fields.trailText: The Bank of England is under mounting pressure to cut interest rates after the government's key measure of inflation plunged to a 25-year low in January.
fields.body:
The Bank of England is under mounting pressure to cut interest rates after the government's key measure of inflation plunged to a 25-year low in January.

The drop to 1.8% from 2% in December was mainly driven by lower oil and petrol costs which have since rebounded, but it also reflected sluggish house prices and cheaper household goods and services.

Underlying inflation, excluding mortgage interest payments, has been below the government's 2.5% prices target for 22 months in a row, and is perilously close to the 1.5% level which triggers a public letter from the bank's governor, Sir Eddie George, to the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

Under the terms of the Bank of England Act 1998, Sir Eddie would have to explain why inflation has fallen a full percentage point below target and set out a strategy for getting it back on track.

Although the Bank cut rates last week by 0.25% to 5.75% to reflate the economy, most City economists believe that further cuts in the cost of bor rowing will be needed to boost the rate of price increases.

The Bank will set out its thinking on the outlook for inflation and interest rates when it publishes its quarterly inflation report today.

Since the US federal reserve began cutting interest rates aggressively at the beginning of January to boost collapsing business and consumer confidence, other central banks have been expected to follow suit. But economic activity in Europe has remained relatively robust, making both the Bank of England and the European central bank (ECB) wary of overstimulating demand. Even so, financial markets are pricing in a further quarter point cut in UK rates by the summer.

Jonathan Loynes, UK economist at the consultancy Capital Economics, believes that British rates will fall to 5% by the end of the year. He said: "It is becoming very clear from the inflation numbers that a US-style slowdown is not a necessary precondition for sharp falls in interest rates."

The office for national statistics said headline inflation, used as a benchmark by wage negotiators, fell to 2.7% from 2.9%, taking it to the lowest level since March last year.

With unemployment at a 25-year low, the more hawkish members of the Bank's nine-member monetary policy committee are thought to remain concerned at the possibility of a rise in wage inflation.

fields.headline: Gerbeau ridicules Legacy dome bid
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Pierre-Yves Gerbeau last night called on Tony Blair to pull the plug on Legacy's £125m bid for the dome and consider bids from him and other groups.
fields.body:
Pierre-Yves Gerbeau last night called on Tony Blair to pull the plug on Legacy's £125m bid for the dome and consider bids from him and other groups.

The Frenchman, hired to salvage the millennium project, accused ministers of seeking a "cheap deal" before the election, as he claimed Legacy's bid, fronted by Labour donor Robert Bourne, would not succeed.

"I think this is really a joke, honestly," said Mr Gerbeau, who said Legacy's deadline should not be extended beyond the end of the week.

"I do understand that we are in election fever at the moment and the government is really desperate to get it right in order to win the election," he said.

Mr Gerbeau's public comments will embarrass ministers ahead of a crucial meeting tomorrow to decide whether to accept Legacy's bid to transform the complex into a hi-tech business park.

His protests are expected to exacerbate the divisions between Tony Blair, who is said to be eager for a quick sale to be agreed, and his deputy, John Prescott, who has led the sale process. Mr Prescott is said to be supporting a plan under which English Heritage would be left in control of the dome site, allowing it to remain in public hands.

Paul Oliver, the chief executive of Teesland, parachuted in this week to inject fresh life into Legacy's bid, insisted last night that the only hurdle to Legacy's success was a veto by government ministers.

He acknowledged that Teesland, majority-owned by Sheffield United director Kevin McCabe, had been approached by Legacy only last week, but said it had always hoped to become involved.

The Scarborough-based property company has close connections with Mr Bourne and his bankers Bank of Scotland, which owns 20% of Teesland.

Mr Oliver, who will take a position on the board of Legacy, insisted the new consortium had enough financing to proceed with the development of the hi-tech market. At some stage, he said, Legacy would approach major fund management groups about taking stakes in Legacy, in which Treasury Holdings, the controversial Irish property group, continues to hold a majority stake.

The counter-offer Mr Gerbeau is suggesting would see the dome used as a visitor attraction, introducing virtual reality experiences, and as a venue for concerts and raves.

Doubts surfaced about Mr Gerbeau's financing last night. He said he was supported by James Palumbo, boss of London's Ministry of Sound nightclub, and was in talks with Japanese bank Nomura, which pulled out of a bid last year.

But he was undermined when Nomura insisted it was not in negotiations with him, though he had been in contact.

fields.headline: Israel kills Arafat's man
fields.standfirst:
Fury as senior guard to the Palestinian leader is killed

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli army struck at the heart of Yasser Arafat's administration by assassinating an officer in his personal security guard yesterday, fuelling the escalation of violence that began with the election of the hardliner Ariel Sharon as the Jewish state's prime minister.
fields.body:
The Israeli army struck at the heart of Yasser Arafat's administration by assassinating an officer in his personal security guard yesterday, fuelling the escalation of violence that began with the election of the hardliner Ariel Sharon as the Jewish state's prime minister.

Massoud Ayad, 54, a lieutenant colonel in Mr Arafat's Force 17 elite body guard, was killed by a volley of rockets fired from two helicopters that had been tracking his white Honda Civic along a main road in the Jabaliya refugee camp, north of Gaza City. The car was reduced to a smouldering wreck, and four bystanders were injured.

Ayad joins more than 20 victims of Israel's official policy of assassinating Palestinians it accuses of attacks on soldiers and civilians. But never before has Israel struck so deeply into Mr Arafat's administration.

All of the operations were sanctioned by the outgoing prime minister, Ehud Barak, who yesterday sent "heartfelt congratulations" to the army for killing Ayad. The murder of Ayad - and the death of a Palestinian teenager shot through the heart by an Israeli sniper in the Gaza Strip yesterday - came as Mr Sharon was finalising a deal for a national unity government with Mr Barak's Labour party.

Mr Barak said Israel would continue picking off Palestinian leaders. "It is a clear message to those who plan to attack Israelis, that they will not get away with it. The long arm of the Israel defence forces will call them to account," he said.

The Palestinian Authority said Israel was guilty of war crimes. "Israel is a state above the law," the justice minister, Freih Abu Medein, declared.

Ayad was the first Palestinian official to be assassinated since December 31, when a middle-aged dentist and a leader of Mr Arafat's Fatah movement, Thabet Thabet, was sprayed with machine-gun fire in a mafia-style hit in the West Bank city of Tulkarm. Thabet had been closely associated with several Israeli peace activists since the late 1980s and his death sparked international outrage.

The Israeli army yesterday called a press conference to list a series of operations Ayad allegedly conducted on behalf of Hizbullah, the Shia Muslim organisation which led Lebanese resistance to Israel's occupation of southern Lebanon.

A spokesman, Brigadier Ron Kitrey, said Ayad had been responsible for several attacks on Israeli soldiers and settlers in the Gaza Strip since December 24 last year. webTitle: Lack of visitors closes lottery's faith centre

fields.headline: Lack of visitors closes lottery's faith centre
fields.standfirst: Millennium curse strikes again as Bradford project funded with £2.2m grant ceases trading after seven months
fields.trailText: Millennium curse strikes again as Bradford project funded with £2.2m grant ceases trading after seven months.
fields.body:
Another costly national lottery project turned turtle yesterday, severing one of the Millennium Festival's few links with its religious origins.

Clergy and lay members of the board of the National Faith Centre in Bradford closed the centre's doors after legal advice that they risked insolvency if they carried on trading.

The £5m attraction, also known as Life Force and designed to celebrate and explain humankind's history of religious belief, opened with a £2.2m millennium lottery grant last July. But visitor numbers have been catastrophic, with 62 paying to look around in the first week, and fewer than 600 in the three peak holiday weeks of August.

The acting dean of Bradford Cathedral, Derek Jackson, who has managed the project since the resignation of board mem ber Manoj Joshi last month, said the closure had been agreed with "deep regret". After advice from insolvency practitioners, the centre's two operating companies, both named after St Peter, have gone into administration - suspending possible claims by creditors.

A spokeswoman for the millennium commission, which welcomed a major religious project when the bid was approved, said staff were working with Bradford Cathedral, the main partner in the inter-faith scheme, to find a way forward. "Obviously, from the commission's point of view, we are very disappointed," she said.

The closure was revealed indirectly via a letter to a small Bradford building firm, which came to the centre's rescue during the torrential rains of November. Contractor Jim Trueman of Access Roofing in Idle, Bradford, was told that his £446 bill could not be paid.

The centre also said the trickle of visitors meant that expecting further grant money was unrealistic, and the project could no longer trade. Mr Trueman said he was annoyed after "doing them a favour when water was cascading through the building".

Life Force called in experienced visitor attraction designers from York to create the centre; it hoped that its even-handed treatment of the world's faiths, and their many connections, would appeal in multicultural Bradford. But the converted post office next to the cathedral received little major marketing and early on rumours of problems began to spread.

Free entry in September raised weekly visitors to 653, but even this fell short of the 770 target, or 40,000 a year, needed for success in the first year; the total in all was under 10,000. The National Faith Centre used innovative technology but was dogged by the technical problems familiar from a rollcall of lottery projects. A special, imported pane of glass broke before reaching Bradford, and Digital City, a databank of local memories, was not fully operational until October.

Optimistic visitor predictions, however, were the real killer, in common with a string of other lottery projects, notably the Millennium Dome.

In Portsmouth, meanwhile, an £18m millennium tower was given the go-ahead yesterday by the city council after five years of planning negotiations since the approval of a commission grant.

Karen Traviss of Portsmouth city council said: "We never imagined the scheme would take this long, but if we are going to build it we are going to get it right. This is a landmark which will last for many, many years to come."

Attractions that failed to draw crowds

 The Millennium Dome took much the biggest grant handed out by the lottery, £538m, but came nowhere near the prediction of 12m visitors that persuaded two governments to flag it through. Only 344,620 people paid to go in during the first month; the final total was 6.5m

 Hampden Park stadium, Glasgow, was given £23m by the millennium commission for refurbishment but had to be rescued in 1999 in a £4m deal between the owners, Queens Park FC, and the Scottish Football Association

 The National Centre for Popular Music, Sheffield, closed in the autumn, taking £11m of arts lottery money with it. It drew only half the expected 400,000 first-year visitors

 The Centre for Visual Arts, Cardiff, closed in November after visitors reached 47,500 in its first year, against a predicted 220,000. The £9m building had had £3m from the Arts Council's lottery pot

 The Earth Centre in South Yorkshire, which took £20m from the commission, is alive but its ambitions have been scaled down. Predictions that recycling and sustainability would lure 500,000 people in the first year proved more than 400,000 off-beam

Attractions that escaped the millennium curse:

 Tate Modern, London - more than double expected attendance

 The Lowry arts centre, Salford - getting on for double

 The Eden Project, Cornwall - nearly double, just from visits before official opening day

webTitle: Hinduja inquiry accused of secrecy and conflict

fields.headline: Hinduja inquiry accused of secrecy and conflict
fields.trailText: MPs last night voiced fears that undue secrecy and apparent conflicts of interest may undermine the credibility of Sir Anthony Hammond's investigation into the Hinduja passport controversy which triggered Peter Mandelson's resignation as Northern Ireland secretary.
fields.body:
MPs last night voiced fears that undue secrecy and apparent conflicts of interest may undermine the credibility of Sir Anthony Hammond's investigation into the Hinduja passport controversy which triggered Peter Mandelson's resignation as Northern Ireland secretary.

A day after Mr Mandelson gave evidence to the inquiry, Norman Baker, the Liberal De mocrat MP for Lewes, whose Commons question precipitated the crisis, warned that the retired QC's report may be too "narrow" to get to the bottom of the affair.

He said Sir Anthony had interviewed him. "He said he had not been subject to influence by ministers," Mr Baker said in a reference to the "stitch-up" theory shared by both the Mandelson camp and by some Labour MPs who are not his supporters.

But a Labour loyalist MP said: "People don't know what is going on, so inevitably it raises suspicions that a bit of an old boys' network is in operation - and will lead to a mutually agreed conclusion.'

In the latest twist, it is now being claimed that Mr Mandelson may after all have briefly intervened in a telephone conversation made by Emma Scott, an official in his private office in 1998.

It was made to her opposite number working for Mike O'Brien, then immigration minister, when the Hinduja brothers asked about Labour's revised passport policy. It later emerged that they were giving £1m to the Millennium Dome. SP Hinduja got his passport the following year.

The possibility of a brief ("Let me have a word") intervention by Mr Mandelson,who was then minister for the dome, might explain why the conversation - alleged to have taken place on June 28 1998 - was not properly logged by civil servants at the time.

The only documented evidence appears to be an ambiguous email between officials at the end of the week, on July 2. The prime minister's office has refused to release it, because Sir Anthony is investigating the affair. "It is up to him to investigate, we are not giving a running commentary," the deputy press spokesman, Godric Smith, said yesterday. Sir Anthony's report is due by the end of the month.

Whether or not Mr Mandelson spoke to a Home Office civil servant that day - though not, his friends still say, directly to Mr O'Brien - the telephone conversation is crucial to Tony Blair's justification for requiring his old friend to resign abruptly on January 24.

The Home Office insists that the conversation took place, and that Mr O'Brien belatedly remembered it. Mr Mandelson has said he had no memory of it, though he briefly "acquiesced" in the Home Office version when confronted directly by Mr Blair who needed to clear the row up before facing Commons question time.

Mr Mandelson denies any wrongdoing. What has troubled some MPs on both sides is the role of two key players: Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's press secretary, in the rapid decision to oust Mr Mandelson, and Sir Richard Wilson, who produced an overnight report for Mr Blair based largely on Home Office evidence.

It is the central role of Home Office officials, past and present, which worries some MPs. Sir Anthony himself is a retired Home Office official. Even the secretary of the inquiry is an official seconded from the prisons department.

Sir Richard is the Home Office's former head, and moved to the cabinet office after working under Jack Straw.

No 10 is blocking all questions about Sir Anthony's investigation and who he will interview, despite Sir Richard saying yesterday he had given Sir Anthony "all the relevant information in my possession".
