fields.headline: Film pick of the day
fields.trailText: Gentlemen Prefer Blondes | Pretty Woman | Notting Hill | Betty Blue
fields.body:
Films

Gentlemen Prefer Blondes (Howard Hawks, 1953) 9.50am 4pm, Sky Cinema Kicking off a lovey-dovey Valentine's Day is this colourful and sassy musical, vibrantly directed by Hawks. As the song famously says, diamonds are a girl's best friend - for cabaret artistes Marilyn Monroe and Jane Russell, who are headed for France on an ocean liner to find their sugar-daddies. It's a glittering singing-and-dancing double-act, with Monroe in show-stopping form with the likes of Diamonds and Two Little Girls From Little Rock.

Pretty Woman (Garry Marshall, 1990) 8pm, Sky Cinema A modern-day fairy tale and box-office smash: Julia Roberts starring as the sensitive hooker who, given a blank cheque to spend in LA's designer stores by client Richard Gere, discovers that there's a better life to be had by marrying a rich man. Expensive, glossy twaddle: but Roy Orbison's theme song is great.

Notting Hill (Roger Michell, 1999) 10pm, Sky Premier Here's Julia again. It may be a cynical exploitation of the success of Four Weddings And A Funeral, but it's an undeniably slick and entertaining romantic comedy. You can pick holes in it - there's not a black face to be seen in this Notting Hill; is Rhys Ifans in Y-fronts really such a hoot? - but the highly unlikely liaison of Hugh Grant's bumbling bookshop owner and Roberts's Hollywood superstar is charmingly played and deftly scripted.

Betty Blue (Jean-Jacques Beineix, 1986) 10pm, FilmFour And finally, an antidote to the preceding slush. Béatrice Dalle was apparently plucked from the streets of Paris to play the eponymous heroine: it's an exuberant performance, by turns sexy, joyful, and disturbing. Her Betty is an elemental force moving in on unsuspecting writer Jean-Hugues Anglade, and championing his unpublished novel; he is charmed, but soon horrified by her self-destructive intensity. Like Beineix's Diva, this is archetypal Cinéma du Look, an exercise in pure, seductive, style.

fields.headline: A-plus for Nord Anglia
fields.trailText: Nord Anglia Education has been a strong performer on the rumours that the education services company is close to winning a number of important contracts.
fields.body:
Nord Anglia Education has been a strong performer on the rumours that the education services company is close to winning a number of important contracts.

Informed sources reckon there is a more fundamental reason for the rise - institutional buying on the back of positive research notes from broker Williams de Broe and Nord Anglia's new house broker, Brewin Dolphin.

"Recent results saw the final phase of the concentration on the core areas of education outsourcing and delivery," said Brewin Dolphin. These two profitable divisions "should lead to steady growth" added Williams de Broe.

The development of online delivery of training material for the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants looks likely to prove a rich seam for the company. Its Emile Woolf colleges, which prepare students for ACCA exams, will launch its online offering by the end of spring.

Yesterday Nord Anglia closed up 16p at 212.5p.

webTitle: Police reveal chaotic life of murder victim

fields.headline: Police reveal chaotic life of murder victim
fields.standfirst: Thirty officers hunt killer of lonely woman desperate for friendship
fields.trailText: Thirty officers hunt killer of lonely woman desperate for friendship
fields.body:
Beneath a giant whiteboard covered with names and arrows, Detective Inspector Ian Mill is trying to solve an apparently uncrackable murder.

"We're taught that when we investigate crimes we're looking at the victim, suspect and location," he said. "In this case, the suspect and location have been removed. We don't even have all the information about the victim."

The incident room in Barnes, west London, is at the centre of a murder hunt which involves more than 30 officers and spans much of Britain. It began on December 17 last year, when police pulled the severed torso of a woman from the river Thames near Chelsea Harbour. Her body had been sawn in half before being dumped in the river; her lower body is still missing.

Within weeks, relatives had identified her as Zoe Louise Parker, 24, thanks to a tattoo and her unusual twisted front tooth. But the breakthrough brought a fresh set of problems as police began to explore her life and discovered how chaotic it had been.

"She had associates all over London and travelled right throughout the country - we've had sightings of her in Bournemouth and Colchester," DI Mill said. The last confirmed sighting was in Hounslow town centre with two unknown men on December 6, although officers still have weeks of CCTV footage to examine.

A mass leafleting campaign and an item on BBC's Crimewatch have brought in fresh information, but the police are struggling to make sense of it all.

Zoe had always lived from day to day, but her last few months were particularly haphazard. She killed time in Hounslow and Feltham or in central London, stopping in hostels or at friends' flats and probably sleeping rough at times. When desperate she would offer sex. "She was prostituting herself, but not in the sense that she was working a beat - nothing about Zoe's life was organised," DI Mill said.

"She looked for attention and somewhere to sleep. She'd go up to men she liked in the pub sometimes and offer sex in return for a bed for the night."

Her aunt, Pauline Knott, believes her niece's extrovert nature led her into dangerous situations. "She used to go up and talk to the wrong people. She was quite lonely and would talk to anybody to make a friend," Mrs Knott said.

"She was very naive. Very gullible. If someone came across as being quite nice that was it. She wanted to trust people."

Her need for affection seemed to have its root in her childhood, which was spent in a series of homes after her mother placed her in care at 18 months.

"Zoe was just sweet, really," Mrs Knott said. "She didn't have many chances in her life, I'm afraid. Through her life she had been promised so many things and she was let down in lots of ways."

On her regular trips to stay with the Knotts, Zoe would watch the film Annie over and over again. It is easy to imagine why the story of an orphan who finds a happy home appealed to her.

"She was always asking, 'Do you love me? Do you love me?'" Mrs Knott said. "She was very insecure. She wanted to be with a family; she wanted to be like us."

Yet Zoe grew into an outgoing and optimistic adult. She had learning difficulties and no qualifications, but still talked hopefully of finding work in a gym.

Shortly before her death she changed her name to Cathy Dennis, apparently to erase her past.

But little seemed to improve. The last time Mrs Knott saw her niece was in early September. Zoe had been thrown out of a hostel for breaking the rules; Mrs Knott, who had taken her in on previous occasions, was on her way to visit a grandchild in hospital and did not have time to help. She asked Zoe to go to her mother or social services.

Zoe had problems communicating with social services. "The only time I found she was difficult was when she wasn't listened to properly," Mrs Knott said. "She said to me, 'They never ever listen, then they wonder why I shout and scream because I'm not listened to.'"

Frustrated and unsettled, Zoe began to drift from place to place again. Within months, she was dead.

fields.headline: Twitchy over Bookham
fields.trailText: When a leading City investment bank starts coverage of a company with a "sell" recommendation the day before the business is scheduled to publish full year results, traders tend to get twitchy.
fields.body:
When a leading City investment bank starts coverage of a company with a "sell" recommendation the day before the business is scheduled to publish full year results, traders tend to get twitchy.

Yesterday, CSFB did exactly that. Starting Bookham Technology as a "sell", it told clients that a share price of between 640p and 830p was appropriate for the optical chip maker. Bookham shares closed 83p lower at 789p.

CSFB analyst Doug Smith reckons Bookham's continuing operating losses - he does not see the company breaking even on an operating profit level until the end of 2002 at the earliest - will be a major deterrent to it generating significant interest from the investment community.

He notes that while Bookham has negative gross margins most players in the optical components world have gross margins between 30% and 50%. Furthermore, he sees potential downside risk to his current revenue forecasts.

While, today's figures are likely to contain few surprises - Bookham warned a couple of weeks ago that fourth-quarter losses would be higher than expected - the guidance given at subsequent analysts presentations will be vital in re-establishing Bookham's market credibility.

In the wider market, leading shares finished mixed as poor performances from BT and Vodafone - down 27.5p to 611p and 8p to 216.5p in the wake of the disappointing debut by Orange - were offset by fresh buying of classic defensive stocks. AstraZencea advanced 34p to £30.75, while GlaxoSmithKline rose 47p to £19.06p.

In fact, the FTSE 100 had spent much of the afternoon session in positive territory after a strong start to trading on the New York market and some soothing words from Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan.

In his twice-yearly testimony to Congress, Greenspan more or less repeated what every body all already knows: that the US economy faces a sharp slowdown this year. Nonetheless, traders interpreted the comments as meaning more rates cuts would be following January's two reductions - good news for equities.

But with market heavyweight BP (down 19p to 590p after disappointing fourth quarter figures) dragging the index lower, the FTSE 100 closed 12.9 points adrift at 6,228.5. Business was steady, with 1.93bn shares changing hands.

Elsewhere, the FTSE Techmark 100 finished 5.73 points weaker at 2,626.67, with the FTSE Mid 250 up 5.9 to 6,775.

British Airways was back at the top of the blue chip leaderboard, gaining 22p to 414.75p after an upgrade from Schroder Salomon Smith Barney.

Shifting its stance to "outperform", Schroder said the recent weakness of the shares, which have fallen 10% since last week's third quarter figures, had presented a buying opportunity, especially for long term investors. Commerzbank was also positive on the stock, advising clients to buy.

In the meantime, catering group Compass improved 16p to 553p on the back of "buy" advice from Lehman Brothers and Reuters added 54p to £10.74 after sparkling full year figures.

Away from the blue chips, buyers were still in good supply for proteomics specialist Oxford Glycoscience (up 35p to £14.65) following Monday's positive trial news on its drug for Gaucher's disease, Vevesca.

Schroder Salomon Smith Barney reckons that the Vevesca news could justify as much as 60% of OG's current market value and allow it to move into profitability by 2003, thereby securing its financial future.

In the smaller companies universe, systems and software firm Vega (down 117.5p to 222.5p) saw 50% wiped off its market capitalisation following a shock profits warning that resulted in the chief executive resigning and the interim dividend being axed.

webTitle: Civilian at helm as US sub sank Japanese boat

fields.headline: Civilian at helm as US sub sank Japanese boat
fields.trailText: A civilian guest was at the helm of the US submarine which rammed and sank a Japanese fishing boat off the coast of Hawaii on Friday, from which nine people are still missing, the Pentagon admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
A civilian guest was at the helm of the US submarine which rammed and sank a Japanese fishing boat off the coast of Hawaii on Friday, from which nine people are still missing, the Pentagon admitted yesterday.

A US defence official did not name the civilian involved but said there was no indication that his or her presence caused the accident.

The navy spokesman, Commander Greg Smith, said that visiting civilians were often allowed in US submarines.

He said it would not be unusual for a visitor to be allowed to sit in one of the vessel's three helm positions, to get an impression of what it was like to command a submarine.

It is thought that the civilian was sitting at controls which regulates the submarine's heading and angle, but defence officials stressed that submariners would have been on hand at every moment to keep control of the vessel.

"The civilian is not in control of any actions that were not ordered by the commanding officer," the commander said.

The submarine, the Greeneville, hit the Japanese ship Ehine Maru as it surfaced at high speed from a depth of 120 metres (400ft) as part of an emergency drill.

The Ehine Maru was holed in the stern and sank in minutes. Twenty-six passengers were rescued but nine are still missing, including four 17-year-old fisheries students.

There were reportedly 16 civilians on board the submarine. Reports quoting an unnamed official said they were local community and business leaders.

Other reports said none were "major public figures".

The accident investigation is focusing on the use of sonar to ascertain what vessels were in the area when surfacing.

The submarine's captain was supposed to have made a visual check of the horizon to back up his sonar observations. It is not clear how he failed to spot the boat.

webTitle: School offers £100 to star GCSE pupils

fields.headline: School offers £100 to star GCSE pupils
fields.trailText: The parents' ploy of a treat to encourage good exam results has been adopted by a struggling school, which has won private funding to offer pupils £100 each for good grades.
fields.body:
The parents' ploy of a treat to encourage good exam results has been adopted by a struggling school, which has won private funding to offer pupils £100 each for good grades.

Every student who gets five or more A*-Cs in GCSEs this summer at Kingswood high school on the Bransholme estate in Hull will qualify for the perk, in a deal with a development company.

The sweetener joins a range of other innovations at the school, which Ofsted put into special measures in November after its disastrous performance in the league tables. Only 3% of the school's GCSE pupils last year would have qualified for the reward, one of the lowest figures in the country.

The headteacher of Kingswood, Kevin Beaton, said the reward system was to encourage success and motivation. The school has introduced breakfast and lunch sessions to give pupils extra attention, and other students are coming in for top-up classes at weekends.

Other carrots include arrangements with building firms to take "challenging" students for day release work on nearby sites. Similar but smaller schemes are being trialled in other education authorities, including a bicycle raffle each term and free burger vouchers for students with 100% attendance records at schools in York.

John Briggs, director of Kingswood Parks Development, which will pay out the £100 gifts, said: "We know that Kingswood high school needs a hand as it strives to achieve the demanding Ofsted targets it has been set. I'm confident that the new scheme, which we will fund in full, will provide extra encouragement."

The scheme is expected to be extended to hard-working children throughout the district.

webTitle: Fresh quake piles on misery in El Salvador

fields.headline: Fresh quake piles on misery in El Salvador
fields.standfirst:
Dozens are feared buried alive by a second tremor
Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: More than 120 people died and more than 1,000 were injured when an earthquake hit El Salvador yesterday morning, causing further destruction and sending waves of panic through a country still traumatised by the massive quake that killed more than 1,000 people exactly one month ago.
fields.body:
More than 120 people died and more than 1,000 were injured when an earthquake hit El Salvador yesterday morning, causing further destruction and sending waves of panic through a country still traumatised by the massive quake that killed more than 1,000 people exactly one month ago.

Dozens of houses already tottering from the January 13 disaster collapsed in rural villages and renewed landslides occurred along the Pan American highway after the quake struck with a force of 6.6 on the Richter scale.

Important sections of the road, which connects El Salvador with Guatemala and Honduras, were already blocked by rock falls from last month's earthquake. A bus-load of passengers covered by falling earth yesterday survived by climbing out of the windows.

"The preliminary total is of 92 dead, and the number of injured totals 714," President Francisco Flores told a news conference. The quake struck at 8:22 am as many Salvadoreans were on their way to work.

The quake destroyed houses in the town of San Vicente, 40 miles east of the capital, the public works minister, Jose Angel Quiroz, said.

"There are about 200 [collapsed] houses where people are buried," he told a local radio station.

Five schoolchildren and their teacher died when the quake levelled a parish school in the village of Candelaria, on the outskirts of the town of Cojutepeque, 20 miles to the east of the capital. Another 15 children in the village were buried by falling debris.

A Red Cross spokesman, Carlos Mendoza, said the worst damage appeared to be in the central provinces of San Vicente and Cuscatlan. Officials fear that many people may have been buried under their collapsed homes.

Mr Mendoza called on people to remain calm in the wake of further aftershocks and to stock up on water and food supplies.

Police throughout the stricken areas were put on full alert to prevent looters from ransacking homes.

The epicentre of the latest quake, which lasted 15 to 20 seconds, was 12.5 miles south-east of San Salvador, along a faultline already disturbed by the last quake a month ago.

In one of the worst-hit towns, Cojutepeque, nine miles east of the capital, almost all the houses came down

The quake was felt in San Salvador and in neighbouring Guatemala and Honduras.

The capital, San Salvador, was left untouched by the quake. But as the ground began to shake and the movements increased in intensity, hundreds of people rushed in panic from offices and factories on to the city's streets.

Radio stations have been relaying messages from people seeking news about relatives, while traffic across the capital came to a standstill as parents rushed to pick their children up from school.

Gloria de Portillo, a maid whose brother died in the January quake, said: "This is terrible, it never seems to end." There have been almost 2,000 aftershocks since the first quake.

On Monday the government declared a large area around the town of Santa Tecla, a few miles from the capital, "temporarily uninhabitable" as a result of the instability of the surrounding mountain range, a part of which was brought down in the January 13 quake.

Almost 1.2m in a population of 6m were affected by last month's disaster and the government has put the cost at more than $1bn.

Reconstruction work, made all the more urgent with the winter rains only eight weeks away, has hardly begun. The UN has appealed for extra aid.

•A major earthquake rocked the south coast of Sumatra, western Indonesia, early this morning, registering 7.4 on the Richter scale.

It was strong enough to generate a tidal wave, seismologists warned.

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Evening Concert | Night Waves | Kirsty MacColl's Cuba
fields.body:
This being St Valentine's Day, the Evening Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM) is built around the two lovers who have inspired composers almost since they flowed from Shakespeare's quill. Natalie Wheen chooses Russian treatments of Romeo and Juliet as the focus of the evening: Tchaikovsky's Fantasy Overture is followed by Prokofiev's 1938 ballet music (dismissed as "too difficult" by the Bolshoi's dancers).

Professor Niall Ferguson swims resolutely upstream for Night Waves (9.30pm, Radio 3) when he talks to Philip Dodd about his latest book The Cash Nexus, a study of money and power over the past three centuries. Ferguson thinks history has shown that political events (not to mention sex and violence) have repeatedly dominated economic change.

With the impending 40th anniversary of America's disastrous attempt to overthrow Fidel Castro's infant regime, Kirsty MacColl's Cuba (10.0pm, Radio 2) comes from the Bay of Pigs, site of the invasion thwarted in April 1961. Gloria Estafan of The Miami Sound Machine recalls her father's involvement with the CIA-backed anti-Castro forces. Ibrahim Ferrer, star of the Buena Vista Social Club, remembers the consequent Cuban missile crisis some 18 months later. As the world trembled on the brink of nuclear war, Ferrer was in Moscow, discussing the likelihood of annihilation with the Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: TV show finds missing woman
fields.body:
TV show finds missing woman

The BBC's new Crimewatch Daily programme has reunited a woman who went missing on February 6 in Hayes, Middlesex, with her family a few hours after an appeal was broadcast yesterday. A viewer who was driving along the A40 saw Baljiit Kaur, 47, and told police at a nearby station.

Children's home cares for adult

A 25-year-old woman spent a month in care at The Manor children's home in Coventry after telling staff she was 15. Social services officials admitted they were suspicious but allowed her to stay while inquiries were carried out.

Teenager on murder charge

Gary Lawson, 19, from Grimsby, charged with murdering a pensioner killed in an arson attack, was remanded in custody until February 21. The body of Alfred Wilkins, 67, was found at his flat in Arundel Walk, Grimsby, at the end of last week.

Girl, four, picks up pipebomb

four-year-old girl brought a pipebomb into her home after picking it up in the Springfield Road area near Belfast's "peaceline" separating nationalist and loyalist communities. Army bomb disposal experts dealt with the device.

GPs urged to wait and see

Doctors should "wait and see" before giving children with acute ear infections antibiotics, a Southampton university report said, to reduce the spread of antibiotic resistance.

Two jailed for killing bouncer

wo men who killed a bouncer in a revenge attack four days after being thrown out of a nightclub were jailed for 5 years yesterday. Anthony Curtis, 21, and Richard Smith, 19, were convicted of the manslaughter of Ben Kamanalagi after a 10-day trial at Manchester crown court. They were cleared of murder.

One in five 'will never marry'

One in five young people will never marry, with many forming partnerships in which the couple live separately, according to a study by Professor John Ermisch of Essex University.

Kindest cut for cats

Cat owners must have their pets neutered to cut the spiralling number of unwanted and stray animals, the RSPCA said at the launch of a £1.5m campaign in which owners in some areas will be offered cheap treatment.

fields.headline: Sir Herbert Ashworth
fields.standfirst: His marketing flair transformed the building society industry
fields.trailText: His marketing flair transformed the building society industry
fields.body:
S ir Herbert Ashworth, who has died aged 90, was chairman of Britain's third largest building society, the Nationwide, from 1970 to 1982 and made a major contribution to the growth of the building society movement from the late 1930s to the 1980s. During this period, home ownership expanded to more than 60% and building society membership was seen within most families.

Ashworth left his local grammar school in Burnley at the age of 15, and joined the Burnley Building Society as a junior clerk, at a salary of £30 a year. He continued his studies by taking an external London University degree in economics and law.

After 10 years, he moved to the London-based Portman Building Society, where he became general manager. In 1950, he was appointed general manager of the Co-operative Permanent Building Society (CPBS), then the fourth largest in the country.

While not legally a cooperative society, and being a fully independent organisation, the CPBS did hold considerable deposits received from the cooperative societies, which, if withdrawn en bloc, would cause liquidity problems. Ashworth realised this danger and had the vision to widen the society's appeal to the public at large.

He set out to greatly expand the branch network. Young men enthusiastically scoured the land to secure inexpensive and temporary premises from which to secure new mortgage and savings business. From these early beginnings, prime high street branches were established, the vast majority of which remain today.

With his flair for market-ing and public relations, Ashworth used leading-edge forms of advertising, such as television - then a "first" for a financial organisation - and press conferences dealing with the housing market and the economy as well as CPBS progress, which received wide coverage.

The result was to enhance Ashworth's reputation and, with strong government support for home ownership, the growth rate of the CPBS greatly accelerated, easily outstripping its rivals. In 1961, by which time the society was the third largest in the country, and he had completed 10 years' service, Ashworth resigned as general manager and became a director and general manager of Hallmark Securities, a property company. At the next annual general meeting of the CPBS, he was elected a non-executive director of the society.

The 1960s saw a continuing growth in the building society industry, but the CPBS was not faring so well. Attracting new business was becoming difficult because of an assumed connection of the society with the cooperative movement. At that time, small business people saw the Co-op as a competitor, and those members of the public who did not support socialist principles shied away.

In 1969, lack of confidence in a small, obscure co-op in Cumbria led to widespread withdrawal of capital across all cooperative societies, along with the CPBS, much to the alarm of Ashworth and his colleagues. This situation led to a decision in 1970 to change the name - from Co-operative Permanent Building Society to Nationwide - and, soon afterwards, Ashworth was elected chairman.

From then on, the society went from strength to strength. Ashworth proved himself a first-class chairman, establishing an excellent board and ensuring both management and staff were able to perform their roles in an enlightened environment.

Ashworth was also vice-chairman of the Housing Corporation from 1964, becoming chairman in 1968, a post he held for five years. He was knighted in 1972. An avid reader, he wrote a number of books, including The Building Society Story (1980). He was a great fan of horse racing and could see the grandstand at Epsom racecourse from his house.

He is survived by his wife, Barbara, and their three children.

Herbert Ashworth, building society leader, born January 30 1910; died December 29 2000

fields.headline: Gordon Dickson
fields.standfirst: Prolific writer of ancient and modern science-fiction fantasies
fields.trailText: Prolific writer of ancient and modern science-fiction fantasies
fields.body:
The science-fiction author Gordon Dickson, who has died aged 77, published his first story, Trespass, in 1950, and continued with more than 80 books and some 200 short stories. Even towards the end, when often too ill to leave his house, he produced a book each year. His novels and collections sold more than 10m copies.

Born in Canada, but resident in the United States for most of his life, much of Dickson's work was straightforward commercial SF or fantasy, and deservedly popular as such. Other stories struck a deeper note, while using genre trappings of spaceships, fantastic weaponry and vast conflicts. The lengthy Childe Cycle, or Dorsai sequence, which Dickson regarded as his life's work, is infused with an offbeat personal mysticism that transcends pulp-SF superman fantasies.

In this imagined future, "full-spectrum humanity" - with deep evolutionary roots - still persists on earth, but interstellar colonists have split along philosophical lines into "splinter cultures" of mercenaries, physical scientists, psychologist-mystics and religious fanatics. Unusually for SF, the scientists are the least interesting group, while the devout and their harsh, sustaining faith are presented with special sympathy.

The Childe Cycle features a series of latent supermen who slowly realise their ability to direct history, and the necessary compassion and responsibility needed to accompany such talent. In Dorsai! (1960) and Tactics Of Mistake (1971), they are gifted military strategists, happy warriors who aim for bloodless victory. Soldier, Ask Not (1967) has as its antihero an influential journalist fatally tempted to remould public opinion and destroy the particular splinter culture he loathes. A shorter version of this novel won a 1965 Hugo award, the Oscar of SF.

Further volumes of increasing length, like The Final Encyclopedia (1984), show the partly recombined human race threatened by an evolutionary dead end.

Plans to extend the Childe Cycle backward, with trilogies of historical and contemporary novels, never came to fruition; this ambitious and often impressive sequence seemingly lost its way and remains unfinished. It moved Brian Aldiss to commend Dickson as one of SF's "legendary monsters" who "embark on projects no mainstream author would attempt".

Dickson was further honoured with two 1981 Hugo awards for the short Lost Dorsai - another Childe story, dealing with the torn loyalties of a pacifist mercenary - and the unrelated The Cloak And The Staff. Here, the quasi-religious garb of a pilgrim becomes the rallying symbol for hopeless resistance to physically invincible alien overlords; this was expanded to book length as Way Of The Pilgrim (1987). Call Him Lord, a short, unflinching parable of power and responsibility, brought Dickson a 1966 Nebula award from the Science Fiction Writers of America, of which he became president from 1969-71.

A lighter side of his talent emerged with the Hoka stories, written with Poul Anderson, first collected in Earthman's Burden (1957) and gaining a cult following among SF fans. Hokas are terminally cute, furry, teddy-bear-like aliens whose enthusiasm for earthly culture and inability to tell fact from fiction lead to comically warped Hoka recreations of the old wild west, the melodramatic excesses of opera, the England of Sherlock Holmes, and so on. When the film-maker George Lucas introduced the physically very similar Ewoks in Return Of The Jedi, some readers felt that the Hokas' creators should sue.

D ickson anticipated the recent boom in humorous fantasy with The Dragon And The George (1976), in which the now traditional difficulties of a modern American, projected into a fantasy land of knights, wizards and monsters, are increased by the fact that he finds himself inhabiting the body of a dragon. Well received in Britain, this light-hearted novel won the British Fantasy Society's August Derleth award. Several sequels appeared in the 1990s.

Besides the popularity of his writing, Dickson was personally well liked in SF social circles, where he was a convivial, entertaining speaker (and guitar player) on the north American convention circuit. The 1984 world SF convention in Los Angeles made him its guest of honour, as did the 1988 British national convention in Liverpool.

Gordon Rupert Dickson, author, born November 1 1923; died January 31 2001

fields.headline: No 1819 David Petrie
fields.body:
Age: 39.

Occupation: Currently unemployed.

What did he do before? International jetsetter.

Looks more like a milkman to me. That's because you are shallow and judge by appearances. This is a man, I'll have you know, who would think nothing of splashing out £21,000 to whisk his girlfriend off to America for a business meeting.

Are you sure he didn't drive a grocery van for a living? Try a £60,000 Porsche 911. Or one of the two other cars parked in his drive.

I stand corrected. Presumably he lived in Chelsea where he spent long, lazy nights in indolent games of baccarat? More like Longtown, near Carlisle in Cumbria, where he was the production manager at a water bottling plant.

Let's get this right. By day he worked in a factory, by night he was the playboy of the western Pennines. How did he manage that? He simply chanced upon a ready source of the purest spring eau .

Which was? A standpipe in the yard.

I'm confused. It's simple, really. Just attach a hose to the tap, fill up a few bottles, stick a flash label on them and market as Longtown mineral water - with a price to match. All that remains is to plunder the company account and spend freely.

This all sounds rather familiar. You may be thinking of a similar scam executed some years ago in south London, by one Del Trotter.

So he got the idea from Del Boy and Rodney? Quite possibly, though unfortunately Petrie will not be able to emulate his fictional TV counterparts and enjoy a millionaire lifestyle in his retirement. He's just been jailed for six months for fraud.

Do say: "Only fools and horses work."

Don't say: "Porridge."

Not to be confused with: Jesus Christ.

Isn't that going a bit far? You're right. Petrie only managed to turn water into water.

fields.headline: Suspected Islamic terrorists arrested
fields.trailText: Four suspected Islamic terrorists were arrested in London yesterday after a two-month police and MI5 investigation which allegedly uncovered plans to launch attacks in Europe, including Britain.
fields.body:
Four suspected Islamic terrorists were arrested in London yesterday after a two-month police and MI5 investigation which allegedly uncovered plans to launch attacks in Europe, including Britain.

Three Algerians and a Jordanian were taken by unarmed anti-terrorist branch officers from addresses in north and west London during raids at 6.30am.

Six homes and one business were searched, though it is understood no weapons or bombs were found.

The men were being held last night at a police station in central London under section 14 of the Prevention of Terrorism Act, which gives the police powers to arrest suspects believed to be "commissioning, instigating, or preparing acts of terrorism".

A fifth man was arrested and detained in connection with immigration offences.

Scotland Yard refused to give further details about the men arrested on suspicion of terrorism. It is known that the four suspects are aged 31, 33, 38 and 40.

Whitehall sources, however, said the two-month investigation had not been able to identify specific targets.

But sources confirmed the men were allegedly planning attacks in Europe rather than Algeria or the Middle East.

The four are not connected with Osama bin Laden, the Islamic militant extremist based in Afghanistan, or any other known group, including Algeria's Armed Islamic Group suspected of carrying out terrorist attacks in France and Algeria, according to the sources.

They allegedly took up jihad - holy war - independently and were not part of any "structured group".

A spokesman for the Met added: "Armed officers were not used in the operation and it is not linked to Irish terrorism and any unsolved terrorism acts.

"We are not prepared to discuss whether the arrests are in connection with any ongoing or previous operations."

fields.headline: Ulster forgives and forgets
fields.trailText: Michael Finucane (They killed my father, February 13) asks "how would you feel if you knew the government was responsible for murdering a member of your family?" Many in Northern Ireland who have suffered at the hands of the IRA also know how it feels.
fields.body:
Michael Finucane (They killed my father, February 13) asks "how would you feel if you knew the government was responsible for murdering a member of your family?" Many in Northern Ireland who have suffered at the hands of the IRA also know how it feels.

They have to accept the presence of a former leader who sanctioned the murder of innocent members of the community in their government. Yet they are asked to forget the past and accept that the killers should go free, and others into government. Should Michael Finucane not do the same?
Thomas Stevens
Belfast

I was a social services manager in central Birmingham on the night the IRA set off huge bombs in pubs full of innocent young people having a night out. I hope Michael Finucane understands how their families felt, how I felt.
Larry Rushton
Northampton

I trust that the increasing discomfort of Labour party leaders caused by their turbulent spin doctor, Peter Mandelson, will ensure that they exercise more caution in appointing future ministers dealing with Ireland.

Tony Blair allowed Mandelson to undermine the Irish peace process by gutting the Patten proposals on the new start to policing in which was promised in the Good Friday agreement.

Republicans and nationalists in Ireland certainly won't forget Mandelson's messing.
Cllr Sean Crowe
Sinn Fein

webTitle: Letters: Richard Branson on the Lottery

fields.headline: Branson: I'll give the money to charity
fields.trailText: I haven't spent 15 years of my life campaigning to see the lottery run with 100% of its profits going to good causes to end up "reducing the amount of money going to good causes" (Lottery compensation claim by Branson 'unlikely to succeed', February 12).
fields.body:
I haven't spent 15 years of my life campaigning to see the lottery run with 100% of its profits going to good causes to end up "reducing the amount of money going to good causes" (Lottery compensation claim by Branson 'unlikely to succeed', February 12).

We were a day from taking over the lottery when the commission's lawyers acknowledged they had made a mistake. As a result it cost us millions to keep the show on the road. Our legal advice is that we have very good grounds for compensation.

There are those who are mischievously suggesting (to deter us from making a claim, I believe) that compensation should come out of the Good Cause Fund rather than from the Treasury.

The Treasury makes billions from the lottery in a special lottery tax. That is where any compensation should come from.

However, since our action is about principle rather than money, I assure you that if the government does insist that the money comes from the Good Cause Fund, then any costs I do retrieve I would either give to charity or (if Camelot's sales keep falling and subject to laws permitting) use it to set up a rival lottery with 100% of profits going to good causes.
Richard Branson
The People's Lottery

fields.headline: When failures are fatal
fields.trailText: As consultant anaesthetists, we were very sorry to hear of the death of a patient at a Brighton hospital under anaesthesia (Report, February 10). Our sympathy goes out to the relatives of the unfortunate patient, and also to the consultant anaesthetist involved.
fields.body:
As consultant anaesthetists, we were very sorry to hear of the death of a patient at a Brighton hospital under anaesthesia (Report, February 10). Our sympathy goes out to the relatives of the unfortunate patient, and also to the consultant anaesthetist involved.

In the last 15 years there have been 13 cases of injecting into patients' cerebrospinal fluid instead of into a vein. As humans we all inevitably make errors. Catastrophic events such as this have been studied in medicine and in aviation. They are invariably the result of a series of failures, including system failures.

Current systems will not prevent this error from recurring. First, the syringes used for epidural and spinal injections are compatible with intravenous systems. They should not be. Second, bupivacaine was used as the local anaesthetic in this recent incident. For a few years local anaesthetics safer than bupivacaine (eg ropivacaine and chirocaine) have been available, but they are more expensive, and their use has been discouraged by the NHS on the basis of cost.

This case is particularly ironic because epidural analgesia saves lives. It dramatically reduces death and complications after major surgery. If the subsequent inquiry wishes to prevent this from ever happening again, it should concentrate on finding solutions to the system failures.
Dr Clifford Barthram and Dr Shelagh Winship
Consultant anaesthetists
Perth

fields.headline: Black Wednesday
fields.standfirst:
Another supremo turns ashen

Football site
fields.trailText: Sheffield Wednesday's 4-1 defeat last weekend at Wimbledon has exhausted the patience of the club's directors, who have now "parted company" with manager Paul Jewell, hired earlier in the season in the hope of saving the club from its second successive relegation.
fields.body:
Sheffield Wednesday's 4-1 defeat last weekend at Wimbledon has exhausted the patience of the club's directors, who have now "parted company" with manager Paul Jewell, hired earlier in the season in the hope of saving the club from its second successive relegation. Mr Jewell left Bradford City at the end of the previous season, having miraculously kept that struggling side in the premiership.

He was replaced by his former assistant Chris Hutchings, but when City continued to struggle, he in turn was supplanted by Jim Jefferies from Hearts. It has not done them much good. City remain at the foot of the premiership, six points behind Coventry City.

Speculation suggests that the Wednesday vacancy may be filled by the former Wimbledon, Watford, Sheffield United, Crystal Palace (in two spells, before and after one of Steve Coppell's three periods there), Nottingham Forest and Barnsley chief Dave Bassett, whom Barnsley let go earlier this season because of their poor results.

They have done no better since. Apart from the threat of relegation, Wednesday are unhappy at lagging so far behind their neighbours and rivals United, now eighth in the first division under the former Scarborough, Notts County, Huddersfield, Plymouth, Oldham and Bury supremo Neil Warnock.

It had seemed for a while as if the urge to sack managers when teams do badly might be abating, not least since research suggested that such changes rarely led to a turn for the better. But now the not-so-merry-go-round is whirling again.

webTitle: Letters: Police accidents and the human genome

fields.headline: Women with spirit
fields.trailText: In referring to my being knocked down by a police van travelling on the wrong side of the road in February 1999, John Sutherland (A police van runs over a man, February 12) appears to suggest that my condition at the time was contentious.
fields.body:
In referring to my being knocked down by a police van travelling on the wrong side of the road in February 1999, John Sutherland (A police van runs over a man, February 12) appears to suggest that my condition at the time was contentious. He misses the point. A representative of the Metropolitan police suggested in court that I was crossing the road under the influence of alcohol. This suggestion was subsequently withdrawn, being baseless. The articles I wrote were not "vigorously contradict(ing)" this allegation so much as drawing attention to the mendacity of the suggestion.
Sheena McDonald
London

Fabulous juxtaposition on your front page (Clouds of glory; Gene code opens new fields of medicine, February 12). The human genome tells us genetic determinism is dead as a 5ft 2in woman sails alone into France to world acclaim. What have genes, gender or race got to do with it? Give me opportunity, courage and application any time.
Susan Casey
London
caseysusan@hotmail.com

Good news! (I heard it on the radio) - the Somerset camel will be returning to the M5 in the next couple of weeks. Apparently he has been to a wedding.
Sue Bird
Bristol

Re your Wallies (Letters, February 12 & 13), could the father of William Hague (anag "I'm a huge Walli") have been at the Isle of Wight concert?
Ray Mitcham
Southport
ray.mitcham@btconnect.com

One and a half to two years in jail for an internet paedophile ring; seven years for cannabis dealers? And the powers that be wonder why people disrespect the law?
Zoe Young
London

webTitle: Taliban's drug tide sweeps by tiny force

fields.headline: Taliban's drug tide sweeps by tiny force
fields.standfirst: Pakistani agents have made a record haul but their net has many holes
fields.trailText: Wandering round his sprawling estate in the deserts of southern Afghanistan, admiring his 12 Toyota Land Cruisers, Haji Jumar Khan must know he is beyond the reach of the law.
fields.body:
Wandering round his sprawling estate in the deserts of southern Afghanistan, admiring his 12 Toyota Land Cruisers, Haji Jumar Khan must know he is beyond the reach of the law.

At the age of 50 this grey-bearded figure is respected locally as a religious Muslim who has made the pilgrimage to Mecca and frequently gives money to the poor.

But HJK, as Pakistan's anti-narcotics officers call him, also runs one of Afghanistan's biggest heroin production and smuggling operations. For the past seven years he has shipped heroin through the golden deserts of western Pakistan into Iran and eventually on to the streets of Britain.

"They say he is a man with a simple lifestyle, but in terms of dollars he is a millionaire," said Brigadier Abdul Razaq Baloch, who leads the anti-narcotics force in the town of Quetta, near the border with Afghanistan. "The biggest problem is arresting him."

His base near the Afghan frontier village of Chotto puts Mr Khan in the heart of Afghanistan's poppy culture and just beyond the reach of the Pakistani authorities.

The border province of Helmand provided more than half the estimated 3,300 tonnes of opium derived from Afghanistan's poppy crop last year. Close to his estate are 100 small mud-hut laboratories which refine opium to 70% pure heroin.

Drug production is one of the many reasons why international lenders and aid donors have tended to shun the Taliban Taliban militia which governs Afghanistan. Trying to improve its image, the regime has banned poppy farming - officially, at least - and reports indicate that this season some farmers have turned to other crops.

But drugs squad officers say the Taliban, who reaps lucrative taxes from the opium crop, have large stocks of drugs which traffickers will continue to smuggle to the west for many years.

Mr Khan, like other smugglers, has teams of heavily armed drug runners who can reach the Iranian border or the Arabian Sea on the Pakistani coast within four days.

They drive only at night, in new pickups loaded with opium, morphine, heroin and hashish, and equipped with rocket launchers, machine guns and Kalashnikov assault rifles. The drivers rely on night-vision goggles and communicate with the rest of the convoy on secure high-frequency radios.

In return for the risk a driver is paid 3,000 rupees (£35) for a night's work and a gunman 1,000 rupees. The only resistance they face is from the ANF, a small force set up six years ago and led by officers from the Pakistan army.

Three hours' drive south of the Chotto heroin laboratories Captain Saif Riaz sat in his office in a heavily guarded ANF post in the remote village of Dalbandin, in the triangular sleeve of Pakistan that juts beneath Afghanistan to meet the Iranian border. A stone monument at the crossroads commemorates Pakistan's first nuclear test in 1998, held in the Chagai hills near by.

"We are sitting in the drug traffickers' den," he said. Three times in six months his post has been attacked by villagers whose livelihoods are under threat. "This is their area. But the ANF has created a deterrence."

The force has limited resources. Capt Riaz has only 26 men to cover an area of 7,250 sq km (2,800 sq miles). There are two ageing Mi-17 helicopters in Quetta but they are too expensive to use on operations.

So Capt Riaz must rely on paid informers. His men, some of them recruited from army special forces, are said to be ready to move at 15 minutes' notice, and are as heavily armed as the smugglers.

Anyone caught carrying more than 1kg of drugs faces an automatic life sentence or death. The smugglers rarely surrender when confronted. But the ANF cannot hope to stop every convoy. Last year the ANF says it seized 3.8 tonnes of heroin and morphine, 4.3 tonnes of raw opium and 18.8 tonnes of hashish in Baluchistan province, which borders Afghanistan. The total figure was a record, but many thousands of tonnes got through, nevertheless.

The official figures for drug seizures in similar operations across the border in Iran are slightly lower but are reported to have exacted a far higher cost. More than 3,000 Iranian police officers and soldiers are said to have been killed in drug-related battles in the past 20 years.

Five hours' drive up the road in Quetta some of the victims of the trade gather under a canal bridge. Pakistan has a growing population of 4m addicts, known in Urdu slang as jahaz - aeroplanes.

Abdul Bari has been smoking heroin for 10 years. "I have no job. I have to take money from my family. But it is hard to do without this," he said, clutching in his hand a slip of silver foil holding a small brown bead of heroin.

He buys two grams a day from a local peddler, which costs him about 200 rupees (£2.40). Most addicts can get enough to sustain them by begging.

"The big shots, we never see them here. We are suffering but they have made a fortune from us and we have lost everything."

A distraught mother, her hair covered in a blue shawl, came running under the bridge. "

Where is my son? Where is Salam?" she screamed at the addicts.

"My son was an addict and then he went to jail. Now he has come out and started again. I want him to be treated but I don't have the money. Just catch him and hand him over to the police, at least he will be free from the drugs."

webTitle: A day to remember, a groom unlikely to forget

fields.headline: A day to remember, a groom unlikely to forget
fields.trailText: Thailand is billing it as the heavyweight Valentine's Day wedding of the century. Others might regard the ceremony as either the prelude to one of the biggest orgies in south-east Asia, or every groom's wildest fantasy.
fields.body:
Thailand is billing it as the heavyweight Valentine's Day wedding of the century. Others might regard the ceremony as either the prelude to one of the biggest orgies in south-east Asia, or every groom's wildest fantasy.

For after Phlai Buabaan, 24, ties the knot with Pang Oi Jai, also 24, in a shopping centre today in the town of Ayut thaya, 45 miles north of Bangkok, he will be expected to strip off his and her clothes and consummate their marriage immediately.

Organisers say that Mr Buabaan, from Pattaya in southern Thailand, who was selected for the match on account of his virility and good looks, will also copulate with the 19 bridesmaids during the couple's two-month honeymoon.

The local authorities are not only condoning these jumbo nuptials, the city's governor is officiating. Hundreds of guests are expected.

But then Mr Buabaan, whose name means "Blossoming Lotus", is no ordinary stud and Ms Oi Jai, or "Sweetheart", is not entering a thinly veiled form of sexual slavery. The pair are elephants and the whole exercise is a publicity stunt for the Ayutthaya elephant camp.

"Our problem is that we have 20 female elephants here that are in heat and only one young male who has no sexual experience," said Kukrit Khaolamai, the camp manager.

The idea for the wedding came when the staff realised that the two-month mating season, the period the females are on heat, coincided with St Valentine's Day, the traditional feast of love and romance.

"After getting married they will hopefully live well and produce well," Mr Khaolamai said.

He stressed that to prevent any elephantine embarrassment the couple would be led to a screened-off outdoor area for their first intercourse after the ceremony, which will be based on traditional Thai services used for humans.

A dinner jacket is being made for the groom and a long flowing sari for the bride.

"The quicker he makes Oi Jai pregnant the quicker he will be allowed to commit adultery," Mr Khaolamai said.

But success will have its downside for the randy Blossoming Lotus. As soon as he makes the 20 females pregnant, or at the end of the mating season, Mr Buabaan will pack his trunk and head back home to his day job, entertaining tourists at the Pattaya elephant park, 50 miles south-east of Bangkok.

It has not yet been decided whether the couple will ever meet again. "We'll see how things go and take it from there," Mr Khaolamai said.

Elephant shows are extremely popular in Thailand but pachyderms are also used for heavy labour, often in poor conditions reminiscent of slavery. In some areas the supply is outstripping demand, so the animals are sold to Burmese logging companies, in whose service they are in danger of being killed or maimed by landmines.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Peru | Phillipines | India | Iraq | Ukraine | China | Poland
fields.body:
Fujimori faces charges in Peru

The Peruvian attorney general will press corruption charges against former president Alberto Fujimori, a spokesman said yesterday.

Mr Fujimori was removed from office as "morally unfit to govern" after fleeing to Japan last year during spiralling scandals involving his fugitive spy chief. Reuters, Lima

Mrs Estrada to run for senate

Joseph Estrada's wife said yesterday she was to run for the Philippine senate to ease the deposed president's "suffering" by pursuing his anti-poverty programmes and clearing his name.

"If ... the programmes of caring for the poor will mean the vindication of the president, I'll be very happy," Luisa Ejercito Estrada said. AP, Manila

Quake creates fresh water

Pools of fresh water apparently forced from a salty wasteland have appeared at the epicentre of last month's Indian earthquake, near the town of Khangarpur. Scientists say new tributaries have also formed in the Indus river delta .

Meanwhile conservative Muslims in quake-ravaged Surat hurled television sets off rooftops yesterday, after clerics blamed the disaster on the corrupting influence of TV. AP, Khangarpur and Ahmadabad

Gulf war bomb kills children

Two children were killed and their mother injured when a bomb dropped during the 1991 Gulf war exploded in southern Iraq, an Iraqi weekly newspaper reported yesterday.

Quoting civil defence sources, al-Rafidean said the children were killed while playing on grazing land in Kerbala province. Reuters, Baghdad

Kuchma's old deputy arrested

The former Ukranian deputy prime minister Yulia Tymoshenko, a leading opponent of President Leonid Kuchma, has been arrested, her spokesman said yesterday.

Ms Tymoshenko was sacked last month after being indicted on smuggling and forgery charges she said were politically motivated. Reuters, Kiev

Trial in China over website

A Chinese entrepreneur arrested after articles commemorating the 1989 Tiananmen Square democracy demonstrations appeared on his website was tried yesterday on subversion charges.

Huang Qi's trial in western China, which was closed to the public, ended without a verdict being announced. AP, Beijing

Poles warned about Manson

Fearing the effects of "bad ideas" on young people in Poland, the mayor of Warsaw has urged parents to keep their children from a concert by the US shock rocker Marilyn Manson. "It promotes bad ideas, bad values. It promotes violence," Antoni Pietkiewicz said. AP, Warsaw

fields.headline: Fresh quake in El Salvador
fields.standfirst: Special report: natural disasters
fields.trailText: At least 70 people died when an earthquake hit El Salvador yesterday morning, causing renewed destruction and sending waves of panic through a country still traumatised by the massive quake that killed more than 1,000 people one month ago.
fields.body:
At least 70 people died when an earthquake hit El Salvador yesterday morning, causing renewed destruction and sending waves of panic through a country still traumatised by the massive quake that killed more than 1,000 people one month ago.

Dozens of houses already tottering from the January 13 disaster collapsed in rural villages and renewed landslides occurred along the Pan American highway after the quake, measuring 6.1 on the Richter scale, struck.

Important sections of the road, which connects El Salvador with Guatemala and Honduras, were already blocked by rock falls from last month's earthquake. A bus-load of passengers covered by falling earth yesterday survived by climbing out of the windows.

A Red Cross spokesman, Carlos Mendoza, said the worst damage appeared to have been in the central provinces of San Vicente and Cuscatlan. Officials fear many people may have been buried under their collapsed homes. There were unconfirmed reports that a village school collapsed with children inside.

The epicentre of the latest quake, which lasted 15 to 20 seconds, was 12.5 miles south-east of San Salvador, along a faultline already disturbed by the last quake.

In one of the worst-hit towns, Cojutepeque, nine miles east of the capital, almost all the houses came down.

The quake was felt in San Salvador and in neighbouring Guatemala and Honduras.

Gloria de Portillo, a maid whose brother died in the January quake, said: "This is terrible, it never seems to end." There have been almost 2,000 aftershocks since the first quake.

Almost 1.2m in a population of 6m were affected by last month's disaster and the government has put the cost at more than $1bn. Reconstruction work, made all the more urgent with the winter rains only eight weeks away, has hardly begun.

webTitle: Charity for children with cancer 'was run as rip-off'

fields.headline: Charity for children with cancer 'was run as rip-off'
fields.trailText: Two trustees of a successful children's cancer charity ran it "as a business of ripping off the public", a court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Two trustees of a successful children's cancer charity ran it "as a business of ripping off the public", a court was told yesterday.

Deborah Munro, 39, and Ian Dyke, 37, are alleged to have handed over just £5,000 of the £250,000 in street donations raised in a year for the Hands of Hope Children's Cancer Fund. Munro, of Beckton, east London, and Dyke, of Manningtree, Essex, each deny three charges of theft between November 1997 and December 1998.

A jury at Oxford crown court has been told that the two, who were trustees of the registered charity, based in Ilford, Essex, stole most of the money from street collections throughout the south of England.

The prosecution alleges that Munro and Dyke ran a team of collectors who raised a "conservative" £250,000 during the year, of which less than £12,000 was paid into the charity's Lloyds Bank account.

Financial records seized at the charity's offices and the defendants' homes after a joint operation by Thames Valley police and the charity commission "gave a totally false picture" of the scale of the collections and "made it impossible to say exactly how much money was stolen", the prosecutor, Nigel Daly, told the jury.

"These books are false, they are there for the benefit of the charity commission and they are doubling up to support the paltry sums paid into the bank account," he said.

"The collectors were not volunteers, but employees. This wasn't a charity, this was a business of ripping off the public in the name of people giving to a children's cancer charity."

Mr Daly added: "It was a business with a turnover in excess of a quarter of a million pounds a year. Less than £5,000 in that year actually went to children's cancer relief. Only £11,000 went into the charity's bank account.

"Huge amounts went elsewhere. The thefts were from members of the public who thought they were giving money to the charity."

fields.headline: Boxer mourned
fields.standfirst: Lonely death of Italian remembered in Raging Bull
fields.trailText: Lonely death of Italian remembered in Raging Bull
fields.body:
A boxer who electrified an era with his grace and glamour was mourned in Italy yesterday after stumbling under a train, unrecognisable as a destitute, abandoned, sick, old man.

Tiberio Mitri, whose world title fight against Jake La Motta was immortalised in the film Raging Bull, was sliced in two after shambling towards a passenger train leaving central Rome. He failed to hear - or ignored - its warning horn and made no effort to get off the tracks.

It took the police several hours on Monday to identify him as the Trieste Tiger, whose fairytale life slid into tragedy and poverty.

Along with the tributes there were recriminations against senators for sitting on a bill to pay higher pensions to retired sports figures. Mitri's had been cited as an urgent case.

Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases may have confused the 74-year-old into thinking he could board a train for what he imagined would be a triumphant homecoming to Trieste, a friend told La Repubblica.

Apart from the local charity Sant'Egidio, which visited him in his tiny flat, he was largely forgotten.

Beginning at 13, Mitri became Italy's best postwar boxer, and was European champion in 1949-50.

Blond, blue-eyed and babyfaced, he burnished a golden image by marrying Fulvia Franco, voted Miss Italy in 1948.

Technique, grit and imagination compensated for his relative lack of power, and he was chosen to fight La Motta in New York's Madison Square Garden on July 12 1950.

Distracted by his wife's efforts to become a Hollywood starlet, he did not prepare properly and lost on points to the Bronx Bull after 15 rounds. "My punches were like caresses, his were blows of mortar. Jake was too strong for me," he said.

Nevertheless he returned home a hero and reclaimed his European title in 1954 by knocking out the Briton Randolph Turpin.

He lost it the same year and retired. By then his private life was spinning out of control. A messy divorce dominated the headlines, and he tried to become a painter and an actor.

Bit-parts in films led to nothing, and he turned to alcohol and heroin. Convictions for drink driving and drug possession followed.

His 30-year-old son Alex died of a heroin overdose in 1981. His only other child, Fulvia, the daughter of a second marriage, died of Aids in 1986.

A broken man, he propped up bars in Rome and lost touch with friends as disease ravaged his mind and body. It is thought that in his final days he neglected to take his medicine and lost his sense of reality.

A friend, Claudio Lazzaro, wrote in Corriere della Sera: "He needed a network of assistance. We were trying to organise it. A battle against time. Lost. Death came first."

The train was travelling at under 20mph when Mitri approached. Three times it sounded the alarm, but the once-lightning reflexes did not react.

webTitle: Pressure on prince Charles over Saudi visit

fields.headline: Pressure on prince over Saudi visit
fields.trailText: Prince Charles came under fire from Amnesty International yesterday after palace officials refused to say whether he will raise the issue of detained Britons during a visit to Saudi Arabia.
fields.body:
Prince Charles came under fire from Amnesty International yesterday after palace officials refused to say whether he will raise the issue of detained Britons during a visit to Saudi Arabia.

Alexander Mitchell, chief anaesthetics technician at a hospital in Riyadh, faces possible beheading after confessing on Saudi television to the car-bomb killing of another Briton, Christopher Rodway. Five other Britons are being held for alleged alcohol offences.

During his three-day visit, which starts on Friday, the prince will open an exhibition of paintings by himself and Prince Khalid al-Faisal.

He will also attend an awards ceremony for achievement in science and social sciences, and discuss plans for a fund called the Saudi youth business trust.

Although the visit is described as non-political, the prince is expected to meet senior members of the Saudi royal family. Yesterday British officials refused to say whether the prince would raise the question of the detained Britons.

"It is not ruled in or out," one said.

A spokeswoman at St James's Palace said: "The prince will discuss a very wide range of issues, but his programme is still fairly fluid and there is no set agenda."

Amnesty yesterday urged the prince to raise the matter. "He is clearly representing the United Kingdom in his dealings with the Saudi authorities," a spokesman said.

"We hope he will use his influence and raise with his Saudi hosts issues such as torture and unfair and secretive trials, particularly in the light of the current detention of a British national."

It is understood that the prince took advice from the Foreign Office before confirming his trip, which had been planned for some time.

A Foreign Office spokesman said yesterday: "Through our ambassador Britain is taking every opportunity to raise these cases at the highest level."

The ambassador, Derek Plumbly, met the Saudi interior minister, Prince Nayef, last week and consular officials were allowed to visit Mr Mitchell in jail last Sunday - a week after his televised confession.

Yesterday a Saudi man convicted of murder was beheaded in Qaseem province, bringing the number of executions in Saudi Arabia since the start of the year to 19. Last year 125 people were put to death.

fields.headline: Behaviour orders 'marginalised family'
fields.trailText: Lawyers acting for three brothers who were the subject of one of the first anti-social behaviour orders are attempting to get the court of appeal to change the law.
fields.body:
Lawyers acting for three brothers who were the subject of one of the first anti-social behaviour orders are attempting to get the court of appeal to change the law.

The court will sit in Manchester to hear the case of teenagers Sean, Joseph and Michael McCann. Their solicitor says their lives had been badly affected by the order, which effectively banned them from contact with members of their family who live in the Beswick area of the city.

At present anti-social behaviour orders are dealt with by the courts as civil proceedings, which require less burden of proof than criminal proceedings. The boys' lawyer wants this to change.

The brothers, aged 16, 15 and 13, had been accused of creating a climate of fear and violence on the Beswick estate when they were made the subject of two-year anti-social behaviour orders at the end of 1999.

"It has been very difficult for the boys' parents and their younger children," said their solicitor, Gillian Crossley. "To some people, they achieved enormous notoriety and gained hero status and to the ordinary population they were seen as the scum of society. The family were marginalised and the anti-social behaviour order caused more trouble for them."

The children, who have legal aid, have already had appeals to lift the orders rejected by Manchester crown court and the high court.

If the appeal on February 26 is successful all 147 anti-social behaviour orders across the country could be challenged.

But Chief Inspector Dave Thompson of Greater Manchester police said the anti-social behaviour orders had been part of a series of measures which had achieved a 30% reduction in crime in Beswick.

fields.headline: 'I saw Algerian soldiers massacre civilians'
fields.trailText: The French foreign minister, Hubert Védrine, made a flying five-hour visit to Algiers yesterday as tension between the two countries was increased by allegations that Algerian troops are as guilty of civilian atrocities as the Islamist militants they are supposed to be fighting.
fields.body:
The French foreign minister, Hubert Védrine, made a flying five-hour visit to Algiers yesterday as tension between the two countries was increased by allegations that Algerian troops are as guilty of civilian atrocities as the Islamist militants they are supposed to be fighting.

Mr Védrine pointedly refused to discuss the accusation, made by a former Algerian army officer, Habib Souaidia, in a book published in Paris last week.

"I am here to work, to feed and develop the important links between France and Algeria," he said before a meeting with President Abdelaziz Bouteflika.

The Algerian government is furious at the credence the French media and intellectuals have given to The Dirty War, a detailed and shocking account of almost a decade of alleged Algerian army involvement in the massacre of tens of thousands of innocent civilians.

"I have seen colleagues burn alive a 15-year-old child. I have seen soldiers disguising themselves as terrorists and massacring civilians," Mr Souaidia wrote. "I have seen colonels kill mere suspects in cold blood. I have seen officers torture fundamentalists to death. I have seen too many things."

A group of prominent French and north African intellectuals has seized on Mr Souaidia's account to denounce France's the kid-glove approach to the Bouteflika regime, calling it "complicity in crimes against humanity".

"For too long the French government has supported Algerian policy which, under cover of a fight against terrorism, aims at nothing less than the eradication, both political and physical, of any opposition whatsoever," the group wrote in the daily Le Monde.

More than 100,000 people, most of them civilians, are estimated to have died violently in Algeria since the government, backed by the armed forces, cancelled a general election in which Muslim fundamentalists had taken a commanding lead in 1992.

According to a leaked Algerian army report, 9,200 people were killed last year alone. The deaths continued last weekend, when 27 civilians - including eight women and 13 children aged from six months to 14 years - were slaughtered in Berrouaghia, a shantytown 60 miles south of Algiers.

In Algeria, The Dirty War has met with outrage in the government-controlled press, which accused Mr Souaidia of being a "common thief" and a "soldier turned criminal".

The former officer's family in the small eastern town of Tebessa have received threatening visits from army security officers, and his brother's video rental shop has been ransacked by unknown intruders.

Mr Souaidia, a volunteer special forces parachute officer, fled Algeria to France last summer after being sentenced to four years in an army prison on theft charges which he says were trumped up.

He says he witnessed many killings staged by the Algerian army to look as if they were done by fundamentalists.

"The generals want to stay in power," he said yesterday. "To justify that, the war has to continue, so we can say to the international community, 'Look, these are the terrorists we are fighting against, look what they do. We need help, give us money'."

Mr Souaidia says his first experience of the "dirty war" came in spring 1993, when he had just left the special forces college. His platoon picked up a group of 20 officers from a supposedly pro-Islamist village where it had dropped them off an hour earlier. Back in barracks, one showed Mr Souaidia his blood-stained bayonet, and mimed drawing it across his throat.

"The day after next, the local and national papers announced a dozen deaths in a terrorist attack in that village," he said. "I understood. I had just taken part, indirectly, in a massacre."

He also recalls accompanying commandos from the army's anti-terrorist squad to Lakhdaria, a reputed rebel stronghold 50 miles from Algiers. Disguised as bearded fundamentalists, the soldiers' mission was to kidnap six suspected activists.

"All the suspects of course ended up being killed," he wrote. "We arrested people, we tortured them, we killed them and then we burned their bodies." In that region, he added, "I must have seen at least 100 people liquidated".

The unit's barracks in Lakhdaria, by a main road, was transformed into a torture centre. Locked in the cellar, suspects "were tortured by military security".

"Alsatian dogs were let loose on them, they were made to sit on broken bottles or to drink bleach. Anyone who entered there was dead; it didn't matter if they had done nothing at all."

The book is the first inside account of the workings of today's Algerian army, naming places, dates and officers in verifiable detail. It is all the more credible because Mr Souaidia shows no sympathy for the rebel cause. "I simply want the lies to end," he said yesterday, calling for an international commission to investigate massacres he believes have taken up to 200,000 lives: twice the official estimates.

"We must arrest and judge those who are guilty, not just the fundamentalists ... Everybody says it's the terrorists who do the killing, but the reality is different: the generals have done the same thing."

France is Algeria's biggest trading partner, selling it £1.6bn in goods and services last year and spending £1.4 bn on its oil and gas. A French foreign ministry spokesman said Mr Védrine would not be raising the subject of Mr Souaidia's memoirs.

"France's position on alleged human rights violations in Algeria will be coordinated with the European Union," he said.

webTitle: Council's new restrictions on cigarette breaks

fields.headline: Smoking gun?
fields.standfirst: Is it fair to make people clock in and out for a fag break?  Patrick Weir on a Derbyshire council's new restrictions
fields.trailText: Is it fair to make people clock in and out for a fag break? Patrick Weir on a Derbyshire council's new restrictions
fields.body:
The sight of smokers huddled in small groups on the edges of their smoke-free workplaces, has become a familiar one. Yet non-smoking colleagues can contemplate no such breaks to allow them routinely to sit back and switch off for 10 minutes, much less leave the building.

Over weeks and months, non-smokers can claim to have worked considerably longer than those vacating their chairs up to three or four times a day to have a cigarette.

In an attempt to redress the balance - and, in the process, perhaps even wean its addicted employees off the weed - Amber Valley borough council, Derbyshire, is moving to regulate smokers' breaks, while also offering smokers the opportunity to seek guidance on giving up from occupational health advisers. From April 1, cigarette breaks at the authority will be restricted to one in the morning and one in the afternoon. Should these prove insufficient, staff will be required to clock out for further breaks.

The approach represents a compromise, the council having previously considered banning smokers' breaks. "We always supported the policy which prohibited smoking in the building, because of the risk of passive smoking," says Simon Holmes, local branch secretary of Unison, the public services union. "But when the authority wanted to abolish smokers' breaks outside, it then became a human rights issue and we opposed it."

As long as the idea is not abused by the management, Holmes says, he is happy with an initiative which is "sympathetic" to smokers but also ensures that lost time is made up. "This was, understandably, the major grievance of non-smokers, who aren't inclined to take as many breaks."

Smokers currently number 45 in a workforce of 300 at Amber Valley. And according to David Holmes, borough personnel and development officer, the new policy has met no opposition. "It has set an agenda and strikes a sensible balance," he says. "Consequently, smoking is no longer an issue with the staff.

"On average, most smokers tend to take two or three breaks a day, and the new guidelines will accommodate these. I think this is fair. And some smokers do, of course, work through these breaks. Having a cigarette does not prevent someone, for example, from reading a report."

Should someone feel the need to excuse themselves five or six times, so upsetting the rhythm of the office, Holmes says he would "obviously have a word in their ear - just as I would with anyone who made six trips to buy snacks".

However, not everybody is content with the fact that this policy is based, at least in part, on the premise that smokers - intentionally or not - take liberties at work. "To my knowledge, there is no evidence that the productivity levels of smokers are any lower than those of non-smokers," says Juliette Torres, spokeswoman for Forest, the smokers' rights group. "So even if they do spend less time in the office, it's irrelevant. And just how efficient would smokers be if they weren't allowed to light up?"

The key issues here, argues Torres, are trust and loyalty. "A responsible and adult workforce shouldn't need to concern itself with someone nipping out for a cigarette," she says. "We all have moments when we stare out of the window and daydream, or take time out for ourselves in the bathroom. It doesn't mean we're not pulling our weight. When we are refreshed, we are more productive.

"Trusting your colleagues in this respect means that the work ethic need not suffer. Otherwise, it could get very silly indeed. Can you imagine having to clock out before visiting the loo? Of course not. Unless smokers are abusing a system, clocking in and out seems a heavy-handed response to their habit."

Not surprisingly, Amanda Sandford, of anti-smoking group Ash, insists that smoking should not be a factor in any area of modern life. "It is out of sync with our health awareness and the improved lifestyle that goes with it," she says. "As for the requirement that smokers at work clock out for their breaks, this can only be a good thing. Quite apart from the fact that they spend more time away from their desks, they also, on average, take twice as much time off work than non-smokers."

That Amber Valley is also offering its staff anti-smoking aids, such as nicotine patches and chewing gum, is only to be applauded, says Sandford. "It's a further move in the right direction, as their employer acknowledges their addiction and wants to help them to kick it," she says.

Holmes insists that the authority is not putting any pressure on smokers to give up. "But if a member of staff is thinking about giving it a go, we can be of assistance," he says. "I really don't think an employer can be fairer than that."
