webTitle: The price of losing a child

fields.headline: The price of losing a child
fields.standfirst: Pain of bereavement compounded by benefits system
fields.trailText: Parents who suffer the loss of a child after lengthy illness face the further blow of a sudden and substantial drop in income through withdrawal of benefits, according to research today portraying the social security system as deeply unsympathetic to family grief.
fields.body:
Parents who suffer the loss of a child after lengthy illness face the further blow of a sudden and substantial drop in income through withdrawal of benefits, according to research today portraying the social security system as deeply unsympathetic to family grief.

In the case of a lone parent previously caring full-time for a teenager, the cut in income was found to be as much as 72%. In the case of a two-parent family, where the father earned £18,000 a year, the loss of benefits amounted to a quarter of the net household income.

The report, Financial Implications of the Death of a Child, calls for the tapering off of invalid care allowance or disability living allowance after a child has died. It also proposes introduction of a bereavement allowance, payable for up to six months after the death, or a one-off grant.

Anne Corden, co-author of the study says: "When the ending of entitlement to social security benefits has such profound, emotional significance, the way it is handled becomes extremely important."

The research, commissioned by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation and carried out by the social policy research unit at the University of York, involved interviews with bereaved parents in 17 families, contacted through a children's hospice. A postal survey was also conducted of all 21 children's hospices, and other bereavement groups, to gauge whether the interviews were representative.

All parents interviewed had felt the financial impact of loss or reduction of benefits, even if they were not already facing financial difficulties when their child died.

The effect was found to be compounded by the financial strains of caring for a terminally sick child, leaving many families in debt. Some of the parents had reduced their hours of work, or had left paid em ployment altogether to care for their child. None of the lone mothers had been able to do paid work during the final years of their child's life.

Such reduction in income was often accompanied by extra costs, such as increased utility bills and abnormally high telephone expenses, as families tried to keep in touch with caring staff, home services, relatives and friends.

The researchers found that families in most difficulty were those whose income only just disqualified them for a social fund grant.

Co-author, Roy Sainsbury, says that the withdrawal of benefits after the child's death puts parents "on a cliff edge". He argues that every benefits office should have a member of staff trained to deal with bereavement, to avoid inappropriate and insensitive treatment.

Financial Implications of the Death of a Child is available at £10.95 plus £1.50 p&p from the Family Policy Studies Centre, 9 Tavistock Place, London WC1H 9SN (020-7388 5900).

webTitle: Lessons exposing professionals to experiences of care

fields.headline: Straight talking
fields.standfirst: Raekha Prasad on lessons exposing professionals to experiences of care
fields.trailText: Raekha Prasad on lessons exposing professionals to experiences of care
fields.body:
When Christopher asks the class, "Any questions?", every student has one. Some want more detail about the presentation, others ask their four attentive teachers for advice. But that is as far as the lesson goes in following educational convention.

In more ways than one, this teacher-pupil relationship is topsy-turvy: five young people - aged between 17 and 20 - who have all spent a chunk of their childhood in care are giving a lesson to a group of social workers.

Started in April last year, the group of "teachers", who have named themselves Yippee (young independent people presenting educational enter tainment), talk to adult professionals about their experience of fostering, custody, residential care and independent living in and around Manchester in order to influence the way they deal with future generations in care.

So far, lessons have been given to youth workers; social work students in Cheshire, Salford and at Manchester University; teachers in Bolton and careers officers. Last year, three Yippee members went to parliament to discuss care services with ministers.

In response to Christopher's question, one student wants to know why Kate - a 19-year-old member of Yippee who, since the age of 14, has been fostered, lived in shared accommodation and two women's refugees - has been moved so many times. "I didn't have a close relationship with my social worker," she says. "I felt that he was never there."

Natalie, a 17-year-old member of the group, has been in and out of care since she was nine. She tells the class that her social worker always spent time asking about her twin when she should have been asking about her. Rosetta, who described in her presentation how she had had several foster parents and been to 21 primary schools, tells a student that she was a quiet child. "I didn't say boo to nobody. My social worker told me to go upstairs and I listened at the top to her telling my foster parents what had happened to me."

Yippee's sister group, Cats (citizens as trainers), which is made up of around 10 adults who use health, social and benefit services, shares the founding principle that each member has skills and abilities not only to offer their students, but also to each other. "The idea is not just about the groups talking to professionals," says Annette Rimmer, a lecturer in social work and policy, who initiated both groups. "Close relationships are built between members and confidence is then raised. Social services always separates people into groups, such as mental health and disability. But the groups have the shared experience of disrespect as service users."

This is backed up by all members. "People don't realise how the spoken word can wound," says Sue, a member of Cats, who is a health and social service user. Rosetta says she was made to feel "like a piece of paper" when she was in care. Brod, a Cats member and father of a disabled child, argues that if social services had to sell their services to users "no one would buy them".

In the two years since Cats was formed, members have given their services to student nurses, social workers and related conferences in the north-west. Both groups are eager to be called upon from every corner of the country.

The seeds of Cats were sown after Rimmer held a public meeting, inviting members of community organisations who were interested in forming a training group. Yippee was later set up in collaboration with Barnardo's Manchester leaving care service. Kim Harwood, of Barnardo's, and Rimmer offer backseat support, allowing members of both groups to lead themselves - a principle of self-directed group work which was developed by academics Audrey Mullender and David Ward, of De Montfort University, Leicester.

Funded by Salford University's faculty of community, social and healthcare, Barnardo's and by donations from training sessions, both groups meet weekly to plan sessions and discuss group policy.

Chris, a Cats member and mother of two, who uses both social and health services, had been home-bound and felt useless before she joined the group. "Not because of my disability but because I didn't know how to be useful," she says.

"Life experience is our only training. There's a lot of financial strain on services, but improving a service is not always about money. Sometimes it's about a different approach."

Students leaving the Yippee session agree. One says: "We work within the care service but we haven't lived it." Adds another: "They can be honest about what happened and we found out that they don't feel listened to." "There are barriers that are not broken down."

Not all students who have been "taught" by Yippee and Cats are so accepting of the role reversal. Despite both groups championing the positive as well as highlighting the negative aspects of the services they receive, some professionals have clearly felt unhappy playing student to people they are used to being in charge of. One teacher became annoyed during Yippee's presentation and told the group that a colleague had suffered a nervous breakdown resulting from the stress of the job.

Rimmer says that because of some resistance from professionals, group members never give sessions alone. "Some people have been teaching or in social work for a long time and they feel uncomfortable having the power relationship turned around," she says. "Students are forced for the first time to confront their own attitudes to people they provide a service to. They're no different from other lecturers but some people do think they know it all."

"We don't want the students to go away with any negative reactions," Brod says. "There is good practice out there."

Aware of how some professionals feel, Natalie says that she avoids saying "you" accusatively when she gives a presentation. But she doubts that all her students will take what the group says to heart. She says: "We edit our lives down because there are some things you just can't tell strangers."

But she adds that even if it has no impact on some students, it benefits her. "It's like a form of therapy," she says. "We're having to live in the past. I'm shaking every time I do it. For most of us, it's the first time we've talked about what happened to us."

More information about Yippee can be found at www.Yippee-group.org or contact Kim Harwood on 0161- 226 6722. Cats is at 0161-295 2482.

fields.headline: Underdog's champion
fields.standfirst: Geoff Thompson, karate hero with a caring touch
fields.trailText: Profile: Geoff Thompson, karate hero with a caring touch
fields.body:
Geoff Thompson is just the sort of person the government has in mind to act as neighbourhood champions in deprived areas, under its commitment to neighbourhood renewal. The hope is that these champions will provide a link between local people and the array of statutory and voluntary organisations delivering services and pumping in funding to the 88 poorest areas.

Thompson, five times world karate champion, and founder of Youth Charter for Sport (YCS) in Moss Side, Manchester, should be pleased that his work is being held up as a model. But he is concerned that the endorsement is little more than lip service from a government he sees as full of fine words and policies, but lacking any real commitment to changing the lives of disadvantaged young people.

It's easy to see why he's formed that view. Last week, YCS almost shut up shop after seven years, when the little voluntary sector and corporate funding that it had dried up. It is now reliant on the goodwill of a handful of volunteers, including Thompson's wife, Janice, also a former world karate gold medallist.

If the government thinks Thompson is such a hero, why has it neither funded his organisation nor consulted him on how to tackle youth crime? Last summer, Tony Blair appointed former BBC director general Lord Birt as his adviser on "yob culture" - a post Thompson's journey from the streets to the victor's rostrum would arguably have better equipped him to hold.

"I was a young, insecure black male who was bullied at my school in Hackney for having a Wolverhampton accent," he says. "Stressed teachers, overcrowded classrooms, underachieving pupils, gangs of youths pinning teachers against the wall - none of this is new. It was happening in the 70s. What saved me from being detained at her majesty's pleasure was karate. From seven to adolescence, karate gave me targets to aim for. Every two months I won another belt. Thompson, now 43, talks with a passion usually reserved for the pulpit, and it comes as no surprise to learn that his intensity of purpose comes from a strong spiritual belief. But while it inspires young people from the inner cities who have heard him speak, he fears his approach is met with suspicion by some in authority who view him as a loose cannon. Perhaps that is why he was passed over last year as chair of Sport England, an organisation he first joined in 1988, when it was then called the Sports Council.

Winning five gold medals opened doors for Thompson. In 1988, he was part of an influential body of sportsmen, academics, business leaders and politicians which drew up a report arguing that sport could keep teenagers out of trouble. On his move to Manchester, he became north-west regional chairman of the Sports Aid Foundation.

In 1993, he set up YCS after 12-year-old Benji Stanley was shot dead in Moss Side. He says: "YCS's aim was, and still is, to utilise sports and their ambassadors as catalysts in providing young people with an opportunity through sport to develop in life and develop more positive attitudes to society."

More than 40 projects, and numerous lecture tours, later, Thompson admits it is difficult to quantify how many youngsters have been helped through YCS. But the fact that its programme has been adopted in 16 countries, and counts Sydney Olympics 200 metres silver medallist Darren Campbell among its success stories, is testimony that it is doing something right.

Thompson has spent three years struggling to raise £4m to open a social centre of excellence for young people in Toxteth, Liverpool. But despite government plaudits, he feels excluded - like the youngsters he's trying to help. "The first I heard that I was being held up as a community champion was in the press," he says. "I'd like to think that what I've been through would afford me the opportunity to be included."

The hope is that these champions will provide a link between local people and the array of statutory and voluntary organisations delivering services and pumping in funding to the 88 poorest areas. webTitle: Politicians warned to take pensioners' issues seriously

fields.headline: Grey areas
fields.standfirst: Politicians warned to take pensioners' issues seriously
fields.trailText: Politicians warned to take pensioners' issues seriously
fields.body:
The votes of half of Britain's 12m pensioners are up for grabs at the coming general election, according to a poll commissioned by Age Concern. The findings are driven home by the charity today in a video manifesto, seeking to ensure that the political parties take on board issues concerning older people.

The video, entitled Dignity, Security, Opportunity, is one of the first such manifestos produced by a voluntary organisation. It features a seven-year-old schoolgirl, Ann Tivey, from Oxfordshire, who says: "It's not just the old people who should be thinking about this. I'm worried about what's going to happen to me when I get to be as old as my nana, unless someone does something now to make things better."

She appears alongside pensioners who share their experiences of ageism and poor public services and set out five priorities for the election. These are: ending pensioner poverty; outlawing discrimination against older people; banning ageism in the NHS and public services; abolishing charges for those who need long-term care; and investing in cheap and reliable public transport to prevent the isolation that many older people suffer. Gordon Lishman, director general of Age Concern England, says: "As Ann points out in our video, more of us than ever before will live to a ripe old age. What lies in store in later life for our children starts with today's politicians.

"The decisions made at this general election will determine whether today's and tomorrow's older people will live in poverty or independence, in sickness or in health, on the margins of society or at its centre, as a resented burden on the state or as equal members of society."

The charity's poll was carried out among 2,000 people of all ages in January and earlier this month. It suggests that some 6m people aged over 60 have not decided which political party to vote for. "For years, older voters have been taken for granted by the parties as having fixed voting intentions," says Lishman. "This is no longer true."

When compared to the results of an identical poll in January 1997, ahead of the general election that May, the findings also indicate that turnout by voters of all ages may fall by as much as 7%. The new poll predicts that the turnout will be 64 to 67%, compared to 71% four years ago. However, the falling interest is entirely among younger and middle-age groups. The num ber of older people intending to vote remains identical.

The charity's manifesto says the most effective way to attack pensioner poverty is by providing a basic pension of at least £90 a week for a single pensioner and £135 for a couple, plus necessary housing costs, uprated each year. It claims that this would reduce greatly the need for reliance on means-tested benefits that are plagued by low take-up and prevent older people with modest incomes from saving or working in retirement without losing out.

Age Concern criticises the government's plan to introduce a pension credit from April 2003. This will add additional complexity, it says, and threatens to leave older people on modest incomes still contemplating a much higher withdrawal of income than that faced by most taxpayers.

The video also calls for a health, housing and care system which offers independence and security for all, and new opportunities for older people to work, volunteer, learn and retrain. It is accompanied by a traditional written manifesto and will be shown to audiences in town squares across the country as part of Age Concern's general election roadshow.

webTitle: How the responsibilities of parenthood place a heavy burden on young parents

fields.headline: Baby blues
fields.standfirst: How the responsibilities of parenthood place a heavy burden on young parents
fields.trailText: How the responsibilities of parenthood place a heavy burden on young parents
fields.body:
Gary Vaughan was 22 when his 18-year-old girlfriend got pregnant. He was shocked - but at the same time he was happy. "It made me feel good about myself, knowing I was going to be a father," he admits.

During the pregnancy, their year-and-a-half relationship turned sour. "We yelled and screamed at each other, and after she had Tyler it was murder," Vaughan recalls. "I was totally left out. He was a mummy's boy. Every time he was left with me he'd scream until his mum came back. It used to stress me out. I used to break down and cry."

Amanda Bawor admits she pushed Vaughan away. "The pressure involved was immense. We had a lot of arguments and just grew apart." When Tyler was nine months old, Vaughan moved in with a friend, but he was determined to be involved in his child's upbringing. Now he comes round to look after his 18-month-old son three times a week when Bawor is at college or studying for her bookkeeping exams.

Vaughan would like to have his own flat and to be able to provide for Tyler financially. For this reason, he's on the New Deal scheme. But he says: "As long as you're there for your boy and he knows that you love him, and you've got a bond, that's the most important thing."

Vaughan 's views will come as a surprise to most people. Young fathers often quickly lose contact with mother and baby and are stigmatised by society as irresponsible, feckless and uncaring. But according to a new report, It's Like That, from the Prince's Trust, Vaughan is not alone in his experience of parenthood.

Of the 100 disadvantaged 16 to 25-year-olds interviewed across the UK about their views on work, crime and parenthood, uninvolved fathers expressed deep pain and sorrow at not being able to see their children on a regular basis.

While the views of unemployed young people and those on the edge, or already in, the criminal justice system, backs up much government thinking on what these groups need - from basic literacy and numeracy skills to role models - the young parents' attitudes should make policymakers sit up and take note.

With the highest rate of teenage pregnancy in Europe - some 90,000 in England each year - it is crucial that misconceptions do not shape the services for this important section of society. As Lesley Morphy, director of policy and development at the trust, says: "If we could better support young fathers' desire to be more responsible in bringing up their children, there are lessons to be learnt here." It's Like That attempts to give young people a voice, and to ensure that the trust reflects their views in the support programmes it delivers.

The research also found that 49% of young mothers gained a sense of confidence, self-worth and achievement and 44% were more motivated to plan for a better future. Above all, they resented any sense that they should feel inferior as mothers because of their age, said that mothering came naturally and that they didn't need parenting skills courses. What they did call for were more social places to meet other young parents.

On the downside, more than 60% felt that childcare problems made it difficult for them to get work, many had problematic relationships with their child's father, and although 70% of mothers agreed that the baby was the best thing in their life, a third would have valued more advice before getting pregnant and regretted not waiting until they were older to have a child.

While young people undoubtedly need ways other than parenthood to fill gaps in their lives, the key messages, says Morphy, are that young parents need guidance building adult relationships and far more family planning, perhaps from mentors their own age.

Bawor and Vaughan, both brought up in care, are benefiting from Gurgles, a parent toddler group in Chatham, Kent, they helped to establish with support from the trust. "We meet once a week," says Amanda. "We invited a health visitor and someone from the job centre and we've learnt about first aid. We're also going to hear more about the New Deal for lone parents. All the young mum's want to work."

It's Like That: the Views and Hopes of Disadvantaged Young People, price £17.50, is available from the Prince's Trust on 020-7543 1234.

webTitle: Struggle to get a short-term loan of a wheelchair for a child

fields.headline: At breaking point
fields.standfirst: Joanna Griffin's struggle to get a short-term loan of a wheelchair for her daughter
fields.trailText: Joanna Griffin's struggle to get a short-term loan of a wheelchair for her daughter
fields.body:
On the morning my four-year-old daughter was discharged from the hospital in Paris, where she had been staying for 10 days with a broken leg, they gave us a wheelchair to test drive. You'll be needing one of these at home, they said. We spent the morning navigating the corridors of the ward, unaware of the scale of problems that lay ahead.

I was beginning to get worried, though. By then, I had already spent several days trying to organise a wheelchair in London for Ella's return. We had been told that Ella would have to lie more or less flat for at least six weeks. She was encased in plaster all the way down one leg from her waist, was helpless and was as stiff as a board.

First, I had called our GP's surgery, which advised me to call the Red Cross and the nearest NHS wheelchair clinic. My mother was also on the case, but our calls had so far turned up nothing. The Red Cross had nothing suitable for a child and, apparently, there would be no NHS wheelchair clinic at the Parkside clinic - our nearest centre, in Southall, west London - for at least two weeks. They would send us a referral form in the meantime.

The GP's surgery then suggested social services. But everywhere we turned it was the same story. Finally, the local occupational therapy department spelled it out. "Funny thing, wheelchairs - they are in a sort of no man's land," we were told. "We can arrange them for permanent use, but not short-term. Try physiotherapy at the hospital."

So, we tried physiotherapy at Ealing hospital, as well as the children's disabilities unit, the paediatric ward, the fracture clinic and St John Ambulance. It felt like being stuck in revolving doors. Have you tried the wheelchair clinic? Tried the Red Cross? And sometimes the answers were strange: "Perhaps you can buy one at the mobility shop." Or: "Have you tried Boots?"

On the day we arrived back in London, we went to see the GP and sat with Ella lying rigid across us in the waiting room. It was obvious that we urgently needed a wheelchair, the doctor said, and Ealing hospital had failed to come up with one because we were not yet registered there. We got a letter for the fracture clinic, requesting a wheelchair and explaining our situation. The GP's secretary would ring the clinic in the morning, find out how to proceed and then call us.

Receiving no call, we rang the secretary, who suggested we "get down to casualty and take it from there". It seemed a sure way of getting a wheelchair - sitting in A&E with Ella's rigid body lying across the seats.But after she had been registered and her x-rays seen by the consultant, the nurse told us it was not going to happen. "If the accident had happened here," she said, "the hospital would have sorted it out."

My husband was going away the next day and I don't drive. I began to panic. Without a car, the only way to carry Ella was in my arms. Surely the hospital could find a wheelchair for an immobile four-year-old. So I declared: "I am not leaving this hospital without a wheelchair."

Several nurses tried to help us. "Have you thought of a pram with a plank across it?" one suggested. Again, though, we were told that there would be no wheelchair clinic for two weeks.

We waited most of the afternoon for the hospital's senior physiotherapist to come out of a meeting. She was unable to help; there were only two wheelchairs in the hospital (which serves a borough of 1m people) for the weekend, but she would call the wheelchair clinic and try to speed up our referral. Finally, we were offered a baby buggy so low and narrow that Ella would have had to lie with her arms clamped to her sides and her cast sticking up in the air. We left empty-handed - except, of course, for Ella.

About 10 days later, we received a second copy of the wheelchair clinic's referral form. I rang and was told that our request had been passed to the short-term loan unit in Willesden - the other side of Ealing from Southall. Did I want the number? By this stage, however, I had more or less given up on getting a wheelchair from our local services and we had grown accustomed either to carrying Ella in our arms or improvising with a borrowed buggy that had been made abroad and had an unusually sturdy frame.

Rita Moloney, office manager of the Parkside wheelchair clinic in Southall told me later that the clinic always "moves heaven and earth for children" and that, had we taken Ella to any of Parkside's other three sites in west London immediately on our return from France, we would have left the same day with a chair.

But how were we supposed to know this if our GP, social services, the hospital and even the clinic's own staff were unaware of it?

Moloney says we were misinformed. The Red Cross supplies short-term wheelchairs to adults, but rarely has chairs for children. The Parkside wheelchair clinic was set up in part to meet that need.

In Ella's case, it did not.

webTitle: Malcolm Dean: Only fools and Trojan horses

fields.headline: Only fools and Trojan horses
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: One threat social services face from care trusts is that the unification achieved in the 70s will again be fragmented
fields.body:
Is the welfare state's fifth arm about to be cut off? Will social service departments, which have survived a succession of child abuse scandals in the past 30 years, finally be dismantled by health ministers determined to free acute hospital beds from being blocked by frail elderly patients? Social service directors last week began their fightback.

The Trojan horse comes in the form of care trusts proposed by the current health and social care bill. Under the 1999 Health Act, social care and health bodies were encouraged to experiment with pooled budgets to improve services. All manner of cooperative initiatives have begun to flow. Mental health trusts have emerged in which control and accountability have been equally divided between the two services.

But under the much more centrally driven system in the new bill, in districts where the health secretary deems services are failing, he will be able to direct social service and health authorities to set up care trusts. They would be directly accountable to the NHS.

Social services face two threats: their biggest spending service, the care of elderly people, will be hived off to NHS care trusts; and the unification of services achieved by the Seebohn reform in the early 1970s will once again be fragmented. All of its many disparate services - elderly people, children, mental health, learning disabilities, adoption - could be hived off into independent free standing trusts.

At one level, Seebohn's unifying umbrella was an artificial construct. There was not as much crossover, or synergy, as some argued. At one end, there was child protection (high risk, skilled work, low numbers) and, at the other, the care of elderly people (large volume, low risk, less skilled). Yet Seebohn did create "a door on which anyone can knock".

If the new battle was about saving departmental boundaries, it would not be worth fighting. Indeed, boundaries have become more complicated, with some social service departments merging with housing and others with education. But there are more important issues to defend. Seebohn gave social services bigger clout - in Whitehall and locally. It's the eighth biggest spending programme.

There are important reasons, too, for resisting the health secretary. Putting care trusts under the NHS would be disastrous. Just look at geriatric services: poor status, few resources. Elderly people are at the bottom of NHS priorities. Worse still, community care would regress from being a social and medical service to purely medical. But elderly people have multiple problems. All require treatment. Health ministers are imposing a "one size fits all" model. They should be resisted.

Social service directors last week began their fightback. The Trojan horse comes in the form of care trusts proposed by the current health and social care bill. Under the 1999 Health Act, social care and health bodies were encouraged to experiment with pooled budgets to improve services. All manner of cooperative initiatives have begun to flow. Mental health trusts have emerged in which control and accountability have been equally divided between the two services. But under the much more centrally driven system in the new bill, in districts where the health secretary deems services are failing, he will be able to direct social service and health authorities to set up care trusts. They would be directly accountable to the NHS. Social services face two threats: their biggest spending service, the care of elderly people, will be hived off to NHS care trusts; and the unification of services achieved by the Seebohn reform in the early 1970s will once again be fragmented. All of its many disparate services - elderly people, children, mental health, learning disabilities, adoption - could be hived off into independent free standing trusts. At one level, Seebohn's unifying umbrella was an artificial construct. There was not as much crossover, or synergy, as some argued. At one end, there was child protection (high risk, skilled work, low numbers) and, at the other, the care of elderly people (large volume, low risk, less skilled). Yet Seebohn did create "a door on which anyone can knock". If the new battle was about saving departmental boundaries, it would not be worth fighting. Indeed, boundaries have become more complicated, with some social service departments merging with housing and others with education. But there are more important issues to defend. Seebohn gave social services bigger clout - in Whitehall and locally. It's the eighth biggest spending programme. There are important reasons, too, for resisting the health secretary. Putting care trusts under the NHS would be disastrous. Just look at geriatric services: poor status, few resources. Elderly people are at the bottom of NHS priorities. Worse still, community care would regress from being a social and medical service to purely medical. But elderly people have multiple problems. All require treatment. Health ministers are imposing a "one size fits all" model. They should be resisted.

webTitle: Council's emphasis on consultation revives local democracy

fields.headline: Council's emphasis on consultation revives local democracy
fields.standfirst: Martin Wainwright  discovers how a local authority's emphasis on consultation has revived an old tradition of local democracy
fields.trailText: Martin Wainwright discovers how a local authority's emphasis on consultation has revived an old tradition of local democracy
fields.body:
On winter nights in north Lincolnshire, a ghostly pony called the Tatterfoal is said to run amok, beguiling the innocent into thickets, where they freeze to death, or on to the treacherous mudflats of the Humber. Traditionally, the spectre's victims have been stray children or young lovers slipping home from secret meetings. But in recent years, it has targeted something more general: the vigorous spirit of local democracy which used to mark out this flat shoreline.

Where nonconformist ministers had the bailiffs in after refusing to pay the 1903 "Anglican" education tax, interest in modern debates at the council chamber in Scunthorpe has slipped almost to nil. Where local people dealt with exorbitant Victorian ferry fares by launching their own boat, and naming her Public Opinion, applications to join any of the political parties are now rare.

The Tatterfoal may soon be corralled, however, if an exercise called You Pay Your Money - Now Make Your Choice continues as successfully as it has started; a start which recently was given the blessing of a ministerial visit. New Labour's hiccupy attempt to get local councils genuinely to consult and involve local people in reforming town halls is in need of pioneer projects, and at North Lincolnshire council, ministers think they have found one.

"Councillors have started to be reasonably comfortable about not being comfortable," says Nic Dakin, Labour leader of the authority, who saw from the start that members of his own team were part of the problem. No one meant any offence, but the template of a hard working Councillor "I'll sort out your problems" Big is not what the national reform programme has in mind.

By June, every council in the country has to get its democratic reform plan to Beverley Hughes, local government minister, and in particular to show that it: (a) has really consulted local people; (b) is bubbling with ideas about how to keep them involved long-term.

North Lincs has the increasingly standard array of citizens' panels, an authority-wide standing conference (partly chosen, partly self-nominated), and youth democracy weeks which tell school students that Britain isn't run by magic and needs volunteers for everything from health authorities to the JPs' bench. But its particular contribution is the use of its punningly-named Local Links, which Hughes drove through snow flurries on the Humber Bridge to see.

"The key thing is that Local Links are where people come to see us," Dakin explained to the minister, in the converted Victorian police station at Barton-on-Humber, which now looks like a well-run transport interchange. While visitors' children sit on mini-chairs with their noses in books, staff in blue uniforms with Local Links embroidered tags dish out information and advice.

Such one-stop shops, where all or any council services can be accessed, have been a success with a population where, according to a survey, seven in 10 people have only the vaguest idea of what North Lincolnshire does. Crucially, their staffing has kept pace with demand - unlike, for example, Leeds, whose overworked one-stop shops were recently the subject of a television programme on workplace stress. More than 100,000 people called in at the six Links last year.

Dakin's consultation was waiting for them. Rather than snowstorm uninterested households with leaflets, the council seized the moment when punters had council matters on their minds. After dealing with the tenancy/drains/rubbish problem, Links staff were encouraged to put democracy on their visitors' agenda.

"We all had to think ourselves into being really pro-active," Mary Vessey, head of the service, told Hughes. "But tactful as well. You don't just hand them the Now Make Your Choice leaflet and say: 'Well, what about this then?' You make it relevant to their problem, whatever the issue is which brought them in. And so you get them talking about what the council does and how they can have a say."

An ideal conversation might start with a complaint about rat infestation in one of Barton's 267 listed buildings and end with a resident primed about pest control (who's in charge; how big the budget is) and maybe wised-up about repair grants or the problems of conserving the authority's heritage. At its best, the result is the democrat's grail of "informed choice", which shows the muscle of public opinion when issues are really grasped.

This happens fleetingly when single issues rouse the man or woman in the street; the Lincolnshire exercise hopes to make it more lasting.

Vessey, Dakin and their colleagues got a pat on the back fromHughes for progress so far; use of the Links has managed to get 7,000 people to vote on changing the council's structure - one of the government's requirements by June. North Lincs deliberately did not offer a preferred option, and all three main political parties accepted the verdict - 60% for the leader/cabinet model, 28% for directly elected mayor and cabinet and 12% for a mayor and council manager.

Hughes passed on her findings approvingly to a conference in Hull Guildhall of just about every local au thority in the Yorkshire/Humber region, together with stakeholders such as chambers of commerce and voluntary agencies. "North Lincolnshire has shown how consultation can generateexcitement and debate among local people," the minister said. The bubbling ideas for long-term involvement, including opportunities for ordinary punters to serve on citizens' scrutiny panels to monitor council work, are meanwhile fed out through the North Lincs Links.

The Tatterfoal may neigh derisively that 7,000 is only 10% of the local population and that Lincs yellowbellies will always prefer digging gardens to democracy. But that's the point, says Dakin. "It's healthy that people should put gardening first," he says. "But it's also healthy that they know how and why decisions are made about their allotments."

Responsible decisions

Councils are undergoing the biggest shake-up in their political structures for more than a century. Ministers want town halls to be run by new mayors and Westminster-style cabinets, and have told councils to consult the public before deciding which option to implement.

With councils and ministers split over which model is best, voters will hold the balance of power in deciding which option their council adopts.

The government is keen for England's town and cities to choose a mayor, who would appoint a cabinet of up to nine to help them run the authority.

This model has to be endorsed by a referendum of local voters before it can be implemented. These are already planned by councils including Birmingham and Brighton and Hove.

Most local authorities, however, favour the leader and cabinet model, where councillors choose their own leader and a cabinet of up to 10 members, each of whom will probably have specific responsibility for an area such as education or social care.

The government's other two options have been widely overlooked both by politicians and the public. The mayor and council manager option will give a powerful chief executive wide-ranging powers to run their local authority, with the mayor providing a political steer.

The government's final option is currently poorly defined, but will essentially allow small councils to streamline the current committee system, rather than abolishing it.

Of course, some councils are not enthusiastic about these changes, and others feel they are simply too cash-strapped and busy to organise consultations. This may explain why a recent survey of 200 councils in England and Wales found that more than two-thirds had yet to ask the public for its views.

Voters can force their council to hold a mayoral referendum if they hand in a petition signed by 5% of the local electorate.

Ministers can also choose to impose a referendum, and say this could be the ultimate sanction for English councils that do not send in their modernising proposals by June.

Councillors who hope to avoid adopting a mayor by putting off consultations may find their efforts have precisely the opposite effect, and that radical change is forced upon them.

Simon Parker

fields.headline: Front...to back
fields.trailText: press cuttings
fields.body:
Rice idea
Teachers at a primary school in Stowmarket, Suffolk, took 110 pupils to a curry house as part of their project on India.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 22.1.01
(David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Learning curve
Students taking science tests at a community college in Ringmer, East Sussex, were given bananas as part of a project to create a "brain friendly" environment for learning.
Brighton Evening Argus, 30.1.01
(J Beeken, Saltdean)

Heavy duty
A 40-stone man from Rochdale, Greater Manchester, had to be winched through a window of his terraced house by a forklift truck so that he could be taken to hospital.
Manchester Evening News, 26.1.01
(RA Holmes, Swinton)

Criminal loss
Thieves broke into a house in Great Wyrley, Staffordshire, and stole a computer containing all the research notes of a woman studying burglary as part of a degree course.
Shropshire Star, 29.1.01
(John Simblet, Shrewsbury)

Biter bitten
A burglar was arrested as a result of DNA tests on a cream-filled chocolate penis he had taken a bite of while ransacking a house in Stockton-on-Tees.
Middlesbrough Evening Gazette, 1.2.01
(M Bolton, Middlesbrough)

Flue cure
Fire crews were called out to free a chimney sweep who became stuck up a flue while working at a restaurant in Lowestoft, Suffolk.
East Anglian Daily Times, 24.1.01
(John Newman, Ipswich)

Deadlier mail A woman from Verwood, Dorset, who suspected her husband of being unfaithful, emailed a fake confession from him to 50 people on his electronic address book.
Metro, 25.1.01
(N Ring, Stirling)

Taking liberties
Essex police information HQ at Springfield received a 999 call from a man asking for a takeaway meal to be picked up because the Chinese restaurant had failed to deliver it.
Essex Chronicle, 26.1.01
(John McGarvey, Chelmsford)

Here comes the brie
A couple planning to get married have asked a shop in Morpeth, Northumberland, to make a three-tier wedding cake made from different varieties of cheese.
Northumberland Gazette, 1.2.01
(Anne Liddon, Tynemouth)

Hoppy is the bride
Bans on the use of confetti at weddings have been overcome by a man from Hereford, who has produced a biodegradable variety made from hops.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 24.1.01
(Jon Gurling, Birmingham)

Security drive
The owners of a golf driving range in Yelverton, Devon, have had to introduce security cameras and dog patrols at night to deter thieves who have stolen more than 5,000 balls in the last 18 months.
Western Morning News, 26.1.01
(Nicola Neale, Sidmouth)

Return visit
A bird warden who travelled 2,500 miles to view swans in the Russian tundra recognised a pair who are regular visitors to the Martin Mere reserve, Lancashire, where he works.
Colchester Evening Gazette, 25.1.01
(John White, Clacton-on-Sea)

Light relief
Unlit stretches of road in County Durham have been fitted with solar-powered cat's eyes that use energy stored during the day, rather than the traditional method of reflecting headlights.
Newcastle Journal, 1.2.01
(CF O'Brien, Tynemouth)

Black and blue
A motorist escaped serious injury after the front of his car was crushed when an eight-foot glass fibre blackcurrant fell off a lorry carrying a Ribena promotion on the M55 near Blackpool.
Manchester Evening News, 26.1.01
(FE Fletcher, Stretford)

Cuttings, preferably from local papers, which reflect interesting or amusing aspects of life in Britain, must be sent on a postcard (with source) to: Society, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. £15 will be paid for each one used.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Environment news
fields.body:
Heart attack

A rather odd Valentine appeared at Eco soundings this week. It says: "If we could shrink the world to a village of 100 people, pro-rata there would be 57 Asians, 21 European, 14 from the Western hemisphere, north and south, and eight Africans. Eighty would live in sub-standard housing, 70 would be unable to read and 50 would suffer malnutrition. Six would possess 59% of the world's wealth and all of them would be from the US. Only one would own a computer. If you can read this message you are more blessed than the two billion in the world who cannot." Very cheering.

Battle of Brittan

Trade secretary Stephen Byers, who last year underwrote £1.5bn worth of military exports, many to Indonesia, Turkey and other regimes with dubious human rights records, has been invited to a lecture on April 9 by that pillar of economic rectitude, Sir Samuel Brittan. Both the theme and the message may surprise him. Organised by the Campaign Against the Arms Trade, the title is Subsidising a Deadly Trade, the economics of government support for arms exports. Brittan, a Financial Times columnist knighted by John Major, takes a tough line on government feather-bedding of the "defence" business. He has written that subsidies are lousy value for money because "arms sales do not represent, even in the narrowest economic terms, the best use of national resources". Let us hope Byers is listening carefully.

Who's afraid of . . .

Norway, which has just blotted its environmental record by allowing the resumption of international trade in whale products, is now intent on wiping out half its wolf population. Wolves are said to be killing a tiny number of sheep in one of the richest countries in the world - yet there are only believed to be 40 wolves in the whole of Norway. Killing the wolves will cost £600,000. Norway would do better compensating the farmers at £1,000 a sheep.

Secrett success

Tony Juniper, campaigns and policy director of Friends of the Earth, is to succeed executive director Charles Secrett when he quits after 10 years' service in 2003. A measure of Juniper's success is that the Labour government regard him as "unhelpful" - that is, he hits them where it hurts.

webTitle: Money helps raise green oscars' profile

fields.headline: A heady brew
fields.standfirst: Money helps raise green oscars' profile
fields.trailText: Money helps raise green oscars' profile
fields.body:
Brewing, building, shopping and whisky-making are an odd alliance, and not one you might expect to find lined up in the cause of conservation. But the latest crop of Whitley Awards winners ranges from a campaign to save the pygmy hippopotamus of west Africa to an energy-efficient wood stove designed to slow deforestation in Rwanda.

From humble beginnings eight years ago, the Whitleys have snowballed into one of the world's most valued conservation awards. One key to this is money - the pot has quadrupled in the last two years and now stands at £400,000, with a top prize of £50,000.

Another is connections - money from brewing (the Whitley family's Animal Protection Trust) has been supplemented by cash from shopping (Sainsbury's), building (Laing) and by an alliance with the Iris Darnton Foundation, chaired by James Teacher, of the whisky family. The pop world has come on board - there is a £20,000 prize for human rights and the environment from Sting and Trudie Styler - and so has royalty, in the shape of the Princess Royal, patron and prize-giver of the Whitley Awards Foundation. Next year, the global environmental network, WWF will sponsor a new £20,000 award for "people-centred" conservation.

Last week's ceremony at the Royal Geographical Society in London thus had a flavour of the green oscars about it.

Edward Whitley, the 39-year-old brewing scion who founded the awards, was deeply impressed as a child by Jersey zoo, where the late Gerald Durrell not only pioneered the captive breeding of threatened species but taught people from all over the world how to do it. In 1992, after abandoning banking and management consultancy for writing, broadcasting and conservation, Whitley wrote a book, Gerald Durrell's Army, which told the stories of Durrell's far-flung graduates. "Visiting all those people and projects showed me just how much they needed help," he says. That insight was the inspiration for the awards.

Durrell would have approved of this year's winner of the £50,000 Whitley award, Alex Peal; against considerable odds he has kept conservation afloat in Liberia.

Peal, now 56, started work as a forester in the 1960s and was goalkeeeper of the Liberian national football side until 1971. When he gave up football he became the first Liberian to go abroad for conservation training, set up and ran its first and only national park, Sapo, and in 1986 co-founded the Society for the Conservation of Nature in Liberia, the country's first and only NGO devoted to biodiversity.

Forced to flee Liberia after war broke out, Peal has, since his return, led an expedition to Sapo under the protection of UN peacekeepers to measure Liberia's largely uncharted wildlife riches. One of his missions is to secure the future of the pygmy hippo, a "flagship" species for which Liberia may well be the last important refuge.

The £30,000 Ashden award for renewable energy went to another war-torn African country, Rwanda, where an uprooted population desperate for wood to cook with is rapidly depleting the surviving forests.

Since the war ended six years ago, the Kigali Institute of Science, Technology and Management (Kist) has developed a bread oven which uses 75% less wood and can also run on biogas. Albert Butare, deputy director of Kist, says the next step is to train people to run the ovens as small businesses - providing employment and cheap food, as well as slowing forest loss.

A series of £20,000 conservation awards went to individuals in India, South Africa, Vietnam, Madagascar and Zimbabwe.

Vivek Menon, who has championed the Indian elephant against poaching and set up five different environmental NGOs, received the Rufford award.

Sean Privett, of the Walker Bay Fynbos Conservancy in the Western Cape, received the Iris Darnton award for his work in a habitat of extraordinary botanical wealth.

Vu Thi Quyen, the dynamic head of Vietnam's first environmental education programme, received the Maurice Laing award.

The Sting and Trudie Styler award went to Jenny Rouquette, a Briton helping people in south-eastern Madagascar reclaim their common land.

And the Wildinvest award went to Greg Rasmussen, the defender of one of the world's rarest canids, the African painted dog.

fields.bodyText: Brewing, building, shopping and whisky-making are an odd alliance, and not one you might expect to find lined up in the cause of conservation. But the latest crop of Whitley Awards winners ranges from a campaign to save the pygmy hippopotamus of west Africa to an energy-efficient wood stove designed to slow deforestation in Rwanda. From humble beginnings eight years ago, the Whitleys have snowballed into one of the world's most valued conservation awards. One key to this is money - the pot has quadrupled in the last two years and now stands at £400,000, with a top prize of £50,000. Another is connections - money from brewing (the Whitley family's Animal Protection Trust) has been supplemented by cash from shopping (Sainsbury's), building (Laing) and by an alliance with the Iris Darnton Foundation, chaired by James Teacher, of the whisky family. The pop world has come on board - there is a £20,000 prize for human rights and the environment from Sting and Trudie Styler - and so has royalty, in the shape of the Princess Royal, patron and prize-giver of the Whitley Awards Foundation. Next year, the global environmental network, WWF will sponsor a new £20,000 award for "people-centred" conservation. Last week's ceremony at the Royal Geographical Society in London thus had a flavour of the green oscars about it. Edward Whitley, the 39-year-old brewing scion who founded the awards, was deeply impressed as a child by Jersey zoo, where the late Gerald Durrell not only pioneered the captive breeding of threatened species but taught people from all over the world how to do it. webTitle: Mining company given a chance to save Aboriginal homelands

fields.headline: Gift of life
fields.standfirst: The world's largest mining company has been given a chance to prove its green credentials and save Aboriginal homelands. By  Paul Brown
fields.trailText: The world's largest mining company has been given a chance to prove its green credentials and save Aboriginal homelands. By Paul Brown
fields.body:
Rio Tinto, the world's largest mining company, has been asked to prove its green credentials by abandoning plans to open a new uranium mine on a world heritage site in the Northern Territory of Australia. The company, which for years has been many environmental groups' most reviled company, has spent the last five years trying to improve its image and, at black spots around the world, clean up both its pollution and human rights record.

Accidently, so the company claims, by taking over an Australian mining company, it has become enmeshed in one of the fiercest environmental struggles in Australian history.

The Jabiluka mine is in the homeland of the Mirrar aboriginal people. The uranium lies under the Kakadu national park and is set to provide fuel for Britain's nuclear reactors. Even before Rio Tinto came along, a number of court cases had already been fought and lost in a bid to protect the Mirrar people's homeland and the park, and there had been hundreds of arrests in demonstrations.

Rio Tinto acquired Jabiluka, and a nearby existing uranium mine called Ranger, in July last year when it took over the Australian conglomerate North Mining Ltd. The Ranger mine supplies fuel both for British Nuclear Fuel's Magnox reactors and British Energy's eight advanced gas cooled reactors, but is now nearing exhaustion. Under North's original plans, the Jabiluka mine was expected to start production to fill the gap.

But for London-based Rio Tinto, opening Jabiluka would be a public relations disaster. Among the projects that blackened Rio Tinto's name in the 1970s and 80s was the operation of the uranium mine in Namibia - in cooperation with the South African regime- to supply uranium for Britain's nuclear weapons programme.

Although the company still operates the Namibian mine on a smaller scale, it claims that uranium is no longer part of its core business. The acquisition of both the Australian mines was a by-product of a much larger takeover of North's iron ore business and, although the takeover was last summer, no decision has yet been reached about the future of the two mines.

Last week, Rio Tinto, which has its world headquarters in London, announced profits of $2.5bn (£1.7bn), 25% up on the previous year. The chairman, Sir Robert Wilson, said it had been a particularly active year, mentioning the acquisition of extra coal, iron and diamond interests.

Friends of the Earth (FOE), which is mounting an international campaign to get Rio Tinto to close both mines in Australia, said a company with so much money could make a one-off gesture by closing the Ranger mine and giving back the Jabiluka land to the Mirrar people.

FOE fears that, to avoid the adverse publicity when it opens the mine, Rio Tinto may sell Jabiluka on to the French nuclear giant Cogema. Although there is a world surplus of uranium and, according to Rio Tinto's own annual report, prices have slumped to an all-time low, Cogema could use Jabiluka to safeguard its own uranium supplies for more than 40 French reactors, as well as export the surplus to the UK.

The Ranger and Jabiluka mines are both inside the Kakadu national park made famous by the Crocodile Dundee films and declared a world heritage site. It is the home of 2.5m water birds, almost 1,000 different plant species and attracts 250,000 tourists a year.

The Mirrar people regard this as their ancestral home and point to the damage done over years by the Ranger mine, which has left 20m tonnes of radioactive tailings in spoil heaps around its operations. According to FOE, there have been 120 breaches of the mine's operational guidelines under North's ownership - most recently in May last year, when there was a leak of 2m gallons of radioactive liquid contaminated with manganese, uranium and radium. Some of this escaped into the Kakadu wetlands.

An investigation by the Australian senate criticised the government for not conducting a social impact study of the Jabiluka project to see what effect it would have on the Mirrar people and found the circumstances surrounding the 1982 mining agreement with the local people was deeply unfair and that the mine should not proceed. The Mirrar people now repudiate the 1982 agreement, saying that they were misinformed about their rights, but the government disagreed and said the mine could go ahead. Construction was completed by North Mining before the takeover, but no uranium has yet been mined.

Ed Matthew, from FOE in London, says: "This mine is on land unjustly wrested from the Aboriginal people and inside a World Heritage site. If Rio Tinto proceed with this mine it will be telling us that there is no place on earth the company is not prepared to plunder. They are a hugely rich company, and they could well afford to make a generous gesture which will show the world they care.

"If Rio Tinto sells the mining leases to another mining company they are condemning the Mirrar people to another 30 years of social chaos. This is a key test of Rio Tinto's claims to respect the environment and support sustainable development. The company's reputation will be soiled for ever if this goes ahead."

Rio Tinto say that the three options were to operate Jabiluka, close it or sell it, but no decision has yet been reached.

British Nuclear Fuels said Australia was just one of a number of sources of supply of uranium, and that Jabiluka was not essential. There were also mines in Canada, South Africa and Russia.

Rio Tinto's troubled record

Madagascar: Plans for a titanium dioxide mine on the south-east coast of Madagascar generated international condemnation following the death from a heart attack of Andrew Lees, former campaigns Director at Friends of the Earth, while investigating the project in 1995. Despite this Rio Tinto are considering forging ahead which FOE says could destroy up to 76% of a unique forest ecosystem. The project also threatens to pollute the local water supply, to destroy its fishing industry and to endanger over 500 species. Titanium dioxide is a mineral used to manufacture a white pigment that is commonly used in paper, paint and plastics. There are many other potential sources not located in ecologically sensitive sites.

Papua, New Guinea: Panguna copper mine began a civil war between the government and Bougainville revolutionary army. In the conflict 15,000 islanders died. A court case began in the US in September last year on behalf of the local people against Rio Tinto.

Hull, UK: In July last year, the families of 200 workers of smelting works on the Humber, many of whom have died prematurely, sued the company for compensation.

Indonesia: A month after buying a stake in the Grasberg mine, 2,700 miles east of Jakarta, the military were accused of murdering and torturing the local people who objected to the mine. The tailings from the mine were said to have severely degraded the rainforests.

fields.headline: Underdog's champion
fields.standfirst: Geoff Thompson, karate hero with a caring touch
fields.trailText: Profile: Geoff Thompson, karate hero with a caring touch
fields.body:
Geoff Thompson is just the sort of person the government has in mind to act as neighbourhood champions in deprived areas, under its commitment to neighbourhood renewal. The hope is that these champions will provide a link between local people and the array of statutory and voluntary organisations delivering services and pumping in funding to the 88 poorest areas.

Thompson, five times world karate champion, and founder of Youth Charter for Sport (YCS) in Moss Side, Manchester, should be pleased that his work is being held up as a model. But he is concerned that the endorsement is little more than lip service from a government he sees as full of fine words and policies, but lacking any real commitment to changing the lives of disadvantaged young people.

It's easy to see why he's formed that view. Last week, YCS almost shut up shop after seven years, when the little voluntary sector and corporate funding that it had dried up. It is now reliant on the goodwill of a handful of volunteers, including Thompson's wife, Janice, also a former world karate gold medallist.

If the government thinks Thompson is such a hero, why has it neither funded his organisation nor consulted him on how to tackle youth crime? Last summer, Tony Blair appointed former BBC director general Lord Birt as his adviser on "yob culture" - a post Thompson's journey from the streets to the victor's rostrum would arguably have better equipped him to hold.

"I was a young, insecure black male who was bullied at my school in Hackney for having a Wolverhampton accent," he says. "Stressed teachers, overcrowded classrooms, underachieving pupils, gangs of youths pinning teachers against the wall - none of this is new. It was happening in the 70s. What saved me from being detained at her majesty's pleasure was karate. From seven to adolescence, karate gave me targets to aim for. Every two months I won another belt. I know about the power of sport to motivate, engage and interest young people, the discipline, self-esteem and confidence it instills."

Thompson, now 43, talks with a passion usually reserved for the pulpit, and it comes as no surprise to learn that his intensity of purpose comes from a strong spiritual belief. But while it inspires young people from the inner cities who have heard him speak, he fears his approach is met with suspicion by some in authority who view him as a loose cannon. Perhaps that is why he was passed over last year as chair of Sport England, an organisation he first joined in 1988, when it was then called the Sports Council.

Winning five gold medals opened doors for Thompson. In 1988, he was part of an influential body of sportsmen, academics, business leaders and politicians which drew up a report arguing that sport could keep teenagers out of trouble. On his move to Manchester, he became north-west regional chairman of the Sports Aid Foundation.

In 1993, he set up YCS after 12-year-old Benji Stanley was shot dead in Moss Side. He says: "YCS's aim was, and still is, to utilise sports and their ambassadors as catalysts in providing young people with an opportunity through sport to develop in life and develop more positive attitudes to society."

More than 40 projects, and numerous lecture tours, later, Thompson admits it is difficult to quantify how many youngsters have been helped through YCS. But the fact that its programme has been adopted in 16 countries, and counts Sydney Olympics 200 metres silver medallist Darren Campbell among its success stories, is testimony that it is doing something right.

Thompson has spent three years struggling to raise £4m to open a social centre of excellence for young people in Toxteth, Liverpool. But despite government plaudits, he feels excluded - like the youngsters he's trying to help. "The first I heard that I was being held up as a community champion was in the press," he says. "I'd like to think that what I've been through would afford me the opportunity to be included."

YCS information at www.ycs.co.uk

webTitle: How a local authority's emphasis on consultation has revived a tradition of local democracy

fields.headline: Choice words
fields.standfirst: Martin Wainwright  discovers how a local authority's emphasis on consultation has revived an old tradition of local democracy
fields.trailText: Martin Wainwright discovers how a local authority's emphasis on consultation has revived an old tradition of local democracy
fields.body:
On winter nights in north Lincolnshire, a ghostly pony called the Tatterfoal is said to run amok, beguiling the innocent into thickets, where they freeze to death, or on to the treacherous mudflats of the Humber. Traditionally, the spectre's victims have been stray children or young lovers slipping home from secret meetings. But in recent years, it has targeted something more general: the vigorous spirit of local democracy which used to mark out this flat shoreline.

Where nonconformist ministers had the bailiffs in after refusing to pay the 1903 "Anglican" education tax, interest in modern debates at the council chamber in Scunthorpe has slipped almost to nil. Where local people dealt with exorbitant Victorian ferry fares by launching their own boat, and naming her Public Opinion, applications to join any of the political parties are now rare.

The Tatterfoal may soon be corralled, however, if an exercise called You Pay Your Money - Now Make Your Choice continues as successfully as it has started; a start which recently was given the blessing of a ministerial visit. New Labour's hiccupy attempt to get local councils genuinely to consult and involve local people in reforming town halls is in need of pioneer projects, and at North Lincolnshire council, ministers think they have found one.

"Councillors have started to be reasonably comfortable about not being comfortable," says Nic Dakin, Labour leader of the authority, who saw from the start that members of his own team were part of the problem. No one meant any offence, but the template of a hard working Councillor "I'll sort out your problems" Big is not what the national reform programme has in mind.

By June, every council in the country has to get its democratic reform plan to Beverley Hughes, local government minister, and in particular to show that it: (a) has really consulted local people; (b) is bubbling with ideas about how to keep them involved long-term.

North Lincs has the increasingly standard array of citizens' panels, an authority-wide standing conference (partly chosen, partly self-nominated), and youth democracy weeks which tell school students that Britain isn't run by magic and needs volunteers for everything from health authorities to the JPs' bench. But its particular contribution is the use of its punningly-named Local Links, which Hughes drove through snow flurries on the Humber Bridge to see.

"The key thing is that Local Links are where people come to see us," Dakin explained to the minister, in the converted Victorian police station at Barton-on-Humber, which now looks like a well-run transport interchange. While visitors' children sit on mini-chairs with their noses in books, staff in blue uniforms with Local Links embroidered tags dish out information and advice.

Such one-stop shops, where all or any council services can be accessed, have been a success with a population where, according to a survey, seven in 10 people have only the vaguest idea of what North Lincolnshire does. Crucially, their staffing has kept pace with demand - unlike, for example, Leeds, whose overworked one-stop shops were recently the subject of a television programme on workplace stress. More than 100,000 people called in at the six Links last year.

Dakin's consultation was waiting for them. Rather than snowstorm uninterested households with leaflets, the council seized the moment when punters had council matters on their minds. After dealing with the tenancy/drains/rubbish problem, Links staff were encouraged to put democracy on their visitors' agenda.

"We all had to think ourselves into being really pro-active," Mary Vessey, head of the service, told Hughes. "But tactful as well. You don't just hand them the Now Make Your Choice leaflet and say: 'Well, what about this then?' You make it relevant to their problem, whatever the issue is which brought them in. And so you get them talking about what the council does and how they can have a say."

An ideal conversation might start with a complaint about rat infestation in one of Barton's 267 listed buildings and end with a resident primed about pest control (who's in charge; how big the budget is) and maybe wised-up about repair grants or the problems of conserving the authority's heritage. At its best, the result is the democrat's grail of "informed choice", which shows the muscle of public opinion when issues are really grasped.

This happens fleetingly when single issues rouse the man or woman in the street; the Lincolnshire exercise hopes to make it more lasting.

Vessey, Dakin and their colleagues got a pat on the back fromHughes for progress so far; use of the Links has managed to get 7,000 people to vote on changing the council's structure - one of the government's requirements by June. North Lincs deliberately did not offer a preferred option, and all three main political parties accepted the verdict - 60% for the leader/cabinet model, 28% for directly elected mayor and cabinet and 12% for a mayor and council manager.

Hughes passed on her findings approvingly to a conference in Hull Guildhall of just about every local au thority in the Yorkshire/Humber region, together with stakeholders such as chambers of commerce and voluntary agencies. "North Lincolnshire has shown how consultation can generateexcitement and debate among local people," the minister said. The bubbling ideas for long-term involvement, including opportunities for ordinary punters to serve on citizens' scrutiny panels to monitor council work, are meanwhile fed out through the North Lincs Links.

The Tatterfoal may neigh derisively that 7,000 is only 10% of the local population and that Lincs yellowbellies will always prefer digging gardens to democracy. But that's the point, says Dakin. "It's healthy that people should put gardening first," he says. "But it's also healthy that they know how and why decisions are made about their allotments."

Responsible decisions

Councils are undergoing the biggest shake-up in their political structures for more than a century. Ministers want town halls to be run by new mayors and Westminster-style cabinets, and have told councils to consult the public before deciding which option to implement.

With councils and ministers split over which model is best, voters will hold the balance of power in deciding which option their council adopts.

The government is keen for England's town and cities to choose a mayor, who would appoint a cabinet of up to nine to help them run the authority.

This model has to be endorsed by a referendum of local voters before it can be implemented. These are already planned by councils including Birmingham and Brighton and Hove.

Most local authorities, however, favour the leader and cabinet model, where councillors choose their own leader and a cabinet of up to 10 members, each of whom will probably have specific responsibility for an area such as education or social care.

The government's other two options have been widely overlooked both by politicians and the public. The mayor and council manager option will give a powerful chief executive wide-ranging powers to run their local authority, with the mayor providing a political steer.

The government's final option is currently poorly defined, but will essentially allow small councils to streamline the current committee system, rather than abolishing it.

Of course, some councils are not enthusiastic about these changes, and others feel they are simply too cash-strapped and busy to organise consultations. This may explain why a recent survey of 200 councils in England and Wales found that more than two-thirds had yet to ask the public for its views.
