fields.bodyText: On winter nights in north Lincolnshire, a ghostly pony called the Tatterfoal is said to run amok, beguiling the innocent into thickets, where they freeze to death, or on to the treacherous mudflats of the Humber. Traditionally, the spectre's victims have been stray children or young lovers slipping home from secret meetings. But in recent years, it has targeted something more general: the vigorous spirit of local democracy which used to mark out this flat shoreline. Where nonconformist ministers had the bailiffs in after refusing to pay the 1903 "Anglican" education tax, interest in modern debates at the council chamber in Scunthorpe has slipped almost to nil. Where local people dealt with exorbitant Victorian ferry fares by launching their own boat, and naming her Public Opinion, applications to join any of the political parties are now rare. The Tatterfoal may soon be corralled, however, if an exercise called You Pay Your Money - Now Make Your Choice continues as successfully as it has started; a start which recently was given the blessing of a ministerial visit. New Labour's hiccupy attempt to get local councils genuinely to consult and involve local people in reforming town halls is in need of pioneer projects, and at North Lincolnshire council, ministers think they have found one. "Councillors have started to be reasonably comfortable about not being comfortable," says Nic Dakin, Labour leader of the authority, who saw from the start that members of his own team were part of the problem. No one meant any offence, but the template of a hard working Councillor "I'll sort out your problems" Big is not what the national reform programme has in mind. By June, every council in the country has to get its democratic reform plan to Beverley Hughes, local government minister, and in particular to show that it: (a) has really consulted local people; (b) is bubbling with ideas about how to keep them involved long-term. North Lincs has the increasingly standard array of citizens' panels, an authority-wide standing conference (partly chosen, partly self-nominated), and youth democracy weeks which tell school students that Britain isn't run by magic and needs volunteers for everything from health authorities to the JPs' bench. But its particular contribution is the use of its punningly-named Local Links, which Hughes drove through snow flurries on the Humber Bridge to see. "The key thing is that Local Links are where people come to see us," Dakin explained to the minister, in the converted Victorian police station at Barton-on-Humber, which now looks like a well-run transport interchange. While visitors' children sit on mini-chairs with their noses in books, staff in blue uniforms with Local Links embroidered tags dish out information and advice. Such one-stop shops, where all or any council services can be accessed, have been a success with a population where, according to a survey, seven in 10 people have only the vaguest idea of what North Lincolnshire does. Crucially, their staffing has kept pace with demand - unlike, for example, Leeds, whose overworked one-stop shops were recently the subject of a television programme on workplace stress. More than 100,000 people called in at the six Links last year. Dakin's consultation was waiting for them. Rather than snowstorm uninterested households with leaflets, the council seized the moment when punters had council matters on their minds. After dealing with the tenancy/drains/rubbish problem, Links staff were encouraged to put democracy on their visitors' agenda. "We all had to think ourselves into being really pro-active," Mary Vessey, head of the service, told Hughes. "But tactful as well. You don't just hand them the Now Make Your Choice leaflet and say: 'Well, what about this then?' You make it relevant to their problem, whatever the issue is which brought them in. And so you get them talking about what the council does and how they can have a say." An ideal conversation might start with a complaint about rat infestation in one of Barton's 267 listed buildings and end with a resident primed about pest control (who's in charge; how big the budget is) and maybe wised-up about repair grants or the problems of conserving the authority's heritage. At its best, the result is the democrat's grail of "informed choice", which shows the muscle of public opinion when issues are really grasped. This happens fleetingly when single issues rouse the man or woman in the street; the Lincolnshire exercise hopes to make it more lasting. Vessey, Dakin and their colleagues got a pat on the back fromHughes for progress so far; use of the Links has managed to get 7,000 people to vote on changing the council's structure - one of the government's requirements by June. North Lincs deliberately did not offer a preferred option, and all three main political parties accepted the verdict - 60% for the leader/cabinet model, 28% for directly elected mayor and cabinet and 12% for a mayor and council manager. Hughes passed on her findings approvingly to a conference in Hull Guildhall of just about every local au thority in the Yorkshire/Humber region, together with stakeholders such as chambers of commerce and voluntary agencies. "North Lincolnshire has shown how consultation can generateexcitement and debate among local people," the minister said. The bubbling ideas for long-term involvement, including opportunities for ordinary punters to serve on citizens' scrutiny panels to monitor council work, are meanwhile fed out through the North Lincs Links. The Tatterfoal may neigh derisively that 7,000 is only 10% of the local population and that Lincs yellowbellies will always prefer digging gardens to democracy. But that's the point, says Dakin. "It's healthy that people should put gardening first," he says. "But it's also healthy that they know how and why decisions are made about their allotments." Responsible decisions Councils are undergoing the biggest shake-up in their political structures for more than a century. Ministers want town halls to be run by new mayors and Westminster-style cabinets, and have told councils to consult the public before deciding which option to implement. With councils and ministers split over which model is best, voters will hold the balance of power in deciding which option their council adopts. The government is keen for England's town and cities to choose a mayor, who would appoint a cabinet of up to nine to help them run the authority. This model has to be endorsed by a referendum of local voters before it can be implemented. These are already planned by councils including Birmingham and Brighton and Hove. Most local authorities, however, favour the leader and cabinet model, where councillors choose their own leader and a cabinet of up to 10 members, each of whom will probably have specific responsibility for an area such as education or social care. The government's other two options have been widely overlooked both by politicians and the public. The mayor and council manager option will give a powerful chief executive wide-ranging powers to run their local authority, with the mayor providing a political steer. The government's final option is currently poorly defined, but will essentially allow small councils to streamline the current committee system, rather than abolishing it. webTitle: Attempts in Birmingham to make opera open to all

fields.headline: Voices of the people
fields.standfirst: Chris Arnot on a bold attempt in Birmingham to break opera's white, elitist image
fields.trailText: Chris Arnot on a bold attempt in Birmingham to break opera's white, elitist image
fields.body:
Great opera houses around the world seek the services of talented director Graham Vick. His name is known from Covent Garden to the Metropolitan, New York, from the Vienna State to Glyndebourne, from La Scala, Milan, to Ladywood.

Yes, that's Ladywood, Birmingham. Geographically, it borders Brindleyplace, with its expensive canalside restaurants and sumptuous Symphony Hall. Socially and economically, it might be on a different planet, an inner-city area scarred by all the problems associated with that term.

Within this area, the Warehouse stands shabbily in a back street, bordered by low-rise and high-rise social housing. Breeze blocks and wooden boards make up most of the exterior. A peeling sign proclaims this building to be a council depot.

Perched somewhere in the scaffolding which runs right round the building's vast interior, a soprano and baritone are letting rip. Down at ground level, Vick listens intently. At 47, he is grey-haired and bespectacled. But an outwardly benign and kindly air masks a passionate belief that opera must appeal to every race and every strata of society, rather than to an overwhelmingly pink-skinned, dinner-jacketed and bejewelled elite.

He has been artistic director of the City of Birmingham Touring Opera since 1987, but recently relaunched it as the Birmingham Opera Company, with a commitment to perform in uncompromisingly urban settings. A marked contrast, this, with the ever-growing number of summer-evening picnic operas in the grounds of big country houses. The son of a credit draper from the docklands area of Liverpool, Vick claims he was "re-politicised" by his nine years at Glyndebourne and views the country-house trend as an extension of opera as a privileged and exclusive club.

The Ladywood warehouse is not just a rehearsal space. It is where Vick plans to stage Alban Berg's 1920s opera, Votzec, in modern dress and in English. Nine professional singers and 21 members of the orchestra will be joined by amateur actors and dancers drawn from such diverse organisations as the Yehlehleh young Asian theatre company, a gay men's performance group and members of Gallery 37 - hitherto unemployed youngsters who are doing apprenticeships in the creative arts.

They will also be joined by the audience as the whole show is to be done in promenade. No plush seats here; indeed, no seats at all beyond a few plastic chairs and a park bench, to which Vick repairs at 5.30pm when he declares a brief break from rehearsals. When it is pointed out that this is a rum venue for an opera, he looks pleased. "Good, good, good," he says. "What I wanted to do was to take the notion of inclusiveness and make it central to the company's work. I wanted to take people by surprise. That's partly to do with where it's set and partly to do with the subject matter. This is a piece that speaks to me of this part of Birmingham."

But wasn't Berg an Austrian? "Yes, but the issues are very contemporary - single parenthood, prostitution, teenage pregnancy, the dispossessed and how they survive," Vick explains. "And all this is set in a harsh, uncaring society with no compassion."

In Vick's view, New Labour has changed little in nearly four years. "We still have a 1980s society with an ostensibly warm and cuddly government," he says. "They talk about opportunities for everybody, but what they're really saying is that 'you, too, can join the elite'. Covent Garden has the lowest subsidies and the highest ticket prices in the world, which is symptomatic of our society. How can we change that as long as the majority of the population sees opera as a plaything of the rich?

"Surveys have shown that the biggest single thing putting people off is the existing audience. My generation worked hard to change that perception, but all that was thrown away in the mid to late 1980s, when there was a return to glamour in the way opera was sold and marketed. My aim is still to help opera to put down roots in British culture. I'm not saying that everybody should like it, any more than everybody should like football, but I do long for its value to be acknowledged by the people it doesn't reach now."

And what is that value? "It's the same for people round here as it is for the rich," he says. "Opera nourishes the spirit and extends human experience. That said, the issue is how do we get people round here to come. The very fact that such an event is happening in Ladywood should attract some local interest, if only curiosity."

Tickets are £10, with half price for concessions. And if Ladywood does not turn out in great numbers, Vick is hopeful that the nigh-on 200 cast members from communities around Birmingham will attract their parents, sisters, cousins and aunts. "My hope is that they'll bring an audience with them," he says.

By now it is 6.30pm and the community groups are arriving for rehearsals. Choreographer Ron Howell puts them through a series of warm-up exercises. "We have to find a way of welcoming more people from ethnic minorities into opera," says Vick, looking on and beaming with approval at the number of black and brown faces on the floor.

He is less happy that he won't be able to go with this vibrant, multi-racial company to its next venue - in a disused aircraft hangar in his home town of Liverpool. "I'm going to have to be in Paris," he says. And he sounds almost gloomy at the prospect.

From hip-hop to arias

Judging by the comments of some of the amateur performers from Birmingham who have joined his company for this production, director Graham Vick has some way to go to convince black youngsters about the value of opera. But at least they have open minds.

"We had a trip from college to an opera and I fell asleep," admits Ajay Dattani, from Handsworth. "But I agreed to come and see what this was all about, and it's OK. I like it."

Asher Gray, from Ladywood, likes hip-hop, soul and rap. She says: "I thought opera was just people screaming. But, hey, opportunity knocks. Know what I mean?"

Natalie Morrison, from Highgate, admits: "I want to be an actress or singer and this is a chance to get something else on my portfolio. This is a new learning experience for me, so I'm not going to say I don't like opera."

Votzek, by Alban Berg, is at The Warehouse, Ladywood, Birmingham, on February 20-21, 23-24; Speke Airport, Liverpool, on March 9-10; and the Concorde Sports Centre, Sheffield, on March 23-24. Box office 0121-236-4455

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: letters
fields.body:
Scot free

It is clear from the latest news from Scotland about the teachers' pay rise and the provision of personal care that the English taxpayer more than compensates for poorer health, largely self-inflicted, in Scotland (Distinct cousins, February 7).

Why do we continue this differential? If the answer is "Scottish oil", my next question is: "When was the middle of the North Sea part of an independent Scotland?"

Bernard Fookes
Sutton Coldfield

My mother-in-law is in a Leeds nursing home which has just informed us that it will close in April because it cannot meet new legal criteria - which I understand to be about toilet facilities in every room - because of the financial and organisational squeeze that this will impose.

How many other such homes will go to the wall for similar reasons and what will be done about resettling the old folk suddenly rendered homeless and whose comforting routines have been ripped from them? Fewer places and everyone chasing them: it is a recipe for disaster.

There should be both breathing space and government money to pay for the improvements to enable all of these places to stay in business. If Scotland can find funds for old folk . . .

I am a member of the Labour party and would ask direct, but Millbank doesn't answer emails (I know - I've tried). Getting into Downing Street's site to ask the question requires a knowledge of obscure rites and ritual. It's damned near impossible.

ND Smith
Sutton Coldfield

Slow train

I hope that the London Development Agency's plans to develop Londoners' skills meet with more success than some current attempts by central government to equip the long-term unemployed with skills to get them back to work (Capital ideas, February 7).

Last October, the employment service referred me to our employment zone, run by a subsidiary of a well-known recruitment chain. As almost all the jobs in which I am interested require advanced knowledge of word processing, spreadsheets and databases, and as my skills are five years out of date, I asked my personal adviser in November to put me on an appropriate training course.

In January, after four reminders, my adviser finally told me that the zone's managing director had informed her that I could have "any course" - provided I got a job first. Cart before horse, or what? I don't know why the managing director thinks a prospective employer will wait six to eight weeks minimum for the zone to train me.

A possible explanation for the zone's reluctance to personally fund reasonable training could be that the management is allowed to use "efficiency savings" to pay staff bonuses, so long as the zone meets its targets for getting people into work. This might explain why zone staff try to convince highly educated people to apply for unskilled jobs.

Jennie Ball
London

On track

I must answer Richard Wexler's splenetic rant on a "new" fast track for adoption (Letters, February 7).

Between 1956 and 1965, my wife and I fostered five babies, each given into our care at a few days old, with the intention of adoption. Two of these children were claimed back by their birth mothers within the six-week period before adoption could begin.

Those were both terrible experiences for us, the worst of our young lives (the tears rise again as I think of it now). But we loved the babies, and for their sakes we loved their birth mothers, accepted that our pain meant their joy, and wished them all happiness. The other three babies became ours, are each happily committed to a life-long partner and have given us seven grandchildren between them.

This may all sound overly personal and highly sentimental, but I hope it demonstrates that the fast track is not new and can be very successful. I find Wexler's attitude patronising, crudely simplistic, authoritarian and crass.

Name and address withheld

Charity case

Richard Hayes suggests that charities with an income of less than £10,000 a year are completely unregulated (Letters, January 17). This is not the case.

Our resources are increasingly targeted at areas of greatest need or risk. A lighter regulatory touch for small charities is part of this. Parliament decided in 1994 that the commission's active monitoring should cover registered charities with income or expenditure of £10,000 or more. This means that, while many smaller charities do not need to fill out the detailed annual monitoring return, the commission actively monitors 98% of the total income of registered charities.

The commission's powers to obtain information, investigate and, where necessary, impose remedies, apply to all registered (and many unregistered) charities, regardless of size.

John Stoker
Chief charity commissioner

Clarification

We have been asked to point out that our report, The Value of Urban Design (Space probe, February 7), mistakenly lists Mill Group as one of the developers and providers of development finance at Standard Court, Nottingham. Mill Group's involvement was solely one of private finance initiative sale and leaseback finance after Standard Court had been designed, built and occupied by the NHS. Mill Group had no involvement in the planning and design of the project.

Jon Rouse
Chief executive, Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment

Write to Guardian Society, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; or fax 020-7713 4154 or email society@theguardian.com Please supply your full address. Letters may be edited.

fields.headline: Price of losing a child
fields.standfirst: Pain of bereavement compounded by benefits system
fields.trailText: Pain of bereavement compounded by benefits system
fields.body:
Parents who suffer the loss of a child after lengthy illness face the further blow of a sudden and substantial drop in income through withdrawal of benefits, according to research today portraying the social security system as deeply unsympathetic to family grief.

In the case of a lone parent previously caring full-time for a teenager, the cut in income was found to be as much as 72%. In the case of a two-parent family, where the father earned £18,000 a year, the loss of benefits amounted to a quarter of the net household income.

The report, Financial Implications of the Death of a Child, calls for the tapering off of invalid care allowance or disability living allowance after a child has died. It also proposes introduction of a bereavement allowance, payable for up to six months after the death, or a one-off grant.

Anne Corden, co-author of the study says: "When the ending of entitlement to social security benefits has such profound, emotional significance, the way it is handled becomes extremely important."

The research, commissioned by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation and carried out by the social policy research unit at the University of York, involved interviews with bereaved parents in 17 families, contacted through a children's hospice. A postal survey was also conducted of all 21 children's hospices, and other bereavement groups, to gauge whether the interviews were representative.

All parents interviewed had felt the financial impact of loss or reduction of benefits, even if they were not already facing financial difficulties when their child died.

The effect was found to be compounded by the financial strains of caring for a terminally sick child, leaving many families in debt. Some of the parents had reduced their hours of work, or had left paid em ployment altogether to care for their child. None of the lone mothers had been able to do paid work during the final years of their child's life.

Such reduction in income was often accompanied by extra costs, such as increased utility bills and abnormally high telephone expenses, as families tried to keep in touch with caring staff, home services, relatives and friends.

The researchers found that families in most difficulty were those whose income only just disqualified them for a social fund grant.

fields.bodyText: Parents who suffer the loss of a child after lengthy illness face the further blow of a sudden and substantial drop in income through withdrawal of benefits, according to research today portraying the social security system as deeply unsympathetic to family grief. In the case of a lone parent previously caring full-time for a teenager, the cut in income was found to be as much as 72%. In the case of a two-parent family, where the father earned £18,000 a year, the loss of benefits amounted to a quarter of the net household income. The report, Financial Implications of the Death of a Child, calls for the tapering off of invalid care allowance or disability living allowance after a child has died. It also proposes introduction of a bereavement allowance, payable for up to six months after the death, or a one-off grant. Anne Corden, co-author of the study says: "When the ending of entitlement to social security benefits has such profound, emotional significance, the way it is handled becomes extremely important." The research, commissioned by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation and carried out by the social policy research unit at the University of York, involved interviews with bereaved parents in 17 families, contacted through a children's hospice. A postal survey was also conducted of all 21 children's hospices, and other bereavement groups, to gauge whether the interviews were representative. All parents interviewed had felt the financial impact of loss or reduction of benefits, even if they were not already facing financial difficulties when their child died. The effect was found to be compounded by the financial strains of caring for a terminally sick child, leaving many families in debt. Some of the parents had reduced their hours of work, or had left paid em ployment altogether to care for their child. None of the lone mothers had been able to do paid work during the final years of their child's life. Such reduction in income was often accompanied by extra costs, such as increased utility bills and abnormally high telephone expenses, as families tried to keep in touch with caring staff, home services, relatives and friends. The researchers found that families in most difficulty were those whose income only just disqualified them for a social fund grant. Co-author, Roy Sainsbury, says that the withdrawal of benefits after the child's death puts parents "on a cliff edge". He argues that every benefits office should have a member of staff trained to deal with bereavement, to avoid inappropriate and insensitive treatment. fields.headline: Joint reviews - a 'useful marriage'?
fields.trailText: When the audit commission and the social services inspectorate banded together to establish the joint review of social services in 1996, their partnership was seen as "useful marriage" by social services chiefs.
fields.body:
When the audit commission and the social services inspectorate banded together to establish the joint review of social services in 1996, their partnership was seen as "useful marriage" by social services chiefs.

In theory, the reviews would be helpful as they combined the commission's financial expertise with the SSI's knowledge of local services. Local directors hoped this would lead to a more joined up inspection process and reduce the myriad of investigations they were put through.

At least that was the theory. While many social services directors believe the joint reviews have proved valuable tools for improving their overall performance, others argue the "marriage" has failed to live up to expectations.

The SSI reports on the effectiveness of services, while the audit commission ensures public money is "properly spent". Joint reviews combined these approaches to examine the overall performance of each local authority. The aim is to improve social services by identifying and promoting policies and practice with the better outcomes and better value.

Tony Hunter, chairman of the Association of Directors of Social Services' standards and performance committee, said: "The joint reviews enable us to link best practice to best value, which helps us to identify how to run better services which are also more cost-effective."

Mr Hunter, who is also director of social services in the East Riding of Yorkshire, added: "They've also led to councils self-auditing. We undertook consultations with service users, the health authority, the police, etc in preparation. This has led to continual improvements in services."

But David Johnston, director of social services in Devon, said the joint review process was "cumbersome, time-consuming and highly costly".

He said: "Aspects of their methodology are unscientific. They do not state or standardise the sample sizes of service users surveyed so you may end of with the views of a small number of people with a bee in their bonnet."

Mike Leadbetter, director of social services for Essex, added: "We were concerned about the style of the review. It's a "one size fits all" strategy. Essex was analysed in the same way as a small unitary authority."

Mr Leadbetter believes the marriage between the commission and the SSI must become an open relationship to create a cover-all inspection system.

"The joint review now needs to inspect health and voluntary services as well as social services to provide a 'whole systems' approach.

"The public need to be able to judge our performance. But what conclusions can they make when the joint review says we're improving overall and the personal social services performance assessment framework says our child care services need urgent attention?"

fields.headline: An odd couple
fields.trailText: Opposites attract, they say. Which possibly explains one of the most unlikely relationships in recent NHS history, between current health minister Lord Hunt and former Conservative health secretary Virginia Bottomley.
fields.body:
Opposites attract, they say. Which possibly explains one of the most unlikely relationships in recent NHS history, between current health minister Lord Hunt and former Conservative health secretary Virginia Bottomley.

Like all the best romances, their - strictly platonic - meeting of minds in the mid 1990s was illicit, disapproved of by their respective "families", conducted by necessity outside of the public gaze and tragically doomed to fail.

Lord Hunt of Kings Heath was then plain Mr Hunt: an ambitious, technocratic NHS manager who had married into a respected provincial Labour family - his mother-in-law is Theresa Stewart, former leader of Birmingham city council.

Mrs Bottomley, from grander metropolitan stock, was on the "wet" wing of the Tory party, an NHS enthusiast who had been sent by John Major to rescue it from the loonier privatisation fantasies of the free-market right.

Ordinarily, the pair might have little in common. But at times of extreme social crisis - this was the NHS under the Conservatives, remember - social and political differences were buried under common cause.

Mr Hunt's future was uncertain. He was chief executive of Nahat - the national association of health authorities and trusts, which is now the NHS Confederation - and a known Labour supporter at the head of an organisation dominated by aggressively Tory trust chairmen, many of them of a distinctly Thatcherite bent.

Mrs Bottomley also had a problem with the trust chairmen, some of whose public policy suggestions, such as floating Guy's hospital trust on the stock market and sending mock "invoices" to patients who fail to turn up for appointments, were proving embarrassing to the post-Thatcher government.

And so the odd couple got it together. Behind the scenes, he would advise her candidly on which Tory policy initiatives would go down well with the NHS. She could help rein in the trust chairmen, who yearned for a Nahat chief executive who wasn't a card-carrying member of the despised Labour Party.

A beautiful relationship bloomed. Mrs Bottomley would later admit that Mr Hunt was "critically involved" in the implementation of the Tory internal market reforms, and that she felt "so comfortable" with him that at one stage she considered offering him a job as her political adviser. He probably wouldn't have taken it.

It was not all plain sailing. Mr Hunt suffered the taunts of many from the Labour Party, which regarded such carryings-on as treachery. Some trust chairmen would privately chide Mrs Bottomley for having "gone native" - in other words become a typical NHS-loving liberal.

Inevitably, it ended in tears, not least because Mr Hunt had been two-timing by also advising the Labour Party on health policy. Soon after Labour was elected in 1997 he was ennobled. By mid-1999 he was health minister, and publicly repudiating the criticisms of Mrs Bottomley and her colleagues.

By now she was reduced to a mere hard-working backbencher, and he rose to on-message ministerial status, and ended up orbiting in a far grander political universe.

Though their paths may meet in Westminster from time to time, it is clear the spark that was drew them together has now gone.

As one source close to the pair told Health Service Journal in 1999: "He (Philip) did have a great reputation for integrity and independence and there are those who feel he has behaved in a partisan way (as a Labour peer).

"He would never have supported waiting lists, rather than waiting times in the past. If he was such a confidant of Number 10 he should have been able to stop that. There's a sense he has now gone into the world of showbiz."

webTitle: In social care you get what you pay for

fields.headline: In social care you get what you pay for
fields.trailText: The government has signalled its wish to raise the wages of key public service workers such as nurses, teachers and police. But social care workers, the fourth public service, never seem to get a look in.
fields.body:
The government has signalled its wish to raise the wages of key public service workers such as nurses, teachers and police. But social care workers, the fourth public service, never seem to get a look in.

Social care workers make up a massive workforce of a million-plus people and the sector includes some of the worst pay and conditions in the public sector. A trawl through recent adverts in the jobseekers press gives an idea of what to expect.

Night care assistant, North East England, £9,852 per annum, part time pro-rata.
Local authority care assistant, working shifts £5.10 an hour.
Local authority care assistant, £4.77 - £5.43 in house, NVQ qualification expected.
Resident manager, private sector, Gloucestershire, £6,923, rent free.
Health authority, Yorkshire, £9,846 per annum, plus shift allowance.
Assistant head of home Midlands, £12,000.

Many of the private services advertisements do not give their rates, which tend to be lower.

My daughter, who has been looking for care assistant work in Yorkshire before starting nursing training, says rates in private provision range from minimum income level to £4.50 per hour. A friend is working for £9,000 a year. In the north west you can expect rates of around £4.80 per hour.

The advertised starting rates for prison ancillaries are often higher than those for social care. In my local shopping centre agency charity collectors were recently out in force hustling for subscriptions. They get paid £8 an hour basic.

Something must change. We know there are serious recruitment and retention problems in social care in the UK. The government's new emphasis on raising standards and improving regulation are part of a big push for better quality. This is embodied in the Care Standards Act and important structures such as the general social care council, national care standards commission and social care institute for excellence.

But what real chance is there of improving quality for service users without improving the pay, conditions and status of workers?

A recent study by the European Foundation across member states, Social public services: quality of working life and quality of service, links improved quality of working life to improved service quality.

How much longer can social care be based on a labour force dependent on moonlighting students, untrained school leavers, welfare to work conscripts and older women returning to the sector to top up household incomes?

Social care workers are expected to respond sensitively and skilfully to the personal, often complex, intimate, painful and, at times, difficult needs that bring people to them.

Reports have shown what service users want from social care workers: respect, reliability, honesty, equality and skill. There now needs to be an independent and strategic review of the pay and conditions of social care workers, alongside the other government social care initiatives, to ensure they have a real chance of becoming reality.

 Peter Beresford is professor of social policy at Brunel University, chairman of shaping our lives - the national user-controlled project, and a long-term user of mental health services.

fields.headline: Ain't misbehavin'... publicly
fields.standfirst: People do not            have much faith in the code of conduct for government ministers. Is there a            better way to ensure accountability ?
fields.trailText: Februrary 14, analysis: People do not have much faith in the code of conduct for government ministers. Is there, asks David Walker a better way to ensure accountability?
fields.body:
Today's Commons' report on the code supposed to govern the conduct of government ministers could hardly be more timely. Last year the prime minister said "no one will be better governed through fine tuning the ministerial code". Yet closer study of this document might have saved him much grief.

The code used to be called Questions Of Procedure For Ministers and was first published by the Major government. Its contents go back to Clem Attlee's time, when ministers were ceasing as a matter of course to be gents who could be expected to know the rules (though Gladstone's share dealings on the back of insider knowledge were active, to put it mildly). Today's document is a compendious mix of high principle and practical advice on avoiding trouble. It is on the Cabinet Office website at www.cabinet-office.gov.uk/ central/1997/mcode/index.htm.

Its cardinal rule is giving parliament "accurate and truthful information" while - relevant in the Mandelson case - "correcting any inadvertent error at the earliest opportunity". There are sections on gifts, ministers' private interests, lobbyists, constituency dealings: few of the Mandelson and Keith Vaz events, real or alleged, are not covered by it at least in outline. "Ministers must scrupulously avoid any danger of an actual or apparent conflict of interest between their ministerial position and their private financial interests."

Gifts worth up to £140 each may be kept, otherwise they have to be handed over to civil servants and sold off or "displayed" in a Whitehall glass case. Ministers must not use knowledge which brings "benefit (or could arouse reasonable suspicion of this) in relation to their private financial interests".

Tony Wright and fellow members of the public administration committee want the code better known, perhaps aligned with the rules for other public officials and put under the supervision of a codefinder-general. It is a moot point whether ministers are schooled in their ethical obligations with sufficient rigour. Did the permanent secretary at the Trade Department thrust a copy into the hands of for example, Peter Hain on his recent transfer there? There are bound to be energy industry interests wanting to sup with him. The MPs suggest recording all lobbying episodes. If that had happened over the ministers' relationship with the Hinduja brothers there would at least be less room for disagreement about facts.

But tinkering with the code would not address a central problem in the way we govern ourselves. The code itself relies on uncodified powers wielded by civil servants and, especially, the prime minister. Labour has promised a civil service act, putting permanent officialdom on a statutory footing for the first time and has enacted new ethical codes for politicians in local government. But much of our governance still relies on aristocracy - the system relies on the state's toffs intrinsically to know right and wrong. As a matter of fact, they do behave rather well. Peculation is remarkably absent from British public life. But recent events show how little faith the public has in such self- regulation.

But where do we start writ ing down the ineffable elements of the British constitution? The obvious place is Number 10. The ministerial code belongs to the prime minister and is put into effect by the prime minister. He is judge and jury on breaches, as Peter Mandelson complains. What the prime minister does not know, the cabinet secretary is there to tell him. But the Aitken and Robinson affairs showed how ill-equipped is Whitehall 's head prefect to handle politicians. Besides, quis custodiet? If in principle the prime minister is bound by the same rules as his colleagues, to whom does Sir Richard Wilson report his receipt of hospitality? Paragraph 128 of the code says ministers receiving food, drink (and hotel rooms) from sources that might "reasonably be thought likely to influence ministerial action", should make a declaration in the Commons register of interests. Sir Richard's problem is that he is the conscience and alter ego of the system and a similar problem of ultimate unaccountability would beset an independent custodian of public ethics.

We need, it seems, to invent mechanisms to call the prime minister better to account for his handling of his immediate colleagues. An obvious one is the Commons, but are we ready for such a radical recalibration of the powers of executive and legislature or what it would mean for political parties?

A holding answer seems to be more detailed specification of duties and responsibilities - the substitution of rules for discretion. Sometime soon we are going to have to go back to first principles and set out in black and white just what it is min isters (and their departmental officials) exist to do. Look at the chart: is that variable performance in answering MPs a legitimate sign of ministerial ineptitude? At present there are no objective measures of how well a minister heads a department, delivers policy targets or sustains cabinet government. The code tells ministers to put cabinet business before all else but neglects to say what cabinet government - as opposed to prime ministerial autocracy - is meant to look like. To say a minister is effective in office might be no defence against a charge of corruption but it might put things in proportion.

fields.headline: Barclaycard warms to the excluded
fields.trailText: Barclaycard, Britain's biggest credit card issuer, is to offer the facility to thousands of people it previously turned down under a new initiative that it says will help tackle the problem of financial exclusion.
fields.body:
Barclaycard, Britain's biggest credit card issuer, is to offer the facility to thousands of people it previously turned down under a new initiative that it says will help tackle the problem of financial exclusion.

The company said the new card was aimed at those it has declined in the past because of their credit history - some 700,000 people last year alone - and it expects to recruit between 3,000 and 5,000 customers a month.

Barclaycard traditionally turns down at least half of the people who apply for a card but will now consider people whose credit records are less than perfect because, for example, they have a minor county court judgment against them from previous years or they have moved home a number of times.

The company, which has a 25% share of the British market, is the first of the big traditional issuers to offer cards to people who have been rejected because of credit history.

It said it was launching the card - which will have the same name - in response to the "overwhelming desire" among the public for reputable lenders to provide products for those who have experienced problems obtaining credit.

Until now only a handful of US-based card issuers, such as Capital One, Providian and The Associates, have been prepared to take on people who have had debt problems in the past.

The government has made tackling financial exclusion a priority because of concern that those people who fall outside the rigid criteria of credit and loan companies are sometimes driven into the arms of loan sharks charging interest rates of up to 500%.

Those people Barclaycard takes on will pay one of two interest rates - either its standard 19.4%APR or a higher rate of 24.9%APR depending on their credit score.

This, however, could prompt criticism that the company is creating a two-tier system.

It said it was launching the card - which will have the same name - in response to the "overwhelming desire" among the public for reputable lenders to provide products for those who have experienced problems obtaining credit. Until now only a handful of US-based card issuers, such as Capital One, Providian and The Associates, have been prepared to take on people who have had debt problems in the past. The government has made tackling financial exclusion a priority because of concern that those people who fall outside the rigid criteria of credit and loan companies are sometimes driven into the arms of loan sharks charging interest rates of up to 500%. Those people Barclaycard takes on will pay one of two interest rates - either its standard 19.4%APR or a higher rate of 24.9%APR depending on their credit score. This, however, could prompt criticism that the company is creating a two-tier system.

fields.headline: A dinosaur comes to Derby
fields.standfirst:
The Contractor
Playhouse, Derby
**
fields.trailText:
The Contractor
Playhouse, Derby
**
fields.body:
When David Storey's play was first staged at the Royal Court in 1969, it was still novel to see the world of work reproduced on stage. Plays were largely about middle-class people talking at each other. Storey's play provided an opportunity for middle-class theatregoers to watch actors pretending to be working class actually working.

Thirty years on, when work has invaded our stages and soap operas and we all think we know what it must feel like to work in a factory, a fast-food outlet or on a building site, this play still feels voyeuristic and fake from the plush comfort of the stalls. Mind you, it is a particularly classy fake and a reasonably enjoyable one.

You have to admire a play where so little happens. It is the day before the wedding of the daughter of tenting contractor Ewbank. Early in the morning his workers arrive and start erecting the marquee. In the final act they return and dismantle it, clearing away the debris from the wedding party that we never actually see. That's about it.

Members of the wedding party occasionally wander in, but for the most part the focus is on foreman Kay and his workers as they labour to raise the tent and lower it. We witness their squabbles and banter and find out a little, but not much, about each of them.

In many ways the open-endedness of the narratives (and there are many) and the ambiguity of the play's meanings (which are also many) make it seem very modern. But the depiction of the workers as loutish, workshy misfits seems appallingly dated.

During the performance, I wondered whether this play might be made to work if it was performed in a field as a site-specific event, but even then the audience would be acutely aware that they were witnessing an intricately choreographed masquerade, never the real thing.

You might wonder what prompted Oxford Stage Company to revive this dinosaur, but you can't complain about Sean Holmes's production. It is tight, observant and boasts some great performances, particularly from Paul Copley as the self-made but still dissatisfied gaffer heading for a coronary, Terence Booth as the reticent foreman and Ferdy Roberts as the simple-minded lad for whom pleasure is a piece of cake.

 Until February 24. Box office: 01332 363275. Then touring to Exeter, Poole, Ipswich and Westcliff on Sea.

fields.headline: Ian Carr
fields.standfirst:
Brewery Arts Centre, Kendal
***
fields.trailText:
Brewery Arts Centre, Kendal
***
fields.body:
Having acquired a large collection of Miles Davis's paintings for their gallery, the arts programmers of the Brewery Arts Centre had the bright idea of inviting his distinguished biographer to open the exhibition, give a little talk and play a little music.

Ian Carr is a remarkable scholar, both a literary and musical chronicler of the life and work of his hero, and he has spent as much time playing the man's music as he has documenting his life.

Even so, Carr is so different from the enigmatically smouldering Davis that trying to compare them is liable to raise a chuckle. Resembling a bumbling, retired headmaster, he talked us through a narrow cross-section of Davis's career, played a few tapes and almost bubbled over with excitement explaining that what came out of Miles's trumpet was always "pure love".

When it came to the musical part of the evening it was astonishing to discover that Carr had agreed to do this gig Chuck Berry style, with a pick-up quintet introduced to him at three o'clock that afternoon. Having already warned us that he has spent most of his life "succeeding in failing" to re-create the luminous quality of Davis's trumpet, Carr turned in a solid, respectable performance. His playing was very like him - not always sure of itself, but full of sincerity and warmth.

Of course, it always helps to have a good band, and in this respect Carr fell on his feet. The almost barrel-house piano of Gerry Richardson and the stinging guitar lines of Malcolm MacFarlane evoked the bluesy side of Miles, while the propulsive rhythm section kept the cabaret atmosphere at bay.

Ultimately, Carr was the victim of a problem he no doubt saw coming a hundred miles away. It is impossible to do justice to a career as darkly multifaceted as Davis's by simply whipping through the most accessible numbers from the "classic Columbia" years.

The choice of material was consciously conservative - there was nothing here from Bitches Brew - and Carr was clearly more interested in Davis the sweet-blowing trumpeter than Davis the visionary leveller of musical boundaries.

However, a pleasant sounding "greatest hits" show was really all anyone could have hoped for in this under- rehearsed situation and while there was none of the artistic risk-taking that formed the essential nub of Davis's career, the combination of bubbly lecture and respectful recital made for a gently agreeable evening.

fields.headline: St Germain
fields.standfirst:
Forum, London
***
fields.body:
St Germain is one of the "invisible" success stories of the past year. A vehicle for self-effacing Parisian producer Ludovic Navarre, you hear tracks from the album Tourist all over Europe, in bars and clubs and clothing shops, on the radio and TV.

A lot of people will recognise the single Rose Rouge without knowing it by name - it's the one with a sample of jazz singer Marlena Shaw crooning "I want you to get together" over a delicious ride cymbal and piano loop that sounds suspiciously like Joe Morello and Dave Brubeck on Take Five.

Navarre sits at the back of the stage in a programmer's cockpit while his six "complices" play live overdubs, from funky noodling to flamboyant blowing. It's not a band in the normal sense: there's no bassist, for example. Navarre provides nearly all the bass-end parts from a battery of machines - simple riffs in club-friendly sounds.

The drummer and percussionist generate excitement, but the music works best when they lock into the leader's rhythmic patterns: the tension between repetitive dance beats and subtle jazz gives St Germain's music a contemporary flavour.

Performed straight by a more regular line-up, tracks such as Land Of . . . and La Goutte D'Or might sound empty, but the St Germain mix of simple riffs with sophisticated ensemble licks is a mix of dumb and smart, of dub and art, that makes compulsive listening. Where Medeski Martin and Wood (their label-mates) are content with a crucial twist of style, St Germain are all style with a dash of high- octane content.

They don't have the organic structure of a jazz band and the procession of solos is sometimes closer to rock show indulgence than improvisation. In fact, the relentless pulse gives a different imperative to the set: Navarre's roots remain in house music and his music has the ebb and flow, the transformations in emphasis and mix, that a club crowd expects.

There's a greater response when Navarre adds a pulse-quickening kick drum to the mix, than for any flash of instrumental brilliance. That said, there were some great solos from the guitarist, who reinterpreted Ernest Ranglin's role on Montego Bay Spleen with a full-bodied semi-acoustic sound, plus nice cameos from trumpet, flute and keyboards.

Whatever Navarre does next, I'm sure he'll influence a new wave of musicians, concerned to make a rapprochement with the shifting nature of sound technology and listening culture. He may introduce a whole new audience to jazz, and he's not doing badly at introducing house to jazz fans.

webTitle: Last call for the man from the Pru

fields.headline: Last call for the man from the Pru
fields.standfirst: Insurer to cut 2,000 jobs
fields.trailText: Up to 2,500 jobs will be cut by Prudential this year as it finally consigns its "man from the Pru" to the history books.
fields.body:
Up to 2,500 jobs will be cut by Prudential this year as it finally consigns its "man from the Pru" to the history books.

The door-to-door visits by the Pru's "men", who numbered more than 9,000 a decade ago, will end and be replaced by a virtual man on the internet and staff on the telephone.

The death of the bowler-hatted figure, who first appeared after the second world war and was more recently heavily marketed by former chief executive Sir Peter Davis in a high-profile advertising campaign, has been a long-drawn out process.

After yesterday's announcement, however, none of its direct sales force will fall into the category of the old-style door-to-door salesman. Instead, the company will employ 250 specialists who will offer more sophisticated financial advice than in the past, and 100 consultants who will specifically advise companies.

The move is part of an attempt by the Prudential to save £135m a year from next year but it will require the insurance company to incur a restructuring charge of £110m.

Jonathan Bloomer, the chief executive, said it was not an attempt by the company to distance itself from its customers. "The man from the Pru is evolving. He'll still be here," Mr Bloomer said, "as a voice over the phone or on the internet."

The new sales force will be expected to generate more sales each year, up from £90,000 each to £200,000. Mr Bloomer said this was necessary to cope with the lower profit margins the Pru would be able to command when low-cost stakeholder pension were introduced in April.

Other insurance groups have also been taking steps to reduce their costs and generate more sales ahead of stakeholder pensions.

Pru said that for more complex transaction it would continue to be able to offer face-to-face advice for customers. But, from 2002, it intends to give a simple financial "health-check" service over the phone and over the internet.

At present, 95% of Pru's customers are dealing with the company either by post or increasing use of the internet.

In total 2,500 jobs will be affected, although the company intends to redeploy 500 of those. All the 1,400 existing "men from the Pru" will be offered redundancy, then given the chance to reapply for the positions in the specialist sales force. The other posts affected are in back-office administration. Prudential said the impact would not target any specific area of the country.

Under the restructuring, the insurer is setting up Scottish Amicable Financial Services, a new independent arm that will distribute products through combining the sales force of Scottish Amicable, which Pru owns, and that of the Pru.

fields.headline: McGoldrick makes their eyes bleed
fields.standfirst:
Peter McGoldrick
Collective Gallery, Edinburgh
*****
fields.trailText:
Peter McGoldrick
Collective Gallery, Edinburgh
*****
fields.body:
These days we are defined not by what we buy but by what we want. Go see Peter McGoldrick's new exhibition, Jesus Died for Gucci, however, and your next shopping trip might be a queasy experience you won't want to repeat too soon.

It is hugely difficult for anyone to comment on consumer culture in newly incisive ways. We know that advertisers have us by the short and curlies and if we didn't know how pernicious it all is, Naomi "No Logo" Klein has made it all very clear. Yet still we crave, still we shop. So I expected McGoldrick to be going over old ground.

And then I saw Gap for Gimps, his brutal image of a hooded figure in bondage gear under the slogan "every one in pain", and Calvin Klein Created This, Kate Moss artificially aged, looking as she might have done in her mature years had she not made it into rehab.

"Let's pretend to be poor" (scotmid) has a Prada print skirt contrasted with a grocery shop carrier bag, while Too Much Gucci Made Her Eyes Bleed features smooth-skinned lovelies, in the glitteriest outfits, blessed with all too perfect beauty. One of them wears shades, the other has blood streaming from her eyes with shocking violence. These are all large-scale, horribly lovely paintings, as superficially gorgeous as the adverts they mimic, as slickly done. They make you want, then turn on you, terribly.

A series of five smaller works, Modern Living Made Easy, are subtler and even bleaker. Depicting the kind of skinny, glossy models found in Wallpaper* fashion spreads, and the most alluring minimalist lofts - empty but in a funky way - these images contain the sum of every urban twentysomething's aspirations. Yet, look closely, and it's literally a bloody mess.

The spiky heel of a Prada shoe leaves an imprint of blood on the pure white rug; a woman's anorexically skinny arm has Prada scratched in blood along it. The most handsome man in the world stands alone, a whisky tumbler in hand. I can't see a flaw, can't see the dysfunction in this perfection, then it hits me. The tiniest, thinnest noose in this season's must-have black leather is tied around his neck, about to pull the life from him.

For the train journey home, I had my new copy of Vogue, always a treat. Flicking through the glossy ads, with their dark aspirations designed only to leave us feeling imperfect and a feature on how bondage is one of the new looks, I feel sick, put the magazine away. McGoldrick's work was done.

 Until February 24. Details: 0131-220 1260.

fields.headline: Taking the stodge out of Schumann
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall/Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
*****/***
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall/Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
*****/***
fields.body:
Emphasising the composer's vocal music, the South Bank's Scenes from Schumann series opened two weeks ago with a concert performance of his only opera, Genoveva. And last Saturday, in the Royal Festival Hall, it brought his first oratorio, Das Paradies und die Peri, conducted by Mark Elder with the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment and its choir.

Though performances are still rare, both Schumann's large-scale choral works, Das Paradies from 1843, and his 1853 Scenes from Goethe's Faust, have fared better in the concert hall in the past 10 years than they did for most of the previous century.

The use of period instruments may have something to do with that. As Elder's excellently paced and played performance showed, all the old gripes about the stodginess of Schumann's scoring are confounded when the music is realised by the forces that he was writing for. Orchestra and soloists balance nicely and the music takes on a lightness and sense of purpose that could be overwhelmed by too much weight of tone.

For all its transporting moments, though, Das Paradies und die Peri may still be an acquired taste. The story, from a poem by Thomas Moore, is cloyingly sentimental: the peri, a transcendentally beautiful creature from Persian mythology, searches for the "gift that is most dear to heaven" so that she may gain entrance into paradise and, of course, eventually finds it. The musical pacing is rarely dramatic, even though Schumann first thought of turning the text into an opera.

Yet taken on its own terms it is still endlessly fascinating. There are moments that echo Schumann's songs, and passages clearly modelled on Beethoven (Fidelio and the Ninth Symphony). But the flavour is intensely personal and beguiling.

The Peri herself was sung by the thrilling American soprano Christine Goerke (making her British debut), turning what can be an insipid character into a wholly credible one. The principal tenor, who bears the brunt of the narration, was the lucid and unforced Paul Nilon. The rest of the line-up, the mezzo Bernarda Fink, soprano Mary Plazas, tenor Peter Auty and bass Tomas Tomasson, was equally distinguished.

The thread running through the Schumann song-recital series in the Queen Elizabeth Hall is the pianist Roger Vignoles. On Monday he appeared with a quartet of young singers - Emma Bell, Sarah Connolly, Toby Spence and Stephan Loges - in some rare works. With its four solo voices and accompaniment for piano duet, Schumann's Spanische Liebeslieder was almost certainly the model for the Brahms Liebesliederwaltzer, its pairing in this programme, but it lacks the direct appeal of the later work.

The poems it sets are not very distinguished and there is always the feeling with Schumann's songs that he responded most ardently to the finer literature; Ruckert and Morike bring out more from him than Geibel's lyrics. In the context of this survey, though, it was good to hear and in such sharply characterised performances too.

 The series continues on February 17 and 22. Box office: 020-7960 4242.

fields.headline: Stephen Malkmus
fields.standfirst:
Garage, London
**
fields.trailText:
Garage, London
**
fields.body:
It's hard to tell what the sold-out crowd crammed into the Garage expect from Stephen Malkmus. Curiosity hangs in the air - the gig coincides with the release of the ex-Pavement frontman's debut solo album, which few people can have heard - but it's impure, fused with a longing to hear a few old Pavement favourites too. Then there's the Justine Frischmann factor: the Elastica frontwoman is supposed to be playing with Malkmus, a combination fizzing with sparky promise.

Unfortunately, he employs the same tactic with his own songs. There are all sorts of strange quirks here: the mention of Stoke-on-Trent in Pink India, for instance, the slightly bewildering steel drum, the ease with which Malkmus replicates the sound of a CD being chewed up just using his guitar. And there are some delicious pop touches, particularly when bassist Joanna Bolme joins in with "woah-woah" vocals in Phantasies, and on the cheerleader chant closing Troubbble. But time and again the songs slide into the murky valley of cod-1970s rock, to sprout squealing guitar solos that grow more preposterous and monotonous as the night wears on.

You can feel the potential for such self-indulgence on the record, but it's kept in check, giving the strange vocals space to breathe. Live you can barely hear the twistedly funny lyrics, surely Malkmus's greatest strength. He, at least, looks delighted by his self-indulgence; he doesn't seem to realise that he's strangling his songs. The one consolation is that he doesn't play Deado, the best song on the album: it's far too subtle and precious to be transformed into a rock anthem.

fields.headline: Presumed guilty
fields.standfirst: Kevin Lane is no angel. As a teenager he was known as Lights Out Lane for his brutal fists. As a nightclub bouncer, he never shirked a fight. But was he really a hitman who killed Great Train Robber Charlie Wilson, and had links to the Russian mob? Nick Hopkins weighs up the evidence
fields.trailText: Kevin Lane is no angel. As a teenager he was known as Lights Out Lane for his brutal fists. As a nightclub bouncer, he never shirked a fight. But was he really a hitman who killed Great Train Robber Charlie Wilson, and had links to the Russian mob? Nick Hopkins weighs up the evidence
fields.body:
Kevin Lane hasn't had much to be cheerful about over the past seven years, but as we face each other in the cramped, windowless room set aside for visits to high-risk (category double A) inmates, he begins to laugh. The subject is nicknames, the only matter he is prepared to discuss in something more than a whisper.

We are sitting on low chairs around a low table - everything here is bolted to the floor - and we are surrounded by three prison officers. One is within arm's reach. Prisoner BV3290 is, after all, regarded by the Home Office as one of the country's most dangerous men, and security at HMP Frankland in Durham is formidable.

Lane has had several aliases. As a 15-year-old growing up in Harefield, Hertfordshire, it was Lights Out Lane - he was a talented middle-weight boxer who fought for the home counties against the Federal Republic of Germany. Lane raises his left fist, then his right. Both are slightly gnarled. He chirps: "Gelignite - dynamite. Take your pick, 'cos you're going to sleep!"

When he was a 20-year-old businessman who wore designer clothes and drove a Porsche 911 Targa, Lane went by two other nicknames: Catwalk Kev and Mr Particular. There is no reason to ask why. Lane is handsome. His boyish face and broad shoulders make him seem much younger than 33. His dark-blue shirt appears to have been ironed and his shoes polished. But it is by another name that he has become notorious, and this one wipes the smile from his face: the Executioner.

Four years ago, Lane was convicted at the Old Bailey of murdering Robert Magill, a 44-year-old businessman who was gunned down near his home in Rickmansworth, Hertfordshire, as he walked his dog, Oscar, on his way to nearby Chorley Wood Common on October 13, 1994. The jury heard Magill was shot five times, twice in the head, at "very close range".

The judge in his second trial, Neil Denison, described the attack as "desperately violent, shocking, horrifying". With a case that even prosecutors admitted was flimsy, Lane was accused of being a professional hitman who had been paid between pounds 40,000 and pounds 100,000. But that was just the start.

Following his conviction, Lane says he was the victim of a sustained smear campaign. In various newspapers, he was dubbed the Executioner, and linked to other unsolved murders. They included the assassinations of Charlie Wilson, the Great Train Robber targeted on the Costa del Sol in 1990, and Karen Reed, a 33-year-old geophysicist, who was shot on the doorstep of her home in Surrey in April 1994 by a man posing as a pizza delivery rider. One report claimed Lane had also worked to order for the Russian mafia.

When the TV presenter Jill Dando was shot on the doorstep of her home in Fulham in April 1999, Lane's name cropped up again. At the time, detectives wanted advice from expert hitmen. Newspapers said they turned to Lane to ask whether Dando's murderer was the work of a professional.

"Nobody from the Dando team came to see me," he says. "It was rubbish, like most of the stuff that has been in the papers. Being wrongly convicted of one was bad enough. Then, overnight, I became a multiple murderer."

Lane says there is another story - his story - and it has only been half told. "Just hear me out," he says. "Then make up your own mind."

During the two visits I have paid him, and in several letters he has sent me from jail, Lane has described his life. He does not pretend he has never been in trouble. He has anecdotes that sound like scenes from Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels. But a killer? "No way."

A prolific hitman?

"It's just nonsense. I'll pick my hands up for a fight, but that's my limit."

He points to the evidence against him for the Magill murder. The prosecution relied on a set of coincidences Lane felt too fearful to explain at the time because he and his 52-year-old mother, Barbara, had been warned "to keep quiet". Lane is planning an appeal with the help of Vicky King, a lawyer with the London firm Thanki Novy Taube. His campaign is building momentum and has been invigorated recently by two very different sources.

The criminal cases review commission, which investigates alleged miscarriages of justice, has launched its own inquiry into the conviction - an unusual, proactive step. Normally, the commission only becomes involved following the rejection of a first appeal. And two criminals, influential figures in north London's underworld, contacted King out of the blue to insist Lane was not the murderer. They are the sort of men who would know.

Listening to Lane talk about his life, it is easy to see why his nicknames never included Lucky. The second eldest of eight children, his parents split up when he was a child. His father, Joseph, died "from drink" nine years ago, aged 44. His mother went abroad for several years when he was a teenager, leaving him in the care of friends. Ask Lane about his childhood and he recalls Special Patrol Group vans lining up outside pubs on his council estate ready for the rucks that started at closing time.

At secondary school in south Ruislip, he fell for a 14-year-old girl called Kim Purcell. This, he says, was the turning point in his life. "Other kids said to me: 'Kev, you know who she is, don't you?' I hadn't the faintest idea. I quickly discovered the Purcell family included some of the main criminals in the area."

Kim's uncle, Pat, the head of the family, who is due to be released from Whitemoor prison later this year, treated Lane like a son, and through the Purcells, Lane was introduced to the fringes of the criminal underworld, learning to survive on his wits and with his fists.

The family gave him work as a doorman, and then sold him a security firm. With Lane in charge - he was still only 18 - it flourished. At its peak, he was pro viding doormen for 12 pubs and six clubs in west London, earning pounds 800 a week - more than enough to keep Kim and their two sons, Tommy and Aaron.

Lane is short for a bouncer - 5ft 11in - but those who worked for him say he was one of the best in the business. "There are advantages in being my size. When you approach a man who is 6ft 6in and ask him to calm down, he's not likely to feel threatened.

"But if someone wanted a fight, I could take care of myself. I was very quick. If a man came at me with a knife, I'd have a go. If he came at me with a gun, I'd still have a go. To be honest, I've never needed to carry a weapon."

Lane remembers once being on the door of a pub called the Firefly in Hayes, Middlesex. There had been trouble earlier in the day and the landlord wanted emergency cover. As Lane stood outside, a car slowed down and a man called out: "Do you want some of this?"

"He pointed a shotgun at me," says Lane. "He said he was going to kill me. I replied: 'Go on then.' And he bloody shot me! I didn't even know the kid. I ducked and several shotgun pellets shaved the top of my head. I've got still got six in my skull. I've never seen the guy since."

Some who crossed Lane learned the hard way. He and two others kidnapped a man they suspected of stealing pounds 100,000 worth of electrical equipment. "We put a car on his legs and threw him in the Grand Union Canal. But we weren't going to kill him! We just roughed him up a bit." For that assault, Lane spent 14 months in prison - his only term before the Magill murder.

A year after his release, Lane had left door work and was making a good living through a range of business ventures ranging from organising raves to selling vacuum cleaners. But his life was about to change again.

He broke up with Kim and, in the spring of 1994, left the UK for Tenerife, where a friend had offered him work. Kim followed him and pleaded with him to return, which he did on September 29 - her birthday. Back at home in Potton, Cambridgeshire, Lane got in touch with his relatives and friends - hardly, he points out, a sensible thing for an assassin to do.

By then, Magill, a car trader and known villain, had been warned that there was a contract on his head. But he had made so many enemies, he didn't know where the threat came from. He became a prisoner in his own heavily protected home in Valley Road, Rickmansworth, venturing out once a day to take his dog for a walk. During his stroll at 8.20am on Thursday October 13, two men got out of a battered X-registered BMW as he approached the junction with Berry Lane. One shot him five times with a pump-action weapon, the other kept look-out.

The case against Lane, who was arrested three months after the murder, was based on one piece of forensic evidence found in the car, and several coincidences.

People who knew Lane were undoubtedly involved in the murder. The weekend before the assassination, Lane borrowed a BMW from a friend - his own car had been stolen - and used it to take Kim and the boys to see his mother, who had moved to Hillingdon. He said he returned it on Sunday evening. Four days later it was used by the killers as their getaway vehicle. When detectives recovered the car, they found Lane's fingerprint on a binliner in the boot. Scientists also found firearms discharge on a piece of plastic piping, and speculated that it had contained a weapon of some sort.

Lane never denied driving the car - his sons' fingerprints were all over the dashboard. "But I didn't have it the day Magill died. I used it once, that's all."

Lane says he knew something was up because he was called hours after the murder by a criminal contact who warned him that the police might pay a visit. "He didn't say anything else. He said there was nothing to worry about. I wasn't going to hang around for a knock on the door, so I took Kim and the kids to Newcastle for a short break."

To detectives, who had launched a huge investigation, his trip to the north-east pointed to his involvement in the murder. Lane's decision not to tell them about the call hardly helped. Nor did he tell them that his mother had also been threatened by a motorcycle rider who appeared at her front door one morning, warning her and Kevin to keep quiet.

The police had two other clues. Shortly after the murder, Lane bought a car for pounds 5,400. Detectives speculated the money was part of his payment, though admitted there was no proof. Lane said it was money he had left in a safe before going to Tenerife, and that he had witnesses to back his story. Officers also discovered Lane flew back to the UK using an exit visa with the name Paul Curtis."We suspected he'd been recruited when he was in Tenerife and returned to do this specific job," says one detective involved in the inquiry. "As far as we were concerned, the pieces of the jigsaw had fallen into place."

Lane insists they jumped to the wrong conclusion. He says he couldn't return to the UK using his real passport because he was in trouble with the Spanish police over a brawl in a restaurant called The Steak House. However, again he didn't tell detectives about the fight.

After consulting with his then lawyers, Lane decided not to tell the jury about his connections to the underworld, a tactic he now considers a huge misjudgment. Instead, the defence focused on the major flaws in the prosecution. There were, for instance, two eyewitnesses to Magill's shooting, but neither picked out Lane at identity parades. Strangely, all the early police messages - reports from informants about likely suspects - made no mention of Lane. Two other names cropped up time and again.

How the police came to look at Lane in the first place has never been fully explained, and is an important avenue for Lane's new solicitor. Their suspicion is that his name was forwarded by the killer to cover himself. Even the police admit they were lucky to convict.

The jury failed to reach a verdict on Lane the first time round and his co-defendant Roger Vincent was acquitted. A retrial was ordered. A second jury deliberated for nine hours and three minutes before reaching a majority decision that Lane was guilty. He was sentenced to a minimum of 18 years, and has been told he will serve at least 25. He has lost Kim, who has re-married, and he hardly sees his sons.

" Kevin Lane has not lived a crime-free life, but is he a contract killer? I am convinced that he is not," says King. "His lifestyle allowed the police to fit a case around him. His fear of those who told him to keep his mouth shut conspired to prevent him from telling the jury about his background. If he had not had any underworld connections, then he would not be where he is now. It would have been impossible to make the case stick."

Lane has not been charged with any other murders since he was in prison, and detectives now admit there is no concrete evidence to link him to any other shooting.

"If I had killed Magill, I would have got out of the country immediately," Lane says, "I wouldn't have hung around and bought a new car. All the way through the trial, people were saying to me: 'Don't worry, Kev, they've nothing on you, you'll get off.' And I believed them. Now I'm locked up for something I didn't do, and I've been accused of murders all over the place.

"I'm not a grass, but I've been inside far too long. I'm not going to give up. I know I can prove my innocence."

fields.headline: Abbey to pre-empt report
fields.standfirst: Bank publishes its results a week early
fields.trailText: Abbey National will today release its annual results a week early, setting out its credentials as a competitor to Lloyds TSB just days before the government decides whether Lloyds' £20bn takeover attempt warrants a full-scale competition investigation.
fields.body:
Abbey National will today release its annual results a week early, setting out its credentials as a competitor to Lloyds TSB just days before the government decides whether Lloyds' £20bn takeover attempt warrants a full-scale competition investigation.

Speculation about whether Lloyds TSB's unwelcome advances would be scuppered by the competition authorities reached fever pitch last night when the office of fair trading's crucial recommendation landed on the desk of Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary.

Mr Byers must make his decision public by February 23 but is increasingly expected to beat that deadline. He and his advisers have been subjected to heavy lobbying by banking unions to refer Lloyds TSB's bid for a competition inquiry on fears of at least 9,000 job cuts and branch closures.

In releasing its profits figures a week earlier than planned, Abbey is expected to produce statistics which show that it has boosted its 5% share of the current account market. Such figures are expected to be central to any decision made by Mr Byers who faces a decision of whether a combined Lloyds/Abbey current account share of close to 30% poises competition fears.

If he decides to recommend the bid to the competition commission it could delay Lloyds TSB's ambitions by six months. Shareholders in Abbey have indicated that they intend to wait for the outcome of any investigation rather than support Abbey's preferred option of a merger with Bank of Scotland.

Sources close to Abbey insisted last night that the decision to publish profits early was an attempt to allow the bank time to talk to shareholders ahead of any decision by the government. It was originally intended to publish pre-tax profits in the region of £1.9bn on February 22, the day before Mr Byers' deadline.
fields.bodyText: Abbey National will today release its annual results a week early, setting out its credentials as a competitor to Lloyds TSB just days before the government decides whether Lloyds' £20bn takeover attempt warrants a full-scale competition investigation. Speculation about whether Lloyds TSB's unwelcome advances would be scuppered by the competition authorities reached fever pitch last night when the office of fair trading's crucial recommendation landed on the desk of Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary. Mr Byers must make his decision public by February 23 but is increasingly expected to beat that deadline. He and his advisers have been subjected to heavy lobbying by banking unions to refer Lloyds TSB's bid for a competition inquiry on fears of at least 9,000 job cuts and branch closures. In releasing its profits figures a week earlier than planned, Abbey is expected to produce statistics which show that it has boosted its 5% share of the current account market. Such figures are expected to be central to any decision made by Mr Byers who faces a decision of whether a combined Lloyds/Abbey current account share of close to 30% poises competition fears. If he decides to recommend the bid to the competition commission it could delay Lloyds TSB's ambitions by six months. Shareholders in Abbey have indicated that they intend to wait for the outcome of any investigation rather than support Abbey's preferred option of a merger with Bank of Scotland. Sources close to Abbey insisted last night that the decision to publish profits early was an attempt to allow the bank time to talk to shareholders ahead of any decision by the government. It was originally intended to publish pre-tax profits in the region of £1.9bn on February 22, the day before Mr Byers' deadline.
